title: Tech Start Up
question_text:
Pete is starting a new job at a tech start-up. He is wondering about the age breakdown of the employees who currently work at the company. Given is the cumulative relative frequency graph summarizing the employees' ages:
What statement is supported by the cumulative relative frequency graph of employee ages?

choices.text: The oldest employee is 70 years old.
Over 50% of employees are younger than 40 years old.
Over one-fourth of the employees are younger than 30 years old.

25%
of employees are aged between 50
and 60
years old.

The youngest employee at the company is 20
years old.

solution:
The ages of employees at the tech start-up are summarized in a cumulative relative frequency graph, or Ogive. A cumulative graph represents the number or proportion of a data set less than or equal to a given number. You can find the proportion of data points in a certain interval by finding the percent for the upper bound and the percent for the lower bound and subtracting the two values.

When looking at this ogive, to find the proportion of employees younger than 40
, follow the horizontal axis until you get to 40
years old. Then move vertically until you hit the line graph, and make a right angle to the vertical axis. You find the proportion of employees 40
years old or younger is approximately 0.52
, which is over half of the employees.

Choice 'B' is correct.

A quantitative variable can provide very specific information about an individual, while a categorical variable can only provide general information about an individual.

title: Warranty Information
question_text:
Three coffee maker companies (each with the same number of customers) offer warranties with their products. Company $A$ only puts the warranty information in the packaging when purchased, Company $B$ sends a follow-up email three days after purchase, and Company $C$ calls the customer and offers the warranty a week after purchase.
The graph shows the proportion of customers that sign up for the warranty on their product.
Loading question supplement...

Company C had a higher proportion sign up than Company A and B combined.
More people signed up for Company B's warranty than not.

Company C
had approximately twice the proportion sign up than Company A
.
The overall proportion of people who signed up for a warranty is greater than those who did not sign up for a warranty.

solution:
The bar chart is a visualization of a categorical variable. The variable is the proportion of people who sign up for a warranty on their coffee maker. The segmented bar chart shows the proportion who has signed up for the warranty and the proportion who did not sign up for the warranty.

Looking at Company C
, they had approximately 0.70
sign up for the warranty, while Company A
had about 0.35
and Company B
had approximately 0.55
, so Company C
did not have more than Company A
and B
combined.

Choice 'B' is correct.

title: Bug Life Cycles - Converting Data Set
question_text:
Jane and John have collected data on the life cycle of palmetto bugs.

At the last minute, they discover that they were supposed to report all their data in centimeters rather than inches. Jane realizes that she left the flash drive containing the Excel spreadsheet of all their raw data at home.
John says not to worry; he knows how to change the summary data without recomputing the mean and standard deviation all $5{,}000\text{ pieces of raw data}$. He performs appropriate statistical operations, makes the necessary changes, and quickly changes the mean and standard deviation.
What are the final values for these two measures, assuming that there are $2.54\text{ centimeters}$ in $1\text{ inch}$?

title: Supermarket Survey
question_text:
Sam is working on a statistics class project and decides to collect data from people at the local supermarket. The survey he is asking collects information on gender, hair color, number of kids, zip code, number of items in the cart, and how much money in their wallet.
Once all the data has been collected Sam organizes the data into two groups: Quantitative or Categorical. The groups are listed below.
Quantitative: number of kids, zip code, number of Items in the cart, and amount of money in wallet
Categorical: gender, hair color
Did Sam correctly break down the variable into the two groups?

choices.text: Yes, Sam correctly identified all the quantitative and categorical variables.
No, Sam listed number of kids as quantitative, when it should be categorical.
No, Sam incorrectly listed zip code as quantitative, but it is categorical.
No, the amount of money in your wallet should be categorical.
Sam has the idea of quantitative and categorical variables completely flipped.

solution:
Sam's survey collected data on individuals from the supermarket. The data can be split into two groups: quantitative or categorical. A quantitative variable is one that takes one a value that can be measured whereas a categorical variable takes on values that are category names or group names.

Although zip code is a numeric value, it is not a value that can be measured from one person to another. Another way to think about it is, we cannot find the average zip code. Since we cannot find the numeric average, the value is categorical.

Choice 'C' is correct.

Suzy also explained for those who buy one box of cereal a week, over the course of one year, they could save an average of more than $\$20$ by purchasing the store brand over the big name brand. "And that's enough to buy at least four large frozen caramel macchiatos with chocolate granola drizzle at your local coffee shop!"
Is Suzy correct? Justify your response.

choices.text: No. The annual savings would only average $\$0.51$ and four large frozen caramel macchiatos with chocolate granola drizzle will cost much more than that.

Probably. As long as one large frozen caramel macchiato with chocolate granola drizzle costs $\$6.63$ or less, the mean annual savings will be enough to cover the cost of four.
Probably. As long as one large frozen caramel macchiato with chocolate granola drizzle costs $\$8.84$ or less, the mean annual savings will be enough to cover the cost of four.
Yes. The annual savings would average $\$180.44$. That should be more than enough to cover the cost of four large frozen caramel macchiatos with chocolate granola drizzle.

title: Baseball Vote
question_text:
A high school baseball conference is voting for All-Area players. The players names are omitted to ensure there is no favoritism when selecting the players. The table below lists the top three first-basemen in the conference.
Player Bats (Hand) Batting Average Hits Homeruns Runs Batted In (RBIs)
A Right $0.325$ $44$ $15$ $58$
B Left $0.315$ $42$ $10$ $52$
C Right $0.298$ $38$ $18$ $60$
Which of the following is considered a categorical variable?
tables:
PlayerBats (Hand)Batting AverageHitsHomerunsRuns Batted In (RBIs)
ARight$0.325$$44$$15$$58$
BLeft$0.315$$42$$10$$52$
CRight$0.298$$38$$18$$60$

choices.text: Batting Average
Hits
Homeruns
Runs Batted In (RBIs)
Bats (Hand)

solution:
Variables in data can be classified into two different types: quantitative or categorical.

In this case, there are four quantitative variables: Batting Average, Hits, Homeruns, and Runs batted in. These values all take on a numeric value where we can find an average.

There is only one value on the table that can be put into categories or groups. Therefore, the hand that the player bats with is a categorical variable.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Golfer's Background
question_text:
A local golf tournament released a breakdown of the backgrounds of all the golfers. A table of the data is provided below.
Continent Relative Frequency
North America $0.72$
Europe $0.15$
Asia $0.08$
South America $0.03$
Australia $0.02$

ContinentRelative Frequency
North America$0.72$
Europe$0.15$
Asia$0.08$
South America$0.03$

Asia has less than half the golfers from Europe.

solution:
Remember: the prompt asks us to find the choice that is not supported by the table.

The table above is an example of a frequency table, but the frequencies are given as relative frequencies instead of counts. It is important to note that percentages, relative frequencies, and rates all give the same information as proportions.

The table given is the breakdown for the background of the golfers in the field. European golfers make up 15%
of the field, where as Asian golfers make up 8%
of the field. Since half of 15%
is 7.5%
, Asian golfer make up more than half of the European golfers, not less than.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Favorite Coffee

Starbucks$125$
Dunkin'$?$

solution:
The table shown represents the categorical variable, "Favorite Coffee". The put all subjects into their respective category.

Since the researcher asked $400$ people, the total amount of people represented in the table needs to equal that amount. The two values given in the table, $125$ and $65$, equal $190$. Therefore, the two values must add to be $210$ subjects. The only answer choice that equals $210$ is $120 + 90$ which is Choice 'D'.

So, Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Lake Houses
question_text:
Sam is vacationing at his friend's lake house one weekend. He's curious about the favorite water activity of the other people at the lake. So, he polls $150$ people at the lake and asks them what is their favorite water activity. The table below summarizes the data.
Activity Relative Frequency
Boating $0.24$
Fishing $0.20$
Tubing $0.18$
Kayaking $0.16$
Paddle-Boarding $0.12$
Swimming $0.06$
Which of the following statements is supported by the table?
tables:
ActivityRelative Frequency
Boating$0.24$
Fishing$0.20$
Tubing$0.18$
Kayaking$0.16$
Paddle-Boarding$0.12$
Swimming$0.06$

choices.text: $20$ people answered fishing as their favorite activity.
$36$ people answered boating as their favorite activity.
Tubing was answered more than paddle-boarding and swimming combined.
Boating and kayaking account for half of the responses.
One-fourth of the responders said boating as their favorite activity.

solution:
The data above is summarized in a relative table that takes the favorite activity and gives the relative frequency of the responses. The relative frequency represent the proportion of times the activity was answered, and all the relative frequencies add up to be 1
.

In order to figure out the amount of people who answered boating as their favorite activity, we need to take the number of people who responded and multiply it by the relative frequency. For example, for boating, we will do the following:

(Number of responders)(Relative Frequency)
150(0.24)
=36 people

Therefore, 36
people answered boating as their favorite activity.

Choice 'B' is correct.

title: Average GPA
question_text:
A high school principal collects some data about students at his school. He uses his student information system to find the grade point average (GPA) of $10$ random students. The GPAs are listed below:
$$3.2, 3.7, 4.0, 2.5, 3.1, 3.5, 3.8, 3.0, 2.7, 2.5$$
This gives the principal an average GPA of $3.2$ on a $4$ point scale.
Can the principal confidently say that the average GPA of his high school is $3.2$?

choices.text: Yes, because he collected data on $10$ students.
Yes, because the data was randomly collected.
No, because the data was randomly collected.
No, because the median does not equal $3.2$.
No, because the data will change with a different sample of $10$ students.

solution:
When data is collected randomly, there will always be some variation. Since variation occurs, the conclusions based off that data is often uncertain.

Since the principal only took a sample of size $10$, we can safely assume the school is larger than $10$ students. Therefore, the "average" of the $10$ is uncertain to be the average of the whole school.

The principal cannot confidently say that the average GPA of the whole school is $3.2$.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: School Fundraiser
question_text: A school is hosting a fundraiser to raise money for a new basketball hoop. The fundraiser has carnival games, competitions, and other events that event-goers can pay to participate in. Which of the following situations would be considered a continuous variable?

choices.text: The number of rings landed on a ring toss game.
The number of jumps in a jump rope competition.
The distance walked in a walk-a-thon.
The amount of whole pies sold by the PTA.
The amount of tickets sold to enter the fundraiser.

solution:
All the above variables are examples of quantitative variables, which can be described as either discrete or continuous. A discrete quantitative variable takes on a countable number of values with gaps between numbers, whereas continuous quantitative variables can take on infinitely many values no matter the size of the interval.

In this case, the only one that can use non-countable numbers would be the distance walked in a walk-a-thon. Since distance is a length measurement, there are infinitely many numbers that the distance can take, no matter the interval.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Library Debate
question_text:
Two high school statistics students are studying in their school's library. They see the librarian seemingly selected random books from the shelves. The two students wonder aloud what they believe the librarian is doing.
Student $1$ states: "I bet she is selecting random books to try and find the average page number for the books in the library."
Student $2$ states: "No, I think she is selecting random books to estimate the proportion of books per category (fiction, non-fiction, etc.)"
Which student is correct?

choices.text: Student $1$ since the number of pages in a book is numeric value.
Student $1$ since the librarian is selected the books randomly.
Both students could be correct since both values are data points that are easily collectable by the librarian.
Student $2$ since the data is easily put in categories.
Neither student's idea make sense statistically.

solution:
The librarian is randomly selected books to collect data. This data, once collected, can lead to a conclusion that is meaningful, when put into context.

Although the students do not know the exact reasoning for the librarian's work, both of their ideas make sense statistically. The librarian could easily find the average number of pages of the book by examining each book and finding the sum of the book pages, then dividing by the number of books. Additionally, the librarian could also easily organize the books into different categories that represent each book.

Both students have presented a logical statistical argument for what the librarian could be doing.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: GPS Survey
question_text:
A data scientist at a major GPS company recently got the results of a survey that asked for the satisfaction levels of customers from their most recent trip. The results are summarized in the table below
Satisfaction Level Percent
Extremely Satisfied $22\%$
Satisfied $25\%$
Neutral $24\%$
Dissatisfied $21\%$
Extremely Dissatisfied $8\%$
The researcher sends a company wide memo with the following headline, "A Majority of Users Were Satisfied With Their Most Recent Trip Using Our App!"
Is the researcher's headline correct?
tables:
Satisfaction LevelPercent
Extremely Satisfied$22\%$
Satisfied$25\%$
Neutral$24\%$
Dissatisfied$21\%$
Extremely Dissatisfied$8\%$

choices.text: Yes, because "Satisfied" has the highest percentage.
Yes, because "Satisfied" and "Extremely Satisfied" add to over $50\%$.
Yes, because "Dissatisfied" and "Extremely Dissatisfied" is less than $50\%$.
No, because "Satisfied" and "Extremely Satisfied" does not add to above half of those who responded.
No, because $24\%$ of customers were "Neutral".

solution:
The above table puts the respondents into groups by their satisfaction level, therefore representing a categorical variable. A researcher can use the frequency table to make claims about the people who responded to the survey.

In this case, the researcher claimed that a majority of respondents answered at least "Satisfied". This is not true, as "Satisfied" and "Extremely Satisfied" only account for $47\%$, which does not represent a majority of the people who responded.

Choice 'D' is correct.

Explanation of Distrators

Choice 'A' is incorrect. Even though "Satisfied" has the highest percentage, it does not represent a majority of the respondents.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. "Satisfied" and "Extremely Satisfied" only add to 47%, not 50%.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. Even though "Dissatisfied" and "Extremely Dissatisfied" don't add to over 50%, "Neutral" would not count for "Satisfied".

Choice 'E' is incorrect. 24% did answer Neutral, but this does not affect the amount that chose "Satisfied".

Veronica Falls: at the $37th$ percentile

choices.text: Iguana Falls, Halo Falls, Veronica Falls, Rainaga Falls
Iguana Falls, Veronica Falls, Rainaga Falls, Halo Falls
Halo Falls, Rainaga Falls, Veronica Falls, Iguana Falls
Veronica Falls, Rainaga Falls, Iguana Falls, Halo Falls
Rainaga Falls, Veronica Falls, Halo Falls, Iguana Falls

title: School Carnival
question_text:
Pete is running a game at his school's yearly carnival. The game consists a giant spinning wheel. On the wheel, there are some spots that say "You're a winner!" and some spots that say "Try again next time."
A couple, Sam and Chris, decide to each play Pete's game $5$ times. Sam wins $3$ times out the $5$ turns and Chris wins only $1$ time out of the $5$ turns.
After they leave, Sam gloats and says ""I'm the better player than you!". Is Sam correct?

choices.text: Yes, since Sam won $3$ times compared to Chris only winning $1$ time.
Yes, because Same won $60\%$ of the time.
No, because Chris won $20\%$ of the time.
No, because Pete could've rigged the game for Sam.
No, since the game was based on "luck" and not "skill", Sam randomly won the game.

solution:
Statistics and data are based around the idea of variation. This idea of variation implies that all data points will not be the same throughout many trials. In this case, the carnival game will provide some winners and some losers.

Since the carnival game was strictly based on luck, and each spin of the wheel has a chance of being a "winner" or a "loser", the fact that Sam won $3$ times out of $5$ is meaningless when looking for a conclusion. Chris could've easily won just as many, or more, games as Sam simply by playing the game.

Therefore, Sam is incorrect in the thinking of being the best player.

Choice 'E is correct.

title: Why Not Normal?
question_text:

If the salaries were normally distributed, someone at the $95^\text{th}\text{ percentile}$ should be making more than $\$140{,}396$.

title: Establishing Normality Based on the $5$-Number Summary
question_text:
The $5$-number summary for a certain distribution is as follows:
$$28$$
$$53$$
$$75$$
$$97$$
$$122$$

Based upon this information, is the distribution approximately normal? Why or why not?

choices.text: Yes, because the $Q3$ value and $Q1$ value are equally far from the median, and the median is approximately equal to the mean.
Yes, because the values in the $5$-number summary are completely symmetric around the mean.
Yes, because approximately $50\%$ of the data falls within one standard deviation of the mean. This is what would be expected in a normal distribution.
No, because $100\%$ of the data falls within $2$ standard deviations of the mean. In a normal distribution, the spread of data would be greater.
No, because the data contains a high outlier. In a normal distribution, no outliers would be present.

solution:
The Bar Chart is a visual representation of a Categorical Variable. In this case, the Categorical Variable would be the children's favorite tv show. The height of the bar corresponds to the percent of children that answered the tv show.

Bluey was selected 40%
of the time, while Bubble Guppies was selected 25%
of the time. Therefore, they account for 65%
of the data, which is more than half.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Test Scores
question_text:
Mr. Johnson is teaching his class about stemplots. He decides to take the latest test scores (in percents) and plot the data in a stemplot to show his class. He purposely makes a mistake on his graph.
What mistake did Mr. Johnson make?

choices.text: He should've omitted $7$ as a stem because there were no $70$s.
He should have split the stems to better show the shape.
Mr. Johnson should have made a histogram instead of a stemplot.
He did not provide a key for his data.
He should not have included $10$ as a stem because all stems need to be the same amount of digits.

solution:
The test scores are compiled in a stemplot, or stem and leaf plot. In a stemplot, each data value is split into a "stem" (the first digit or digits), and a "leaf" (usually the last digit).

In our stemplot, the data is correctly split into stems and leaves. The mistake Mr. Johnson made, was not having a key to display what the data represents. It is very important to include a key at the bottom of your graph (for example, $5 | 7 = 57\%$) to show what the data inside the graph means.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Can We Extrapolate?
question_text:
A statistics student wanted to do a study by examining data from last year's baseball season. He wanted to randomly select $40$ players and note their weight and the number of home runs they hit. The student wanted to see if weighing more might predict more home runs being hit.
Of the $40$ players, the weights ranged from $180$ to $280$ pounds. He obtained a regression equation of $\hat{y}=-60+0.4x$. The student wondered if it was reasonable to predict the number of home runs hit by a $300$ pound man and by a $400$ pound man.
Which answer below seems most reasonable?

choices.text: No. Predicting beyond the range of values for the explanatory variable is never reasonable.
Yes. Predicting beyond the range of values for the explanatory variable is always reasonable.
Yes. These predictions are not always reasonable, but in this case they might be as the $400$ pound man could be very tall and very strong.
No. These predictions are unreasonable simply because the home run numbers are too high.
Yes and No. It is reasonable to predict for the 300 pound man since that weight is very close to the others, but to predict as far away as 400 pounds is not reasonable.

title: Interpret Slope: Square Footage and Cost of Houses
question_text:
A local real estate agent is interested in the relationship between the cost of a house ($y$) in dollars and its area ($x$) in square feet. She randomly selects $50$ houses around town and computes the least squares regression line: $\hat { y } =136.89x+14578.91$.

choices.text: For each dollar increase, the estimated square footage of the house increases by $136.89$.
For each dollar increase, the estimated square footage of the house increases by $14578.91$.
For each additional square foot, the estimated cost of the house increases by $\$136.89$.
For each additional square foot, the estimated cost of the house increases by $\$14578.91$.
Since we are not given the $50$ data points, it is impossible to interpret the slope of the least squares regression line in this problem.

title: Hours of Television
question_text:
A researcher is interested in seeing if there is a connection between the number of hours of television a child watched per week while they were young and the score on a reading comprehension exam. The researchers believe that the more hours of television watched, the lower the score on the comprehension exam.
Which of the following graphs could represent the researchers' beliefs?
solution:
The data regarding amount of time watching television when younger and reading comprehension make up a bivariate quantitative data set. A bivariate quantitative data set consists of observations of two different quantitative variables made on individuals in a sample or population.

The graphical representation of bivariate quantitative data is called a scatterplot. As noted in the prompt, the researchers believed the more television hours watched as a child, the lower the reading comprehension scores would be. Therefore, we are looking for a graph that has a negative direction. The only graph that has a negative direction is Graph E.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Accuracy in Predicting the Height of a Sunflower?
question_text:
Melanie planted a sunflower seed and decided to track its growth. Letting $x$ represent the number of days since the seed was planted and letting $y$ represent the plant's height in inches, she carefully gathered data each day beginning on day $7$ when the seed sprouted and continued for $30\text{ days}$ after that. She then developed the following LSRL:
$$\hat { y } =-6.78+1.43x$$
The correlation for the relationship was $r=0.972$.
Melanie wonders how tall her sunflower will be $6\text{ months}$ after the seed was planted and decides to use the LSRL to make a prediction. Which of the following statements would best describe the accuracy of her prediction?

choices.text: Since the correlation for the relationship was near $1$, the relationship is very strong. Therefore, the LSRL will provide an extremely accurate prediction for the height of the sunflower.
From the given information we can determine the coefficient of determination to be: ${ r }^{ 2 }={ 0.972 }^{ 2 }=0.945$ This means that the prediction will be about $94.5\%$ accurate.

Since the correlation was not $1$, the relationship between height and number of days since the seed sprouted is not strong enough for Melanie to be able to make an accurate prediction about the height of the sunflower in $6$ months.

Trying to use the LSRL to make a prediction about the height in $6\text{ months}$ will most likely be inaccurate since Melanie only collected data for about the first month after the seed sprouted. This would be an example of extrapolation.

It would be impossible to use the LSRL for making a prediction about the height of the sunflower in $6\text{ months}$. since the LSRL was created using data that related height to number of days (not months) since the seed sprouted.

title: Golf Preparation
question_text:
A golfer is preparing for a tournament on an ocean course. The wind is notorious for causing golfers to struggle. The golfer wonders if there is an association between the speed of the wind (in miles per hour) and the number of birdies (making the golf ball in the hole one stroke under the expected number of strokes) a golfer makes.
He examines historical data for hole $13$ on the course and records the wind speed for the day and the number of birdies made by golfers. A graph is shown below.
The golfer believes there to be a positive association between the wind speed and number of birdies made. Is he correct?

choices.text: Yes, because the wind is obviously affecting the number of birdies.
Yes, as the wind increases, the number of birdies incease.
No, it does not seem like the wind has an affect on the number of birdies made by a golfer.
No, the scatterplot shows a negative association between wind speed and number of birdies made.
There is no association as past outcomes do not affect future outcomes.

solution:
The scatterplot is a graph of bivariate quantitative data, which is two data points collected on one individual. In this case, the graph shows the number of birdies golfers made against the wind speed on the day of play.

Examining the scatterplot, it shows that the number of birdies drastically decreased as the wind speed increases. This would imply a negative association, meaning as the values of one variable increases, the values of the other variable tend to decrease.

Since the graph is showing a negative association, and not a positive association, the golfer's belief is incorrect.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Touchdown Correlation
question_text:
As the sport of football grows, teams are becoming increasingly interested in using statistics to better their teams. In a typical football game, a touchdown scored by a team is worth $6$ points. Suppose a team wants to make a graph for the number of touchdowns scored and points scored for their team.
Which of the following would be the correlation for this data, assuming there are no extra points scored after each touchdown?
solution:
The correlation, $r$, gives the direction and quantifies the strength of the linear association between two quantitative variables. A correlation is considered strong if its value is close to $1$ or $-1$.

In this case, as the number of touchdowns increases, the number of points will increase by a constant $6$. For example,

Since points are increasingly constantly, the graph would be perfectly linear in a positive direction, as both variables are increasing. Therefore, the correlation would be $r = 1$.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Studying vs Test Score
question_text:
A mathematics teacher recorded data from her students on how much they studied for their last exam. The teacher then plotted the study times values against the students test scores. A scatterplot of the data is shown below.
Which labeled point on the scatterplot would be considered an outlier?

choices.text: A
B
C
D
E

solution:
An outlier in regression is a point that does not follow the general trend shown in the rest of the data and have a large residual when the least-squares regression line (LSRL) is found.

In this example, the general trend is the more you study, the higher your test score. Students who studied a good amount of time for the test, typically did well, while students who did not study much, typically did poorly on the exam. Only one point in the graph does not follow this trend, Point B.

Choice 'B' is correct.

title: Baseball Statistics
question_text:
A baseball coach was wondering if his team got more hits, would they score more runs? He collected data from his last $30$ baseball games and found a least-squares regression line of:
$$\hat{y} = 3.2 + 1.3x$$
...where $x = $ the number of hits per game and $y = $ the number of runs scored in a game. He also found that $45$ percent of the variation of runs can be accounted for the number of hits.
What is the value of the correlation coefficient?
solution:
Given in the problem is the least-squares regression line, and the percent of variation, which is also known as, $r^2$. The question asks you to find the correlation coefficient, which is more commonly known as r.

In order to find the correlation coefficient from the percent of variation, one must take the square root of the $r^2$ value. For example,

$$r^2 = 45\% = 0.45$$
$$\sqrt{r^2} = \sqrt{0.45}$$
$$r = 0.67$$

The value of the correlation coefficient is r=0.67.

Choice 'D' is correct.

Which of the following is the residual of the birth rate (per $1000$ women) in the year $2000$?
correct_answer: Choice 'A' is incorrect. The year $2000$ was substituted into the LSRL, but the residual was never calculated. Also, when the year $2000$ is substituted in, the predicted birth rate is $14.16$ and not $-14.16$.

title: Pear Tree Production
question_text:
A researcher wondered if the pear tree in his backyard would keep its current production during future years. He decided to look at historical records for this certain type of pear tree and found a least squares regression line of $\hat{y} = 156 + 25.4x$, where $x =$ the age of the pear tree in years and $y =$ the amount of pears produced by the tree.
Given is the residual plot for the least-squares regression line.
Should the researcher use the linear model to represent the pear production?

choices.text: Yes, because the least squares regression line has a y-intercept and a slope.
Yes, because there are some points above and below 0 on the residual plot.
Yes, because the points on the residual plot are in clusters.
No, because the residual plot shows a parabolic form.
No, because the residual plot is not in a linear form.

solution:
A residual plot shows the residuals graphed against the explanatory variable. A residual shows the difference between the actual response variable and the predicted response variable found from the least-squares regression line.

A residual plot can be used to to investigate the appropriateness of the model used. Apparent randomness in the residual plot is evidence for a linear model. For this problem, the residuals are in a parabolic form, which is not random. Therefore, a linear model is not appropriate for the researcher.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Cicada Invasion
question_text:
A specific breed of Cicada, a type of tree insect, only appears in the Eastern United States every $17$ years. But, the cicadas do not simply show up all at one time. A researcher is working on developing a model to predict the number of cicadas that will show up in his town during the summer. Using historical data, the researcher created the following model:
$$ln(\hat{y}) = 3.4 + 0.87x$$
...where $x = $ the number of weeks since the Summer Solstice and $y = $ the number of cicadas in his town (in hundred thousands).

The regression model used to predict the number of cicadas was a non-linear regression model. Specifically, it was transformed using the natural logarithm function.

To use the model to predict, we need to get our $\hat{y}$ by itself. To "undo" the natural log, we use its inverse, the natural exponential function, e.

title: Baby Measurements
question_text:
After a baby is born, doctors take routine measurements of three different statistics: height, weight, and head size. A pediatrician wonders if there is a linear association between height and head size. She collects data from the next $20$ babies she examines and finds a correlation of $0.82$.
Interpret this value in the context of this problem.

choices.text: When height goes up by $1$, the head size increases by approximately $0.82$.
When height equals $0$, the head size is approximately $0.82$.
$82\%$ of the variation in height is accounted for by the least-squares regression line of height and head size.
There is a strong, positive, linear association between height and head size.
The correlation is $0.82$ inches.

solution:
The correlation, $r$, is a measure of the linear association between two quantitative variables. Correlation is unit-free, and always between $−1$ and $1$, inclusive. A value of $r = 0$ indicates that there is no linear association. A value of $r = -1$ or $r = 1$ indicates that there is a perfect linear association.

To interpret the correlation, one must discuss strength and direction. Since it's a measure of linear association, the form of the graph will always be linear. Therefore, since the correlation is $0.82$, the correlation is strong, while also being positive.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Changing Units and the Effect It Has on Correlation
question_text:
The correlation between distance (in kilometers) and airfare (in dollars) is $0.8$.
If we were to change the distance to be measured to miles (all the values in the distance will therefore be divided by $1.61$), what effect will this have on the correlation?

choices.text: The correlation will become $0.5$.
The correlation will decrease by $0.5$, making the new correlation $0.3$.
The correlation will become $1.3$.
Since only the distance measurements have changed, the correlation will decrease significantly.
Because changing units does not affect the correlation, the correlation will remain the same.

correct_answer: The correct answer is Choice 'E'. Changing the units of variables does not change the correlation coefficient “r,” because we get rid of all our units when we standardize (get z-scores). The standardization allows us to compare correlations between data sets where variables are measured in different units or when variables are different.

title: Growth of Puppies
question_text:
A certain breed of dog's growth during the first year of life can be summarized by the least squares regression line $\hat{y} = 10 + 1.2x$, where $x =$ the age in month and $y =$ the weight in pounds.
What would be the predicted increase in weight for a $5$ month old puppy?

choices.text: We should not calculate the predicted increase because the value is outside the domain.

solution:
A simple linear regression model is an equation,
$$\hat{y} = a + bx$$
that uses an explanatory variable, $x$, to predict the response variable, $y$.

This problem is asking for the predicted increase of the response variable, not the predicted response variable. To solve this problem, we can do two different methods:

Method $1$: Use $x = 5$ and $x = 0$ and find the difference:
$$\hat{y} = 10 + 1.2(5) = 16$$
$$\hat{y} = 10 + 1.2(0) = 10$$
Therefore,
$$16 - 10 = 6$$

Method $2$: Simply use the slope of the equation. Since the slope of the equation, $\hat{y} = a + bx$, is represented by $b$, the slope in our equation is $1.2$. The slope is the increase of the predicted response variable for every increase of $1$ unit of the explanatory variable.

Therefore,
$$1.2(5) = 6$$

Choice 'D' is correct.

No. The conditional distributions of stress levels are very similar for both boys and girls. Since the stress levels occur in about the same proportions for both genders, we cannot claim that there is a difference.

title: Housing Market
question_text:
The housing market in a small town is currently going through a real-estate boom. A realtor is interested in looking at the relationship between the price of a house and the number of days on the market. She collects data from the last $20$ real-estate transactions from her town and created the scatterplot below.
Loading question supplement...
Which of the following is true about the point labeled "A" on the scatterplot?

choices.text: If the labeled point is removed, the slope would increase and the correlation would increase.
If the labeled point is removed, the slope would decrease and the correlation would increase.
If the labeled point is removed, the slope and correlation coefficient are both unchanged.
If the labeled point is removed, the slope would remain the same and the correlation coefficient would decrease.

solution:
Here's the given graph:

The labeled point, $A$, is considered a high-leverage and influential point for the scatterplot. A point is considered high-leverage when it has a significantly larger or smaller $x$-value than the other observations have. In this case, the house labeled "A" has been on the market much longer than the other homes.

An influential point is any point that when removed changes the relationship substantially. It can change the y-intercept, slope, or correlation coefficient. In this case point $A$ is increasing the correlation coefficient of the least-squares regression line by keeping the points in a more strongly linear form. When point A is removed, the correlation would thus decrease and the slope of the regression line would remain the same (approximately) because point A is approximately on the same linear path as the other data points.

So, Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Drying Time
question_text:
A company that produces clothes dryers is interested in making changes to its flagship dryer. They want to add a sensor that will alter the time needed to fully dry the clothes. A quality assurance representative collects data on the amount of time it takes a load of clothes to fully dry and records the weight of the clothes in pounds. She creates the following linear regression model that predicts the time needed to fully dry a load of clothes:
$$\hat{y} = 32.6 + 1.3x$$
...where $x = $ the weight of clothes in the dryer in pounds and $y = $ the amount of time needed to fully dry the clothes in minutes.
Which of the following statements is false regarding the linear regression model?

choices.text: The more clothes put in the dryer, the longer the predicted drying time.
As weight increases by $1$ pound, the predicted drying time increases by $1.3$ minutes.
As time increases by $1$ minute, the predicted weight increases by $1.3$ pounds.
The $y$-intercept does not have a logical interpretation in this situation.
A load of clothes that weighs $10$ pounds has a predicted time of $45.6$ minutes.

solution:
Remember: we're looking for the answer choice that is false.

When given a least-square regression line in the form of:

$$\hat{y} = a + bx$$

...where $a$ represents the $y$-intercept and $b$ represents the slope of the LSRL.

In this case, our LSRL was:

ˆ
y
=32.6+1.3x

...so the slope of the LSRL was 1.3. The slope is the amount the predicted y-value changes for every unit increase in x.

Therefore, the slope is not predicted by the weight, it is predicting the time needed to dry the clothes.

So, Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Mushroom Hunting
question_text:
A common tradition in the Midwest is hunting for Morel mushrooms during springtime. These mushrooms only grow during certain weather conditions and in certain locations. A mushroom hunter wonders about the production from a location in his local forest. He gathers historical data regarding the amount of rainfall (in inches) and the amount of mushrooms (in ounces) from a mushroom tracking website and finds a least-squares regression line of:
$$\hat{y} = 18.2 + 0.85(x)$$
...where $x =$ the amount of rain in inches and $y =$ the amount of mushrooms in ounces. In the most recent year, the forest received $3$ inches of rain and produced $20.2$ ounces of mushrooms.
Which of the following is true about the mushroom production?

choices.text: The graph of the mushroom production will have a negative direction.
If the forest receives $0$ inches of rain, it will still produce $18.2$ ounces of mushrooms.
The hunter should hope for seasons that have low amount of rain.
The actual amount of mushrooms for the most recent year was more than predicted.
The actual amount of mushrooms for the most recent year was less than predicted.

solution:
When looking at the difference between the actual response variable, $y$, and the predicted response variable, $\hat{y}$, we want to examine the residual of the data. The formula to find this is
$$\text{residual} = y - \hat{y}$$

The given least-squares regression line was
$$\hat{y} = 18.2 + 0.85(x)$$
Plugging in our rainfall amount, $x = 3$,
$$\hat{y} = 18.2 + 0.85(3)$$
$$\hat{y} = 18.2 + 2.55$$
$$\hat{y} = 20.75$$

Therefore, to find the residual,
$$\text{residual} = y - \hat{y}$$
$$\text{residual} = 20.2 - 20.75$$
$$\text{residual} = -0.55$$

Therefore, the actual amount is less than the predicted amount from the least-squares regression line.

Choice 'E' is correct.

A person who answered is more likely to live at home if they are employed than not employed.
Of people who answered unemployed, half still live at home.
The proportion of unemployed who live at home is higher than the proportion of unemployed who rent or own combined.
The proportion of people who rent is over $50\%$.

solution:
The table shows the relationship between two categorical variables. To examine the relationship between categorical variables, find the conditional relative frequencies. A conditional relative frequency is a relative frequency for a specific part of the contingency table (e.g., cell frequencies in a row divided by the total for that row).

To find the conditional relative frequency for unemployed students, we must only look at the $160$ students who answered "unemployed". When looking at the $160$ students who answers "unemployed", $80$ answered that they lived "at home", which is exactly half.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Blocking and Matched Pair Studies
question_text:
Read the following statements about randomized blocked experiments and matched pair experiments.
Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Blocks should be formed on variables that cannot otherwise be controlled, such as age or gender.
A randomized block study in which all blocks have exactly two subjects is a type of matched pair study.
A matched pair study is an advantageous experiment design because it is a simple design that controls for a large number of variables.
When a research team is able to foresee a confounding variable, it should block on that variable.
At the end of a randomized block experiment, it is most important to compare the blocks to each other.

title: Matched Pairs: Computer Program
question_text:
Suppose a teacher wishes to determine if his students learn better through in-class instruction or computer program.
The teacher has only $10\text{ students}$, so he randomly divides them into two groups of $5$, one group of which learns through in-class instruction while the other group learns via computer program.
Why could the results be better trusted if the experiment were done in a matched pairs fashion?

choices.text: The teacher would have $10\text{ data points}$ to work with instead of $5$.
Even if the subjects were randomly divided, such a small sample size makes it very likely that one group could have more intelligent students than the other simply by chance.
Students would feel more comfortable doing an experiment such as this with a pair.
A matched pairs design in this situation allows the teacher to use a control group.
A matched pairs design ensures the correct teaching method would be found in this situation.

title: Migraine Medication
question_text:
Millions of people suffer from migraine headaches. A research team believes it has created a new medication that will help those who suffer from migraines. They recruit $100$ people who suffer from migraines and give all of them the new medication to take when a migraine headache occurs. They are asked to rate the effectiveness of the medication in helping reduce the effects of the migraine out of $10$. Overall, the sample rates the medication $7.6$ on average.
Can the research team prove that the medication caused the a reduction in the migraine effects?

choices.text: Yes, because the rating is $7.6$.
Yes, because all members of the sample suffered from migraines.
No, because $100$ people is not a large enough sample.
No, because $7.6$ is not significant enough.
No, because it is an observational study and not an experiment.

solution:
The researchers had two choices of studies they could've performed: an observational study or an experiment. In an observational study, the researchers do not attempt to influence the response variable, meaning that different groups within the sample do not receive different treatments. In an experiment, different treatments are imposed to different experimental units.

In the above case, since all members of the study received the medication, this was an observational study, not an experiment. And since this was an observational study, it is not possible to to determine a causal relationship between variables using data collected in an observational study. So the researchers cannot prove the medication caused the reduction of symptoms.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: High School Testing
question_text:
A professor wanted to know whether a prep course would increase students’ test scores.
Twelve subjects were randomly chosen to take the prep course, and they scored an average of $20.3$ with a standard deviation of $8.3\text{ points}$. Another $12\text{ subjects}$ were randomly chosen who were not allowed to take the test prep course, and they scored an average of $18.3$ with a standard deviation of $9.1\text{ points}$.
Despite these scores, why might the professor not be convinced that the course helps?

choices.text: A difference of $2\text{ points}$ on the test is not practically significant.
The variability is such that the higher scores achieved by the group who took the prep course could have been a result of chance.
Randomization was not properly used in this situation.
A control group was not properly used in this situation.
Bias was obvious in the measurement of the students’ test scores.

title: Identifying the Experimental Design
question_text:

To explore this, $100$ adults who experience migraines volunteered to participate in a study to compare the effects of caffeine on migraine symptoms. Each volunteer is assigned at random to one of two groups and is provided either a daily capsule that contains caffeine or a placebo. Each volunteer will monitor the amount of and severity of migraines they experience over the next month and results will be compared for each group.
What type of experimental design is being described?

choices.text: A completely randomized design
A block design
A matched-pairs design
The placebo effect
This is not an experiment - this describes a voluntary response sample.

title: Why an Experiment?
question_text: Which of the following best describes a reason why we may decide to gather data by way of conducting an experiment?

choices.text: By conducting an experiment, we can estimate the probability of something occurring.
By conducting an experiment, we are able to gain an understanding of the behavior of our subjects even when we are not able to observe such behaviors first-hand.
By conducting an experiment, we gain insight into how a specific explanatory variable affects a certain response variable.
By conducting an experiment, we can better understand the thoughts and opinions of those individuals in our population of interest.
By conducting an experiment we are able to remove all bias from our results.

title: Tennis Racket Strings
question_text:
A high school tennis coach wonders if she can improve her team's performance by replacing the nylon strings on the tennis rackets with polyester strings. The $26\text{ tennis players}$ will be randomly assigned to two groups - one group's rackets will get nylon strings and the other group's rackets will get polyester strings.
Each player will serve a tennis ball $35\text{ times}$. For each player, the coach will record the proportion of serves that land in the service box and the average speed of the serves.
Which of the following statements is FALSE?

choices.text: The treatments are the $35\text{ serves}$ each player attempts.
The experimental units are the $26\text{ tennis players}$.
There is replication in this study design because there are $13\text{ tennis}$ players using each type of racket.
The group of players using the nylon strings is the control group.
Because the players were randomly assigned to the two groups, it is unlikely that one group will include all of the best players on the team.

Set A receives a high-nitrogen fertilizer and full sun.
Set B receives a low-nitrogen fertilizer and full sun.
Set C receives a high-nitrogen fertilizer and part shade.
Set D receives a low-nitrogen fertilizer and part shade.
At the end of the growing season, Terrie compares the number of tomatoes produced from the four sets within each variety group.
The variable being blocked in this experiment is

choices.text: The variety of tomato plant.
The amount of nitrogen in the fertilizer.
The number of tomatoes produced by each plant.
The amount of sunlight the plants receive each day.
The nursery where the tomatoes were purchased.

title: Research Designs: Diabetes Drug
question_text:
A researcher wants to determine the effectiveness of a new diabetes drug to control blood sugar levels.
The clinic where he will be conducting his research has $500\text{ patients}$ following a diet plan that was formulated to help control blood sugar levels. The researcher would like to use these $500\text{ patients}$ to determine what the effectiveness of $60\text{ mg}$, $80\text{ mg}$, and $100\text{ mg}$ pills would have on blood sugar levels.
Which of the following research designs would be the most appropriate?

choices.text: A randomized block design by diet plan for the three levels of drug dosage.
A stratified random sample where the experimental design has four strata, one for each of the drug dosage levels and one placebo/control group.
A double-blind study with patients assigned randomly to one of four groups, one for each of the drug dosage levels and one placebo/control group.
A stratified random sample with no placebo/control group since there are already three groups that can be measured against one another.
A research design is only necessary when sample is conducted, so there is no need for an experimental design since the entire population of $500\text{ patients}$ at this clinic is being measured.

title: A New Restaurant
question_text: The manager of a new restaurant wishes to know if there is local interest in the cuisine his restaurant offers prior to signing a contract in Foodtown, NY. He obtains a complete list of all residents of Foodtown and decides to select a simple random sample of $150$ residents. He will send sample menus and an invitation for a complimentary lunch to the $150$ residents randomly chosen. What is the likelihood that all $150$ randomly chosen residents will live in the same neighborhood?

choices.text: Zero. By taking a simple random sample, the manager is ensuring the residents selected will be spread out throughout Foodtown, NY.
The same as for any group of $150$ residents in all of Foodtown, NY.
Very unlikely as each neighborhood could be considered a cluster and in a cluster sample, each cluster is unlikely to be chosen.
The population size divided by $150$.
Very likely. A simple random sample ensures each group of $150$ residents is very likely to be chosen as the final sample.

title: Conclusions About Effectiveness
question_text:
Suppose $100$ volunteers were selected for a study over a $6$-month period.
Of these, $50$ randomly chosen subjects were given a weight loss drug. These $50\text{ subjects}$ had an average weight loss of $11.6\text{ lbs}$ with a standard deviation of $4.2\text{ pounds}$. The remaining $50\text{ subjects}$ lost an average of $12.2\text{ lbs}$ with a standard deviation of $4.1\text{ lbs}$ on a placebo.
What could one conclude about the weight loss drugs’ effectiveness?

choices.text: The weight loss drug is most likely effective; subjects lost a significant amount of weight, which is unlikely to happen by chance.
Most likely other factors lead to weight loss in this situation; there is not convincing evidence the weight loss drug is effective.
There is inconclusive evidence concerning the drugs’ effectiveness due to the small sample size.
There is inconclusive evidence concerning the drugs’ effectiveness since the subjects were volunteers.
The weight loss drug is most likely effective; losing $11.6\text{ pounds}$ is both a practically and statistically significant amount.

title: Benefit of Matched Pairs
question_text: What is the main benefit of using a matched pairs design as opposed to a controlled randomized design?

choices.text: A matched pairs design reduces measurement error.
A matched pairs design reduces variation among different aspects of the subjects.
A matched pairs design allows us to randomize subjects better.
A matched pairs design allows us to get more data points.
A matched pairs design reduces inherent bias from the people conducting the experiment.

title: Teacher Salaries
question_text:
A local school board is trying to estimate the proportion of the school district's population that feels that teacher salaries should be increased.
Which of the following sampling methods is most effective in minimizing bias in this sample proportion?

choices.text:
$100\text{ adults}$ will be randomly chosen from voter registration records. Each adult will be asked the question, "Given the many hours that teachers work outside of the regular school day and during the summer months, do you feel their salaries should be increased?"
If the voter cannot be reached on the first attempt, the surveyor will continue calling back until they are able to reach the voter.

$100\text{ adults}$ will be randomly chosen from voter registration records. Each adult will be asked the question, "Do you feel teacher salaries should be increased?"
If the voter cannot be reached on the first attempt, the surveyor will continue calling back until they are able to reach the voter.

$100\text{ adults}$ will be randomly chosen from voter registration records. Each adult will be asked the question, "Do you feel teacher salaries should be increased?"
If the voter cannot be reached on the first attempt, the surveyor will move on to another randomly selected voter who can be easily reached.

$75\text{ adults}$ will be randomly chosen from among the attendees at a school board meeting. A teacher wearing her school ID badge will ask subjects the question, "Do you think teacher salaries should be increased?"

$75\text{ adults}$ will be randomly chosen from among the attendees at a school board meeting. The interviewer will ask subjects the question, "Given the many hours that teachers work outside of the regular school day and during the summer months, do you feel their salaries should be increased?"

title: Types of Sampling: High School Schedule
question_text:
A vice principal wanted to investigate student opinion about a possible change in the high school schedule for the upcoming school year. The vice principal selected random samples of $30$ freshmen, $30$ sophomores, $30$ juniors, and $30$ seniors to get their input about the possible change.
Which of the following best describes the vice principal's sampling plan?

choices.text: A convenience sample.
A cluster sample.
A stratified random sample.
A simple random sample.
A systematic sample.

title: Bird Perfume and Experimental Design
question_text:
Many people enjoy bird watching and try to attract colorful songbirds to their yard. Are songbirds attracted to certain fragrances? An ornithologist believes so and has developed a chemical compound that she believes will attract birds without harming plant life. In order to test her theory, she sprays the chemical compound onto plants in one back yard and does not spray the chemical compound onto plants in a neighboring back yard. The yard to receive the spray is randomly determined. She then counts the number of songbirds observed in each of the two back yards for a period of five days.
Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Different types of plants in each of the two back yards could confound the results of this experiment.
The weather during the period in which the ornithologist is recording results could impact the results of this study.
This experiment seeks to determine whether spraying the chemical compound on surrounding plants will result in more song birds visiting the area.
If the plants in both back yards are harmed by the spraying of the chemical compound in the single treatment yard, then we cannot determine the effectiveness of the treatment.

With sufficient replication, and if the ornithologist is able to control for the effects of outside variables, an experiment of this type could help to establish a cause-and-effect relationship between the usage of the chemical compound and the appearance of song birds in a back yard.

title: Finding a Census
question_text: Which of the following scenarios describes a census?

choices.text: Jack wants to know the average weight of a single chicken wing served at his favorite restaurant. To gather data, he places an order for wings, weighs each and every one of the wings in the order, and then finds the average.

Amy is worried about her addiction to buying shoes and wonders if her shoe collection is larger than the average for high school girls. To find out, she randomly contacts $10$ of her female high school friends and asks them how many pairs of shoes they own. She then finds the average so that she can compare it to the number of pairs that she owns.

Margeaux wants to know the average age of the people who belong to her book club. To gather data, she consults the membership list which consists of $40$ individuals. She then contacts each of these $40$ people who provide her with their age so that she can find the average.

In order to estimate the proportion of grocery shoppers who use coupons, a researcher observes a randomly selected line at a certain grocery store for a period of $3$ days. He then determines the proportion of shoppers who were observed using a coupon.
Owners of a travel website wants to know the favorite foreign destination for American travelers. To gather data, they post a survey on the website and ask people to vote.

title: Carrot Consumption and Weight
question_text:
A researcher thinks there may be a negative correlation between the number of carrots an individual consumes and that individual’s weight.
The researcher surveys $250$ randomly selected females and asks each her weight and how many servings of carrots she consumes per month.
The researcher also surveys $250$ randomly selected males and asks them the same questions. A scatterplot is made with different symbols for male and female data.
The study done by this researcher is:

choices.text: A controlled randomized experiment.
An experiment with a block design, blocking on gender.
A census.
An observational study.
A matched pairs experiment where a male could be paired with a female of similar weight.

title: Going to College: Sample Distance
question_text:
On average, how far away from home do graduating high school seniors go to attend college?
Representatives for the admissions department of a small college decided to do a study in order to answer this question. To gather data, they contacted a random sample of graduating seniors and asked them to identify both their home town and the college or university that they would be attending.
From this information, they determined the approximate distance that each student would be traveling to attend college and then calculated the average.
What was the goal of gathering this information?

choices.text: They wanted to be able to estimate the mean distance that graduating seniors in their sample would be travelling to attend college.
They wanted to be able to estimate the mean distance that all graduating seniors travel in order to attend college.
They wanted to be able to estimate the proportion of graduating seniors who would consider attending their college.
They wanted to be able to identify individuals within the sample who represent the overall population of graduating seniors.
They wanted to be able to identify seniors who would be attending their college.

title: Undercoverage
question_text: If undercovereage occurs in a sample, it means that

choices.text: The sample did not cover enough respondents.
The sample size was too small because some subjects did not respond.
The question in the sample was not asked in a thorough enough manner as to capture the true feelings of the respondents.
Certain groups of the population were systematically excluded from the sample.
Calculations in the data results were incomplete and did not give a complete description of the sample.

correct_answer: Undercoverage means that certain groups are excluded from the sample, based on how the sample was conducted.

title: Why Use Matched Pairs?
question_text:
A manufacturer of hair care products believes that they have developed a new formula for their shampoo that will leave hair feeling softer and silkier. The shampoo that contains the new formula looks and smells like the original formula, so those who use the shampoo would not be able to tell the two formulas apart.
Several volunteers who use the company's shampoo have agreed to help them test their theory, and since the group of volunteers is very diverse, the manufacturer believes that the volunteers actually would be a good representation of the population of individuals who would use their shampoo.
For this study, each volunteer will have the hair on one side of their head shampooed with the original formula and the hair on the other side of their head shampooed with the new formula. Which side receives which formula will be determined at random and the hair on the left side of the head will always be shampooed first.
After the hair is then dried and styled to the individual's preference, each individual will be asked to rate how soft and silky their hair feels on the side with the original formula and on the side with the new formula. Ratings will be based on a scale from $1$ to $5$ with $1$ being "not soft and silky" and $5$ being "the most soft and silky". The difference between the new formula rating and the old formula rating will be recorded for each individual in the study.
What is the advantage of using matched pairs design for this study?

choices.text: Using matched pairs design gives each individual an opportunity to experience both shampoos so they will know which one they prefer.

Using matched pairs will help the researchers to be able to determine if the new formula of shampoo will work better on certain types of hair (such as curly, thin, coarse, etc.) than on other types of hair.

By using matched pairs, each individual is able to act as their own control. Each individual can control for the effects of the different formulas so they will know which formula works best for them. Using matched pairs ensures that the individuals will not be influenced by the opinions of others.

By using matched pairs, each individual is able to act as their own control. Each individual has their own opinion on what "soft and silky" feels like and different individuals may have different types of hair. Using matched pairs design reduces the chances that the results will be affected by these differences.

Using matched pairs design requires the use of more individuals than completely randomized design or block design. Therefore it may provide better opportunities for the company to market their products to more individuals.

title: Newspaper Headline
question_text:
A recent headline in a national newspaper read,
$$\text{Running Ten Miles a Day Lowers Blood Pressure}$$
Upon reading the article, you realize that the study had $30$ volunteer participants that normally ran $10$ miles per day, and that the results showed the participants had lower blood pressure than an average person.
Which statement is false regarding the situation?

choices.text: The results cannot be generalized for the general population.
The study is done in such a way that we cannot prove a causal relationship.
The results of the study can only be generalized to people like the $30$ volunteers.
The headline is a correct interpretation of the results of the study.
This is a prospective survey as it follows a sample of individuals into the future collecting data.

solution:
The headline is interpreting the results of a study from $30$ volunteer participants. The participants in the study also consistently ran $10$ miles a day. This fact leads you to the belief that since the participants were already running $10$ miles per day, we cannot generalize the results to the whole population.

Additionally, the study is an observational study as there was no treatment imposed on the individuals in the study. Therefore, we cannot show a cause and effect relationship between running $10$ miles per day and the lowering of blood pressure. We would need a well-designed experiment to show a causal relationship.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Laundry Detergent Effectiveness
question_text:
A company just launched a new formula of laundry detergent, and is curious about the effectiveness of the detergent as measured by proportion of clothes that were stain free after being washed.
Of the following designs, which would be the best way to use results from their customers to determine the effectiveness of this new detergent?

choices.text: Randomly select $100\text{ current customers}$. For each subject, flip a coin. If the coin lands heads these customers will use the new detergent for $60\text{ days}$. If the coin lands tails these customers will use the old detergent for $60\text{ days}$. Then ask each group about their level of satisfaction of their detergents.
Randomly select $100\text{ subjects}$. Ask them to use the new detergent for $60\text{ days}$, and then ask for their opinion on the effectiveness of the new detergent.
Give out free samples at a nearby supermarket to $100\text{ subjects}$. After $60\text{ days}$, follow up on these subjects and ask them their opinion on the new detergent.
Randomly select $100\text{ current customers}$, ask them to use the new detergent. After $60\text{ days}$, ask the customers their opinion on the new detergent.

Randomly select $100\text{ current customers}$, ask them to flip a coin each time they do laundry. If it lands heads, they will use the new detergent formula. If it lands tails, they will use the old detergent formula. After $60\text{ days}$, ask the customers which formula was more effective.

title: Census: Education in the Summer
question_text:
A large seminar was presented for teachers about possible retirement options. During the seminar, a random sample of $50$ math teachers attending the conference was selected. Among the teachers selected, $85\%$ have been teaching math for more than ten years.
For which of the following populations is $85\%$ a reasonable estimate of the percentage of those who have been teaching math for more than ten years?

choices.text: All teachers.
All teachers who attended the seminar.
All people involved with education.
All math teachers.
All math teachers who attended the seminar.

title: Understanding Blocking in an Experiment
question_text: In the context of an experiment, blocking refers to

choices.text: Dividing subjects up in the such a way that they are in the group they wish to join.
Performing the experiment on a variety of different subjects to make generalizing the results to the population more effective.
Dividing the subjects up in such a way that the subjects in each group have less variability.
Performing the experiment on many different people as a way to reduce variability.
Hiring a third party so that neither the subjects nor the people conducting the experiment know who gets what treatment.

title: Potassium Water Study | 2 of 2
question_text:
Would drinking water with potassium during a workout on the treadmill help you to reach a higher average speed during your workout than drinking regular bottled water? A sports doctor decided to do a study and twenty volunteers who typically work out on a treadmill agreed to participate.
Each volunteer was asked to walk on the treadmill for $30$ minutes on two separate occasions with a one week break in between. During one of the two workouts, the participant was given a bottle of regular water to drink and during the other workout they were given a bottle of potassium water which looks and tastes just like regular water.
Which type of water was received first was determined at random. While participants were unable to see their speed on the treadmill during their workouts, the average speed for both workouts was recorded and the difference between the two mean speeds was determined for each individual.
What type of study is being described?

choices.text: A comparative experiment using completely randomized design but lacking proper control.
A comparative experiment using completely randomized design and a single replication.
A comparative experiment using block design where the two types of water represent the two blocks.
A matched pairs experiment for the difference in mean speed when consuming the two types of water.
An observational study.

title: Type of Sample and Possible Concerns
question_text:
According to the National Center for Education Statistics, $65.9\%$ of students enrolled in college in the fall immediately after completing high school in the year $2013$.
Wendy just did some research for an article she is writing for the school newspaper and knows that at her high school, $84.1\%$ of students who graduated the previous year immediately enrolled to attend college that fall. She started to wonder if the percent of students who enroll in college immediately after completing high school is now greater than $65.9\%$.
To investigate, she contacted $437$ students (some from her school and some from other schools) that she knew would be graduating this year. She found that $80.3\%$ of them were planning to enroll in college immediately after completing high school.
Which of the following best describes the type of sample that Wendy used and the potential concerns that may result from using this type of sample?

choices.text: This was a cluster sample. The cluster selected consisted of people that Wendy knows will be graduating this year. This is a problem because it undercovers those who graduated or will be graduating in future years.

This was a convenience sample consisting only of people that Wendy knows about. While these individuals may be easy to reach and will probably be quite cooperative in answering Wendy's questions, the sample may not accurately represent the population of interest.

This was a systematic sample in which Wendy systematically decides to only survey individuals who she knows will be graduating this year. This could create problems if those who are graduating this year are different from those who graduate in other years with respect to their post-graduation plans.

This was a stratified random sample which is the best type of sample possible under the circumstances. Since Wendy can only survey individuals who she knows, she selected this strata as her sample. There should be no concerns that result from using this sample.

This is a voluntary response sample in which individuals are able to decide whether or not they want to voluntarily answer Wendy's questions. This is a problem because those that choose to respond will most likely be the individuals who are planning to attend college immediately after graduating from high school.

title: Designing a Study and Looking for a Cure
question_text:
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is an extremely rare degenerative brain disorder that is usually fatal within a year of the onset of symptoms. There is no cure and treatment is generally aimed at alleviating symptoms.
Suppose a new medication has been developed which shows some promise of alleviating symptoms while also slowing the progression of the disease and extending the lives of individuals who are affected.
If $30$ individuals who have recently been diagnosed with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease have agreed to take part in a study to evaluate whether the new medication will alleviate symptoms and help those with the disease live longer lives, which of the following outlines how best to conduct the study?

choices.text: A matched pairs experiment in which each of the $30$ individuals receives both the current treatment and the new medication.

A single blind experiment using two groups which are formed by completely randomizing the individuals into treatment groups.
One group would receive the new medication while the other group would receive the current treatment.

A double blind experiment using completely randomized design. Three treatment groups would be determined at random.
The first group would receive the current treatment, the second group would receive the new medication, and the third group would receive a placebo.

A double blind experiment using completely randomized design. The researcher would randomly assign $15$ individuals to receive the new medication and $15$ individuals to receive the current treatment.

An experiment using block design. Individuals who the researchers suspect will react better to the new medication will be blocked into one group and will be given the new medication, while individuals who the researchers believe will not benefit from the new medication will be blocked into the other group and will receive the current treatment.

title: Superintendent Survey
question_text:
Suppose the superintendent of a large school district is interested in district-wide student satisfaction with the cafeteria food.
The superintendent decides to conduct a stratified sample by randomly selecting $30\text{ subjects}$ from each grade level, K-12, for a total of $390\text{ students}$ surveyed in the district.
What is the greatest benefit of conducting a stratified sample such as this one, compared to a simple random sample of $390\text{ students}$?

choices.text: A stratified sample can contact more individuals to get more pieces of data and less variability.
A stratified sample can reduce bias.
A stratified sample can give more detailed information, showing food satisfaction for a variety of different ages.
Students are less likely to lie about their feelings regarding cafeteria food in this district if the sample is stratified.
In this situation, there are no benefits of a stratified sample compared to a simple random sample.

title: Issues with Experiments: Fabric Softeners
question_text:
A scientist wants to test three different laundry fabric softeners.
Of a total of $150\text{ towels}$, $50$ were randomly selected and washed with a certain fabric softener. Another $50$ randomly selected towels were washed with a different fabric softener, and the remaining $50\text{ towels}$ were washed with the third fabric softener.
Each laundry load was done with the same detergent, same water temperature, and on the same washing machine. A total of $50$ trained observers then felt the towels from each of the three treatment groups for softness. The response variable will be which towel the observers say is the softest.
Which of the following could be a problem with this experiment?

choices.text: There is not enough replication to get trustworthy results.
There should be a placebo group in this experiment.
The experiment should use randomly selected consumers instead of trained observers.
The experiment should be single blind so that the observers do not know the brand of softener being used for each towel.
There are obvious lurking variables present in this experiment.

title: Taking a SRS of Student Council Members
question_text:
A state convention for student council members has been announced. Washington High School is allowed to send $5$ students and the advisor has decided to select a SRS of interested student council members in order to determine who will represent their school at the state convention.
Created for Albert.io. Copyright 2016. All rights reserved.
Each of the $25$ students who expressed interest in attending the state convention was assigned a unique numerical code as shown above.
If the random digits provided are used to select the SRS, which of the following students will NOT be included in the SRS?

choices.text: Brad.
Deanna.
Francisco.
Sam.
William.

title: Double-Blind Experiment
question_text:
A manufacturer of hair care products believes that they have developed a new formula for their shampoo that will leave hair feeling softer and silkier. The shampoo that contains the new formula looks and smells like the original formula, so those who use the shampoo would not be able to tell the two formulas apart.
Several volunteers who use the company's shampoo have agreed to help them test their theory, and since the group of volunteers is very diverse, the manufacturer believes that the volunteers actually would be a good representation of the population of individuals who would use their shampoo.
For this study, each volunteer will have the hair on one side of their head shampooed with the original formula and the hair on the other side of their head shampooed with the new formula. Which side receives which formula will be determined at random and the hair on the left side of the head will always be shampooed first.
After the hair is then dried and styled to the individual's preference, each individual will be asked to rate how soft and silky their hair feels on the side with the original formula and on the side with the new formula.
