Ratings will be based on a scale from $1$ to $5$ with $1$ being "not soft and silky" and $5$ being "the most soft and silky". The difference between the new formula rating and the old formula rating will be recorded for each individual in the study.
What would it mean for this experiment to be double blind? Why is this an important characteristic of the experiment?

choices.text: No one will know which side of each individual's head is shampooed with which formula. This is important because it will allow the researchers to properly analyze the results.
No one will know which side of each individual's head is shampooed with which formula. This is important because it ensures that the ratings given by the individuals will be entirely free from bias.

Neither the individuals who are having their hair shampooed nor the people who are shampooing the hair will know which side of the head is shampooed with which formula. This is important because it helps to reduce the chance that the ratings given by the individuals will be unfairly influenced by knowing which side of their hair received which treatment.

Neither the individuals who are having their hair shampooed nor the people who are shampooing the hair will know which side of the head is shampooed with which formula. This is important because we want the individuals to be able to feel a decisive difference in the softness and silkiness of the hair on both sides of the head.

The hair on the left side of the head will not know which formula of shampoo it received. Neither will the hair on the right side of the head. This is important because we want the hair on both sides of the head to feel equally soft and silky.

title: Telephone Surveys and Types of Bias
question_text:
Janice received a telephone call from a research organization asking if she would be willing to answer a few questions about how often she buys certain types of groceries. Janice told the researcher that she was not interested in participating.
Nevertheless, two days later she received another phone call from the same organization asking if she would participate in their survey about buying certain types of groceries. Once again, Janice refused. When the same organization called her for a third time, Janice became irate. She told the researcher "No matter how many times you call me, I will not participate in your survey! Please do not call this number again!"
Which of the following best describes the type of bias Janice (and others like her) may have introduced into the research organization's survey results?

choices.text: Undercoverage bias may be present since information about how often Janice (and others like her) buy certain types of groceries will not be included in the survey results.

Voluntary response bias may be present since Janice did not voluntarily provide information about how often she buys certain types of groceries. The people who do voluntarily provide such information may differ from Janice in some way that would cause the survey results to be inaccurate.
Response bias may be present. Since Janice became irate when the organization called her for the third time, this interaction could affect the organization's survey results.

Non-response bias may be present. Since Janice (and probably many other people who were contacted by the research organization) would not cooperate with answering the researcher's questions, the results of the survey may not accurately represent the population of interest.
There is no chance that Janice's refusal to participate in the survey would introduce bias of any type.

title: Consequences of the Non-Response: Music Festival
question_text:
The city council of a small town is interested in public opinion regarding hosting a large music festival in the town.
The council sent out $500\text{ surveys}$ via mail, $274$ of which were filled out by respondents and mailed back.
Of those mailed back, $\frac{201}{274} = 73.4\%$ were in favor of the town hosting the music festival.
What could be a possible consequence of the non-response?
How could the city fix the issue of non-response to get a better read on how the residents really feel about hosting the music festival?

choices.text: People who do not respond may have different opinions on supporting the music festival than those who do respond. The city council should survey an additional $226\text{ subjects}$ to get the survey size back to $500$.

People who did not respond may have different opinions on supporting the music festival than those who did respond. The city council should use some other method to attempt to contact those $226\text{ subjects}$ who did not respond.
There will be a larger margin of error in this sample since $226\text{ people}$ did not respond. The city council should send additional surveys out until $n = 500$.

The subjects who responded are more likely to have lied about their true feelings regarding the festival. The city council should contact these $274\text{ subjects}$ a second time and ask them how they feel about hosting the event.
Non-response is not a major issue here since the sample size is still large ($n = 274$).

title: Statistically Significant Findings
question_text: Bright colors usually attract more attention than dark colors. A clothing store owner wants to investigate whether displaying bright clothing in the front window of the store will increase the volume of shoppers more than displaying dark clothing. The owner decides to change the clothing display once a week. At the beginning of each week, the color of the clothing displayed is randomly chosen to be either bright or dark, and the amount of shoppers for the week is recorded. At the end of the study, the owner determined that the amount of shoppers was greater when bright colors were displayed in the front window. In fact, the owner found the difference to be statistically significant. What can be concluded from the study?

choices.text: The amount of shoppers will always be greater when the bright clothing is displayed in the front window.
The amount of shoppers increased over the time of the study.
Any conclusion is problematic because the different types of clothing were not taken into account as part of the study.
Shoppers will buy more brightly-colored clothing if they see it in the front window of the store.
Displaying bright clothing in the front window of the store causes an increase, on average, in the amount of shoppers in the store.

title: Annual Income Survey
question_text:
Suppose $100\text{ subjects}$ were asked what their annual income was last year.
This is an example of...

choices.text: A stratified sample.
An experiment, but not a double-blind experiment.
A comparative observational study.
A double-blind experiment.
A sample, but not a stratified sample.

title: Investigating Relationships: Power Lines
question_text:
Researchers are curious if there is a connection between childhood cancer rates and living near power lines.
What could be a viable way to investigate this relationship?
I. Randomly select $200\text{ children}$ and move half of them near power lines while ensuring the other half do not live near power lines then compare cancer rates.
II. Randomly select $100\text{ children}$ who live near power lines and another $100\text{ children}$ who do not live near power lines then investigate cancer rates of the respective groups.
III. Randomly select $100\text{ children}$ who have cancer and another $100\text{ children}$ who do not have cancer and compare where the children live.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
I and II only.
II and III only.
I, II, and III.

title: Bugs in the Trees in the Great Smoky Mountains: A Study | 2 of 2
question_text:
The hemlock woolly adelgid is a small invasive insect that came to North America via Japan and is responsible for killing most of the hemlock trees in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. To try to control the destruction of hemlock trees caused by the hemlock woolly adelgid, biologists have released lady beetles from Japan (which are known to be natural predators of the hemlock woolly adelgid) onto several of the remaining healthy hemlock trees in the park.
Which of the following describes the experimental units in this study?

choices.text: Biologists.
The Great Smoky Mountains.
Healthy hemlock trees in the park.
Hemlock woolly adelgids.
Lady beetles.

title: Vitamin B$12$
question_text:
Vitamin B$12$ helps to prevent a type of anemia that makes people tired and weak. A group of doctors wants to determine whether a small increase in Vitamin B$12$ will help their anemic patients to feel a bit more energetic and strong. The doctors obtain a group of volunteers with anemia and randomly assign them to two groups. Prior to the study, all patients were ingesting a standard amount of Vitamin B$12$ and so the doctors decide to keep that amount constant for one group and to increase the amount by $5$ micrograms (mcg) for the other group. The doctors monitor the health of the volunteers for the duration of the study.
Which of these statements is NOT true about this study?

choices.text: An advantage of using only anemic volunteers is that there should be less variability in the response to the treatment.
A disadvantage of using only anemic volunteers is that the scope of inference is limited to only anemic patients.
An advantage of using the doctors' patients is that it is easier to maintain control to avoid confounding factors.
This is a single-blind study in which the patients do not know which treatment they are receiving.
If the patients with increased Vitamin B$12$ feel more energetic than those who do not get an increase in Vitamin B$12$, it cannot be determined that the increased Vitamin B$12$ caused the response.

title: Student Random Sample
question_text:
Suppose the student council at a large high school wants to measure student approval of school leadership using a simple random sample of size $n = 100$.
What would be the best way to select these students?

choices.text: Go to the cafeteria during lunch and select $5$ students at each table until the sample size is $100$.
Since $100$ students are currently enrolled in AP Statistics in this school, sample those $100$ students.
Obtain a list of all students from the registrar and assign a number to each, then use a random number generator to select $100$ students.
Since government is a required daily course, survey all the students in the government classes during one school day until $n = 100$.
Have each of the $10$ members of the student council ask $10$ of their friends, telling the members try to ask different types of people.

title: Survey of New Cola
question_text:
Soft drink manufacturers want to introduce a new flavor of spicy cola to compete with the leading brand of cola.
They went to a local shopping mall and administered a blind taste test that included the new spicy cola and the leading cola brand.
They surveyed $100\text{ subjects}$, and gave each of them an unmarked cup of each cola, in randomized order. The researchers found that $56$ liked the new cola better.
This is an example of

choices.text: A voluntary response survey.
A double-blind experiment.
An observational study.
A blocking experiment, where cola type is a block.
A single-blind experiment.

title: Pitching Substance
question_text:
A professional baseball pitcher is trying to determine which substance helps create more spin on a baseball. He decides to try three different substances: $A$, $B$, and $C$. Additionally, he needs to throw the baseball to determine the spin rate without a substance. The pitcher will randomly assign the substance to a baseball and measure the spin rate of a fastball.
Which of the following is true about the experiment?

choices.text: Spin rate is a quantitative variable
The treatments are the different substances used by the pitcher
The pitcher can show a causal relationship between the substances and spin rate
The results can be generalized to all baseballs as the baseballs in the experiment were randomly assigned
All the above are true

solution:
All the above answers are correct. Since spin rate is a numerical value in which it makes sense to find an average, it is a quantitative variable. Additionally, since the substances are the different conditions that are being applied, this makes them the treatments in the experiment. Since the study is an experiment, we can prove a cause-and-effect relationship between the substances and the spin rate. And finally, since the baseballs were randomly assigned, we can generalize about the whole population of baseballs.

Therefore, since all the above answers are correct, we must select Choice 'E'.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Sample Design: Friends and Classmates
question_text:
Eddie wanted to estimate the proportion of students at his large high school who would be interested in having a chess club at the school. To gather data, he distributed a survey to his friends and many of his classmates.
The survey simply asked: Yes or No? Would you be interested in having a chess club at school?
Eddie asked that the survey be returned to him by the end of the week. Not everyone returned the survey. From those who did however, Eddie was able to calculate the observed proportion to be $ \hat { p } =0.32$.
Based on the way the sample was designed, what type of sample was used AND what is the biggest problem with using a sample of this type?

choices.text:
This is a SRS (Simple Random Sample).

There is no problem with taking a SRS since it is the type of sample that is most likely to represent the population of students at this high school.

This is a stratified random sample with two different strata - friends and classmates.

When using this type of sample, it is possible that the opinions of some portions of the population may not be represented at all.

This is a convenience sample.

When using a convenience sample, it is likely that individuals selected to be part of the sample will not truly represent the population of interest. This means that the results of the survey cannot be generalized to the entire population of students at this high school.

This is a voluntary response sample.

Although Eddie attempted to include his friends and many of his classmates as well, only some of these individuals voluntarily responded to his survey. Since only those with strong opinions in favor of a chess club are likely to return the survey, the calculated sample proportion is likely higher than the true proportion of students at the high school who would like having a chess club at the school.

This is a systematic random sample.

However, since many individuals who were selected to be surveyed did not respond to the survey, non-response bias will be a problem.

title: New Start Time
question_text:
A school is pondering starting the school day earlier. The assistant principal comes up with a survey to ask students if they support the change to an earlier time. She then waits at the school entrance and asks the first $30$ students who show up to school.
Should the school trust the results of the survey?

choices.text: No, because the first students to the school will not be affected by an earlier start time.
No, because the assistant principal did a survey and not an experiment.
Yes, because she asked a sample of students.
Yes, because she asked $30$ students.
Yes, because a random sample is not necessary.

solution:
The assistant principal is collecting data regarding the new school start time. She asks $30$ students their thoughts on the new schedule for a survey.

The issue that the assistant principal has is that she asks the first $30$ students. This does not represent a random sample, and given that variation may or may not be random, the conclusions are uncertain. These students would be the most likely to not be affected by a schedule change.

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: Plans for an Art Gallery: Would Customers Approve?
question_text:
The manager of a city coffee shop is thinking about adding a small art gallery to her shop to display the work of local artists. First, she decides to gather some opinions on whether or not this is something her customers would enjoy.
To do this, the manager places surveys at the counter and on the tables of the coffee shop. Customers can fill out a survey and return it to any store employee.
Identify the sampling method being described and describe a potential problem that could result from using this type of sample.

choices.text: A stratified random sample was used. Since this type of sample is able to provide information about a cross-section of the population of customers of this coffee shop, there should be no potential problems in interpreting the results of the survey.

A SRS was used. However, since this type of sample does not ensure representation from all of the coffee shop's customers, we will not be able to generalize the results of the survey to the entire population.

A convenience sample was used. Although it is quick and easy to sample customers in this way, the results of the survey may be very prone to response bias since many customers will just want to fill out the survey quickly to be done with it.

A voluntary response sample was used. However, since those who have strong opinions about the issue may be those most likely to take and return the survey, the results of the survey may overstate the proportion of customers who would like to see the addition of the art gallery.

A cluster sample was used with clusters consisting of those who take a survey at the counter and those who take a survey at one of the coffee shop tables. However, there is probably only one counter and many tables. Therefore, there will be undercoverage of the opinions of those who take a survey from the counter.

title: Ice Cream Bar at the Hotel Pool
question_text:
A large hotel has just installed an ice cream bar at its pool and would like to gauge its success by conducting a survey. The hotel manager randomly selects $3$ of the $32\text{ floors}$ of the hotel and surveys all the residents on those $3\text{ floors}$.
The design of this survey is best described as a

choices.text: Simple random sample.
Stratified random sample.
Cluster sample.
Blocked sample.
Matched pair sample.

title: Building Blocks for Language Learning
question_text:
A large international company provides language training to many of its employees so that they will be able to conduct business in Japanese.
An experiment is being planned to determine if a new program for teaching adults Japanese is more effective than the program currently on the market. Block design has been requested.
Which of the following best describes how to create the blocks?

choices.text: Subjects should be allowed to choose which block they will belong to.
Subjects should be randomly assigned to blocks.
Each block should have an equal representation of those individuals who find it easy to learn another language and those who find it difficult to learn another language.
Within each block, subjects should be as similar as possible with respect to their language learning abilities.
Subjects in different blocks should receive different treatments.

title: Ways to Collect Data
question_text: Which of the following is not a data collection method?

choices.text: Observational study.
Matched pairs experiment.
Experiment using completely randomized design.
Stratified random sampling.
Survey.

title: Types of Bias: Sports Arena
question_text:
The athletic director of a large university is curious about community opinion of a new initiative to open a sports arena for both community members and college students to use. The cost of this initiative will be funded through a county-wide sales tax.
The athletic director went to several different health clubs and asked members there if they would support the initiative. Out of $500$ people surveyed, $374$ said they would support the sports arena.
What is a type of bias present here? Furthermore, is the true population proportion who support this initiative higher, lower, or about the same as the sample proportion?

choices.text: Response bias; population proportion is about the same.
Non-response bias; population proportion is about the same.
Non-response bias; population proportion is lower.
Undercoverage bias; population proportion is higher.
Undercovereage bias; population proportion is lower.

title: Statistical Advantages/Disadvantages in Prolonging Dog Life Study
question_text:
Suppose a large dog food company has a new prototype that is supposed to prolong the life of dogs.
The company randomly selects two groups of $100\text{ dogs}$ each: one group will be fed this new food for the duration of their entire lives; the other group will be fed the leading competitor’s brand of dog food.
Variables such as exercise, location, and medical treatment are all controlled for. However, the company needs to decide whether to use only a specific breed of dog or include a variety of dogs.
What is a statistical advantage of using only one specific breed of dog for this study? A statistical disadvantage?

choices.text:
Advantage: less variability in results
Disadvantage: difficult to generalize the results to other breeds

Advantage: less expensive to run the experiment
Disadvantage: difficult to generalize the results to other breeds

Advantage: more detailed information
Disadvantage: more lurking variables

Advantage: less variability in results
Disadvantage: difficult to obtain dogs of all the same breed

Advantage: less expensive to run the experiment
Disadvantage: more lurking variables

title: School Spirit Sample
question_text:
A high school principal wanted to investigate teacher's opinions on a plan to improve school spirit. The principal randomly selected $3\text{ teachers}$ from each department (math, English, foreign language, etc.) at the school and asked them to complete a survey.
Which of the following best describes the principal’s sampling plan?

choices.text: Cluster sample.
Convenience sample.
Simple random sample.
Stratified random sample.
Voluntary response sample.

title: Best Type of Study? Holey Socks!
question_text:
For runners and other athletes, the right type of socks can make the difference between comfort and painful blisters! We Are Socks sells wicking socks that draw moisture away from the skin and help to prevent blisters. Unfortunately, the socks become thinner and often develop holes after a relatively short period of time. Many customers have been complaining.
Chemical engineers at We Are Socks have developed a new chemical compound. They believe that when this chemical compound is applied to the socks during the manufacturing process it will strengthen the fibers and help to create a wicking sock that is less prone to thinning and developing holes. The compound does not change the appearance or feel of the socks, so those who wear the new socks would not be able to tell the difference between socks treated with the new compound and those not treated with the compound.
Which of the following would be the best way to gather data in order to establish whether or not the new chemical compound helps socks to stay stronger, thicker, and hole-free for a longer period of time?

choices.text: An experiment using completely randomized design.
An experiment using matched pairs design.
An experiment using block design.
An observational study.
An anonymous survey.

title: Lurking Variables: Daily Breakfast
question_text:
Suppose that a study of a group of randomly selected people found that those who eat breakfast daily weigh less than those who do not eat breakfast daily.
What is a possible lurking variable in this study?

choices.text: People who eat breakfast are more likely to exercise.
People who eat breakfast are more likely to read books.
People who eat breakfast are more likely to brush their teeth.
People who eat breakfast are more likely to sleep less.
People who eat breakfast are less likely to smoke cigarettes.

title: Disadvantages of Survey
question_text: Which of the following represents a disadvantage of gathering data by using a survey?

choices.text: A survey cannot be used to help estimate a population parameter such as a population mean or population proportion.
Since a survey must be conducted in person, it is a very time-consuming way to gather data.
A survey is a very expensive method of collecting data. It can be even more expensive to properly analyze the results of the survey.
There is likely to be a lot of undercoverage when conducting a survey since some individuals may choose not to respond to the survey.
Surveys must be designed carefully or the results may be unreliable due to response bias.

title: Purpose of a Control Group
question_text: In an experiment, a control group is used to

choices.text: Increase sample size.
Control for measurement error by the researchers.
Make sure subjects can’t choose which group they are in.
Serve as a baseline to compare effects of one treatment to a standard treatment or placebo.
Give subjects groups to choose from.

title: Undercoverage Bias: Homework
question_text:
A teacher wants to know the average amount of time a typical student at her school spends per night on homework. The teacher decides to survey $73$ students in AP classes.
Of the following, which is the most likely example of undercoverage bias?

choices.text: The students might want to impress the teacher (give those kids an apple) and as a result might exaggerate the amount of time they spend per night on homework.
Students not in AP classes are overlooked in this sampling procedure used to determine who will be surveyed.
The wording of the questions in the survey leads students to respond in a certain way.
The behavior of the teacher encourages students to respond in a certain way.
Many of the students chosen to participate in the survey who do respond might spend a vastly different amount of time on homework than those who do not respond.

title: Questioning Team Mascots: Types of Bias
question_text:
The marketing department for a professional sports team surveys a random sample of individuals who are fans of the team. They ask the following question.
"Several professional sports teams have team names and/or mascots that are considered offensive to many Native Americans. Do you believe that these teams should be forced to change their team names and mascots even though such a change would likely cost the team millions of dollars and could potentially upset loyal fans who would then have to go out and purchase all new merchandise in order to show their support?"
The results of this survey are most likely to suffer from what type of bias?

choices.text: Non-response bias caused by the fact that some fans will not care deeply enough about the issue to provide an honest answer to the question.
Response bias caused by the way in which the question was worded.
Sampling bias caused by the method in which the sample was selected.
Undercoverage of the opinions of fans who were not included in the sample.
Voluntary response bias caused by the fact that not everyone who is surveyed will be willing to answer the question.

title: Women's Opinions about their Doctors
question_text:
A polling organization randomly sampled $1{,}287\text{ female U.S. residents}$ between the ages of 40 and 60 to ask them if they agreed with the statement, "My doctor does a good job of listening to my concerns."
The population of interest for this study was all American

choices.text: Citizens between the ages of 40 and 60.
Women.
Women between the ages of 40 and 60.
Doctors.
Doctors who treat women between the ages of 40 and 60.

title: Reducing Road Rage through Sampling
question_text:
An engineer has been given the task of adjusting the stop lights at a particular intersection to reduce driver frustration. To begin his study, the engineer needs to randomly select $20\text{ days}$ from the next calendar year to take traffic measurements.
Which of the following correctly describes a method for randomly selecting the $20\text{ days}$?

choices.text: Write all of the days of the year on individual cards of paper of the same size and put them sequentially in a card box. The days corresponding to the first $20\text{ cards}$ drawn will be in the sample.

On each day of the next year, the engineer will flip a coin. If it lands "heads" the engineer will take measurements on the intersection that day. If it lands on "tails" he will not take measurements that day. The process will be finished after $20\text{ days}$ have been selected.

The engineer will assign each day of the year a unique three digit number from $001$ to $365$. He will take $20\text{ sets}$ of three digits from a random digit table, ignoring repeats and numbers over $365$. The days corresponding to the selected numbers will be in the sample.

For the first day of the year, the engineer will draw a single digit from a random number table. If it is even the engineer will take measurements on the intersection that day. If it is odd he will not take measurements that day. The process will be repeated for the subsequent days, until $20\text{ days}$ have been selected.
The engineer will look at the calendar and choose the $20\text{ days}$ from the following year that he feels will best represent traffic conditions at that intersection.

title: Purpose of Blocking
question_text: What is the essential purpose of blocking, and how should the blocks be designated?

choices.text: Blocking reduces variability within the blocks; individuals within each block should be as similar as possible.
Blocking reduces measurement error; individuals should be self-selected in each block.
Blocking makes subjects more comfortable; subjects select their own groups.
Blocking increases the sample size, which in turn reduces variability; individuals within blocks should be as different as possible to create a more heterogeneous experiment.
Blocking reduces bias in experiments; individuals should be randomly divided into their blocks.

title: Golf Coach
question_text:
A golf coach creates a tutorial video to help fix a golfer's swing. The coach states that $99.07\%$ of those who watched and responded to his survey reported an improved swing. He posts this video to all his social media accounts.
Can we say with certainty that $99.07\%$ of golfers who watch the video fix their swing?

choices.text: Yes, because the video says so.
Yes, because he collected data from all the golfers who watched the video.
Yes, because the golfers who respond should answer the same as those who don't.
No, because not all people who watch the video will respond to a survey regarding their swing.
No, because $99.07\%$ is too high.

solution:
The golf coach is using data collection to present his findings to help promote his video. He is claiming that there is a $99.07\%$ success rate after watching the video.

The issue with this claim is that not all golfers who watch the video will answer a survey regarding whether or not the video helped. Many golfers will quickly watch the video and move on with their life. He will mainly only get responses from the people in which the video helped. We have no way of knowing if the video helped the golfers who did not respond.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Would You Like a Toaster with That Loan?
question_text:
A bank wonders if it can increase the number of loan applications it receives each day by promising a toaster to clients who apply. To investigate, it conducts an experiment on all the bank's loan customers for a day.
For each loan customer, the bank loan officer will flip a coin. If it lands "heads" the loan officer will promise the applicant a toaster if they complete the application process. If it lands "tails", the toaster will not be offered. At the end of the day, the proportion of applicants who completed the loan application for the two groups will be compared.
Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: This is not a completely randomized experiment because the subjects were not randomly chosen.
This is not a completely randomized experiment because the subjects were blocked on whether they were promised a toaster.
This is not a completely randomized experiment because the explanatory variable was not randomly chosen.
This is not a completely randomized experiment because the assignment of toasters was not determined by chance.
This is a completely randomized experiment.

title: Statistics Project
question_text:
Robert and Kaliyah are working together on their end of the school year Statistics project. They want to test texting speeds on two different types of cell phones to see which cell phone has the keyboard that allows for the greatest typing speed. The plan is to recruit $60$ fellow students and split them into two groups and compare the results against each other.
Robert's plan is to have the participants select the phone they would like to text on, while Kaliyah's plan is to randomly assign the students to a group.
Whose plan will give the most trustworthy conclusion?

choices.text: Robert, because people will select the one their most comfortable with.
Robert, because the phone they use doesn't really matter.
Kaliyah, because the random chance process will give the most even groups.
Kaliyah, because she knows which phone's keyboard is better.
Neither student's plan will result in trustworthy results.

solution:
When collecting data for an observational study or experiment, it is important to make sure the groups are even, or as even as possible. Allowing subjects to select their own groups will not allow the groups to have a good mix of skills.

In this case, Robert's plan allows subjects to select their own treatment, therefore his plan is untrustworthy. In fact, data collection without a chance process will most always result in untrustworthy results. Therefore, Kaliyah's plan will result in the most trustworthy results as her plan includes a chance process when she randomly assigns the subjects to their group.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Hybrid Flowers: Factors and Treatments
question_text:
A horticulturist has developed a new type of hybrid flower and is trying to determine the ideal conditions for growing the flower. She has several seedlings and wants to test the growth of the seedlings under various conditions.
All of the seedlings will be planted in potting soil and grown in one of her greenhouses where she can control the amount of light and the temperature at which the seedlings are grown.
To determine what type of sunlight will produce the best growth she wants to plant some seedlings in full sun, some in partial sun and some in the shade.
To determine the right level of water for optimal growth she plans to give some seedlings only a little water, some seedlings a moderate amount of water, and some a lot of water.
Finally, to determine the best temperature for growing the flowers, she wants to plant some in a greenhouse which is maintained at $70$ degrees and some in a greenhouse maintained at $85$ degrees.
Which of the following describes the number of factors and the number of treatments in this study?

choices.text: There are $2$ factors and $5$ treatments.
There are $3$ factors and $3$ treatments.
There are $3$ factors and $8$ treatments.
There are $3$ factors and $18$ treatments.
There are $4$ factors, but we cannot determine the number of treatments without knowing how many greenhouses the horticulturalist will use.

title: Advantages of Stratified Random Sampling
question_text:
A school district has hired a new janitorial services company and the superintendent wants to inspect a random sample of classrooms in each of the district's eight total schools in order to see how well the rooms are being cleaned. Each of the eight schools has its own building.
The superintendent has decided to conduct a stratified random sample where the eight different school buildings represent eight different strata. In this situation, what is an advantage to using stratified random sampling?

choices.text: Inspecting classrooms identified from a stratified random sample would be easier and less costly than inspecting classrooms from a simple random sample.
By using a stratified random sample, classrooms in every building will be represented in the superintendent's assessment of the performance of the new janitorial services company.
By using stratified random sampling, the superintendent's assessment of the performance of the new janitorial services company will be less impacted by non-response bias.
Using stratified random sampling is the only way in which the superintendent can ensure that the classrooms that he inspects are part of his population of interest.
There is no advantage to using stratified random sampling. It is always better to use a simple random sample.

title: Sally's Earbud Experiment
question_text:
Sally writes a popular technology blog for a teenage audience. For her next blog she will review two new brands of earbuds. To help write her review, Sally runs an experiment using twenty of her friends.
Which of the following is not a feature of a completely randomized experiment?

choices.text: Sally will randomly assign the two earbud brands to her friends by rolling a six-sided number cube for each friend. If the number cube shows a $2, 4,$ or $6$, that friend will get the first brand of earbud. If the number cube shows a $1, 3,$ or $5$, that friend will get the second brand of earbud.

Sally will divide her friends into two groups - one group of friends who listen to more than five hours of music per week and the other group of friends who listen to less than five hours of music per week. Sally will then randomly assign the two earbud brands to each group of friends.
Sally will remove any brand markings from all of the earbuds.
Sally will make sure that all of her friends use the same brand of mp3 player to play music from the same playlist of songs.
At the end of the experiment Sally will compare the sound quality ratings for the two types of earbuds.

title: Sample Type
question_text: A sample of school opinion at a local middle school selects an SRS of $30$ of the $300$ eighth-grade students and a separate SRS of $10$ of the $100$ teachers. This kind of sample is called a

choices.text: Simple Random Sample
Stratified Random Sample
Cluster Sample
Block Design
Convenience Sample

title: Best Method of Data Collection for a Population Mean
question_text:
Isaac wanted to know the mean number of students in mathematics classes at his small high school.
What is the best way for him to collect his data?

choices.text: Census.
Convenience sample.
Experiment.
Stratified random sample.
Use the number of students in his own mathematics class as a reasonable estimate.

title: Classical Music Improves Memory?
question_text:
For his AP Statistics final project, Ludwig hopes to prove that listening to classical music will improve people's memories more than listening to rock music. The subjects in his study will listen to either classical music or rock music while they study a list of $20\text{ words}$ for $5\text{ minutes}$. The subjects will be called back the following day and asked to recall as many words from the list as possible.
Ludwig's experiment will NOT be well-designed if it involves

choices.text: Allowing subjects to select which type of music they listen to during the study period.
Using a table of random digits to assign the type of music to the subjects.
Flipping a coin to assign the type of music to the subjects.
Giving all subjects the same list of 20 words to memorize and instructing them not to discuss the list with anyone else in the experiment.
Using many subjects so that there is replication.

title: Experimental Design Principles
question_text:
In a well-designed experiment, which of the following principles must ALWAYS be adhered to?
I. A placebo should be used as a method of control.
II. Randomization should be used to determine which experimental units get which treatment.
III. The experiment must be replicated by being conducted multiple times under different conditions to ensure the results are valid.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
I, II, and III.

title: Simulation Digits
question_text:
The Athletic Director at a large high school claims $60$% of student-athletes at the school will receive a college scholarship. To simulate a student-athlete receiving a scholarship, which of the following assignment of random digits could be used?
Digits $0-4$ represent a student-athlete receiving a scholarship and digits $5-9$ represent a student-athlete not receiving a scholarship.
Digits $00-59$ represent a student-athlete receiving a scholarship and digits $60-99$ represent a student-athlete not receiving a scholarship.
Digits $00-60$ represent a student-athlete receiving a scholarship and digits $61-99$ represent a student-athlete not receiving a scholarship.
Digits $0-6$ represent a student-athlete receiving a scholarship and digits $7-9$ represent a student-athlete not receiving a scholarship.

choices.text: I only
II only
IV only
II and IV
III and IV

title: Advantage of Stratified Random Sample
question_text:
A local school has $2{,}000$ students enrolled and $100$ faculty members. The Vice-Principal of the school will select a sample of $210$ students and faculty members in order to gauge the opinions of both students and faculty on the quality of the food offered in the school cafeteria.
Why is it advantageous to take a stratified random sample, using students and faculty as strata, rather than a simple random sample?

choices.text: A stratified sample ensures the most random sample is taken.
A stratified sample ensures both students and faculty members are chosen to be part of the sample.
A stratified sample is the simplest and easiest way for the Vice Principal to gather opinions.
A stratified sample will ensure the quality of the food in the school cafeteria will improve.
There is no advantage in taking a stratified sample rather than a simple random sample.

title: Bugs in the Trees in the Great Smoky Mountains: A Study | 1 of 2
question_text:
The hemlock woolly adelgid is a small invasive insect that came to North America via Japan and is responsible for killing most of the hemlock trees in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. To try to control the destruction of hemlock trees caused by the hemlock woolly adelgid, biologists have released lady beetles from Japan (which are known to be natural predators of the hemlock woolly adelgid) onto several of the remaining healthy hemlock trees in the park.
Even if the lady beetles effectively control the damage done by the hemlock woolly adelgid, it may appear that the lady beetles have no effect on the health and survival rate of hemlock trees in the park.
Which of the following may describe why?

choices.text: Tree damage caused by hikers and other visitors to the park may contribute to the death of hemlock trees in the park.
Forest fires and chemicals that are released into the air by the fires may negatively impact the health and survival rate of hemlock trees in the park.
Harsh weather conditions may cause a decrease in the population of lady beetles and may also negatively affect the health of hemlock trees in the park.

If predators of the lady beetles being released into the park are also present in the park, the survival rate of the lady beetles may not be sufficient to impact the health and survival rate of the hemlock trees in the park.
All of the above describe possible sources of confounding.

title: College Dean
question_text:
A college dean is interested in whether students feel their campus has an appropriate academic setting. The dean sends out the survey to all students at the campus.
The college dean is attempting to conduct a(n)

choices.text: Census.
Stratified sample.
Controlled experiment.
Observational study.
Convenience sample.

title: Drawing Conclusions: Smokers
question_text:
A researcher decided to analyze the weights of smokers and non-smokers.
Suppose a random sample of $100\text{ smokers}$ averages $196.4\text{ lbs}$ with a standard deviation of $6.5\text{ lbs}$, and a random sample of $100\text{ non-smokers}$ averages $174.5\text{ lbs}$ with a standard deviation of $4.6\text{ lbs}$.
What conclusions could be drawn when comparing smokers to non-smokers?

choices.text: Smokers in this random sample tended to weigh more, but it is unclear if smoking is the reason people weigh more.
Smoking probably causes weight gain.
Who weighs more is inconclusive.
Who weighs more is inconclusive evidence since the sample sizes were too small.
It is clear that smoking makes people weigh more.

title: Do You Stretch?
question_text: In a recent study, $50$ student-athletes from Knoxville State University were randomly selected to complete a survey. One of the goals of the study was to estimate the percent of athletes who stretch prior to exercising. $36$ of the $50$ athletes said they stretch prior to exercising. Which of the following gives the best explanation for why these results cannot be used as an estimate of all student-athletes in the United States who stretch prior to exercising?

choices.text: Only student-athletes from Knoxville State University were able to participate in the study; thus the results can only be generalized to student-athletes at Knoxville State University.
Only student-athletes from Knoxville State University were able to take part in the study; thus the results can only be generalized to student-athletes around the Knoxville State University campus.
The results can only be generalized to students attending Knoxville State University, as only student-athletes from Knoxville State University were surveyed.
The sample of $50$ student-athletes is not a large enough sample.
Different Universities may have different requirements for their student-athletes and the percent that stretch prior to exercising may be different at other universities.

title: Loyalty Program Perks - Best Method of Collecting Data
question_text:
A large cruise line operates many different sailings from many different home ports to many different destinations around the world.
Executives at the cruise line are considering making changes to their customer loyalty program.
Of course, they want to keep customers who are already part of the loyalty program happy, so they are interested in in learning more about what benefits these individuals find most advantageous. To do so, they are planning a survey that asks customers to rank the importance of various perks of the loyalty program.
Which of the following describes the best way to collect the data?

choices.text: Randomly select a few of the cruise line's ships that will be sailing during a certain month. Then, provide surveys to each individual who is currently enrolled in the loyalty program and sailing on one of the selected ships.

For each of the cruise line's ships, randomly select three sailings that are scheduled during the upcoming year. Then randomly select individuals who are on each of these sailings and provide each of these individuals with the survey.
Provide the survey to every individual sailing on one of the cruise line's ships during a randomly determined period of one month.

Send the survey by email to each individual currently enrolled in the customer loyalty program. If an individual does not respond, follow up the email with a paper survey addressed to the individual's home.
Place surveys in various travel-related magazines and ask that the surveys be returned to a given address.

title: Type of Design: Neighborhood Watch
question_text:
Neighborhood watch is a program designed where a group of civilians are devoted to prevent crime and vandalism in a neighborhood. A research group, known as the Watchmen want to know if the neighborhood watch is actually effective.
The Watchmen locate $20$ pairs of neighborhoods, where each pair is similar in size, economic status, number of streetlights, number of dogs, number of nosy neighbors, etc. One neighborhood in each pair is randomly assigned to have the neighborhood watch program and the other does not.
This is an example of

choices.text: An observational study.
A completely randomized experiment.
A matched pairs experiment.
A randomized block design, but not matched pairs.
A stratified random sample.

title: Burn Treatments
question_text:
A medical doctor is trying to determine which medical cream helps her patients recover from burns the best. She recruits the next $60$ people, and separates them into three groups $1$, $2$, and $3$. Then she assigns group $1$ cream $A$, group $2$ cream $B$, and group $3$ cream $C$. She then measures the results at the end of the study.
What are the treatments in this experiment?

choices.text: All patients with burns.
The $60$ patients in the experiment.
The three groups of patients.
The three different creams.
The results at the end of the experiment.

solution:
In an experiment, different conditions are assigned to the experimental units. The experimental units are those that have been recruited or offered to be a part of the study. The different conditions that are assigned to the experimental units are called treatments.

In this experiment, the doctor is trying to determine the best cream to help her patients recover. The experimental units in this study would be the $60$ patients. The treatments that were imposed on the experimental units would be the three different creams.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Correlation and Causation: Study Session
question_text:
Suppose a teacher decided to offer an after-school study session the day before a $100\text{ point}$ test.
The $34\text{ students}$ who came to this study session averaged scores $8\text{ points}$ higher on the test than the $72\text{ students}$ who did not come to the study session.
Based on this information, what may one conclude?

choices.text: Enough evidence exists to say the study session was helpful.
If the teacher really wanted to see if the study session is helpful, she should have randomly assigned students to attend the session.
Since the samples sizes were quite different, no reasonable comparisons can be made in this situation.
Since it was not a double-blind experiment, no reasonable comparisons can be made in this situation.
An increase of $8\text{ points}$ is not significant enough to determine whether the study session helped.

title: Social Media Poll
question_text:
An author is trying to gather responses on her latest novel. She is very active on a social media site where people must follow her to see her posts. On the poll, she gives two choices to rate the book,
$$1. \text{ Love the Book!}$$
$$2. \text{ Not My Favorite}$$
The author gets $1425$ people to respond and $92\%$ of people select "Love the Book!" Who can the author apply the results of the study?

choices.text: All novel readers
All her fans
$1425$ people who responded
Her followers on the social media site
All people

solution:
The author used a survey to collect data. The poll collects data regarding her new novel on a social media site that requires her fans to follow her.

Since people on the social media site have to follow her, only those who choose to follow her see her social media posts. Therefore, we cannot apply the results to all people or all fans. We can only apply the results to those who follow her on the social media site and directly responded to the survey. We cannot say for certain that people who don't follow her on social media sites feel the same way, nor can we say that the results are representative of all her social media followers since only those who care enough to respond take the time to do so.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Long-Lasting Lightbulbs
question_text:
A researcher would like to determine which brand of light bulbs burns the longest.
A simple random sample of $30\text{ Brand A bulbs}$ and $30\text{ Brand B bulbs}$ are tested by screwing the bulbs into two different sockets at the same time and measuring the average number of hours before the bulbs burn out.
What is wrong with this experimental design?

choices.text: The sample size for each bulb is too small since the population of bulbs is theoretically infinite.
A simple random sample of $30\text{ bulbs}$ from each brand is adequate for studying light bulbs so there is nothing wrong with this design.
The type of socket used to test the bulbs is a confounding variable.
This should be a blind study where the researcher does not know which brand of bulb is being tested.
A simple random sample of bulbs is not necessary because there is no reason to believe that a bulb from one brand is different from any other bulb within the same brand.

title: Gathering Student Opinions on the School Schedule
question_text:
The principal of a large high school would like to gather the opinions of the student body regarding a possible change to how the school schedule would run. He gathers a sample of $100$ students by selecting a simple random sample of $25$ students from each grade level (freshman, sophomore, junior and senior).
What type of sampling method did the principal use and why might he have decided to use this method?

choices.text: The principal used a systematic random sample because it was the quickest and easiest way to obtain opinions from students at each grade level.
The principal selected a convenience sample because he wanted to make sure that the opinions he gathered truly represented the opinions of all students at his school.
The principal used block design to ensure that he was able to sample an equal number of students from each grade level.
The principal used a cluster sample because he wanted to get opinions from students from each grade level.
The principal selected a stratified random sample because he wanted to make sure that opinions from students at each grade level were represented.

title: Let's Do an Experiment
question_text: In which of the following situations would it be most appropriate to conduct an experiment rather than an observational study?

choices.text: The principal at a local high school wants to know if teachers in the school tend to call on boys more often than girls when asking questions in class.
A medical researcher wants to investigate how the average number of cigarettes someone smokes per week is related to the average medical costs that the individual incurs in one year.
A researcher wants to know if elementary school students who are physically bullied are more likely to become bullies in middle school.
A developmental psychologist is interested in knowing how different room temperatures affect a preschooler's ability to complete a series of tasks involving fine motor skills.

A nutritionist has noticed that healthier foods often cost more than less healthy alternatives. She wants to investigate if lower levels of family income are related to higher levels of childhood obesity.

title: Sampling Bouncy Balls
question_text:
A quality control inspector in a bouncy ball plant must select a simple random sample of bouncy balls at the end of each day to make sure they are producing the required amount of bounciness.
Which of the following correctly describes a valid simple random sampling procedure?

choices.text: Place all of the bouncy balls for the day in a large container and mix them up. Draw $10\text{ bouncy balls}$ out of the container.

Place all of the solid color bouncy balls in one container and all of the swirly bouncy balls in another container. Mix the bouncy balls in each container and draw $10\text{ bouncy balls}$ out of each.

As the bouncy balls come off the production lines, randomly choose one of the first $50\text{ bouncy balls}$. Then choose every $50^\text{th}\text{ bouncy ball}$ after that one until the end of the day.
Place all of the bouncy balls from production line A into a large container. Do the same for production lines B and C. Mix up the bouncy balls in each container and draw 10 bouncy balls out of each.
All of the above describe a valid simple random sampling procedure.

title: Sampling to Diagnose Anemia
question_text:
According to the Mayo Clinic, a patient is considered to be anemic if the blood hematocrit value (the proportion of the blood made up of red blood cells) is lower than $35\%$.
A doctor takes a sample of her patient's blood to check for anemia and measures the hematocrit value to be $38\%$. Which of the following statements is true concerning this study?
I. 38% is the population parameter.
II. The blood drawn by the doctor is the sample for this study.
III. The doctor obtains a sample of blood from the patient in order to draw a conclusion about the overall population of the patient's blood supply.

choices.text: II only.
I and II only.
I and III only.
II and III only.
I, II, and III.

title: Sleepy After Lunch
question_text:
Many office workers experience sleepiness after lunch that slows down their productivity. A psychologist runs a completely randomized experiment in an attempt to identify the causes of this sleepiness. $144\text{ office workers}$ are randomly assigned to one of the following groups:
Group A is assigned to a low-calorie lunch and a brightly-lit office.
Group B is assigned to a low-calorie lunch and a softly-lit office.
Group C is assigned to a high-calorie lunch and a brightly-lit office.
Group D is assigned to a high-calorie lunch and a softly-lit office.
An hour after lunch, all the workers are asked to rate their sleepiness on a scale from $1$ to $10$.
Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: There are four explanatory variables.
The response variable is the level of sleepiness reported by the workers after lunch.
The experimental units are the $144\text{ office workers}$.
The type of lunch and the type of office lighting are the explanatory variables.
There are two levels of lunch type and two levels of office lighting.

title: So You Think You Can Juggle?
question_text:
The winner on the show 'So You Think You Can Juggle' is selected based on the number of votes received via text message. At the end of each episode, a text number is displayed on the screen for each of the jugglers. The juggler with the most text votes is the winner of that round of competition.
This process of selecting each episode's winner suffers from

choices.text: Non-response bias because some people will not text in their vote.
Response bias because only those who feel strongly about the jugglers are likely to text their vote.
Response bias because seeing the jugglers on the screen with their text number will influence their vote.
Voluntary response bias because only those who feel strongly about the jugglers are likely to text their vote.
Voluntary response bias because seeing the jugglers on the screen with their text number will influence their vote.

title: Nutritional Value of Snacks
question_text:
A school nutritionist wants to determine if parents of elementary school children are concerned with the nutritional value of their children’s snacks. She decides to conduct an observational study using simple random sampling.
Which of the following scenarios best describes this research design?

choices.text: Parents’ choices are observed while shopping for snacks in a supermarket. The parents are then administered a survey to determine attitudes toward nutritional snacks and to gather relevant demographic data.

A table of random numbers is used to generate $500$ phone numbers from a list of parents whose children are in elementary school. These parents are called to determine their concerns about the nutritional value of their children’s snacks.

A table of random numbers is used to generate $500$ phone numbers from a list of parents whose children are in elementary school. These parents are interviewed in person to determine their concerns about the nutritional value of their children’s snacks.

Five hundred parents with children who attend a local elementary school are asked to partake in a study involving nutritional snacks for their children. After viewing an educational video on snacking, the parents are asked to complete a survey to determine their attitudes toward nutritional snacks.

From a list of all parents of elementary school children in a certain town, 500 parents are selected using a table of random numbers. These parents are then given a choice of two coupon sets: one set is for healthy snacks, and the other set is for unhealthy snacks. The parents can pick only one set of coupons. Their choices are recorded and tabulated.

title: Defeating Mold: An Experiment
question_text:
Mold on walls and windowsills is not only unsightly, it can also pose a health risk to those who live in the home. The best way to prevent mold is to control moisture. However, this can be difficult in places where the climate is hot and humid.
A chemical engineer has developed a solution that he believes will prevent mold from growing on treated surfaces. To test the solution, he has built $8$ small rooms. Each room has one window. Two of the $8$ rooms will be maintained at a relative humidity level of $60\%$, two rooms will be maintained at a relative humidity level of $70\%$, two rooms at $80\%$, and two rooms at $90\%$.
All $8$ rooms will be maintained at a temperature of $80$ degrees. At each relative humidity level, the surfaces in one of the two rooms will be treated with the new solution and the surfaces in the other room will remain untreated.
Which of the two rooms is treated with the new solution will be determined at random. Mold spores will then be introduced into all $8$ rooms and the growth of mold in the treated and untreated rooms will be compared.
Which of the following describes the biggest flaw in the design of this experiment?

choices.text: The experiment suffers from lack of control.
The experiment suffers from lack of randomization.
The experiment suffers from lack of replication.
The experiment suffers from lack of realism.
The experiment suffers from undercoverage.

title: Advantages of a Census
question_text: Which of the following represents an advantage of taking a census?

choices.text: A census can generally be conducted more quickly and easily than taking a sample.
A census can be used to find the value of the statistic related to a smaller group within the population.
Taking a census may allow one to accurately find the value of the population parameter.
When taking a census, you are ensured that the statistic you find will be totally unbiased.
When taking a census, you never have to worry about undercoverage or non-response bias.

title: Experimental Design: Burn Those Calories
question_text:
Is running on a treadmill for one hour or jumping rope for twenty minutes better at burning calories?
Which option below gives the most effective method at determining which treatment is better at burning calories?

choices.text: Let students volunteer which group they want to go in and compare the results.
Randomly separate the group and have half of them jump rope for twenty minutes while the other half runs on the treadmill for an hour.
Randomly divide the subjects into three groups. The first group will jump rope, the second group will run on the treadmill for twenty minutes, and the third group will do neither of the activities.
Randomly select which activity the entire group does on the first day followed by the different activity on the second day.

Randomly separate the group and have half on them jump rope for twenty minutes the first day and then run for an hour the next day. The other group will run for an hour the first day and jump rope for twenty minutes the next.

title: Soft Drink Market
question_text:
A researcher for a beverage company would like to test market a new carbonated soft drink.
She believes that age might affect the preference for this drink. The researcher divides the population into four age categories and then takes a random sample from each of the age groups.
This is an example of

choices.text: Systematic sampling.
Stratified sampling.
Simple random sampling.
Cluster sampling.
Multi-stage sampling.

title: Website Redesign
question_text:
A popular website wants to know if a site-wide redesign would be more popular among its viewers.
They showed the last $25{,}000$ visitors who were on the site both the new and old designs, and $51.2\%$ of respondents determined the new design is preferred. The remaining preferred the old design.
Even if the result is statistically significant, why might the company decide not to spend the extra money to incorporate the redesign?

choices.text: The subjects were not randomly chosen, so the results will be biased.
An additional blank-cover design should have been used as a control.
More browsers of this site should be surveyed since the population is so large.
The difference is statistically significant since the sample is so large, but not practically significant or worth the company spending money to change it since the percentage difference is so small.
Both people who go to this site and people who do not go to this site should be surveyed.

title: Completely Randomized Design: Which One?
question_text: Which of the following describes an experiment using completely randomized design?

choices.text:
A group of $20$ students was given a computer-based survey consisting of $4$ questions.
The order in which the questions appeared on the survey was completely randomized for each student and students were required to type their responses.

A group of $20$ students was given a one-minute typing test. The test consisted of typing as many words as possible from a long list of words.
The order of the words was determined at random for each student. The order in which the students were tested was also determined at random.

Are students able to type faster while listening to music? To investigate, $20$ students were asked to complete a one-minute typing test on the computer on two separate occasions.
On one occasion music was playing in the background. On the other occasion the room was silent. Which condition was tested first was determined at random.

Are students able to type faster while using a desktop keyboard or a laptop keyboard? To investigate, $20$ students were divided at random into two groups of $10$ students each.
Students in the first group were given a one-minute typing test on a desktop keyboard and students in the second group were given a one-minute typing test on a laptop keyboard.

Are students able to type faster in a cold room than in a warm room? From a group of $20$ students $5$ boys and $5$ girls were randomly selected and placed in a cold room where they were given a one-minute typing test.
The remaining $5$ boys and $5$ girls were placed in a warm room and given the same one-minute typing test.

title: Collecting Data About A Major Rivalry
question_text:
There is a major rivalry between the two Major League Baseball teams in the city of Chicago, Illinois! Fans of the southsiders were overjoyed when their White Mittens won the 2005 World Championship, while fans of the "lovable losers" have been waiting a very long time for their Northside Chicago Calves to win a World Series. But which team really has more fans in the city of Chicago? Researchers decided to do a study. To gather data, they randomly called phone numbers with $312$, $773$ or $872$ area codes (the current three Chicago area codes), and asked which of the two teams the person answering the phone preferred.
Which of the following best describes the manner in which data was collected?

choices.text: Experiment.
Simulation.
Survey.
Randomization.
Convenience sample.

title: Congressional Approval Rating
question_text:
A pollster is interested in the approval rating of a congressman in his district.
Using an address book to select households randomly within the representative’s constituency, the pollster went from door to door and asked, “Do you approve of your United States representative?”
What is a potential bias the pollster may encounter?

choices.text: The wording of the question.
The constituents may not be informed on the representative.
The sample was stratified on homeownership when it should not be.
The pollster is leaving out any constituents who are homeless or have unlisted addresses.
Some of these constituents may not be eligible to vote.

title: Household Income
question_text:
A sociologist was interested in his hometown’s average household income.
The sociologist selected $45$ houses on his block to visit during the day and ask each household’s income.
Of these, $35$ houses had, at least, one person home. These $35$ households had an average income of $\$42,035$ and standard deviation of $\$14,352$.
Why might it be dangerous to generalize the sociologist’s results to the rest of the town?
I. There was undercoverage.
II. The sample was not random enough.
III. The sample was too small.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
I and II only.
II and III only.
I, II, and III.

title: Volunteering Survey
question_text:
A local church wants to know how often people of the community volunteer. Pastors of the church visited $100$ randomly selected houses during the day and asked respondents approximately how many hours per month they perform volunteer work.
Which of the following bias(es) could be present in this study?
I. Undercoverage
II. Nonresponse
III. Response bias

choices.text: I only.
II only.
I and II only.
II and III only.
I, II, and III.

title: Problems with Voluntary Response
question_text: What could be a potential problem with a voluntary response sample?

choices.text: Subjects who choose to respond may respond incorrectly.
Subjects who choose to respond may systematically have different opinions than the rest of the population.
Voluntary response samples typically have lower sample sizes.
Voluntary response samples typically have higher non-response rates.
Subjects who choose to respond are more likely to lie about their true feelings.

title: Data Gathering
question_text:
Which of the following statements are true in regards to gathering data?
I. A census attempts to contact every individual from the sample.
II. An observational study is different from an experiment in that a treatment is imposed in an observational study.
III. A matched pairs experiment can reduce variability.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
II and III only.
I and III only.

title: Convenience Sample
question_text: A convenience sample

choices.text: Is a type of simple random sample.
Usually does a poor job of representing the characteristics of the population.
Can be double blind.
Deals with people choosing to respond to the question themselves.
Often divides up different parts of the population by various strata.

title: Dessert Preference with Table
question_text:
A study was conducted to determine if there is a difference in dessert preference among adults based on gender. Researchers offered a random assortment of desserts to a random sample of adults and recorded each adult's dessert choice. The results can be found in the table below.
Apple Pie Chocolate Cake Sugar Cookie Brownie
Female $3$ $8$ $4$ $7$
Male $8$ $2$ $5$ $10$
Which of the following is a true conclusion based on the above information?
tables:
Apple PieChocolate CakeSugar CookieBrownie
Female$3$$8$$4$$7$
Male$8$$2$$5$$10$

choices.text: Females chose Brownies more often than any of the other desserts.
The most common dessert choice by the males was Apple Pie.
The percent of women who chose Sugar Cookie is higher than the percent of men who chose Sugar Cookie.
Apple Pie was the dessert chosen the least, regardless of gender.
More than half of the women chose Chocolate Cake or Sugar Cookie.

title: SRS or Not?
question_text:
At a large high school, there are $20$ senior homerooms each with between $20$ and $25$ students. A random sample of $40$ seniors is to be selected as follows.
Each homeroom teacher will be asked to place the names of the students in their homeroom into a box and then randomly select two names. The two students selected from each of the $20$ homerooms will then be combined to form the sample of size $40$.
Will this method result in a simple random sample of seniors at this high school?

choices.text: No, because the homerooms are from the same grade.
No, because not each group of $40$ students has the same chance of being selected.
Yes, because each student in each homeroom has an equal chance of being selected.
Yes, because this is a very simple method of random selection.
Yes, because the names are randomly selected in each homeroom.

title: College Exam
question_text:
A teaching assistant is in charge of grading the exams given in their college class. The professor wants a general idea of how the students are doing in his course so he asks the assistant to give him a small sample of the scores while grading. The assistant selects the first $10$ exams from the pile (organized by who turned in the exam first) and grades them and sends the average to the professor.
Will the sample the assistant provided give the professor the best idea of how his students are doing?

choices.text: Yes, because it's a sample of $10$ scores.
Yes, because the sample is from the students in his class.
Yes, because the assistant found the average score.
No, because $10$ is not enough students.
No, because students who turned in the test first might have different scores than those who turned in the exam later.

solution:
The professor has asked the teaching assistant to collect data to create a sample of scores to show how the students are learning. The teaching assistant selects a sample of $10$ students, but selects the first $10$ tests that are turned in.

The issue lies that the test are not selected using a chance process. In fact, we know that data collected by not using a chance process is untrustworthy. Therefore, the data the professor received from the assistant is not to be trusted as it was not selected using a chance process.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Nonresponse Via Email
question_text: A large university emailed a questionnaire to a randomly selected sample of $120$ students in this year's freshman class. The questionnaire included topics on student life, academics, and athletics. Thirty of the students emailed did not respond to the questionnaire. What is the best plan of action for the university?

choices.text: Send another email to those $30$ students who did not respond encouraging them to complete the questionnaire.
Start over with a new sample of $120$ students from this year's freshman class.
The university should abandon work on the survey as most of the students in the freshman class are uninterested in completing the questionnaire.
Use the $90$ questionnaires that were submitted as the final sample.
Randomly choose $30$ more students from this year's freshman class and email them the questionnaire.

title: Gathering Data With Pizza Crackers
question_text:
Mamma Mia wonders whether her toddler Tony will eat more pizza flavored crackers when watching television or when eating his snack at the table without any distractions. To test her suspicions, she feeds him pizza flavored crackers at snack time on several different occasions.
Each time she gives him the crackers, she randomly determines whether or not she will allow him to watch television as he eats. Mamma always counts how many crackers Tony consumes at snack time, so that she can compare the overall average number of crackers consumed with and without watching television.
Which of the following best describes Mamma's method of gathering data?

choices.text: Experiment.
Observational study.
Simulation.
Survey.
Randomization.

title: Vegetarians and the Common Cold: Flaws in the Study
question_text:
Can following a vegetarian diet reduce the occurrence of the common cold? An observational study is being planned to compare the average number of colds self-proclaimed vegetarians suffer from each year with the average number of colds non-vegetarians suffer from each year.
Which of the following represents the biggest problem with this type of study?

choices.text: Blinding is not possible since the individuals in the study will know whether or not they are vegetarian.
It will be impossible to see if there is a relationship between following a vegetarian diet and the occurrence of the common cold.
Confounding could occur. Perhaps vegetarians get fewer colds because they try to follow a healthier overall lifestyle than non-vegetarians.
Undercoverage could occur since individuals who are following other specific types of diets (like gluten free or low fat diets) are not specifically included in the study.
The placebo effect may cause individuals to feel like they do not have a cold when really they do.

title: Hannah's House of Hobbies Revisited
question_text: The manager of Hannah's House of Hobbies wants to improve his method for gathering customer opinions. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: If a salesperson stands at the door to ask customers' opinions in a quick three-question interview, the proportion of satisfied customers will be overestimated due to response bias.

If the cashiers randomly select survey participants from the checkout lines, the proportion of satisfied customers will be overestimated because customers who leave the store without making a purchase will not be included in the sample.

The manager can avoid as much bias as possible if he rolls a number cube for each customer who walks in the store. If the number cube shows a $3$, the customer will be given a written survey to be turned in at the end of their shopping.
The manager can avoid as much bias as possible if he gives a written survey to customers who spend more than $\$100$ in the store.
The manager's survey will suffer from nonresponse bias if too many customers refuse to participate in the survey.

title: Experimental Design
question_text:
A fitness researcher is interested in learning which form of exercise helps people lose weight the best. She decides to run an experiment with three groups. One group will do no exercise, the second group with be on a strictly cardio regimen, while the third group will be on a strictly weight-lifting regimen. She decides to take $30$ volunteers for the study, and will use a random number generator to assign $10$ volunteers to each group. She decides to let the volunteers choose their own diet throughout the experiment. At the end, she will measure the weight loss from each group and compare.
Which principle of experimental design is not followed in this experiment?

choices.text: Comparison
Random Assignment
Control
Replication
All principles are followed

solution:
Any well-designed experiment will meet all four-principles of experimental design: 1. Comparison, 2. Random Assignment, 3. Control, and 4. Replication. In order to meet comparison, the experiment must have two or more treatments. Additionally, volunteers must be randomly assigned to each treatment, and we must have more than one experimental unit per treatment (replication).

To meet control, one must take into account variables that could affect the response that aren't our experimental treatments. A control group is one positive step for the experiment, but a well-designed experiment takes into account ALL variables that could be confounding. By not controlling the volunteers diets, we cannot be sure if the weight loss is due to the exercise regimens or the volunteers' diets. Therefore, control was not adequately met in this experiment.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Studying the Relationship Between Second Hand Smoke and Asthma
question_text:
