A study was done to determine whether having a parent who smokes in the house has any effect on whether or not children develop asthma later in life.
Over a period of several years, the study followed the health records of $140$ children whose parent(s) smoked in the house and $140$ children whose parent(s) were non-smokers and compared the rates of asthma in these individuals at the age of $25$.
Which of the following BEST describes how the study was conducted?

choices.text: This was an experiment with both a treatment group and a control group.
This was a comparative experiment using block design.
This was an experiment conducted without the use of blinding.
This was a long-term observational study.
This was a survey.

title: College Exercise Routines
question_text:
Researchers want to know how often full-time college undergraduates exercise per week.
What method would be most appropriate to answer their question?

choices.text: Randomly select five universities and ask all college students in these universities how often they exercise.
Randomly select three universities (one large, one medium, and one small) and ask all college students in these universities how often they exercise.

Obtain a list of all undergraduate college students, number them, and use a random number generator to randomly select $5{,}000$ college students and ask these $5{,}000$ students how often they exercise.
Select $10$ students by going to every university bookstore and ask them how often they exercise.
Have surveys at all schools’ health club for the students to fill out when they leave.

title: Headache Relief
question_text:
A drug manufacturer believes it has developed a faster-acting pain-relief medication. To test the new drug, researchers identify $45\text{ subjects}$ who suffer from frequent headaches. The subjects are randomly assigned to take one of three treatments when they experience their next headache: the new medication, a currently available medication, or a sugar pill. All pills are manufactured to look identical to each other. The subjects will record the amount of time it takes to experience pain relief.
Which of the following statements is true?
I. Some subjects might perceive quicker pain relief simply because they've taken a pill (either active medication or sugar pill). Researchers control for this placebo effect by giving all subjects a pill.
II. The sugar pills are a part of the blinding in this experiment.
III. The researchers use the sugar pills in order to determine the effects of sugar on pain relief.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
I and III only.

title: Engineering Study
question_text: A researcher decides she is going to do an observational study regarding civil engineering. She selects a random sample of $1500$ civil engineers that have a job in the United States to be a part of the study. Which of the following would be the population in which it would be the most reasonable to generalize the results of the study?

choices.text: All employed engineers
All employed engineers in the United States
All employed civil engineers
All employed civil engineers in the United States
You cannot generalize the results of an observational study.

solution:
In an observational study, investigators examine data for a sample of individuals in order to investigate a topic of interest for a population. It is important to note that you cannot prove cause and effect from an observational study because treatments are not imposed.

However, you can make generalizations and determinations from an observational study. It is only appropriate to make generalizations about a population based on samples that are randomly selected or otherwise representative of the population. Therefore, wherever the sample has been selected from is what we can generalize from. So, in this study, we can only generalize about the civil engineers from the United States.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Increasing the Fish Population
question_text:
A state Wildlife and Fisheries agent is trying to stimulate the growth of the population of a certain type of fish. She will conduct an experiment that involves randomly assigning $3\text{ different treatments}$ to $36\text{ fish}$ to determine which treatment will cause the largest amount of weight gain in the fish. The agent wants to make sure that the $3\text{ treatment groups}$ each have exactly $12\text{ fish}$.
Which of the following methods should be used to assign the treatments?

choices.text: Catch $36\text{ fish}$. For each fish roll a six-sided number cube. If the cube shows a $1$ or $2$, the fish will receive treatment 'A'. If the cube shows a $3$ or $4$, the fish will receive treatment 'B'. If the cube shows a $5$ or $6$, the fish will receive treatment 'C'.

As each fish is caught, draw a number from a random digit table. If the number is $1$, $2$, or $3$, the fish will receive treatment 'A'. If the number is $4$, $5$, or $6$, the fish will receive treatment 'B'. If the number is $7$, $8$, or $9$, the fish will receive treatment 'C'. If the number is $0$, a new number will be drawn. If a treatment group already has $12\text{ fish}$ then another number will be chosen to assign the fish to one of the other groups.
The first $12\text{ fish}$ caught will be assigned to treatment 'A', the second $12\text{ fish}$ to treatment 'B' and the last $12\text{ fish}$ to treatment 'C'.

Catch $36\text{ fish}$ and assign each fish a unique number between $1$ and $36$. Write the numbers from $1$ to $36$ on separate slips of paper. Place the slips in a fish bowl and mix them up. Draw $12\text{ slips}$ of paper. The fish corresponding to those numbers will receive treatment 'A'. Draw $12\text{ more slips}$ of paper. The fish corresponding to those numbers will receive Treatment 'B'. The remaining fish will receive treatment 'C'.
All of these methods will randomly assign the treatments to $3\text{ groups}$ of $12\text{ fish}$.

title: Getting to Work: Comparing Boston and Chicago
question_text:
A large company has regional offices in Boston and Chicago. Recently, the personnel department at each location surveyed employees to determine the modes of transportation that employees use to get to work. The results of the survey are shown in the side-by-side bar graph below.
Which of the following statements is NOT indicated by the graph?

choices.text: The percentage of employees who get to work by car is greater in Chicago than in Boston.
The percentage of employees who take public transportation to work is lower in Chicago than in Boston.
In both cities a greater percentage of employees walk to work than bike to work.
In Chicago, the percentage of employees who get to work by public transportation is about half that of those who get to work by car.
The number of people who use other modes of transportation to get to work is just a little higher in Boston than in Chicago.

title: Prostate Cancer in Male Volunteers
question_text:
Suppose a new cancer drug is being tested on $200\text{ male volunteers}$ who have prostate cancer. The researchers decide to use a block design and wish to test the difference between the new drug and a more traditional treatment.
What would be an effective variable to block on?

choices.text: Type of cancer.
Alphabetical by patients’ last names.
Advancement phase of the cancer.
Gender.
Geographical location of the patients.

title: Stratified
question_text:
Suppose a worker in the school cafeteria wants to know if the students feel the cafeteria is offering enough healthy items on the daily menu.
What could be a useful variable to stratify for the purposes of this study?

choices.text: Type of food.
Their 6 digit student ID number
Gender of respondents.
Their homeroom teacher.
The number of siblings the students have.

title: Features of a Well-Designed Survey
question_text:
Which of the following statements is true?
I. A well-designed survey asks questions using the same wording for all of its subjects.
II. A well-designed survey uses volunteers to make sure that the survey is not an inconvenience for respondents.
III. A well-designed survey does not need to use a sample that is representative of the intended population as long as the sample size is large enough.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and III only.
II and III only.

title: Cell Phone: Type of Sampling
question_text:
The buyer for a cell phone store wants to estimate the proportion of defective cell phones in a shipment of $10,000$ received cell phones. The shipment consists of $500$ boxes, each of which contain $20$ cell phones.
The buyer numbers the boxes $1$ through $500$, and using a random number generator, he selects ten numbers in that range (ignoring repeats). He then opens the boxes with the matching numbers and determines the proportion of cell phones that were defective.
What type of sample is this?

choices.text: Cluster random sample.
Convenience sample.
Simple random sample.
Stratified random sample.
Systematic random sample.

title: Pain Relief Study
question_text:
A doctor wishes to investigate pain relief medications aspirin and acetaminophen. The doctor has $600\text{ volunteers}$ for this study.
The doctor randomly selects $200$ of these volunteer subjects receive aspirin, $200$ to receive acetaminophen and the remaining $200$ to receive a placebo pill.
Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: The sample size should be larger for an experiment such as this one.
A placebo, in this case, is not necessary.
A matched pairs design should have been used in this case instead of the process described.
The doctor should have let the subjects choose which group they want to be in so that the subjects feel more comfortable.
This experiment should be conducted in a double-blind manner.

title: Printer Comparison
question_text:
A small boutique owner ships her own products when ordered online. Recently, she bought two printers, Printer A and Printer B, to help with the process. She then uses Printer A for $30$ labels and then Printer B for $30$ labels, then compares the results.
What question is the shop owner most likely trying to answer?

choices.text: Which printer sells more products?
Which printer expediates the shipping process?
What printer is the cheapest?
Which printer sounds the best?
Does the boutique need two printers?

solution:
The shop owner is using data collection to determine a potential solution in her shipping process. She is comparing the two different printers, A and B, while printing $30$ labels from each printer.

Although some of the other answers might seem correct, the owner is most likely looking to see which printer expediates the shipping process. By printing the same amount of labels from each printer, she is more than likely looking at which printer will make shipping her products easiest.

Choice 'B' is correct.

title: Skate Park Survey and Types of Bias
question_text:
A researcher is interested in knowing how residents of a certain town feel about a proposal to build a skate park in town. To gather data, the researcher stations surveyors at the four grocery stores in town during each day of one particular week and asks shoppers who are exiting the stores whether or not they would support building a skate park.
Identify the type of sampling method described AND a potential problem that can result from using this type of sample.

choices.text: This is a voluntary response sample. Since those exiting the store can choose to answer the question or not, non-response bias may cause the results of the survey to be unreliable.

This is a systematic random sample where only those who are exiting one of the town's four grocery stores is asked whether or not they support building a skate park in town.
This will result in undercoverage of those who are entering one of the grocery stores.

This is a stratified random sample where each of the grocery stores represents a different strata.
However, the characteristics of those who shop at each of the different stores may cause response bias. Therefore, the results of the survey would most likely not be accurate.

This is a convenience sample. However, since the opinions of residents who shop at one of the town's grocery stores may be different from the opinions of residents who do not shop at one of the town's grocery stores, the results of the survey may not accurately represent the opinions of all residents of this town.
This is a census. Since all residents of the town will shop at one of the town's grocery stores, there should be no problem with this type of sampling method.

title: Mayor's Constituents
question_text:
A small town mayor wonders if his town will support a new city hall building in their town. He decides to send a survey to $50$ houses in order to get a feel for those who support the building. Only $30$ of the households return the survey.
What is the population of interest in this setting?

choices.text: All the mayor's constituents.
The $50$ households selected for the survey.
The $30$ households who returned the surveys.
The $50$ surveys sent out.
The mayor

solution:
When planning a study, one must know the population and the sample from which the data comes. The population consists of all items or subjects of interest, while the sample is the subset of the population selected for the study.

In the problem, the mayor is trying to gather data about his constituents by sending a survey to a sample of $50$ households. Therefore, the subjects of interest in this setting would be all the mayors constituents.

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: Evidence of Causation
question_text: Which of the following is the best way to give evidence of causation?

choices.text: Case-controlled studies.
Random samples.
Observational studies.
Well-designed experiments.
Stratified samples.

title: Lisa's Jewelry Beads
question_text:
Lisa is an artist who makes jewelry from glass beads. She samples each container of beads she receives from the manufacturer to make sure the bead size is consistent with what she ordered.
Which of the following is the most important for Lisa to include in her sampling in order to ensure that the sample is representative of all of the beads in the container?

choices.text: Lisa should be sure to sample less than $10\%$ of all the beads in the container.
Lisa should choose a sample of at least $30\text{ beads}$.
Lisa should sample the beads at the top of the bag because they are easiest to reach.
Lisa should thoroughly mix the beads in the container and randomly choose the beads for her sample.
Lisa should select as large of a sample as possible.

title: Hannah's House of Hobbies
question_text:
Hannah's House of Hobbies prints a website address at the bottom of every receipt. Customers can choose to visit the website to answer a customer satisfaction survey.
Which type of bias could result from this type of survey?

choices.text: Response bias.
Voluntary response bias.
Nonresponse bias.
Undercoverage bias.
There is no bias in this selection method.

title: Correlation: Boating Accidents
question_text:
Recent studies have found a strong, positive correlation with ice cream sales and boating accidents.
This correlation can best be described by the fact that

choices.text: Ice cream must somehow cause boating accidents.
This correlation is simply a coincidence that could have easily happened by chance.
Temperature is likely a common response variable.
The sample must have been too small to draw any reasonable conclusions about ice cream and boating accidents.
The sample must have been gathered in a biased manner to get such an absurd statement.

title: Confounded by Sunshine?
question_text:
A study of adults over the age of $50$ who live in Miami, Florida was conducted to determine if there is a relationship between the mean number of hours of sunlight that an individual receives each day and the general health of the individual.
The results of the study showed that adults over the age of $50$ who receive more sunlight are generally healthier than those who receive less sunlight.
Which of the following could be a confounding variable in the context of this study?

choices.text: The mean age of those who live in Miami, Florida.
The mean number of hours of sunshine that individuals in the sample receive each day.
The overall general health of adults over the age of $50$.
The overall lifestyle of people who would choose to spend time outdoors rather than indoors.
There are no possible confounding variables in this situation. The results of the study can be used to prove the health benefits of sunshine.

title: Biased Design
question_text:
The Director of Activities at a local museum is introducing a new film series detailing the events of the assassination of John F. Kennedy, Jr. To see if there is local interest, the Director mails a survey to a random sample of $100$ residents who live in the cities near the museum.
Seventy-five responses are received and $70$% of the responses express much interest in the new film series. These results encourage the Director of Activities to launch a large advertising campaign for the new film series boasting strong local support.
Bias is present in the design of this study. Which of the following best describes the bias?

choices.text: Residents vary a lot in their opinions about the assassination of John F. Kennedy, Jr.
The percent of residents that responded was too small.
The sample of local residents was too small.
Residents who responded to this survey might generally have opinions that differ from those who did not respond.
The sample of $100$ residents could, by chance, have included many people who are interested in the assassination of John F. Kennedy, Jr.

title: Concept of Sampling
question_text: The concept of sampling describes

choices.text: Taking large samples that are nearly the same size as the population.
Taking a sample in hopes that it will give the statistician a snapshot of how the population behaves or feels.
Taking only simple random samples, where everybody in the population has an equal chance of being selected.
Getting results from all subjects in the population.
Interviewing subjects that are easiest to reach, hoping to get as large of a sample as possible.

correct_answer: Choice 'A'is incorrect; in most situations, the sample is much smaller than the population, and if the sample is perfectly random, a sample size of $1,000-2,000$ subjects is usually large enough.

title: Blood Pressure Pills
question_text:
A doctor has developed a new pill to hopefully lower her patients blood pressure. She recruits $30$ patients and prescribes them the new pill. The new patients are not told to keep their diet and exercise routine the same.
Can the doctor be certain the pill helps lower blood pressure?

choices.text: No, because the people are not random.
No, because we cannot be sure if it's the pill or other factors that help lower the blood pressure.
Yes, because the doctor developed the pill.
Yes, if the results show a decrease in blood pressure.
Yes, as she can compare person to person.

solution:
The doctor is putting together a study in order to collect data about her new weight loss pill. The hope is that after collecting the data, she would be able to make a conclusion with certainty about whether the pill helped lower blood pressure.

But, the doctor did not take into account the outside factors that might lower blood pressure that aren't her pill. Since she did not tell her patients to keep the rest of their lives the same, she cannot be sure whether he pill lowered the blood pressure, or the other factors. Therefore, we are unsure whether the data we collected is accurate.

Choice 'B' is correct.

title: Effective Variables: Food Satisfaction
question_text:
Suppose the superintendent of a large school district is interested in district-wide student satisfaction with the cafeteria food, grades K-$12$.
If the superintendent decided to make a stratified sample, what could be an effective variable to stratify on?

choices.text: Favorite color.
Favorite food.
Alphabetically by last name.
Height.
Favorite sport.

title: Mean Age of Those Who Visit the Mall Easter Bunny
question_text:
A researcher wanted to determine the average age of children who visit the Easter Bunny at a local mall. To gather data, the Easter Bunny's helpers asked and recorded the age of every $10^\text{th}$ child who came to visit the Easter Bunny over a period of several days.
What type of sample was the researcher using?

choices.text: Convenience sample.
Simple random sample.
Stratified random sample.
Systematic random sample.
Voluntary response sample.

title: Getting Pumped for Pumps Again
question_text:
Many professional women have abandoned their high-heeled shoes for more comfortable footwear. Perry's Pumps has devised a new insole for its high-heeled shoes in an attempt to make them more comfortable and increase sales. Before selling them in stores, an experiment is conducted to see if the company can truthfully advertise that the new insole is indeed more comfortable.
Which of the studies described below best avoids bias and the effects of a confounding variable?

choices.text: Fifty women are randomly divided into two groups. One group gets the new insoles with instructions to wear them on at least five dinner dates. The other group gets the previous insoles with instructions to wear them to the mall at least five times.

Fifty women are each given a pair of Perry's Pumps. One of the shoes has the new insole, labeled "Comfy-sole". The other shoe has the previous, unlabeled insole. The women wear the shoes three times a week for two weeks.

Fifty women are randomly divided into two groups. One group gets the new insoles labeled "Comfy-sole" and the other gets the previous insoles. After a week of wear, all the women get another pair of shoes with the other insole to wear for a week.

Fifty women are each given a pair of Perry's Pumps. One of the shoes has the new insole and the other shoe has the previous insole, both unlabeled. The women wear the shoes three times a week for two weeks.
Twenty-five flight attendants and 25 computer programmers volunteer to participate in the study. The computer programmers get the new insoles and the flight attendants get the previous insoles.

title: Sample Design and Reliability of Conclusions
question_text:
IN $2014$, the FIFA (Men's) World Cup was held in Brazil. In $2016$, Brazil also hosted the Summer Olympics.
Which fans know where their next big event will be held? Researchers decided to investigate.
In $2014$, researchers asked a random sample of fans attending the FIFA World Cup to identify where the next World Cup would be held. Of those fans surveyed, $61\%$ correctly said that the next World Cup was scheduled to be held in Russia.
In $2016$, researchers also asked a random sample of fans attending the Summer Olympics to identify where the next Summer Olympics would be held. Of those fans surveyed, $56\%$ correctly identified that the next Summer Olympics were scheduled to be held in Japan.
Based on the way the samples were selected, which of the following describes a reason why the conclusions of this study would most likely not be very reliable?

choices.text: Non-response bias.
Response bias.
Undercoverage.
Voluntary response bias.
Since both samples were selected randomly, there should be no reason why the results of the study are not reliable.

title: Matched Pairs
question_text:
Suppose a teacher wants to determine whether the $30$ students in her class learn better by class lecture or by computer program.
What would be an appropriate matched pairs design to determine this?

choices.text: Shuffle the students’ names in a hat and draw $15$ names. These students will learn by class lecture while the remaining will learn by computer program. Compare results.
Have all students learn by class lecture for the first unit, then have the same students learn by computer program for the second unit. Compare differences in test scores for each student.

Shuffle students’ names in a hat and draw two names. These students will be a pair. Then flip a coin to determine which student will learn by class lecture and which will learn by computer program. Repeat this process for the remaining students and measure differences in test scores for each of the $15$ pairs.

Use class rank to pair students together, starting with the two top-ranked students and pairing through the two lowest-ranked students. Flip a coin for each pair to determine which student will learn by class lecture and which will learn by computer program. Repeat this process for the remaining pairs, then measure differences in achievement for the $15$ pairs.

Divide the students by gender and randomly select half of the males to learn by class lecture while the other half learns by computer program. Repeat this process for the females, then compare differences in achievement for the groups.

title: Response Bias in Context of a Sample
question_text: In the context of a sample, response bias is another term for the respondents

choices.text: providing inaccurate or misleading answers.
choosing not to answer the question.
forgetting how to answer the question.
filling out the survey incorrectly.
inability to be contacted for the survey.

title: Truck Showroom
question_text:
Hoping to find a new way to boost pick-up truck sales, a showroom manager runs a week-long study. For each shopper who walks in, a coin is flipped. If it lands on heads, the shopper will be greeted by a sales representative who will offer them bottled water and then let the shopper browse the inventory on their own.
If the coin lands on tails, the shopper will be offered a bottle of water and then guided through the showroom by the sales representative. At the end of the week, the manager will compare the proportion of shoppers from each group who purchased a pick-up truck that week.
What is the response variable in this study?

choices.text: Whether or not the sales representative guided the shopper around the showroom.
The number of bottles of water consumed by the shoppers.
Whether or not each shopper purchased a truck that week.
The number of times the coin landed on heads during the week.
The number of trucks sold in the showroom that week.

title: Music Sampling for Money
question_text:
The music industry is a huge financial industry. When a song is played on a radio station, the musicians are entitled to a royalty payment. It would be impossible to listen to every song played on every radio station to determine the royalties due to each musician. Instead, The American Society of Composers, Authors, and Publishers (ASCAP) randomly samples radio stations and times of day to listen to the music being played and to determine the royalties due to each musician.
Which of the following statements is FALSE?

choices.text: The sample is the group of songs randomly chosen by ASCAP.
ASCAP's song selection procedure most closely resembles a census.
The population of interest is all songs played on all radio stations.
Because the radio stations and times of day are randomly selected, the sample of songs should be representative of the population of all songs played on all radio stations.
The more times an artists' songs are played, the more they stand to earn.

title: Study Session
question_text:
Suppose Mr. Rodriguez, a statistics teacher, is considering offering an optional after-school study session right before the next unit test.
Mr. Rodriguez touts his study session, saying that last year the $30$ subjects who attended scored an average of $10.3$ points higher than those who did not attend.
There is not convincing evidence the study session helps increase scores because

choices.text: An increase of $10.3$ points could have easily happened by chance.
An increase of $10.3$ points is of no practical importance.
The sample size is too small to develop any reasonable conclusions.
There is no way to make the experiment double-blind.
Students who chose to go to this optional study session are most likely more motivated and would have done better regardless of the study session.

title: Elements of an Experiment
question_text:
Of the following, which is/are important elements of a well-designed experiment?
Random assignment of subjects to treatment groups.
Use of a large sample of subjects to ensure small variability.
Control of any variable that may have an effect on the response variable.

choices.text: I only
I and II
I and III
II and III
I, II, and III

title: Observational Study vs. Experiment
question_text: What is the main difference between an observational study and an experiment?

choices.text: An experiment is more likely to involve a random sample of individuals while an observational study is more likely to involve volunteers.
In an experiment, some type of treatment is imposed upon subjects, while in an observational study no treatments are imposed.
An observational study never looks for an association between two variables, while an experiment is seeking to find an association between two variables.
Data obtained from an observational study will usually have less bias than data obtained through a well-designed experiment.
There is no difference. An observational study is a specific type of experiment.

title: Counseling in Weight Loss Programs
question_text:
A personal fitness trainer believes that having his clients participate in counseling groups will improve their success rate in reaching their weight loss goal. To investigate, he conducts an experiment.
Which of the following should the personal trainer include in order to conduct a well-designed experiment?

choices.text: The trainer should include a control in the experiment by requiring the female subjects to attend counseling and the male subjects to attend no counseling.
The trainer should include a control in the experiment by allowing subjects to follow their normal daily diet.
The trainer should include replication in the experiment by assigning one of his clients to receive counseling and one of his clients to not receive counseling.

The trainer should include randomization in the experiment by asking his clients to set a weight loss goal. The clients with smaller weight loss goals will receive no counseling and the clients with the higher weight loss goals will receive counseling.
The trainer should include randomization in the experiment by drawing names out of a hat to decide which subjects will receive counseling.

title: Conducting a Simulation
question_text: Which of the following is false regarding the use of simulation?

choices.text: We might choose to conduct a simulation because gathering the desired data by means of an experiment may be considered unethical.
We might choose to conduct a simulation because we want to gain insight into real world probabilities or expected values.
Conducting a well designed simulation can mimic real world outcomes.
Conducting a simulation can help to establish a cause and effect relationship between two variables.
A simulation must be repeated many times in order to provide reliable information about probabilities.

title: Types of Sampling: Self-Defense
question_text:
A large company wants to conduct a survey to determine the proportion of its female employees who practice self-defense on a daily basis. $4$ of its regional offices are randomly selected and all of the women in those offices are surveyed.
This plan is an example of which type of sampling?

choices.text: A convenience sample.
A cluster random sample.
A simple random sample.
A stratified random sample.
A systematic sample.

title: Appropriateness of a Survey
question_text: In which of the following situations would it be inappropriate to gather data by way of a survey?

choices.text: A boutique hotel wants to know how satisfied guests are with the accommodations and services that are offered.
The publisher of textbooks wonders whether students would be able to remember more information if the text were printed in a variety of colors instead of simply with black type.
A researcher for a major movie chain wants to know the average number of times per month that teenagers go out to the movies.
A marketing researcher wants to know the proportion of women who usually skip breakfast at least twice a week.
All of these situations could effectively be investigated by using a survey.

title: Congressional Candidate
question_text:
A pollster wants to determine the support of a congressional candidate in a certain district.

The pollster selects the $12\text{ counties}$ the district represents then randomly selects $10\text{ towns}$ in each of the $12\text{ counties}$. Finally, he randomly selects $10\text{ subjects}$ in each town for a total of $1{,}200\text{ respondents}$ in the sample.
What type of sample best describes this situation?

choices.text: Simple random sample.
Stratified sample, where county is the strata.
Stratified sample, where town is the strata.
Multistage sample.
Observational study.

title: Radio Poll
question_text:
The host of a nationally syndicated radio program is discussing whether the United States military should intervene in fewer situations in foreign countries. The host asks callers to voice their opinions by going to an online poll and voting.
What is a likely form of bias present in this situation?

choices.text: Voters might lie about their true feelings.
Non-response is very likely.
The question wording is unclear.
Undercoverage is very likely.
The sample size will most likely be too small.

title: Goal in Selecting a Sample
question_text: Which of the following best describes the goal in selecting a sample as a means of providing information about a specific population of interest?

choices.text: The sample should contain individuals who are as similar as possible.
The sample should contain individuals who are as diverse as possible.
The sample should represent the population of interest as accurately as possible.
The sample should include those individuals that are as easy to reach as possible.
The sample should include those individuals who are most eager to participate as possible.

correct_answer: In order to better understand (and be able to conduct valid statistical inference about) a specific population of interest, it is most important that we collect our data from a sample that best represents that specific population of interest. In this way, we will be able to generalize the results of the study to the population that we are concerned with.

title: Raising Taxes to Pay for a New Expressway
question_text:
The local highway commission draws a random sample of $150\text{ adults}$ from the driver's license database to ask, "Would you support raising taxes $1\%$ to pay for a new $10\text{ mile}$ expressway?"
This survey will most likely suffer from

choices.text: Response bias because the wording of the question is misleading.
Response bias because there are not enough people in the sample.
Undercoverage bias because taxpayers who do not have a driver's license will not be able to contribute their opinions.
Undercoverage bias because there are not enough people in the sample.
Voluntary response bias because only those who feel strongly on the issue will choose to participate in the survey.

title: Keyboard Design
question_text:
An engineer is working on new prototypes for the new model of a laptop for a major computer company. He has narrowed down the keyboard design to two different designs, $A$ and $B$. He sets up a study to investigate the new keyboards.
Which of the following is not a problem the engineer would be investigating?

choices.text: The overall comfort of the new keyboards.
The overall design of the keyboards
The cost effectiveness of the keyboards.
The overall feel of the keyboards.
Which keyboard color is the coolest.

solution:
The engineer is collecting data in order to solve a problem. The issue we have is that we are unaware of the problem that the engineer is trying to solve.

When looking at problems the engineer could be investigating, the obvious ones are effectiveness, compatibility, comfort, and design. Once the engineer decides which keyboard they want to use for the new laptop, they can then customize the computer with the color keyboard of their choice.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Block Design vs. Stratified Random Sampling
question_text: Which of the following describes a difference between block design and stratified random sampling?

choices.text: Block design involves splitting the sample into two distinct blocks. With stratified random sampling however, we can split the sample into as many strata as we wish.

With block design, blocks are formed based upon some naturally occurring characteristic. With stratified random sampling however, strata may be formed based upon any characteristic the researcher deems appropriate.

With block design, we are able to guarantee that all groups within the population of interest are represented. Stratified random sampling cannot ensure that all groups within the population will be represented.
Block design is a specific method used for designing an experiment while stratified random sampling is a method of gathering a sample.
There is no difference between block design and stratified random sampling. Blocks and strata are different words that basically mean the same thing.

title: Absorbs-All
question_text:
Absorbs-All is a paper towel company that claims its paper towels can absorb $25\%$ more liquid than the leading paper towel. At the end of each day, quality control inspectors at the manufacturing plant collect a sample of all the paper towels produced that day to ensure the absorbing standard is being met.
Which of the following describes the best way for quality control officers to collect the sample?

choices.text: The inspectors will select the first $10\text{ rolls}$ of paper towels produced each day so that the inspection can be completed early in the day.
The inspectors will select the last $10\text{ rolls}$ of paper towels produced each day because the best towels are produced at the end of each day.
The inspectors will select $10\text{ rolls}$ of paper towels that look like typical rolls.

The packaging equipment will sequentially number each of the paper towel rolls produced in a day. The inspectors will program a computer to randomly select $10\text{ unique numbers}$ from among all of the paper towel numbers. The paper towel rolls corresponding to the $10\text{ numbers}$ will be part of the sample.
The inspectors will select $10\text{ rolls}$ of paper towels from one of the factory's seven assembly lines.

title: Benefits of Random Selection
question_text: Which of the following is NOT a valid reason for using random selection of the sample in a well-designed survey?

choices.text: Random selection ensures that each member of the population has an equal chance to be selected for the sample.
Random selection makes it likely that the sample will be representative of the population of interest.
Random selection greatly reduces bias in the sample statistic.
Random selection of subjects will allow the researchers to determine a causal relationship.
Random selection of subjects will allow the researchers to generalize their findings to the population of interest.

title: Blocking
question_text: Adults in a local city have volunteered to participate in an experiment. The statistician organizing the experiment decides to use a randomized block design. The purpose of the experiment is to compare two hair shampoos that claim to moisturize even the driest of scalps. Which of the following methods should the statistician use when forming the blocks?

choices.text: Volunteers in the same block should receive the same shampoo.
Volunteers should be randomly assigned to the blocks.
Volunteers within each block should be as similar as possible with respect to how dry their scalp is prior to using the shampoo.
Volunteers within each block should be as different as possible with respect to how dry their scalp is prior to using the shampoo.
Volunteers should be kept blind as to which block they are in.

title: Characteristics of a Well-Designed Experiment
question_text:
Which of the following statements are true?
I. Random assignment of treatments is an important feature of a well-designed experiment because it controls for factors within treatment groups that might affect subjects' responses.
II. Controlling conditions in an experiment helps to reduce the effects of suspected confounding variables.
III. It is not possible for a well-designed experiment to have both randomization and control.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
I, II, and III.

title: Student Council Candidates
question_text:
Jeff sends everyone in his high school a survey asking which of three student council candidates his peers will support. Out of $1{,}300\text{ students}$, $403$ returned completed surveys.
What is the biggest problem with Jeff’s survey technique?

choices.text: Undercoverage is clearly present in this survey.
He did not ensure that males and females were equally represented in the response.
The data may exhibit non-response bias.
He should have done a matched pair analysis.
He did not talk to the respondents in person.

title: New Reality Show
question_text:
A new reality TV show is testing contestants on how long it takes to solve four different types of puzzles. Because it is thought that males and females tend to solve puzzles differently, contestants were randomly divided into groups by gender. Each subject solved all $4\text{ puzzles}$, in a randomized order.
Which statement concerning this experimental design is true?

choices.text: This is a matched pairs design.
Gender is a blocking factor.
Gender and puzzle type are confounding variables.
There are eight treatment combinations in this experiment.
Puzzle type is a blocking factor.

title: Quick Quiche
question_text:
Quick Quiche is a fast-food restaurant that has $150\text{ locations}$ in the southeast region. The regional manager will randomly select $10\text{ restaurants}$ to make a surprise inspection. He assigns each restaurant a unique number between $1$ and $150$.
He then draws ten pairs of numbers from a random digit table. The manager will make a surprise visit to the restaurants corresponding to those numbers.
Which statement best describes the main flaw in the sampling method for this study?

choices.text: All the restaurants do not have the same chance of being chosen. The manager should make a surprise visit to the restaurants whose numbers were a multiple of $15$.

All the restaurants do not have the same chance of being chosen. The manager is only selecting pairs of numbers from the random digit table. Restaurants with the numbers $100$ to $150$ have no chance of being chosen.

All the restaurants do not have the same chance of being chosen. Restaurants labeled with repeating digits (such as $33$ or $88$) have a smaller chance of being selected because it is unlikely that a number would repeat on a random digit table.
This is a convenience sample. Only the restaurants that are easy to reach by car are being sampled.
The regional manager should not be selecting the sample. The sample should be chosen by someone who does not work for Quick Quiche.

title: Advantages and Disadvantages of Experiments
question_text: There are advantages and disadvantages to conducting experiments. Which of the following does NOT represent a potential disadvantage of trying to conduct an experiment?

choices.text: Conducting an experiment can be very time-consuming and costly.
For ethical reasons, it may not even possible to conduct certain types of experiments.
Experimental research can create situations that are not realistic.
Some experiments (such as those involving medication) can only be completed with a group of volunteers. This may limit how well we are able to generalize our findings to the entire population.
In an experiment, we should control for the effects of outside variables. This can be difficult to do.

title: Type of Surveys: Vote for Me!
question_text:
After noticing that you are lacking in extracurriculars, you decide to run for class president. Being the statistician that you are, you decide to do some polling before deciding what issues to run on. You stand by the school library during 4th period and survey every member of your class who walks by.
What type of survey did you just administer?

choices.text: Convenience survey.
Simple random survey.
Stratified survey.
Cluster survey.
Systematic survey.

title: Explaining Behaviors: Crime Reduction
question_text:
A recent study found that people who exercise at least $4\text{ times a week}$ are less likely to have a criminal record than those who do not exercise at all.
This fact could be explained by

choices.text: Simple coincidence since exercising has nothing to do with crime involvement.
Some other type of common response or confounding variable.
A possible causal link between exercise and lack of a criminal record.
A flaw in the implementation of the experiment.
Nothing; since this was an observational study, no real linkage can be made between exercise and criminal activity.

title: Observational Study
question_text: Which of the following is not true about an observational study?

choices.text: An observational study can only be retrospective, not prospective.
You can not prove cause and effect with an observational study.
A treatment is not imposed during an observational study.
A sample survey is a type of observational study.
You can collect data from a sample to try and learn about a population from which the sample was selected.

solution:
When looking at studies, a researcher can choose between an observational study and an experiment. In an observational study, a researcher does not impose treatments and follows a sample in order to learn about the population in which the sample was selected. In an experiment, treatments are assigned to experimental units to investigate an experimental treatment.

A researcher can do an observational study to examine data from a sample of individuals (retrospective) or follow a sample of individuals into the future to collect data (prospective) in order to investigate a topic of interest about the population. Therefore, an observational study can be both retrospective and prospective.

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: When to Use a Census
question_text: In which of the following situations would it be most appropriate to use a census?

choices.text: To determine the average sales price for the $83$ homes currently listed for sale in a small town.
To estimate the average age of all quarters currently in circulation in the United States.
To find the average time it takes a high school senior to walk one mile.
To determine the proportion of longleaf pine trees that are affected by brown-spot needle blight.
To estimate the proportion of American children under the age of 10 who go to bed hungry at night.

title: Making Work Better
question_text:
The offices of a large corporation occupy all floors of a $10\text{-story}$ building. The corporation is planning to renovate the building and would like to incorporate features that will boost the morale of its employees. They will survey a group of $40\text{ employees}$ to help them decide which features to include.
The study would be well-designed with all of the following EXCEPT

choices.text: Random selection of the $40\text{ participants}$ from a list of everyone who works in the building.
Sorting all of the employees into three groups (upper management, middle management and office worker) and randomly choosing one of those groups. All of the people in that group will be surveyed.
Random selection of $4\text{ floors}$ in the building followed by random selection of $10\text{ employees}$ from each of those floors.
Employees answering an anonymous written survey.
Following up with employees who were randomly chosen to participate, but who were absent on the day of the survey.

title: Type of Design: Laundry Detergents
question_text:
The manager of a dry cleaning facility wants to compare the effectiveness of two different types of laundry detergents. The manager thinks light colors and dark colors will react differently.
Which type of design should the manager use to effectively compare the two types of detergents?

choices.text: A completely randomized design.
A randomized block design with the detergents as blocks and the light and dark colors as the treatments.
A randomized block design with the light and dark colors as the blocks and the types of detergents as the treatments.
An observational study.
A matched pair design with the detergents being the pair.

title: Types of Sampling: Turn the Lights on
question_text: A town committee is thinking about investing $\$200,000$ for lighting the baseball fields. The first selectman of the town wants to survey $500\text{ citizens}$ of the town to see what they think. Which of the following will produce a simple random sample?

choices.text: Surveying every fourth citizen who walks by the town hall.
Randomly selecting $500\text{ citizens}$ from the local phone directory.
Using the latest census data from the town, numbering the citizens, and using a random number generator to select $500\text{ citizens}$.

Separate by age groups using the latest census data from the community. The age groups would be $18-30$, $31-45$, $46-65$, and $65$ and over. Randomly select two of the age groups and randomly survey $250$ citizens from those two age groups.

Separate by age groups using the latest census data from the community. The age groups would be $18-30$, $31-45$, $46-65$, and $65$ and over. Randomly select $125\text{ citizens}$ ages $18-30$, $125\text{ citizens}$ ages $31-45$, $125\text{ citizens}$ ages $46-65$, and $125\text{ citizens}$ ages $65$ and over.

title: Types of Bias: School Lunch...Sloppy Joes!
question_text:
In a recent poll of students at the local high school, $20\%$ of the students reported that they did not vote if the school should change the lunch menu. However, the vote data showed that actually $55\%$ of the student body did not vote if the school should change the lunch menu.
Which of the following types of bias is most likely to have occurred in the poll?

choices.text: Undercoverage bias.
Sampling bias.
Selection bias.
Non-response bias.
Response bias.

title: Census: Most Difficult
question_text: In which of the following situations would it be most DIFFICULT to use a census?

choices.text: To determine what proportion of homes in a small town have garages.
To determine what proportion of students at a high school get driven to school by their parents.
To determine what proportion of teachers at a high school love teaching.
To determine what proportion of sharks in the oceans are great white sharks.
To determine what proportion of Major League Baseball teams are east of the Mississippi River.

title: Preventing Falling Cakes
question_text:
No one likes a cake that collapses on itself after it comes out of the oven! To find the best way to prevent falling cakes, a baker runs an experiment using $24\text{ cakes}$:
Group A: $12\text{ cakes}$ are made with $1\text{ teaspoon}$ of baking powder and bake at $350\text{ degrees}$ for $35\text{ minutes}$.
Group B: $12\text{ cakes}$ are made with $1.5\text{ teaspoons}$ of baking powder and bake at $375\text{ degrees}$ for $30\text{ minutes}$.
Ten minutes after the cakes come out of the oven, an assistant measures the height of each cake at its center. The assistant does not know the specific treatment given to any of the cakes he measures. The average height of the cakes in Group B is significantly higher than the average height of the cakes in Group A.
This study is flawed because it demonstrates

choices.text: Response bias.
Confounding.
Blinding.
The placebo effect.
There is no flaw in this study.

title: Cucumber Bubble Gum
question_text:
A bubble gum company would like to predict how well its new cucumber flavored bubble gum will sell. The company takes a sample by sending a team of surveyors to a randomly chosen veggie juice bar for a day. As the $72\text{ customers}$ of the day leave the juice bar, the surveyors give them a sample of the cucumber bubble gum and ask them if they like it enough to pay $\$3.00$ for a pack of $5\text{ pieces}$.
The bubble gum is unwrapped so the subjects can't tell which brand of bubble gum they are tasting. At the end of the day, the surveyors will use the responses from the sample to estimate the proportion of all customers who would answer 'Yes'.
What is the main flaw in this sampling method?

choices.text: There is no flaw in this sampling method.
The sample size will not be large enough to satisfy the conditions for inference.
This is a convenience sample that is biased towards those who like vegetables. The estimated proportion of people who answer 'Yes' is likely to be too high.
There will be response bias. Since the brand of bubble gum is unknown to the subjects, the estimated proportion of people who answer 'Yes' is likely to be too low.

There will be non-response bias. Since the subjects aren't being paid for their time, fewer people who would have answered 'Yes' will be included in the sample. The estimated proportion is likely to be too low.

title: Identifying a Double Blind Experiment
question_text: Which of the following experiments could best be performed double-blind?

choices.text: Determine if an individual can kick a soccer ball further off their left foot or right foot.
Determine if aspirin or Tylenol reduces the intensity of pain more for a patient.
Determine if running or swimming burns more calories per hour for an athelete.
Determine if a prep course increases a student's ACT score.
Determine if subjects who exercise daily weigh less than subjects who don’t exercise daily.

title: The Goal in Designing a Sample
question_text: Which of the following best describes the goal of sample design?

choices.text: To include all individuals within the population in our sample.
To gather a sample quickly and in a way that saves money.
To create a sample that is truly representative of the population of interest.
To choose individuals from the population of interest using a method that involves random selection.
To have a sample in which every possible opinion on the matter under study is equally represented.

title: Experimental Design for Learning Styles
question_text:
Students, and people in general, have different styles and preferences of learning new material. An AP Statistics teacher is interested in two types of instruction:
One instruction type is considered "traditional" consisting of note-taking, written assignments, and paper-and-pencil assessments.
The other instruction type is considered "progressive" and includes exploratory activities, oral presentations, and project-based assessments.
The teacher decides to randomly divide his current AP Statistics class into two equal groups. One group will get the traditional instruction and the other group will get the progressive instruction. At the end of one month, the teacher will compare the amount of learning by each group in the form of a test, given in the style of the instruction each group used for the past month.
Which of the following best describes why a completely randomized design is an appropriate design to use in this situation?

choices.text: The number of students participating in the study was greater than or equal to $30$.
Each type of instruction is a block, and a completely randomized design is not blocked.
There is no blocking variable, and the students were selected at random.
There is no blocking variable, and the type of instruction is randomly assigned to the students.
Each type of instruction is randomly assigned to pairs of students with similar grades before the study began.

title: Cable Network Survey
question_text:
A large cable network is planning a survey of $180$ of their own subscribers to learn more about their preferences in television programs.
Which of the following is NOT required in order for this to be a well-designed survey?

choices.text: Every customer should have an equal chance to be selected as part of the sample.
The network should secure that every possible subgroup of $180\text{ customers}$ should have the same chance of being chosen as the sample.
The subjects should all be customers for this cable network.
The wording of the survey question should be the same for all subjects.
Randomness should be used in the selection of the subjects.

title: Caffeine Wars
question_text:
Does a high level of caffeine in a drink help teenagers stay awake longer, or does it actually have the opposite effect? A psychologist will investigate this issue using $94\text{ subjects}$ who complain of frequent fatigue at the end of the day. The psychologist will instruct the subjects to drink either soda ($15 - 23\text{ mg}$ caffeine per serving) or coffee ($95 - 150\text{ mg}$ caffeine per serving) when they feel like they cannot stay awake any longer. The subjects will record the amount of additional time they are able to stay awake.
While collecting preliminary information from his subjects, the psychologist finds that some work in dimly lit rooms at the end of the day and some work in brightly lit rooms. Previous studies have shown that brightly lit rooms reduce fatigue.
On what variable should the experiment be blocked? Why?

choices.text: The psychologist should block on the lighting in the room because he wants to see if it affects how late a person can stay awake.
The psychologist should block on the lighting in the subjects' rooms because he knows that room lighting affects how late a person can stay awake.
The psychologist should block on the type of caffeinated drink because he wants to see if the amount of caffeine affects how late a person can stay awake.
The psychologist should block on the type of caffeinated drink because he knows that the amount of caffeine affects how late a person can stay awake.
This experiment should not be blocked because blocking will not improve the design.

title: Restrooms in the Park
question_text:
A large neighborhood association is considering adding a small restroom building to its three neighborhood parks and will choose a random sample of residents to ask their opinions.
The association decides to sort the neighborhood homes into two groups: those located near one of the parks and those not located near a park. The association will then randomly choose $10\text{ homes}$ from each of those groups.
Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: The homeowner's association stratified on the locations of the homes to guarantee equal representation of opinions from both groups.
The homeowner's association stratified on the locations of the homes to make the surveys easier to collect.
The homeowner's association stratified on the locations of the homes because that is a characteristic that could have an effect on people's opinions about the bathrooms.
The homeowner's association stratified on the locations of the homes so that it can compare the opinions of one group to the other.
The homeowner's association stratified on the locations of the homes to reduce variability in the difference between the two sample proportions.

title: Effectiveness of a Test Prep Course
question_text:
A company just launched an ACT prep course.
What would be the best way to determine the effectiveness of this course?

choices.text: Randomly select $100\text{ students}$ who have taken the ACT once, have them take the prep course, and then have them take the ACT a second time. Randomly select another $100\text{ students}$ who have taken the ACT once and have them take the ACT again without the prep course. Compare the increase in ACT scores of the two groups.

Randomly select $100\text{ students}$, enroll them in the prep course, then have them take the ACT. Randomly select another $100\text{ students}$, do not allow them to take the prep course, then have them take the ACT. Compare ACT scores of the two groups.

Find $100$ randomly chosen students who have taken the prep course, then have these students take the ACT. Compare these scores to the ACT scores of $100$ randomly chosen students who have not taken the prep course.

Randomly select $100\text{ students}$ who have not taken the ACT or the prep course and have them take the ACT once, then take the prep course, and then finally take the ACT a second time. Compare the difference in scores on the ACT.

Randomly select 200 students, pair each student up with another who is about the same age, and have one student in each pair take the prep course while the other does not. Compare ACT scores of each of the 100 pairs.

title: Prime Time Wrestling: Sport or Drama, Two-Way Table
question_text:
Shane and Emma have been having a big disagreement. Although they both watch Prime Time Wrestling, Emma believes it is all drama - basically a soap opera for men! Shane says no way! "It's all sport" he claims.
In order to investigate whether gender influences opinions, Shane and Emma conducted a survey of several randomly selected individuals who watch Prime Time Wrestling. Respondents were asked to choose between the following three options concerning their beliefs.
$\bullet$ It's All Sport
$\bullet$ It's All Drama
$\bullet$ It's Part Sport, Part Drama
Responses was recorded separately for both men and women and are shown in the two-way table below.
All Sport All Drama Part Sport, Part Drama Total
Men 28 5 15 48
Women 17 10 14 41
Total 45 15 29 89


Which of the following correctly identifies the explanatory and response variables in this study?
tables:
All SportAll DramaPart Sport, Part DramaTotal
Men2851548
Women17101441
Total45152989

choices.text:
Explanatory Variable: Opinion on Prime Time Wrestling
Response Variable: Gender

Explanatory Variable: Gender
Response Variable: Opinion on Prime Time Wrestling

Explanatory Variable: Male
Response Variable: Belief that Prime Time Wrestling is "All Drama"

Explanatory Variable: Female
Response Variable: Belief that Prime Time Wrestling is "All Drama"
Since both variables of interest are categorical, either of the two variables could be considered the explanatory variable while the other variable would be considered the response variable.

title: Potassium Water Study | 1 of 2
question_text:
Would drinking potassium water during a workout on the treadmill help you to reach a higher average speed during your workout than drinking regular bottled water? A sports doctor decided to do a study and twenty volunteers who typically work out on a treadmill agreed to participate.
Each volunteer was asked to walk on the treadmill for $30$ minutes on two separate occasions with a one week break in between. During one of the two workouts, the participant was given a bottle of regular water to drink and during the other workout they were given a bottle of potassium water which looks and tastes just like regular water.
The type of water received first was determined at random. While participants were unable to see their speed on the treadmill during their workouts, the average speed for both workouts was recorded and the difference between the two mean speeds was determined for each individual.
How could this study incorporate double blinding?

choices.text: No one was allowed to know which bottles contained regular water and which bottles contained potassium water.
Labels identifying the type of water were removed from each bottle prior to being distributed to the subjects involved in the experiment.
Neither the individuals drinking the water nor those distributing the water to them knew which type of water was being given to each individual.
The study is already double blind as described since the participants were not able to see their speed while walking on the treadmill.
There is no way to include blinding in this experiment because the subjects will all know that they are drinking water.

title: Babies Pacifier
question_text:
A company that produces pacifiers for babies is conducting an experiment to see which prototype of pacifier babies prefer. The company recruits $100$ babies between the age of $3$ and $9$ months that use pacifiers. Of the $100$ babies, $50$ babies are assigned to use pacifier $A$, while the remaining $50$ babies are assigned pacifier $B$. The company measures the length of use and overall enjoyment of the pacifier.
What are the experiment units of this experiment?

choices.text: The two different types of pacifiers.
The $50$ babies that use pacifier $A$.
The $50$ babies that use pacifier $B$
The sample of $100$ babies.
All babies that use pacifiers.

solution:
In an experiment, different conditions, called treatments, are assigned to experimental units, or subjects. In the pacifier experiment, the treatments that were assigned would be the two different types of pacifiers.

While the treatments are the pacifiers, the experimental units are the $100$ babies that are recruited for the experiment. The experimental units are then split into two groups, one assigned to pacifier $A$ and the other assigned to pacifier $B$. Therefore, the experimental units are the $100$ babies.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: The Thrill of Competition: A Study
question_text:
Does the thrill of competition help students to complete basic multiplication problems more quickly? On two separate occasions, $20\text{ third grade students}$ were asked to complete as many multiplication facts as possible in two minutes and the number they got correct was recorded.
On one occasion, they were told that they would be competing against a fellow classmate while on the other occasion they were told to try for a personal best. For each student, the order in which they were told these statements was determined at random.
What type of experimental design is being used and why?

choices.text: This is not an experiment. It is an observational study and was done to determine the average number of multiplication facts that third grade students can complete in two minutes.
Block design was used because all students are in third grade and therefore should be similar to each other with respect to their ability to complete multiplication facts.

Matched pairs was used to control for the fact that some third grade students will naturally be able to complete more multiplication facts than other students regardless of whether or not they are competing.

Completely randomized design was used because the researcher did not expect any major difference in the number of multiplication facts that the students would be able to complete under the two experimental conditions.
Controlled randomized design was used because the researcher wanted to be able to control for the way in which students were randomly assigned to treatment conditions.

title: Generalize to the Population: Politics
question_text:
A simple random sample of people ages sixty-five and over living in Pinella County, Florida were surveyed to determine which of the two presidential nominees they favored in the upcoming election.
To which of the following population can we generalize the survey results to?

choices.text: All people in the United States.
Only people 65 and over in the United States.
All people in the state of Florida.
Only people 65 and over in the state of Florida.
Only people 65 and over in Pinella County, Florida.

title: Real World Application: Stratified
question_text:
A pollster hopes to determine the support distribution for three different mayoral candidates in a large city.
If a stratified sample is used, which of the following could the pollster do?
I. Randomly divide the subjects into three groups and then poll each group.
II. Divide the subjects into groups by race and then poll within each group.
III. Divide the subjects into groups by gender and then poll within each group.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
I and II only.
II and III only.
I, II, and III.

title: Experiment vs. Observation
question_text: An experiment is different than an observational study in that an experiment

choices.text: Typically involves more subjects.
Typically involves more variables.
Imposes a treatment or specific task for the subjects.
Usually divides the subjects based on similar characteristics.
Typically has more lurking variables.

title: Randomly Selected
question_text:
Pat and Amy are doing an experiment for their AP Statistics final project. They will be splitting their volunteers into two groups, Group $A$ and Group $B$.
Which of the following methods will not result in randomly selected groups?

choices.text: Assigning numbers to all volunteers then using a random number generator to get the two groups.
Placing all names on equal slips of paper and drawing two groups out of a hat.
Assigning numbers to all volunteers and using a random digit table.
Using a coin and assigning "Heads" to Group $A$ and "Tails" to Group $B$.
Pat and Amy will alternate selecting members for Group $A$ and Group $B$.

solution:
In a completely randomized experiment, treatments are assigned to experimental units completely at random. Using random assignment will hopefully balance the effects of the uncontrolled (confounding) variables so we can attribute the difference in the response to the treatments.

Methods for randomly assigning treatments in experimental units in a completely randomized design must have a chance process involved. Some examples of methods are using a random number generator, a random digit table, drawing names out of a hat, etc. The only choice above that won't result in random assignment is Choice 'E'.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Weight Loss
question_text:
Suppose a researcher wants to determine if a new weight loss drug is effective. She has $100\text{ volunteer subjects}$.
Which would be an appropriate method to determine the drug's effectiveness?

choices.text: Have all $100$ of the subjects take the weight loss drug for three weeks and measure mean weight loss.
Give all $100\text{ subjects}$ the weight loss drug for three weeks, then no treatment for three weeks, and measure the differences in weight of the subjects both on the drug and off the drug.
Give half of the volunteers the new weight loss drug and the other half a placebo, then compare changes in weight between the two groups.
Draw subjects’ names out of a hat at random, giving the first $50$ the new weight loss drug and the remaining $50$ no treatment, then compare changes in weight between the two groups.
Draw subjects’ names out of a hat at random, giving the first $50$ the new weight loss drug and the remaining $50$ a placebo, then compare changes in weight between the two groups.

title: Which Fertilizer Produces More Crops?
question_text:
In order to test the effectiveness of two fertilizers, Grow Fertilizer and Fertilizer Plus, a farmer designs the following two experiments:
Experiment A: The farmer will first divide his land into $10$ equal sections. For each section, the farmer flips a coin; if the coin lands on tails, Grow Fertilizer will be used on the East side of the section, and if the coin lands on heads, Fertilizer Plus will be used on the East side of the section. Whichever fertilizer is not used on the East side of the section will be used on the West side. This process will be repeated for each of the remaining nine sections. After $4$ weeks, the farmer will observe which side of each section produced more crops.
Experiment B: The farmer will first divide his land into $10$ equal sections (the $5$ sections on the East side of his land and the $5$ sections on the West side of his land). A coin will be flipped once to determine which of the two fertilizers is used on the East side of his land. If the coin lands on tails, Grow Fertilizer will be used; if the coin lands on heads, Fertilizer Plus will be used. Whichever Fertilizer is not used on the $5$ sections on the East side of his land will be used on the five sections on the West side of his land. After $4$ weeks, the farmer will observe which side of his land (East or West) produced more crops.
Which of the following statements is not true?

choices.text: Both experiments incorporate randomness.
Lurking variables are present in both experimental designs.
Experiment B could lead to confounding.
Both experiments use matched pairs in their design.
The experimental units are the sections of the farmer’s land.

title: Online Shopping: Producing a Graph from a Table
question_text:
A marketing research firm is interested in whether men and women have similar habits related to shopping online. To gather data, they surveyed a random sample of men and women and asked them to identify whether they shop online "Often", "Sometimes", or "Rarely". The results of the survey are shown in the table below.
Men Women Total
Often 29 48 77
Sometimes 32 40 72
Rarely 32 19 51
Total 93 107 200


Which of the following graphs appropriately displays the conditional distribution of online shopping habits by gender?
tables:
MenWomenTotal
Often294877
Sometimes324072
Rarely321951

title: What is it?
question_text:
The following table represents a cumulative probability distribution for $x$:
$x$ $4 $ $5$ $ 6$ $7$ $ 8$
$?$ $ 0.32$ $ 0.54$ $ 0.72$ $0.86$ $1.0$
Which of the following answers correctly explains the meaning of the value of $0.72$?
tables:
$x$$4 $$5$$ 6$$7$$ 8$
$?$$ 0.32$$ 0.54$$ 0.72$$0.86$$1.0$

choices.text: The number $0.72$ is simply the value that is associated with the number $6$ in the distribution.
Because it is cumulative, divide $0.72$ by $6$, and then you will find that the probability of obtaining a $6$ for the random variable, $x$, will occur $12\%$ of the time.
The value $0.72$ is the probability that the random variable, $x$, will equal to $6$ a total of $72\%$ of the time.
The value $0.72$ is the probability that the random variable, $x$, will take on a value greater than or equal to $6$ a total of $72\%$ of the time.

title: Don't Worry, Bee Happy: Combined Variance
question_text:
Don't Worry, Bee Happy is a store that sells artisanal honey. One of their best sellers is Wild Wildflower Honey, packaged in glass jars that are labeled as containing $8\text{ ounces}$ of honey. The owners want to make very sure that their customers are happy however, so the actual mean amount of honey contained in the jars is $8.05\text{ ounces}$. And while production standards are tight, not all jars contain exactly $8.05\text{ ounces}$. In fact, the standard deviation is $0.09\text{ ounces}$.
For true lovers of Wild Wildflower Honey (and for those looking for a more economical way to purchase several jars), the store offers a special $3$-pack consisting of three individual $8\text{ ounce}$ jars of Wild Wildflower Honey.
Since knowing the actual weight of one jar of honey will tell you nothing about the actual weight of another jar of honey, the weights of all $3$ jars in the pack would be considered independent.
Which of the following shows how to calculate the variance of the number of ounces of honey in the $3$-pack?

choices.text: $3\cdot { \left( 0.09 \right) }^{ 2 }$
${ \left[ \left( 3 \right) \cdot \left( 0.09 \right) \right] }^{ 2 }$
$\left( { 3 }^{ 2 } \right) \cdot \left( 0.09 \right) $

title: Let's Play Ball
question_text: Danny wanted to do a simulation on the types of hits in baseball. Danny wanted to simulate $200$ at bats using these percentages. How would he assign numbers using a random number table? Then, how would he calculate the estimated probabilities from using his table?

choices.text:
Let $00$ to $62$ indicate a single, let $63$ to $80$ indicate a double, let $81$ to $84$ indicate a triple, and let $85$ to $99$ indicate a home run.

Let $00$ to $62$ indicate a single, let $63$ to $80$ indicate a double, let $81$ to $84$ indicate a triple, and let $85$ to $99$ indicate a home run.
Danny would then count up the number in each category and divide each number by $100$.

Let $01$ to $63$ indicate a single, let $64$ to $81$ indicate a double, let $82$ to $85$ indicate a triple, and let $86$ to $99$ and $00$ indicate a home run.
Danny would then count up the number in each category and divide each number by $100$.

Let $01$ to $63$ indicate a single, let $64$ to $80$ indicate a double, let $81$ to $84$ indicate a triple, and let $85$ to $99$ indicate a home run.
Skip $00$.
Danny would then count up the number in each category and divide each number by $200$.

Let $01$ to $63$ indicate a single, let $64$ to $81$ indicate a double, let $82$ to $85$ indicate a triple, and let $86$ to $99$ and $00$ indicate a home run.
Danny would then count up the number in each category and divide each number by $200$.

title: Trivia: Standard Deviation of a Linear Transformation

title: Coke vs Pepsi
question_text:
Years ago, Pepsi wanted to show it was more popular than Coke.
So, Pepsi went around the country to various shopping centers giving people both colas to taste and tried to see if they knew the difference. Assuming that people do not know the difference (so $p=0.5$) if $64$ people came by to take the test, and $40$ seemed to know the difference, does this show it is likely true that people could tell the difference between Coke and Pepsi? Say "yes" or "no" and explain why using appropriate calculations.

choices.text: No. With a mean of $32$ and a standard deviation of $16$, we would expect to find $16$ to $48$ people on average to taste the difference. $40$ falls within this range so it is likely they can not taste the difference.

No. With a mean of $32$ and a standard deviation of 4, we would expect to find $28$ to $36$ people on average to taste the difference. $40$ just is not that much higher and is not unusual so the people probably could not taste the difference.

Yes. With both the mean and the standard deviation equal to $16$, we would expect to find up to $32$ people on average who could taste the difference. Since $40$ is higher than $32$, then it is likely that they can taste the difference.

Yes. With a mean of $16$ and a standard deviation of $4$, we would expect to find up to $20$ people on average who could taste the difference. $40$ is well above this so it is likely they can taste the difference.

Yes. With a mean of $32$ and a standard deviation of 4, we would expect to find $28$ to $36$ people on average to taste the difference. $40$ is $2$ standard deviations above $32$ so it is likely they can taste the difference.

title: The Coin Toss

choices.text: Cory is correct. We expect $10$ heads and $10$ tails, and since this result occurred, we know it is due to a random process.
Cory is correct. While these exact results may not happen often, they certainly can happen and be the result of a random process.
Jackie is correct. She had tried tossing a coin at home for a homework assignment and never achieved this result. Therefore, this result must have been made up.
Jackie is correct. While patterns can occur in a random process, this pattern is too perfect and goes on for too long, so it must have been made up.
Jackie is correct. Since this pattern would happen so rarely, it most certainly must have been made up.
