title: Encouraging Recycling: A Simulation
question_text:
According to some reports, $25\%$ of Americans never recycle. An environmental group wants to investigate why this is true and if there is anything that can be done to encourage more recycling. They plan on creating and conducting a widespread survey, but first they want to interview $5$ people who never recycle in order to better understand the situation.
Which of the following describes how they could conduct a simulation to estimate how many people on average they would need to contact before finding $5$ who never recycle (let us assume people will be honest about their recycling habits)?

choices.text: Assign the digits $0$ and $1$ to represent people who never recycle. Assign the digits $2$, $3$, $4$, $5$, $6$ and $7$ to represent people who sometimes/always recycle. Looking at a line of the random digit table, go through digit by digit until you have encountered a total of five $0$'s or $1$'s. Count how many total digits you had to go through (ignoring the digits $8$ and $9$) to accomplish this. Record this number. Repeat this process many times and then calculate the average from your simulations.

Assign the digits $01$ through $25$ to represent people who never recycle. Assign the digits $26$ through $100$ to represent people who sometimes/always recycle. Beginning at any line of the random digit table, go through two digits at a time until you have encountered a total of five pairs in the interval from $01$ to $25$. Count how many total pairs you had to go through in order to accomplish this. Record this number. Repeat this process many times and then calculate the average from your simulations.

Assign the digits $00$ through $24$ to represent people who never recycle. Assign the digits $25$ through $99$ to represent people who sometimes/always recycle. Beginning at any line of the random digit table, go through two digits at a time until you have encountered a total of five pairs in the interval from $00$ to $24$. Count how many total pairs you had to go through in order to accomplish this. This number will represent your answer.

Assign the numbers $1$ through $25$ to represent people who never recycle. Assign the numbers $26$ through $100$ to represent people who sometimes/always recycle. Use a computer to randomly generate $100$ sets of $5$ numbers. Count the number of sets that contain $5$ numbers in the interval from $1$ to $25$. Record this number. Repeat this process many times and then calculate the proportion of simulations that resulted in $5$ numbers in the interval from $1$ to $25$.
All of the above describe appropriate ways to conduct the simulation.

title: Recessive Trait
question_text:
A genealogist reads a recently published study that claims only $0.5\%$ of people have a certain recessive trait. The genealogist is intrigued after reading the article and decides to do their own research. Once they received many random samples of patients' genes, they begin testing for the recessive trait. During the first three trials, the genealogist finds that all three have the recessive trait.
If the $0.5\%$ is actually true, what is the most likely explanation for this scenario?

choices.text: The three positives were randomly chosen first, and most of, if not all, the rest will not have the trait
The sample includes all patients that have the recessive trait
The testing mechanism must be flawed
The recessive trait must be more common than the study states
The collection method from the sample is confounded with the lab results.

solution:
When researchers begin to look at data, they understand that there will always be some variation, especially when the data is collected randomly. Simply because the data that is collected displays a pattern at some point in the research, does not imply that data is not random.

In this case, we know the researcher collected many random samples. And while the percent that should have the recessive trait is $0.5\%$, the researcher gets three positives in the first three trials. As stated in the question, we know that the $0.5\%$ is true, meaning that the researcher more than likely examined the few positive cases in the sample first, and that many after the initial three will end up being negative.

Choice 'A' is correct.

The next round consists of $4$ games and the round after that consists of $2$ games. Finally a winner is determined in a single game between $2$ teams.
If Jordan is correct and either team is equally likely to win a game, what is the probability of correctly selecting the winner of every game in the tournament by selecting the winning teams randomly?

title: Homework Days
question_text:
Mr. Anderson is a first-year AP Statistics teacher. He doesn't want to collect homework everyday but still wants to make sure his students do their homework nightly. He devises a plan to use a random number generator, using the numbers $1-10$, on the day that homework is due that says if the number generated is even, he will collect the homework. If the number generated is odd, he will not collect the homework. He will use this process throughout the whole semester.
Mr. Anderson believes that since half the numbers are even, he will be guaranteed that students will turn in half the assignments throughout the year. Is Mr. Anderson correct?

choices.text: No - because probability relies on randomness and can't be guaranteed
No - because the random number generator will not select $10$ because it has two digits.
Yes - because half of the numbers are even and half are odd
Yes - because the random number generator will make sure that $50\%$ of the numbers are even and $50\%$ are odd
Yes - because the number of assignments is so large, that the percent is guaranteed to be $50\%$

solution:
When dealing with randomness and probability, it is important to note that probability is unpredictable in the short run, but in the long run $approaches$ a pattern. This does not necessarily imply that it is guaranteed to be a certain percentage, or observations, even though we have enough trials.

So when Mr. Anderson believes that his random number generator will guarantee him that half of the assignments will be turned in, he is not correct. Even though the probability of having the students turn in their assignment is $50\%$, probability is never a guarantee and the overall percentage at the end will be left up to fate!

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: All Boys and Girls
question_text:
Pete is doing an experiment at his research facility. He gets $50$ volunteers to be a part of the study, $25$ males and $25$ females. He will flip a coin to randomly assign the treatments to the subjects. When he randomly assigned the subjects to the treatments, group $1$ contained all $25$ males, while group $2$ contained all $25$ females.
Pete believes his coin must be defective. Is Pete correct?

choices.text: Yes, there's a $0\%$ chance all males and females would be in separate groups.
Yes, we are guaranteed to have at least one male and one female in each group.
Yes, we should have gotten approximately half males and half females in each group.
No, because patterns in data do not necessarily mean that the variation is not random.
No, since it's a $50-50$ split, we would expect all males in one group and all females in the other.

solution:
When introducing statistics, it is important to examine random and non-random patterns. Patterns in data will help us answer questions about a set of data. Even when data seems to be random or non-random, the presence of a pattern does not imply a random or non-random pattern.

Even though the groups ended up being all males and all females, since the researcher used a chance process, the groups are still considered to be random. Albeit a small probability, but using a chance process can still lead to non-random looking groups.

Choice 'D' is correct.

choices.text: Trial $1$

solution:
When using a chance device to determine randomness it is important to realize that each roll is not affected by previous rolls. This means that one each roll, each side of the six-sided number cube is equally likely to occur. Additionally, just because there seems to be a pattern in my data does not imply that the outcomes were random.

In this case, just because the number cube repeats itself, or seems to follow a pattern, does not mean that the outcomes are less random then if they do not follow a pattern. Therefore, since all trials used the same number cube, all outcomes are equally random.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Repeated Testing
question_text:
During a professional football season, athletes are routinely and randomly screen for performance enhancing drugs (PEDs). Each week, five players from each team will be randomly selected using a chance process to be tested for PEDs. One football player is confused on why he has been "randomly" selected five weeks in a row.
What is the player misinformed about?

choices.text: Randomly means that he should be selected every week
He is being targeted by the league for PED usage
Random means every player has an equal chance of being selected each week.
The chance process used to select players is broken
Since they select five players a week, he should expect to be selected five weeks in a row.

solution:
Random variation is a topic that is often misunderstood. Many people believe that if an outcome occurs using a chance process, that the outcome can no longer happen, even if it has a probability of doing so. Using a completely random chance process implies that each individual has an equally likely chance of being selected every time the process is used.

In this case, the football players selected for testing as selected using a chance process. Therefore, every player has an equally likely chance of being selected each week. Therefore, even though the probability could be relatively small, the athlete that was selected five weeks in a row simply was due to randomness, not anything nefarious.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Simulating the Game of Craps
question_text:
The game of Craps is a casino game in which a player rolls a pair of $6$-sided dice. On the first roll of the dice, if the sum is $7$ or $11$, it is called a “natural” and the player wins. Sierra wants to try the game but wonders what the probability of a “natural” is.
Unfortunately, she is really bad at probability so she programs her computer to simulate $10,000$ tosses of a pair of dice and use the results to calculate the probability of a “natural”.
Which of the following would Sierra most likely conclude as a result of this simulation? Why?

choices.text: Sierra will conclude that the probability of a “natural” is $0.001$. Although the true probability is $0.03$, $10,000\text{ simulations}$ is not a sufficiently large number to predict the true probability with any degree of accuracy.

Sierra will conclude that the probability of a “natural” is $0.04$. The true probability is $0.06$ but $10,000\text{ simulations}$ is not a sufficiently large number to predict the true probability with reasonable accuracy.

Sierra will conclude that the probability of a “natural” is $0.080$ because $10,000\text{ simulations}$ is a sufficiently large number to predict the true probability with reasonable accuracy and the true probability is $0.083$.

Sierra will conclude that the probability of a “natural” is $0.113$ because $10,000\text{ simulations}$ is a sufficiently large number to predict the true probability with reasonable accuracy and the true probability is $0.111$.

Sierra will conclude that the probability of a “natural” is $0.221$ because $10,000\text{ simulations}$ is a sufficiently large number to predict the true probability with reasonable accuracy and the true probability is $0.222$.

title: Combining Standard Deviations: Spinner
question_text:

title: Coin Toss Game
question_text:
Two friends are playing a game where you toss a fair two-sided coin. When it is your turn, you flip the coin once and record your result. Then, to keep playing you flip the coin until you no longer match your initial flip.
Player $A$ flips "tails" $10$ straight times. Player $B$ gets upset and thinks the coin is rigged. Player $A$ states that since it's a random chance device, the side is not pre-determined.
Is Player $A$ correct?

choices.text: Yes - But the coin will most likely flip $10$ "heads" on the next ten flips.
Yes - although improbable, since it's a random chance device, a pattern does not imply the data is not random.
No - 10 "Tails" in a row is impossible and the coin is rigged.
No - Since there's only two outcomes, you would be guaranteed 5 "heads" and 5 "tails" on the 10 flips.
No - Because "tails" never fails, therefore since he went first the probability of "tails" is greater.

solution:
A coin is a great example of a chance device as it has two equal outcomes with the same probability. Flipping a coin will result in either a "heads" outcome or a "tails" outcome.

When we examine the data from a chance device, it is important to note that fact that simply because there is a pattern in the data, this does not imply that the data is not random. On each flip, the coin still have an equally likely chance to land on "heads" or "tails", therefore it is theoretically possible to have 10
"tails" in a row.

Choice 'B' is correct.

p(ace or red card) $=\dfrac{4}{52}+ \dfrac{26}{52}=\dfrac{30}{52}$

p(ace or jack) $=\dfrac{4}{13}+ \dfrac{4}{13}=\dfrac{8}{13}$

p(ace or king) $=\dfrac{4}{52}+ \dfrac{4}{52}=\dfrac{8}{52}$

Find the probability of picking a spade or a black card.
p(spade or black card) $=\dfrac{13}{52}+ \dfrac{26}{52}=\dfrac{39}{52}$

Find the probability of picking an ace or a heart.
p(ace or heart) $=\dfrac{4}{52}+ \dfrac{13}{52}=\dfrac{17}{52}$

title: Drive to School

title: Student Body President
question_text:
Suppose $52\%$ of a high school student body support a certain candidate for school body president. The statistics teacher is going to take samples of $100$ random students and ask who they support for student body president.
Which proportion is not a realistic answer if $52\%$ of the school truly supports the candidate?

choices.text: All options given are realistic proportions

solution:
If the proportion of the school that supports the candidate is truly $0.52$, this does not imply that every sample taken by the teacher will produce a proportion of students who support the candidate will always be $0.52$. This is due to the fact of sampling variability.

Therefore, we do not know what each sample will produce as a proportion, but it is likely to be around $0.52$. Since all the options given are near $0.52$, all the options given are realistic proportions for each sample.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Flight Delays
question_text:
Air travel can be very frustrating when flights don't leave on time! Over the last $5\text{ months}$, $15\%$ of Be Free Airline flights were delayed. For the same time period, $20\%$ of Fly Me Away Airline flights were delayed.
In the process of investigating the difference between the two airlines, a consumer's group randomly selects $80\text{ flights}$ from each company during this time period and finds the proportion of flights that were delayed for each. They calculate the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the difference between these two proportions. Their calculations are shown below:
$${ \sigma }_{ { p }_{ B }-{ p }_{ F } }=\sqrt { \dfrac { (0.15)(0.85) }{ 80 } } +\sqrt { \dfrac { (0.20)(0.80) }{ 80 } } =0.085$$
Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: The calculation should use the delayed flight proportions from the two samples instead of the true proportions of delayed flights.
These two distributions should not be combined because they don't come from two independent samples.
The two samples should be combined into one large sample before computing the standard deviation.

The consumer organization added the standard deviation of the Be Free proportion to the standard deviation of the Fly Me Away proportion. Instead it should first add the variances from the two distributions, then take the square root: ${ \sigma }_{ { p }_{ B }-{ p }_{ F } }=\sqrt { \frac { (0.15)(0.85) }{ 80 } +\frac { (0.20)(0.80) }{ 80 } } =0.06$
The consumer's group calculated the standard deviation correctly.

title: Apple Picking
question_text:
A couple decides to go to an apple orchard to pick some apples. After searching the orchard for the best looking apples, they decide to pick $10$ apples from a single tree. When they go to pay, they figure out the average weight of each apple is $75$ grams.
Can the couple speculate that the average size of the apples from the farm is $75$ grams?

choices.text: Yes, since they selected $10$ apples, they can safely assume the average weight of all the apples on the farm is $75$ grams.
Yes, because all samples of $10$ apples will produce a mean weight of $75$ grams.
Yes, since the apples are random, we can safely assume the mean will be $75$ grams for all samples of size $10$
No, due to sampling variability, not all samples of size $10$ will have a mean of $75$ grams
No, because the Large Counts Condition is not met

solution:
As stated in the problem, the couple selected a sample of $10$ random apples from a tree. Due to the fact of Sampling Variability, not all samples of size $10$ are guaranteed to have a mean of $75$ grams. Some samples will produce a mean that is greater, while some will produce a mean that is less.

Therefore, not all samples of size $10$ will result in a mean weight of $75$ grams.

Choice 'D' is correct.

question_text:

title: The Polls

What is the probability that City $2$ can show the candidate ahead by at least $3\%$ over City $1$? Round to the nearest whole percent.

title: Gone Fish Samplin'
question_text:
A large pond in rural Vermont with thousands of fish has an established proportion of $ 40 \%$ native brown trout. April of $2019$ brought severe weather with tornadoes and massive flash floods, during which much of the natural features in the area were disturbed. If Wes sampled $20$ fish, the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of $\hat{p}$ would be larger than if he had sampled $30$ fish.

Under which circumstance can Taylor assume that the sampling distribution of average weight of a sample of $12$ eggs is approximately Normal?

The population of $40{,}000$ eggs is skewed left

title: Bamboo Gains
question_text:

If this process were repeated over and over, we would expect to see a difference in sample means of $1.5$ or less only $0.7\%$ of the time.

Waldo purchased $12$ snack-sized bags of this fruit-flavored candy and found that the average weight of these bags was $63\text{ grams}$.
Does Waldo have reason to believe he was cheated?
Calculate the probability of obtaining a sample mean less than or equal to $63\text{ grams}$.

choices.text: The conditions for using the normal model are not met in this situation.

II. $np$ and $n (1-p)$ must both be greater than or equal to $10$, where $n$ is the sample size and $p$ is the proportion of success.
III. The sample size must be over $30$.

Assuming the lawns are randomly selected, find the probability of coming across $5\text{ lawns}$ that average more than $5\text{ inches}$ long in this neighborhood.

question_text:

title: Probability Greater Calorie Savings

What is the probability that their average calorie savings is equal to or greater than $600\text{ calories}$ when John and Mary both opt for the healthier alternative?

title: Getting in Shape
question_text:
The population of cyclists in a large city is skewed right and has a known mean weight of $\mu_c=160$ pounds and a standard deviation of $\sigma_c=7.8$ pounds. In the same city, the population of runners is skewed right and has a known mean weight of $\mu_r=150$ pounds with a standard deviation of $\sigma_r=8.1$pounds.
A study recorded the weight of individuals who participated weekly in only one of the aforementioned activities. Included in the study were $50$ cyclists, and $40$ runners.
What is the shape of the sampling distribution of the difference in mean weight of cyclists and runners in the large city?

Skewed Left
Approximately Normal

title: Voter Participation
question_text:
A political polling company wants to know what percent of a particular city’s population votes in a general election.
A week before the election, the company asks $100$ registered voters if they intend to cast a ballot, and $72\%$ of them say yes. Three days after the election, city officials state that $67\%$ of registered voters cast ballots during the election.
What can be said about the two percentages?

choices.text: $72\%$ is a statistic; $67\%$ is a parameter.
$72\%$ is a parameter; $67\%$ is a statistic.
$72\%$ and $67\%$ are both statistics.
$72\%$ and $67\%$ are both parameters.
Without information about the standard deviations, one cannot say with certainty that either of these percentages is a statistic or a parameter.

title: Different Means
question_text:
Jayla is trying to estimate the average GPA at her high school. Her counselor gives her an anonymous list of students and their GPA values. Jayla takes an initial sample of 25 students and finds a mean GPA of $2.45$. Jayla then decides to take a second sample to check her work, and selects a second sample of $25$ students. Jayla is surprised when the mean GPA for the second sample was $2.65$.
What is the best explanation as to why the sample means for the average GPA at her high school were different?

choices.text: The samples were different because of sampling variability.
Jayla most likely made a mistake when selecting the second sample.
There is likely bias in the second sample.
Jayla found the median of the data, instead of the mean for the second sample.
The counselors list must have been incomplete or incorrect.

solution:
When selecting samples of the same size, $n$, the samples will rarely result in statistics that are the same. This is the definition of sampling variability. Therefore, when taking samples of the same size, $n$, the sample means will most likely not be the same value.

So, Jayla, in fact did nothing wrong. The differences in the sample means are most likely due to the fact of sampling variability.

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: Robbie's Red Cards
question_text:
A standard deck of playing cards is made up of $26\text{ red cards}$ and $26\text{ black cards}$. Robbie obtains $5$ identical decks of cards. He shuffles and deals a card and records its color. He replaces the card in the deck and repeats this process $25\text{ times}$, obtaining $10\text{ red cards}$ and $15\text{ black cards}$ - only $40\%$ red!
Robbie wonders if the stack of cards has an unusually small proportion of red cards.
What is the probability of obtaining a sample proportion less than or equal to $0.4$?

choices.text: The conditions for using the normal model are not met in this situation.

title: Which is More Random?
question_text:
Two students are working on a project in AP Statistics. The students are taking random samples of size $n = 100$ from a population with a known mean of $\mu = 10$. The students sample means are given below:
Student Mean
$1$ $\mu_1 = 9.5$
$2$ $\mu_2 = 10$
Each student is claiming their sample was "more random". Which student is correct?
tables:
StudentMean
$1$$\mu_1 = 9.5$
$2$$\mu_2 = 10$

choices.text: Student $1$ - Because their mean was close to the population mean, but did not equal the population mean exactly
Student $1$ - Because student $2$'s mean was a whole number, which is very uncommon
Student $2$ - Because their sample mean equaled the known population mean
Student $2$ - Because Student $1$'s mean was not a whole number
Both sample were equally random because different samples taken from the sample population can be different

solution:
When selecting a sample from a population, with or without a known population mean, it is important to remember that differences between the samples can exist. This idea is called sampling variability. All sample of size $100$ will not produce the same sample mean.

Therefore, since both students took random samples of size $100$, both of the samples would be considered equally "random", even if one sample produced the a sample mean that was equal to the population mean.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Roll of Two Dice
question_text:
Two friends are playing a board game. One friend decides to find the mean of the sum of his last three rolls. His $3$ rolls are shown below:
$3$ Rolls: $8, 7, 6$ for a mean sum of $7$.
Is this friend's next three rolls guaranteed to be equal to $7$?

choices.text: No, because rolling $2$ dice produces random sums
No, because $8, 7$ & $6$ have been rolled and can't be rolled again
No, because a sum of $7$ has a probability of $\frac{1}{6}$, so it won't happen for $5$ more turns
Yes, because the mean will always be $7$ as it's the most likely outcome
Yes, because we divide by $3$ the mean will always be $7$

solution:
Since rolling two dice represent a chance model, the sum produced when rolling two dice will be random on each turn. For example, since each number on each die has a $\frac{1}{6}$ probability of showing on each roll, each sum has it's own probability. Therefore the sums will not always average out to be $7$.

The players next roll is not guaranteed to have an average of $7$, and in fact can be any number from $2-12$.

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: Applying Normal Approximation
question_text:
Someone determined that $53\%$ of houses are painted white in a given large town.
Supposing a random sample of $2{,}000\text{ houses}$ were selected, what is the probability that less than half of these houses are painted white?

title: Wrens or Hens?
question_text: In their baseball league, near the end of the season, the Wrens were to play the Hens. The Wrens had averaged $8.2$ runs per game with a standard deviation of $3.0$ runs during the season. The Hens averaged $5.4$ runs per game with a standard deviation of $2.5$ runs during the season. Each team had played $112$ games thus far. Now that they will play each other, what is the probability that the Wrens will beat the Hens by at least $3$ runs? Round to the nearest percent.

title: Estimating Parameters: Free Throws
question_text:
Suppose an athlete shoots $200\text{ free throws}$ and makes $160$ of them.
Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: This athlete is an $80\%$ free-throw shooter.
A sample of $100\text{ free throws}$ would be more effective in estimating the athlete’s true free-throw percentage.
The athlete’s true free-throw percentage is probably somewhere near $80\%$.
The athlete could easily make fewer than $100\text{ free throws}$ in the next set of $200\text{ free throw attempts}$.
No reasonable conclusions can be drawn from this data.

title: Three Potato, Four
question_text:
A large grocery store chain regularly receives shipments of potatoes from two main suppliers. The Potent Potato Company sends potatoes that come in sacks that weigh an average of $6.2$ pounds with a standard deviation of $2.8$ pounds. The Portly Potato Company sends sacks of potatoes that weigh an average of $5.7$ pounds with a standard deviation of $3.1$ pounds. The grocery store wants to compare the potatoes coming from the two companies so a random sample of $24$ potato sacks was taken from Potent Potato and a random sample of $32$ sacks was taken from Portly Potato.
Could the analyst then proceed to find the probability that the potato sacks from one company weigh more than the potato sacks from the other company? Why?

choices.text:
Yes.
Though we do not know that the potato distributions are normally distributed, at least one sample size is greater than or equal to $30$, so it is okay to proceed.

Yes.
We can because both samples are random samples.

Yes.
We checked it out with both the Potent and Portly Potato companies and found that the sample numbers were less than $10\%$ of the population size.

No.
Since we know that both sample sizes must be greater than or equal to $30$, and that of Potent Potato was only $24$, we cannot continue with our calculations.

No.
We needed to be given the parameters for the differences of the sampling distributions.

title: The Central Limit Theorem

The average salary of a large number of real estate agents has a distribution with a similar shape (but not as strongly skewed) as the population distribution.
The average salary of a large number of real estate agents has a distribution that is close to Normal.
The average salary of a large number of real estate agents has a distribution that is exactly Normal.

title: AP Prep Course
question_text:
Suppose at a large high school, the average AP test score for AP Statistics is $2.84$ with a standard deviation of $0.45$.
The school decided to offer nightly study sessions and randomly chose $30$ students to participate. These $30$ students averaged AP scores of $3.1$.

Nothing, since the sample size is too small to develop any reasonable conclusions.
The students in the study sessions did not perform much better than their peers; their effort is only $0.58$ standard deviations above the mean of their peers.
These students performed much better than their peers; their results are $3.16$ standard deviations above the mean of their peers.
While this study shows that these $30$ students did better than their peers, it would have been more effective to compare these students’ scores to the national AP average.

question_text: The mean of a sampling distribution can be considered an unbiased estimate of $\mu$ when...
