variability is uncertain at first but gets smaller as $n$ increases.
a sample mean and population mean $\mu$ are equal.
the expected value of the sample mean equals the population mean $\mu$.
its expected value changes as the sample size n increases.

title: Roughly Normal
question_text: A binomial distribution will be approximately normal if

choices.text: The sample size is at least $30$.
Each trial is independent.
$n(P)$ and $n(1-P)$ are both over $10$, where $n$ is the number of trials and $P$ is the probability of success.
The population is at least $10$ times the sample size.
Each trial has the same probability.

title: Sampling Distribution of Sample Prop: Get Off Social Media, Mom!
question_text:
A recent survey in the town of Pleasantville found that $55\%$ of the adults had a social media account. The true percentage of adults that have a social media account in Pleasantville is $58\%$.
Using simple random samples of size $100$, what are the mean and standard deviation respectively, for the sampling distribution of the sample proportions of adults who own a social media account in Pleasantville?

title: When Does the CLT Apply?
question_text:
Each answer choice describes the shape of the population distribution and the sample size, $n$ for a sampling distribution.
We are not assured of a nearly normal sampling distribution for which choice?

choices.text: Nearly normal population distribution; $n = 12$
Bimodal population distribution; $n = 37$
Nearly normal population distribution; $n = 48$
Skewed left population distribution; $n = 83$
Bimodal population distribution; $n = 5$

title: Statistic or Parameter
question_text:
Mr. Jones works in a large high school and wants to determine the average grade of all the biology students. Mr. Jones found the average grade in his biology class ($n = 30$) was $80.2$. This compares to the school-wide average of $77.3$.
Which of the value is a statistic and which is a parameter?

choices.text: Statistic: $80.2$; parameter: $77.3$
Statistic: $77.3$; parameter: $80.2$
Both $80.2$ and $77.3$ are statistics.
Both $80.2$ and $77.3$ are parameters.
Parameter: $80.2$; $77.3$ is neither a statistic nor a parameter.

title: Biased and Unbiased Estimators
question_text: A poll was recently taken asking local citizens about their opinions on the mayor's recent speech. A random sample of $200$ local citizens was taken. If, instead of randomly sampling $200$ citizens, $500$ citizens were sampled, which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: The increased sample size will reduce the bias of the poll result.
The increased sample size will reduce the variability of the poll result.
The increased sample size will reduce the effect of nonresponse on the poll.
The increased sample size will reduce the variability of the opinions.
The increased sample size will be less accurate when representing the opinions of the entire city.

title: Phone Numbers | 1 of 2
question_text:
A statistics teacher collected data on the last digit of her $50$ students’ home or cell phone numbers.
She remarked that the results were very similar to choosing $50$ digits from a random digits table. The mean $\mu$ from this distribution was $4.5$, and the standard deviation $\sigma$ was $2.87$.
She then had her students take all possible samples of size $4$ (a daunting task!) from the $50$ pieces of collected data and compute the mean for each sample. They graphed the sample means and calculated the new mean and standard deviation.
What did the graph look like, and what were the values of the new mean and standard deviation?

choices.text:
Shape: discrete uniform
Mean: $4.5$
Standard deviation: $2.87$

Shape: discrete uniform
Mean: $4.5$
Standard deviation: $1.44$

Shape: a unimodal and symmetric histogram
Mean: $4.5$
Standard deviation: $2.87$

Shape: a unimodal and symmetric histogram
Mean: $4.5$
Standard deviation: $1.44$

Shape: normal curve
Mean: $4.5$
Standard deviation: $1.44$

title: Men's and Women's Cholesterol Levels
question_text:
Having a cholesterol level above $200\text{ mg/dL}$ is a definite cause for concern. Do women have more reason to be concerned than men?
On average, men's cholesterol level is $191\text{ mg/dL}$ with a standard deviation of $46\text{ mg/dL}$. For women, the average is $196\text{ mg/dL}$ with a standard deviation of $44\text{ mg/dL}$.
A computer randomly selects the medical records of $30\text{ men}$ and $30\text{ women}$ and calculates the difference of the average cholesterol level of the two genders. This process is repeated many times.
What is the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the difference of the mean cholesterol levels for men and women?

choices.text: ${ \sigma }_{ { \overline { x } }_{ M }-{ \overline { x } }_{ W } }=\sqrt { \dfrac { 46 }{ 30 } +\dfrac { 44 }{ 30 } }$
${ \sigma }_{ { \overline { x } }_{ M }-{ \overline { x } }_{ W } }=\sqrt { \dfrac { { 46 }^{ 2 } }{ 30 } } +\sqrt { \dfrac { { 44 }^{ 2 } }{ 30 } }$

title: Golf Darts
question_text:
Golf darts are played in a large field that has several targets made out of net. If the player hits the ball and it lands in one of the nets, the player scores points and the golf ball is automatically sent back to the player through an underground tunnel system. If the golf ball does not land in the net, it stays on the field where it is later picked up by a tractor system.
Suppose the true proportion of golf balls that land on the field each day is $60\%$. What are the mean and standard deviation of the sample proportion of golf balls that land on the field when samples of $100$ golf balls are shot?

title: Text Messages
question_text:
A teacher has his students record the number of text messages they send and receive for one month. The class then puts together a list of all the amounts of text messages to create a population with a known mean and standard deviation. The teacher then has the students randomly select samples of size $5$ and finds an average amount of text messages sent for a group of $5$ students.
Three students make the following claims:
I. All the samples of size $5$ are independent of each other
II. The distribution of all the samples means will be approximately normal
III. The samples means will vary from the population mean, and random samples will produce random results
Which statements are true?

choices.text: I only
I and II only
II and III only
I and III only
I, II, and III are all correct

solution:
When we take samples of the same size from the same population with a known mean there are a few characteristics that we know. We know that each sample of size, $n$, ($n = 5$ in this problem) are independent from each other. Meaning, that knowing the results from one sample does not affect the results of the other sample.

Additionally, we know that each random sample of size $n$ will produce a random value for the mean. This value will most likely be different from the known population mean, even though it could equal the population mean, and these values will often be different from each other.

Regarding the shape, since we do not know how many students are in the class, we do not know the number of samples taken from the population. Additionally, since the population has unknown shape, we cannot say anything about the shape of the distribution of sample means.

Therefore, only statements I and III are correct.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Pick a Hotel
question_text: Great Eastern Hotels reported an average stay of $4.8$ nights with a standard deviation of $2.8$ nights, while Motel Seven reported an average stay of $2.2$ nights with a standard deviation of $1.7$ nights. Random samples of $45$ hotels from each hotel chain were taken by a company that was hired to answer the question: "What is the probability that the average stay at a Motel Seven is $3$ nights or less than an average stay at a Great Eastern Hotel?" What is that answer? Round your answer to the nearest percent.

title: Statistically Significant
question_text:
If an experiment yields results that are statistically significant, this means the results
I. Are from a well-designed experiment.
II. Are unlikely to happen by chance.
III. Are practically important.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
II and III only.

title: Accounting for Differences: Gun Control
question_text:
Suppose a local group in support of tighter gun restrictions gives a nationwide survey to $200$ randomly chosen subjects.
The question they asked was “Do you favor increased gun control?” In the survey, $66\%$ of respondents said yes, compared to the national average of $64\%$.
How might a statistician explain this difference ($64\%$ vs. $66\%$) to the group?

choices.text: The sample of $200$ subjects was too small to come up with any credible comparisons to the population proportion of $64\%$.
Since the sample was conducted by a group that supports tighter gun control, it is probable the poll sampled people who would be more likely to support their cause.
Since the sample was conducted by a group that supports tighter gun control, it is likely the question was worded in a confusing or biased manner.
Since the group who conducted the survey was local, the respondents might have the opinions of this area, but not necessarily the opinions of the entire country.
For samples of size $200$, sampling variability exists where samples can easily be $1\%-3\%$ off the true population proportion.

title: High School Drivers
question_text:
In a large metropolitan area, the proportion of high school seniors who drive to school at least $3\text{ days a week}$ is $0.45$. A random sample of $25\text{ students}$ is chosen.
How would you calculate the probability that at least $13$ of these students drive to school at least $3\text{ days a week}$?

choices.text:
Use the multiplication rule for probabilities for the following item from the sample space, where $D$ = drives and $N$ = does not drive:
$DDDDDDDDDDDDDNNNNNNNNNNNN$
Calculate the binomial probability on a calculator using $\mu = 11.25$, $\sigma = 6.19$, and $X \ge 13$.
Use the normal approximation to the binomial because the sample size is large.
Use the binomial formula for $n = 25$, $X = 13$, and $p = 0.45$.
Use the normal approximation to the binomial because $np \ge 10$ and $n(1-p) \ge 10$.

title: Unusual Sample Proportion?
question_text:
Four of the choices below describe the population proportion and the sample size for a sampling distribution for proportions.
$0.27$ as a sample proportion would be most unusual for which sampling distribution?

choices.text:
Population proportion $= 0.26$
Sample size $= 50$

Population proportion $= 0.26$
Sample size $= 100$

Population proportion $= 0.30$
Sample size $= 50$

Population proportion $= 0.30$
Sample size $= 100$
This cannot be determined since none of the answer choices would have a nearly normal sampling distribution.

title: $p$-value Interpretation
question_text:
A study reported that the proportion of college students who experience heart palpitations after drinking an energy drink is $0.18$. The dean of a university believes that the proportion of students at his university who experience heart palpitations after drinking an energy drink is less than $0.18$. The dean randomly sampled students from the university who had just had an energy drink and found that $16\%$ of them had experienced heart palpitations.
All conditions for inference were met, and the $p$-value for the appropriate hypothesis test was $0.30$. Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the $p$-value?

choices.text: The probability that the alternative hypothesis is true is $0.30$.
The probability that the null hypothesis is true is $0.30$.
If the proportion of students who experience heart palpitations at the university is $18\%$, then the probability of observing results of at most $16\%$ is $0.30$.
If the proportion of students who experience heart palpitations at the university is $18\%$, then the probability of observing results of at least $16\%$ is $0.30$.
The probability of observing $16\%$ of students who experience heart palpitations at this university is $0.30$.

title: Rejecting a Null Hypothesis: Steak or Chicken
question_text:
A waitress wanted to find out if there was a significant difference in the proportion of her male customers to female customers that ordered the steak dinner instead of the chicken dinner. Over the course of the month, she randomly selected $60$ male and $60$ female customers and recorded which dinner they ordered. She calculated a $95\%$ confidence interval and found that the true difference in the proportion of male customers to female customers who ordered the steak dinner over the chicken dinner was between $7\%$ to $12\%$.
Based on the confidence interval, do you think that the difference in the proportion of male customers who ordered the steak over the chicken compared to the female customers is statistically significant at the $5\%$ level (assume all of the conditions are met)?

choices.text: Yes; since $0\%$ is in this confidence interval, the waitress fails to reject the null hypothesis at the $5\%$ level. She concludes that there is insufficient evidence that there is adifference in the proportion of male customers that prefer the steak dinner over the chicken dinner than the female customers.

Yes; since $0\%$ is in this confidence interval, the waitress rejects the null hypothesis at the $5\%$ level. She concludes that there is sufficient evidence that there is a difference in the proportion of male customers that prefer the steak dinner over the chicken dinner than the female customers.

Yes; since $0\%$ is outside this confidence interval, the waitress rejects the null hypothesis at the $5\%$ level. She concludes that there is sufficient evidence that there is a difference in the proportion of male customers that prefer the steak dinner over the chicken dinner than the female customers.

No; since $0\%$ is outside this confidence interval, the waitress fails to reject the null hypothesis at the $5\%$ level. She concludes that there is sufficient evidence that there is a difference in the proportion of male customers that prefer the steak dinner over the chicken dinner than the female customers.

No; since $0\%$ is outside this confidence interval, the waitress rejects the null hypothesis at the $5\%$ level. She concludes that there is insufficient evidence that there is a difference in the proportion of male customers that prefer the steak dinner over the chicken dinner than the female customers.

title: Say Cheese!
question_text: A company producing packages of cheese needs to make sure that it sells cheese that is fresh. To check the freshness of the cheese, $50$ packages are selected randomly at a time, and the proportion of spoiled packages is assessed. Generally $2\%$ of the packages are spoiled, but it is hoped this percentage can be shown to have decreased. The packages will be tested at a $5\%$ significance level. Which of the following could increase the probability of a Type II Error?

choices.text: The value of the power of the test is increased.
The sample size of the tested packages is increased to 75.
The significance level of the test is lowered to $1\%$.
The standard error of the test is decreased to 0.04.
It is shown that the true parameter is farther away from the current value of 0.02.

title: Healthy Teeth | 1 of 2
question_text:
Recently a random survey found that $48$ out of $100\text{ college freshmen}$ fail to brush their teeth twice a day. This compares higher than the national average of $39\%$.
What would be an appropriate interval at $99\%$ confidence to estimate the true proportion of college freshmen who do not brush their teeth twice daily?

title: Which is the Correct Way to Go?
question_text: Two baseball fans were arguing as to which was the better hitting team. One fan claimed his team was better because of $50$ randomly selected seasons over the past $100$ years, his team batted higher than $0.250$ in $30$ of those seasons. The other fan said of $40$ randomly selected seasons over the past $100$ years, in $28$ of those seasons her team batted higher than $0.250.$ Given this information, which of the following statistical methods is an appropriate way to compare these two teams?

choices.text: Use a 2-sample t-interval interval for the difference between population means.
Use a one-sample t-test of significance for a population mean.
Use a one-sample z-interval to examine a population proportion.
Use a 2-sample z-interval interval for the difference between population proportions.
Carry out a chi-square test for goodness of fit.

title: Situations for a One Proportion Z Test
question_text: In which of the following situations would it be appropriate to use a one-proportion Z-test?

choices.text: Determine whether males are more likely to vote Republican than females are.
Determine if a political candidate will get at least $50\%$ of the vote in an upcoming election.
Determine if an association exists between favorite type of music and socioeconomic status.
Determine the proportion of people who prefer Coke over Pepsi in a blind taste test.
Determine if students who study on a regular basis score higher on the ACT than their peers who do not study on a regular basis.

title: Convertibles: Conclusions from a Confidence Interval
question_text:
In order to plan a new advertising campaign, a marketing firm wants to know whether men in a certain area of the country are more likely to purchase a convertible than women in that same area. To gather data, they took a random sample of men and a random sample of women who had recently purchased a new vehicle and then determined both the proportion of men and the proportion of women who had purchased a convertible. A $90\%$ confidence interval for the difference in the proportion of men vs. women who purchased a convertible was found to be $(-0.021, 0.115)$.
Based on this confidence interval should the marketing firm conclude that the proportion of men who purchase a convertible is higher than the proportion of women who purchase a convertible?

choices.text: Yes. Most of the confidence interval consists of positive values which show that the proportion of men who purchase a convertible is greater than the proportion of women who purchase a convertible.
Yes. The proportion of women who purchase a convertible was estimated to be $0.021$ while the proportion of men who purchase a convertible was estimated to be $0.115$.
Yes. The difference in proportions of men and women who purchased a convertible was $0.047$ and this value is well above $0$.
No. Since $0$ is included in the confidence interval, there may be no difference in the proportion of men and the proportion of women who purchase a convertible.

No. The proportion of men who purchase a convertible was estimated to be $0.021$ while the proportion of women who purchase a convertible was estimated to be $0.115$. It actually appears that the proportion of women who purchase a convertible is higher than the proportion of men who purchase a convertible.

title: Power and Type II Error
question_text:
A significance test was conducted using a two-sided alternate hypothesis and a significance level of $\alpha=0.05$. The power of the test was calculated to be $0.92$.

Which of the following gives the probability of making a type II error on this test?

title: Determining a $p$-Value
question_text:
A group of college students in a psychology class wonders if the order of treatments changes the outcome of a study.
To test this, they ask students in a blind taste test which of two colas they prefer, Pepsi or Coke. In this blind taste test, the first $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Pepsi and then Coke, with $34$ preferring Pepsi. The next $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Coke and then Pepsi, with $29$ preferring Pepsi.
Does this give evidence that the order in which colas, or options, are presented makes a difference?
Determine the approximate $p$-value of a test to answer this question.

title: Check the Polls
question_text:
National polls for a political candidate were being compared between two different polling companies.
Company $1$ randomly polled $32$ people and found $22$ planning to vote for the candidate.
Company $2$ randomly polled $34$ people and found $31$ planning to vote for the candidate.
A person was commissioned to analyze the results by creating a confidence interval for the difference between the two proportions. Which of the following pairs of checks would fail to verify the conditions for the confidence interval?

choices.text:
$\dfrac{22}{32}\times32$
$\dfrac{31}{34}\times34$

$\dfrac{22}{32}\times32$
Both samples were randomly selected.

title: Those Testing Errors
question_text: A company manufactures television sets. It wants to keep the number of defective sets it makes low and believes that it makes fewer that $1\%$ defective sets. The company tests this claim using a test of proportions with a significance level of $0.05$. The power of the test is $0.80$. Which of the following gives the probability of a Type II error for this test?

title: Take a Tablet
question_text: A company sold two tablet computers: the Earth Tablet and the Air Tablet. The company was looking to investigate whether men or women prefer either tablet. In a random sample of $60$ women, $70\%$ preferred the Earth Tablet. A random sample of $60$ men showed that $50\%$ of them preferred the Earth Tablet. Based on a $99\%$ confidence interval, can we be sure that women prefer the Earth Tablet more than the men? Answer "yes" or "no" and state why.

choices.text:
Yes.
Clearly, $70\%$ is quite a bit greater than $50\%$, so the women prefer the Earth Tablet.

Yes.
We obtain a confidence interval of about $(.03, 0.37)$. Since zero is not included in the interval, we can be sure that the true proportion shows that women prefer the Earth Tablet more than men.

No.
We obtain a confidence interval of about $(-.03, 0.43)$. Since zero is included in the interval, we cannot be $99\%$ sure that the true proportion shows that women prefer the Earth Tablet more than men.

No.
We obtain a confidence interval of about $(.03, 0.37)$. Since zero is not included in the interval, we cannot be sure that the true proportion shows that women prefer the Earth Tablet more than men.

No.
We obtain a confidence interval of about $(.00, 0.40)$. Since zero is at one end of the interval, we cannot be $99\%$ sure that the true proportion shows that women prefer the Earth Tablet more than men.

title: Hypotheses About Young Voters
question_text:
According to media reports, a certain political candidate has a higher rate of support among "young" voters (those age $30$ and under) than "older" voters (those over the age of $30$). A researcher wanted to investigate whether the media reports were true. To gather data, he selected a random sample of $200$ "young" voters and a random sample of $200$ "older" voters and asked if they supported the political candidate.
Which of the following hypotheses could the researcher use to determine if the media claims are true?

choices.text:
${ H }_{ 0 }: \hat { { p }_{ Y } } >0.50 $
The proportion of young voters who support the candidate is greater than $0.50$.
${ H }_{ a }:\hat { { p }_{ O } } <0.50$
The proportion of older voters who support the candidate is less than $0.50$.

${ H }_{ o }: \hat { { p }_{ Y } } =\hat { { p }_{ O } }$
The proportion of "young" voters who support the candidate is equal to the proportion of "older" voters who support the candidate.
${ H }_{ a }:\hat { { p }_{ Y } } <\hat { { p }_{ O } } $
The proportion of "young" voters who support the candidate is less than the proportion of "older" voters who support the candidate.

${ H }_{ o }: { { p }_{ Y } } = { { p }_{ O } }$
The proportion of "young" voters who support the candidate is equal to the proportion of "older" voters who support the candidate.
${ H }_{ a }: { { p }_{ Y } } > { { p }_{ O } } $
The proportion of "young" voters who support the candidate is greater than the proportion of "older" voters who support the candidate.

${ H }_{ o }: { { p }_{ Y } } = { { p }_{ O } }$
The proportion of "young" voters who support the candidate is equal to the proportion of "older" voters who support the candidate.
${ H }_{ a }:{ { p }_{ Y } }\neq { { p }_{ O } } $
The proportion of "young" voters who support the candidate is not equal to the proportion of "older" voters who support the candidate.

${ H }_{ o }: { { \mu}_{ Y } } = { { \mu }_{ O } }$
The mean number of "young" voters who support the candidate is equal to the mean number of "older" voters who support the candidate.
${ H }_{ a }: { { \mu}_{ Y } } > { { \mu}_{ O } } $
The mean number of "young" voters who support the candidate is greater than the mean number of "older" voters who support the candidate.

title: Conditions for 2-sample $z$-test for Proportions
question_text: Which of the following is not a condition necessary for conducting a two-sample $z$-test for proportions?

choices.text: We have a random sample from each of the two populations or from each of two different treatment groups.
The samples are independent of each other.
Each of the two populations is sufficiently larger than their respective sample size.
The total number of observations must be at least $30$ or we must know that the population distribution is approximately normal.
For each population, we expect a sufficient number of successes and a sufficient number of failures.

title: P-value of a 2-sided Test Given z-score
question_text:
A significance test was used to test the null hypothesis ${ H }_{ 0 }$: $p=0.20$ versus the alternative ${ H }_{ a }$: $p≠0.20$. The resulting test statistic is $z=-1.73$.
The p-value for this test is approximately

title: Cereal Games
question_text:
Two top cereal producers were competing with each other by putting game cards in their cereal boxes. Toot Loops cereal claimed that $33\%$ of their boxes contained winning cards and Major Munch cereal claimed that $31\%$ of their boxes contained winning cards. In an attempt to test this, a consumer goods company randomly purchased $60$ boxes of Toot Loops and $55$ boxes of Major Munch cereals.
Find a $99\%$ confidence interval for the difference of the proportions of game cards contained in the boxes of the two kinds of cereal.

title: Hypotheses for Two-Proportions
question_text:
Suppose a recent survey found that $74\%$ of dog owners say their pet appears cheerful, while only $59\%$ of cat owners say their pet appears cheerful.
If one wants to perform a test to see if these two proportions are significantly different, what would the null and alternative hypotheses be?

title: Type II Errors and Snow Days
question_text:
Many school districts in various parts of the country routinely add extra days onto the school calendar to account for the possibility of snow days or other unexpected days off. Ananya has been carefully watching the weather report and sees that the forecast is calling for $6\text{ inches}$ of snow overnight.
Based upon past history, she knows that school will be cancelled if more than $3\text{ inches}$ of snow fall. Therefore, she forms the null hypothesis that there will be no school tomorrow.
In this situation, what would be the meaning and potential consequences of Ananya making a Type II error?

choices.text: Ananya decides that the weather report is wrong yet again. As a result, she stays up late in order to complete her homework and study for the tests that have been scheduled for tomorrow. OOPS! Oh well! It snowed $8\text{ inches}$ and school got cancelled. Now Ananya is wishing that she had slept in!

Ananya decides that the weather report is wrong yet again. As a result, she stays up late in order to complete her homework and study for the tests that have been scheduled for tomorrow. It turns out that she was right. It barely snowed one inch, so school is not cancelled! Although she is a bit tired, Ananya has all of her homework done and is well prepared for the tests that she must take.

Ananya truly believes that tomorrow will be a snow day and that she will get to sleep as late as she wants to in the morning. As a result, she decides not to do her homework or to study for the tests that are on tomorrow's schedule. Thank goodness she was right! School was cancelled and she has another day to complete her homework and study for upcoming tests. Bonus - she got to sleep late!

Ananya truly believes that tomorrow will be a snow day and that she will get to sleep as late as she wants to in the morning. As a result, she decides not to do her homework or to study for the tests that are on tomorrow's schedule. OOPS! It doesn't snow at all and school goes on. She can only hope that her teachers do not check homework and that she passes those tests! After all, she is really tired from the late-night Netflix binge!

Ananya is making mistakes (or errors) all over the place. She makes mistakes on her homework, makes mistakes on her tests, and makes a mistake when deciding when to go to sleep. She even ends up sleeping late in the morning and ends up missing the bus.

title: Margin of Error When Given an Interval: Airline Flight
question_text:
A $99\%$ confidence interval for the proportion of people who don't show up for their airline flights is $(.022,.076)$.
Using this data, what is the margin of error for the proportion of people who don't show up for their flights?

title: Margin of Error Calculation
question_text:
A biologist hopes to estimate the proportion of alligators in Florida that are adult.
When sampling alligators, the biologist computes the one-proportion $Z$-interval going from $0.67$ to $0.74$ at $99\%$ confidence.
The margin of error for a $95\%$ confidence interval would be

title: Estimating Parameters: Margin of Error Calculation
question_text:
A sociologist wishes to determine whether a significant difference exists in quality of life between people in urban and rural areas.
A survey will be sent out to randomly selected people in rural and urban areas and ask, “Are you happy with your quality of life?”
Assuming equal sample sizes and that no prior information is known, what is the minimum number of people in rural and urban areas that needs to be selected for a $95\%$ confidence interval (estimating the difference in happiness) to have a margin of error no more than $3\%$?

choices.text: $2{,}135$ rural and $2{,}135$ urban subjects.
$432$ rural and $432$ urban subjects.
$323$ rural and $323$ urban subjects.
$188$ rural and $188$ urban subjects.
$128$ rural and $128$ urban subjects.

title: Baseball Logo
question_text:
A local baseball team is considering changing its logo.
A large survey of $5,000$ randomly selected subjects found that the majority of respondents preferred the new logo $(p = 0.02)$ to the old one.
Why might the team consider NOT changing their logo?

choices.text: The survey most likely contained high amounts of bias.
With large surveys, even a small difference can be considered statistically significant and give low p-values.
The $p$-value is too high to give any strong evidence of a preference.
There is no information to indicate that the distribution is approximately normal.
None of the solutions listed are correct; the team should change its logo.

title: Possible Errors
question_text:
Recently a random survey found that $48$ out of $100\text{ college freshman}$ fail to brush their teeth twice a day. This compares higher than the national average of $39\%$.
The researcher decided to test the claim that college kids are more likely not to brush their teeth twice daily than the rest of the public, at the $\alpha = 5\%$ level.
What type of error could the researcher have made, and how could this error be described in the context of the problem?

choices.text: Type I; the researcher decided college kids brush their teeth less often than the general public when this is not the case
Type II; the researcher decided college kids brush their teeth less often than the general public when this is not the case
Type I; the researcher decided insufficient evidence exists to say college kids brush their teeth less often than the general public, but college kids really do brush their teeth less often
Type II; the researcher decided insufficient evidence exists to say college kids brush their teeth less often than the general public, but college kids really do brush their teeth less often
Both type I and II errors could be made in this situation

title: Which Type of Significance Test to Use: Sporting Event
question_text:
In a random sample of $100$ consumers at a sports store, $64$ indicated that they had gone to a professional sporting event in the past year. In an independent random sample of $75$ consumers from a bookstore, $15$ said they had gone to a professional sporting event in the past year.
What significance test should be used to determine whether the proportion of consumers at a sports store attending a sporting event in the past year is significantly greater than the proportion of consumers at a bookstore attending a sporting event in the past year?

choices.text: One proportion z-test.
Two proportion z-test.
Chi-square goodness-of-fit test.
One sample t-test for means.
Two sample t-test for means.

title: Not Getting Enough Sleep: One and Two-Sided $p$-Values
question_text:
The National Sleep Foundation recommends that teens should get $8.5$ to $9.25\text{ hours}$ of sleep each night, but do they? Boris believes that fewer than $15\%$ of students in his high school would say that they get enough sleep.
He conducts a survey by randomly selecting students at school and asking them if they get enough sleep. Completing a one-sided $z$-test for proportions, he calculates his $p$-value to be $0.93$.
Using the same data, what would the $p$-value be for a two-sided test?

title: Testing Hypothesis: Conditions
question_text:
Which of the following is/are conditions necessary for a one-proportion $Z$-test?
I. The data must come from a random sample.
II. $np$ and $n(1-p)$ must both be more than $10$, where $n$ is the sample size and $p$ is the probability of success.
III. The sample size must be more than $30$.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
II and III only.

title: Two-Proportion Z-Interval: Drawing Conclusions
question_text:
A high school athletic director was interested whether high school males are more likely to compete in sports than high school females are.
He randomly sampled $200$ high school males across the country and found that $82$ of them participated in at least one high school sport at some point during the year. This compares to $68$ out of $200$ randomly sampled high school females who participated in at least one sport during the year.
What conclusion can be drawn if the athletic director conducts a two-proportion Z-test?

choices.text: Evidence exists that a higher proportion of males competes in high school sports than do females, significant at the $5\%$ and $10\%$ levels, but not at the $1\%$ level.
Evidence exists that a higher proportion of males competes in high school sports than do females, significant at the $10\%$ level, but not at the $5\%$ or $1\%$ levels.
Evidence exists that a higher proportion of males competes in high school sports than do females, significant at the $1\%$, $5\%$, and $10\%$ levels.
No evidence at the $1\%$, $5\%$, or $10\%$ levels exists that a higher proportion of males is involved in sports than are females.
At the $5\%$ level, there is evidence that males and females have about the same percentage of being involved in sports.

title: Did the Scores Improve?
question_text: Ten years ago, $45$ of a teacher's $90$ AP Statistics students scored a $4$ or $5$ on their AP exam. Last year, $50$ of this same teacher's $80$ AP Statistics students did the same. Did this teacher's classes show improvement? Use a $95\%$ confidence interval to support your answer to the question.

choices.text: Yes, because the sample proportion values rose from $0.50$ to $0.625$.
Yes, because $0$ is not included in the confidence interval.
Yes, because the two samples are independent of each other.
No, because the sample sizes are not large enough and violate the conditions for the interval.
No, because $0$ is included in the interval.

title: Two-Proportion $Z$-Interval
question_text: A two-proportion $Z$-interval attempts to estimate

choices.text: How many times larger one proportion is than the other.
How many times smaller one proportion is than the other.
The difference between two proportions.
Each of the two proportions.
The sum of the two proportions.

title: Type I error: Waiting Time
question_text:
A valet company claims that a customer's average wait time for their car is $8\text{ minutes}$. After waiting $20\text{ minutes}$ to get your car, Bobby believes the valet company's time to get a car is greater than $8\text{ minutes}$.
Which of the following describes a type I error in the context of this situation?

choices.text: Bobby concludes the average wait time it takes the valet company to get a car is $8\text{ minutes}$, when it is actually greater than $8\text{ minutes}$.
Bobby concludes the average wait time it takes the valet company to get a car is greater than $8\text{ minutes}$, when it is actually $8\text{ minutes}$.
Bobby concludes the average wait time it takes the valet company to get a car is greater than $8\text{ minutes}$, when it is actually is greater than $8\text{ minutes}$.
Bobby concludes the average wait time it takes the valet company to get a car is $8\text{ minutes}$, when it is actually is $8\text{ minutes}$.
A type I error cannot be committed in this situation

title: 2 Proportion z-Intervals: 2-sided Testing
question_text:
A two-sample $z$-test for proportions had the hypotheses:
$${ H }_{ 0 }:{ p }_{ 1 }-{ p }_{ 2 }=0$$

$${ H }_{ a }:{ p }_{ 1 }-{ p }_{ 2 }\neq 0$$
The test produces a $p$-value of $0.04$.
Which of the following must be TRUE?
I. A $90\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.
II. A $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.
III. A $99\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.

choices.text: I only.
III only.
I and II only.
II and III only.
I, II, and III.

title: Sample Size and Significance: Who Has the Smallest Power?
question_text: In a hypothesis test, ${ H }_{ 0 }:p=0.75$ versus ${ H }_{ a }:p<0.75$, the power of the test $p=0.75$ would be the smallest for which of the following choices of sample size $n$ and significance level $\alpha$ ?

choices.text: $n=110\qquad \alpha =0.01$
$n=110\qquad \alpha =0.05$
$n=210\qquad \alpha =0.01$
$n=210\qquad \alpha =0.05$
The answer cannot be determined from the information given.

title: Belief in Santa Claus
question_text:
A researcher wants to study the difference between $6$-year-old boys’ and girls’ belief in Santa Claus.
She asks $18$ randomly selected boys and $18$ randomly selected girls. Of those, $9\text{ boys}$ and $13\text{ girls}$ said they believe in Santa Claus.
The $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference in the response rates for the boys and girls was $-0.532$ to $0.088$ (boys to girls).
What can be inferred from this result?

choices.text: It is highly likely that the same proportion of $6$-year-old boys and $6$-year-old girls believe in Santa Claus.
A significantly greater proportion of $6$-year-old girls believes in Santa Claus than do $6$-year-old boys.
No inference can be made because the samples are not random and independent.
We cannot conclude that the proportion of $6$-year-old girls who believe in Santa Claus is different from the proportion of 6-year-old boys who believe in Santa Claus.
No inference can be made because this is a confidence interval, not a hypothesis test.

title: Libertarian Voters
question_text:
A political scientist wishes to estimate the true proportion of citizens who consider themselves Libertarian.
Last year, it was estimated that $14\%$ of all United States citizens were Libertarian.
What is the minimum number of people the political scientist have to interview to keep the margin of error less than $2\%$ for a $95\%$ confidence interval?

choices.text: $1{,}157\text{ people}$
$1{,}998\text{ people}$
$1{,}156\text{ people}$
$815\text{ people}$
$301\text{ people}$

title: Can the Test be Done?
question_text: The CEO of a company wanted to randomly select $12$ people to see if they would purchase a new product. $8$ of the randomly selected people said that they would make the purchase. Could a test of significance for a population proportion be done to help the CEO make a decision?

choices.text: Yes, since the sample was random.
Yes, since the sample proportion was greater than $0.5$.
Yes, since the proportion of failures was less than $10$.
No, since the proportion of successes was less than $10$.
No, since the proportion of failures was greater than$10.$

title: Margin of Error
question_text:
A local news station was covering a city council race and said that Candidate $A$ was polling ahead of Candidate $B$ with $52\%$ of voters favoring Candidate $A$. The news station also stated their results come with a margin of error of $3\%$.
What is believed to be the true proportion of voters who favor Candidate $A$?

choices.text: Somewhere between $49\%$ and $55\%$
Exactly $52\%$
Less than $52\%$
More than $52\%$
Less the $49\%$ but greater than $55\%$

solution:
When a random sample is taken, the sample proportion will rarely equal the true population proportion. In this case, the sample proportion produced a $\hat{p} = 0.52%$ or $52\%$. But, this value came with a margin of error, so the news station does believes that the value of $52\%$ is a good starting point, but might not be exactly correct. The news station believes the true population proportion will be:

$52\% \pm 3\%$

Therefore, they believe the true proportion who favor candidate $A$ to be somewhere between $49\%$ and $55\%$

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: AP Passing Score
question_text: In the year $2020$, $63.4\%$ of students taking the AP® Statistics exam passed it, meaning they obtained a score of 3 or higher. There are $200$ students who took the exam in a given county and $140$ of them passed. Did these students achieve higher than the national average? Show the equation of the test statistic and give the range of where the $p$-value of that statistic falls.

choices.text:
test statistic: $ z=\dfrac{0.7-0.634}{\sqrt{\dfrac{0.7(1-0.7)}{200}}}$
$p$-value: $0.05$ < $p$-value <$ 0.10$

test statistic: $ z=\dfrac{0.7-0.634}{\sqrt{200}}$
$p$-value: $0.025$ < $p$-value < $0.05$

title: Righties and Lefties
question_text:
Researchers wanted to test whether right-handed individuals earn more than left-handed individuals.
A survey of $60$ randomly selected left-handed individuals found that they had an annual income of $\$42{,}345$ and standard deviation of $\$7{,}450$.
The same survey found that $50$ randomly selected right-handed individuals had an annual income of $\$46{,}812$ and standard deviation of $\$5{,}943$.
If researchers concluded that this data gives significant evidence right-handed individuals earn more, they

choices.text: Are correct at the $5\%$ level, but not at the $1\%$ level.
Are correct at the $10\%$ level, but not at the $5\%$ level.
Risk a small chance of committing a type I error.
Risk a small chance of committing a type II error.
Should have surveyed more people to get a $p$-value significant at $1\%$.

title: Two-Proportion Distribution
question_text: Inference comparing two proportions uses the ____________________ distribution.

choices.text: Approximately normal T.
Standard normal Z.
Chi-squared.
Binomial.
Poisson.

title: Constructing an Interval
question_text:
A group of college students in a psychology class wonders if the order of treatments changes the outcome of a study.
To test this, they ask students in a blind taste test which of two colas they prefer, Pepsi or Coke. In this blind taste test, the first $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Pepsi and then Coke, with $34$ preferring Pepsi. The next $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Coke and then Pepsi, with $29$ preferring Pepsi.
If the students wish to determine whether the order in which options are offered changes preferences, what would be an appropriate interval at $95\%$ confidence?

title: Estimating Parameters: Conditions
question_text:
Suppose the conditions are not met for a confidence interval.
When conditions are not met, then

choices.text: The confidence level in the interval must be lowered.
The width of the confidence interval must be raised.
The results may not be able to be generalized to the population.
The margin of error of the confidence interval will increase.
The critical value $t^*$ or $z^*$ will need to increase.

title: Targeted Advertising
question_text:
You are a researcher for a seed company and want to advertise to those with vegetable gardens.
You will use your advertising budget to advertise on either Lifetime (primarily female viewers) or ESPN (primarily male viewers).
Your null hypothesis is that the proportions of men and women who have a vegetable garden are equal. You randomly choose $20\text{ men}$ and $20\text{ women}$ from your community and ask them if they have a vegetable garden.
Of those asked, $3$ of the men and $5$ of the women have a vegetable garden. You calculate your $z$-test statistic and compute your $p$-value.
What assumptions or conditions for comparing two proportions have you violated?

choices.text: Independent random selection procedure.
Population size $N$ compared to the sample size.
Calculating a $z$-value for a two-sample proportion test.
Sample sizes for the two samples.
There are no violations of the assumptions or conditions.

title: Making a Type I Error When Diagnosing Diabetes
question_text:
Diabetes is a metabolic disease that is characterized by prolonged periods of high blood sugar levels. The disease can be very dangerous, so it is important that those affected by diabetes be diagnosed quickly. Diabetes can be diagnosed if two separate blood sugar readings result in $126\text{ mg/dL}$ or higher. However, due to sampling variability and variations in an individual's diet and activity level, two separate readings of $126\text{ mg/dL}$ or higher are possible even in individuals who do not truly have diabetes.
Suppose a physician notices two consecutive blood sugar readings of exactly $126\text{ mg/dL}$ for a particular patient. Since these results are very borderline, she decides to do a hypothesis test with the following hypotheses:
$H_0:$ The patient has diabetes
$H_a:$ The patient does not have diabetes
In this situation, what would be the meaning and potential consequences of the physician making a Type I error?

choices.text: The physician believes that that patient has diabetes and begins to treat the patient for the disease. However, the physician was wrong. The patient really does not have diabetes and is now receiving treatment that is not necessary and could even be dangerous.

The physician decides that the patient does not have diabetes and therefore, does not treat the patient for the disease. However, the physician was wrong. The patient really does have diabetes and is not receiving treatment that is necessary. This could be very dangerous for the patient.
The physician made a mistake when testing the patient's blood sugar level. The blood sugar readings of $126\text{ mg/dL}$ were both incorrect.
The physician determines that the patient does have diabetes and begins treatment. It turns out that the patient needed this treatment because he truly is diabetic.

The physician determines that the patient does not have diabetes and therefore, does not treat the patient for the disease. It turns out that the patient really is not diabetic and simply had two consecutive blood sugar readings of $126\text{ mg/dL}$ because he had been eating a lot of sweets.

title: College Football Coach
question_text:
A college football coach has had a dismal year.
The alumni association queries members of the alumni club. Of an SRS of $100\text{ members}$, $64$ of them are in favor of firing the coach.
Compute a $95\%$ confidence interval for the true proportion of alumni who favor firing the coach.

title: Politics and Age
question_text:
A political pollster was interested in whether there’s any link between age and political preference.
The pollster interviewed $15$ randomly chosen subjects ages $18-24$ and found that $9$ of them said they voted Democrat the last election. This compares to $15$ randomly chosen subjects ages $50$+ where $5$ of them said they voted Democrat last election.
A two-sided test gave a p-value of $0.1432$ and test statistic of $1.46$. The pollster was confused why the sample proportions were so different ($60\%$ vs. $33.33\%$) yet failed to show any significant differences at any common alpha levels ($1\%, 5\%$, or $10\%$).
How might you describe this discrepancy to the pollster?

choices.text: Respondents could have easily lied to the pollster.
Conditions were not met in this problem for a two-proportion Z-test.
The p-value and test statistic calculations are incorrect for this problem.
It is likely a type I error was committed in this test.
This test had low power.

title: Random Sample Convinces the Mayor
question_text:
Last year, $100$ randomly selected dog owners in a certain town were asked, “Do you walk your dog every day?”
Suppose this sampling distribution has a mean of $p = 0.38$.
Last week, a random sample in the same town found that $45$ out of $100$ subjects walk their dogs every day. The mayor is convinced that people in this town now walk their dogs more.
Is there evidence to support the claim stated by the mayor? Use alpha = 10% as your level of statistical significance.

choices.text: No, since only $7$ people walk their dogs more than what would be expected.
No, since the conditions for any calculations involving this problem are not met.
No, a result such as this could easily happen due to sampling variability.
Yes, this result would be somewhat unlikely to happen by chance.
Yes, the sample clearly shows $7$ more people walk their dogs.

title: Part $2$: Which Interval is Wider?
question_text:
A group of students has collected data from a random sample. They need to decide between a $90\%$ confidence interval or a $99\%$ confidence interval.
How will these intervals differ?

choices.text: To determine which confidence interval will be wider, we need to know the sample size.
To determine which confidence interval will be wider, we need to know whether we used a $z$-statistics or a $t$-statistic.
The $90\%$ confidence interval and $99\%$ confidence interval will be the same length, as they are both from the same random sample.
The $90\%$ confidence interval will be wider than the $99\%$ confidence interval.
The $99\%$ confidence interval will be wider than the $90\%$ confidence interval.

title: Reject ${H}_{0}$
question_text:
Suppose a one-sided hypothesis test gives a p-value of $0.19$.
One can reject ${H}_{0}$

choices.text: At alpha = $0.01$ only.
At alpha =$0.05$ only.
At alpha = $0.1$ only.
At none of the common alpha levels of $0.01$, $0.05$, or $0.1$.

title: Weight Loss
question_text:
A new weight-loss drug was on the market. Its slogan promised that people could lose $10\%$ of their weight in the first month. A research company wanted to test this and examine the difference between men and women. $64$ men and $66$ women were randomly selected from those using the drug. Of the men, $38$ said they lost $10\%$ of their weight and $28$ of the women said they did, too. A researcher wanted to know if more men lost weight.
Write the appropriate hypotheses to test this with $p_1$ representing the proportion of men who lost weight and $p_2$ representing the proportion of women who lost weight.

title: Which Label is Better?
question_text:
A soda company is redesigning their label and will hold a focus group to see which label is preferred more by a random group of people. After the focus group, the company finds the proportion of people that like label $A$ to be $0.7$.
If the labels had no effect on each person's choice, what would we assume the probability of selected label $A$ to be?
solution:
When we believe that the design of the label has no effect on the people who chose label $A$, that means the people are choosing label $A$ by chance. Therefore, since there are only two options of labels to choose from, the probability of selecting label $A$ purely by chance is $\frac{1}{2}$.

The probability of selecting label $A$ purely by chance (if the labels do not have any effect on the person's choice) is $0.5$.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: How Many Students to Ask?
question_text: At your high school of $3000$ students, you are curious as to what proportion of the students own a car. To estimate this proportion with a margin of error of $\pm4\%$, how many students should you randomly sample to find this estimate with $95\%$ confidence?

choices.text: $601$ students
$600$ students
$577$ students
$423$ students
$25$ students

title: Student Absences
question_text:
An administrator reads a report that says "The National Rate of Absenteeism for High School Students is $5\%$". She wonders if this holds true for her school. She takes an SRS of $50$ students from her high school and finds the absentee rate to be $10\%$.
To see if it is possible that her school was in line with the national absenteeism rate, even though her sample provided a much larger proportion, she used a statistical software to simulate samples of size $50$ with a known parameter value of $5\%$.
Below is the sampling distribution of the administrator's simulation.
Can the administrator claim that her school's absenteeism rate is in line with the national average?

choices.text: Yes, because a majority of the samples were around $0.05$
Yes, because all samples in the simulation were $0.10$ or below
Yes, because $0.10$ did not occur in the simulation, therefore it is a possibility
No, because $0.10$ did not happen in the simulation, therefore it is so far above the data it could not have happened by chance.
No, since the administrator had a proportion of $0.10$, the true proportion of students that are absent must be $0.10$, not $0.05$

solution:
When making an inference on a set of data, there are typically two conclusions that can be made. In this case those conclusions are:

I. The proportion of $0.05$ is true, and the sample proportion of $0.10$ happened purely by chance

Or

II. The proportion of $0.05$ is not true, and the sample proportion of $0.10$ tells us the proportion must be higher

The simulation was run to see if $0.10$ would happen purely by chance if the proportion of students absent was truly $0.05$. As you can see from the dot plot, $0.10$ did not happen by chance in many trials, we can come to the conclusion that the proportion of students absent at the administrator's high school must be higher than $0.05$.

Choice 'D" is correct.

title: Is the Test Valid?
question_text: For a senior project, a student wishes to compare the proportions of girls and boys taking AP exams in Calculus. In her school, there are more than $1{,}000$ boys and $1{,}000$ girls. She randomly samples $30$ girls and $20$ boys and asks if they are taking a Calculus AP exam. $16$ boys responded yes and $24$ girls responded yes. While she performs the test and is pleased with her work, she realizes she forgot to check the conditions. Do these results verify the conditions of her making any statistical inference while comparing these two proportions?

choices.text: Yes, because she sampled both of her populations randomly and because both of her samples are less than or equal to $10\%$ of their population sizes.
Yes, because both of her samples are less than or equal to $10\%$ of their population sizes and because both values of $\hat{p}$ are equal which means that $\hat{p}_{c}$ is also equal..
Yes, because both values of $\hat{p}$ are equal which means that $\hat{p}_{c}$ is also equal and because her sample sizes are all greater than $10$.
No, because both values of $\hat{p}$ are equal, but the sample sizes are not.
No, because the value of ${n}_{1}(1-\hat{p}_{c})$ is only equal to $4$.

title: Save Room for Dessert: Hypotheses
question_text:
BBQ Basement is a restaurant that specializes in barbecue pork. They also serve desserts, but have realized that only $10\%$ of their customers order dessert. The manager wonders if they can increase their sales of desserts by showing each table a dessert tray before they place their order.
The manager decides to do an experiment. For three weeks, he will have his servers bring around a dessert tray to display to each table when they are seated. The server will suggest that the customers at the table “save room for dessert” and the manager will keep track of the proportion of customers who do order dessert during this period of time.
In order to determine whether his tactic will help to increase dessert sales, the manager plans to do a significance test. What hypotheses should be used?

title: Traffic Engineer Phone Speeds
question_text:
A traffic engineer wishes to determine whether cell phone use while driving causes subjects to speed.
The engineer has organized for subjects’ friends to call while they are driving on a highway and then records their speeds before, during, and after the call.
A test is performed on the following hypothesis:
$H_0: { P }_{ \text{phone} }= { P }_{ \text{no phone} }$
$H_a: { P }_{ \text{phone} } ≠ { P }_{ \text{no phone} }$
Define ${ P }_{ \text{phone} }$ as the proportion who speed while on the phone and ${ P }_{ \text{no phone} }$ as the proportion who speed while not on the phone.
If this test yields a $p$-value of $0.0782$, which of the following conclusions can be made?

choices.text: A $90\%$ confidence interval will NOT contain $0$.
A $95\%$ confidence interval will NOT contain $0$.
A $99\%$ confidence interval will NOT contain $0$.
Both $90\%$ and $95\%$ confidence intervals will contain $0$.
A $99\%$ confidence interval will contain $0.0782$.

title: What Is the Largest Confidence Level? $2$-sided Test
question_text:
A one proportion $z$-test was used to conduct a test of the null hypotheses:
$$H_0: p = 0.74 $$

$$H_A: p \neq 0.74$$
The $p$-value was $0.062$. A confidence interval for $p$ is to be constructed.
Of the following, which is the largest level of confidence for which the confidence interval will NOT contain $0.74$?

title: Vampires and $p$-Values
question_text:
One night at twilight, Bella began to wonder if the proportion of teenage males who believe in vampires is lower than the proportion of teenage females who believe in vampires. She decided to investigate and selected a random sample of teenage males and a random sample of teenage females.
The samples were independent and people in each sample were asked if they believe in vampires. $14$ of the $150$ teenage males surveyed said “yes”, while $25$ of the $150$ teenage females said “yes”.
What is the $p$-value for a test to determine whether the proportion of teenage males who believe in vampires is less than the proportion of teenage females who believe in vampires?

title: Ad Campaigns: Type I Error
question_text:
Suppose the CCO of a local fast food chain is considering two different advertising campaigns: One campaign focuses on low prices, while the other campaign focuses on great service.
In the same large city, $15$ randomly selected stores within the chain focused on low prices, and another $15$ randomly selected stores within the chain focused on great service. The CCO hopes to determine if any significant difference exists between the effect of the two advertising campaigns.
Describe a Type I error in this context and give consequences of a Type I error.

choices.text:
Type I error: incorrectly identifying the campaign that focuses on low prices as a better when it is not.
Consequence: incorporating with a failed advertising campaign.

Type I error: incorrectly stating that the low prices campaign fails to increase sales.
Consequence: failing to see this campaign is helpful.

Type I error: incorrectly identifying the good service campaign as better when it really is not.
Consequence: incorporating with a failed advertising campaign.

Type I error: failing to determine a difference in sales that really existed.
Consequence: the company would miss out on the chance to increase sales by use of a better advertising campaign.

Type I error: determining there is a difference in campaign effectiveness, when in fact no difference exists.
Consequence: the company would incorporate a campaign but would not be overly successful in increasing sales with it.

title: 2 Proportion z-Intervals: 1-sided Testing
question_text:
A two-sample $z$-test for proportions had the hypotheses:
$${ H }_{ 0 }:{ p }_{ 1 }-{ p }_{ 2 }=0$$
$${ H }_{ a }:{ p }_{ 1 }-{ p }_{ 2 }<0$$
The test produces a $p$-value of $0.043$.
Which of the following must be TRUE?
I. A $90\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.
II. A $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.
III. A $99\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions will contain the value $0$.

choices.text: I only.
III only.
I and II only.
II and III only.
I, II, and III.

title: Defective Light Bulbs
question_text: A researcher was hired to examine a company's production of defective light bulbs. The bulbs were made in two wattages, $60$ and $100$. Fifty $60$-watt bulbs were randomly selected and $70$ $100$-watt bulbs were randomly selected. Eight defective bulbs were found in the $60$-watt type and $11$ defective bulbs were found in the $100$-watt type. While the company wanted to lower the defective rate overall, it was particularly concerned with keeping the defective rate the same for both bulb types. Which procedure below would most effectively give this information?

choices.text: Keep taking samples until the defective rates match.
Find a confidence interval for a proportion.
Find a confidence interval for the difference of two proportions.
Find a confidence interval for a mean.
Find a confidence interval for the difference of two means.

title: Reducing the Probability of a Type I Error
question_text:
For a summer internship with a statistical consulting company, Alison proposed conducting a one-sided (greater than) significance test at the $\alpha = 0.05$ level. Her supervisor suggested that she try to reduce her probability of making a type I error. If Alison does adjust her significance test so that the possibility of a type I error is reduced, which of the following will also happen? Assume that Alison will still be conducting a one-sided test with the same sample size.
I. The significance level of the test will be increased.
II. The probability of making a type II error will be increased.
III. The power of the test will be decreased.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and III only.
II and III only.

title: Healthy Teeth | 2 of 2
question_text:
Recently a random survey found that $48$ out of $100\text{ college freshmen}$ do not brush their teeth twice a day. This compares higher than the national average of $39\%$ of people who do not brush their teeth twice a day.
If one wants to see if college kids are significantly less likely to brush their teeth, what would be appropriate null and alternative hypotheses for this study?

title: Is the Drug Better?
question_text: A study was conducted to determine if there was a difference in the proportions of a new drug and a placebo using a $95\%$ confidence interval. The resulting confidence interval was $(-0.21, 0.15)$. Which of the following represents a correct conclusion based on this information?

choices.text: We are $95\%$ confident that the confidence interval $(-0.21, 0.15)$ captures the difference in population proportions of the drug and the placebo. Because zero is included in the interval, we can state that a difference between the effectiveness of the drug and the placebo exists.

We are $95\%$ confident that the confidence interval $(-0.21, 0.15)$ captures the difference in population proportions of the drug and the placebo. Because zero is included in the interval, we cannot state that a difference between the effectiveness of the drug and the placebo exists.
Because $-0.21- 0.15=-0.36$, we are $95\%$ confident that the difference between the proportions of the drug and placebo effectiveness is $36\%$.
Because zero is included in our confidence interval of $(-0.21, 0.15)$, we are $95\%$ confident that there is no difference between the the drug and the placebo.

Our confidence interval of $(-0.21, 0.15)$ tells us that we are $95\%$ confident that the probability of finding that the drug proportion is greater than the placebo proportion is $0.15-(-0.21)=36\%$.

title: Proportion: Which Condition Failed? - Parking Policy
question_text:
A boss wants to estimate the proportion of her employees who are satisfied with the company's parking policy. She puts all $600$ employees' names into a hat and shakes it before picking $50$ different names out of the hat. Of the $50$, $47$ are satisfied with parking policy and $3$ are not satisfied with it.
Which condition for constructing a $1$-sample $z$-interval for proportions has the boss failed to satisfy?

choices.text: The data is a random sample from the population of interest.
The normality rule for success is not satisfied.
The normality rule for failure is not satisfied.
The sample is less than $10\%$ of the population.
All of the conditions have been satisfied.

title: Checking Those Conditions!
question_text: In order to calculate a confidence interval to estimate a population proportion, which of the following is a correct check?

choices.text: To check that the sampling distribution of $\hat{p}$ is approximately normal, check that the number of successes is $n\hat{p}\leq 10$.
To check that the sampling distribution of $\hat{p}$ is approximately normal, check that the number of failures is $n\hat{p}\geq 10$.
To check for independence when sampling without replacement, check that $n\leq10\%N$.
To check for independence when sampling without replacement, check that the number of successes is $n\hat{p}\geq 10$.
To check that the sampling distribution of $\hat{p}$ is approximately normal, check that data was collected using a random sample or a randomized experiment.

title: Bad Grapes
question_text:
A large retailer always receives a shipment of grapes every Friday. On average, about $10\%$ of the packages of grapes are determined to be rotten. After looking at many, many shipments, the produce manager wants to figure out the probability that shipment will contain more than $12\%$ rotten packages.
What question must the produce manager answer first?

choices.text: How many packages of grapes did the store receive?
How many shipments did the store manager examine?
Is the distribution of shipments of grapes approximately normal?
What is causing the grapes to be rotten?
What is the proportion of the population of all packages of grapes that are rotten?

solution:
After looking at many, many shipments for grapes for the large retailer, the manager is essentially looking at a sampling distribution of the packages of grapes that are rotten. When examining the sampling distribution, the manager can find the probability if and only if the distribution meets the Large Counts condition, which is used to assess the normality of the approximation of sampling distribution.

Therefore, the manager must find out if the approximation of the sampling distribution is approximately normal in order to find the probability.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: A Test of Baseball Cards
question_text: Hank and Mickey both collected baseball cards. They wanted to know if the proportions of pitchers depicted on cards varied between the two major baseball card companies, Dopps and Upper Teck. So, they each ordered $500$ random baseball cards, Hank from Dopps and Mickey from Upper Teck. To compare their proportions of pitchers using a test of significance for two proportions, what would their hypotheses be?

title: Laptop Battery Life: Interpreting a $p$-Value
question_text:
When Carter bought his new laptop computer, the sales person told him that the average battery life was $5$ hours and that the number of hours of battery life is approximately normally distributed. After using the computer for a few days, Carter began to have his doubts. The next $10$ times that Carter used his computer, he kept track of how long it took for the battery to drain. The sample average was $4.25$.
Conducting a one-sided significance test, he found the $p$-value to be $0.038$.
What is the best way to interpret this $p$-value in the context of this situation?

choices.text: A $p$-value as small as $0.038$ gives Carter good reason to doubt that the average battery life of his laptop really is $5$ hours.
If the average battery life really is $5$ hours, then a sample of $10$ observations having a sample mean of $4.25$ hours or lower would only occur about $3.8\%$ of the time.
When $10$ observations are made, the battery life will be as low as $4.25$ hours in $3.8\%$ of the observations.
There is a $3.8\%$ chance that Carter's laptop computer battery will last for $4.25$ hours anytime he uses it.
Only $3.8\%$ of all laptop batteries will last as long as $5$ hours.

title: Conditions for Two-Proportions
question_text:
Which of the following conditions is/are necessary for a hypothesis test concerning inference on two-proportions?
I. The data must be from a simple random sample.
II. ${ { n }_{ 1 } }(p),{ { n }_{ 1 } } \times (1-p),{ { n }_{ 2 } }(p)$ and ${ { n }_{ 2 } }(1-p)$ must all be greater than $5$, where ${ { n }_{ 1 } }$ and ${ { n }_{ 2 } }$ are the sizes of the first and second samples, respectively, and p is the pooled sample proportion.
III. The samples must be stratified.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
II and III only.

title: Part $1$: Which Interval is Wider?
question_text:
A group of students has collected data from a random sample. They need to decide between a $95\%$ confidence interval and a $99\%$ confidence interval.
How will these intervals differ?

choices.text: The $95\%$ confidence interval will be wider than the $99\%$ confidence interval.
The $99\%$ confidence interval will be wider than the $95\%$ confidence interval.
The $95\%$ confidence interval and $99\%$ confidence interval will be the same length, as they are both from the same random sample.
To determine which confidence interval will be wider, we need to know the sample size.
To determine which confidence interval will be wider, we need to know whether the students used the population variance or the sample variance.

title: Refer to the Formula
question_text: Which of the following represents the variance when completing a $z$-test for the difference between two population proportions?

choices.text: $\dfrac { \sigma }{ \sqrt { n } }$
$n(p)(1-p)$ where $p$ is the observed proportion of successes from both populations combined.

$\dfrac { \left( { p }_{ 1 } \right) \left( 1 -{ p }_{ 1 } \right) }{ { n }_{ 1 } } + \dfrac { \left( { p }_{ 2 } \right) \left( 1 - { p }_{ 2 } \right) }{ { n }_{ 2 } } $ where ${ p }_{ 1 }$ is the hypothesized proportion for population $1$ and ${ p }_{ 2 }$ is the hypothesized proportion for population $2$.

$\dfrac { \left( \hat { { p }_{ 1 } } \right) \left( 1 -\hat { { p }_{ 1 } } \right) }{ { n }_{ 1 } } + \dfrac { \left( \hat { { p }_{ 2 } } \right) \left( 1 - \hat { { p }_{ 2 } } \right) }{ { n }_{ 2 } } $ where $\hat { { p }_{ 1 } } $ is the observed proportion from population $1$ and $\hat { { p }_{ 2} }$ is the observed proportion from population $2$ .
$\left( p \right) \left( 1 - p \right) \left( \dfrac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 1 } } + \dfrac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 2 } } \right) $ where $p$ is the observed proportion from both populations combined.

title: Meaning of a Confidence Interval: Athletes and Steroids
question_text:
A random sample of $50\text{ professional athletes}$ were asked: "Would you use steroids to improve performance?" A $95\%$ confidence interval was constructed from the data to find the proportion of athletes who would use steroids to improve performance. The resulting interval is $(0.44,0.53)$.
Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Between $44\%$ to $53\%$ of all athletes would use steroids to improve performance.
We are $95\%$ confident that in this particular sample of athletes, $44\%$ to $53\%$ would use steroids to improve performance.
We are $95\%$ confident that the true proportion of all athletes that would use steroids to improve performance is between $44\%$ to $53\%$.
In $95\%$ of all surveys, between $44\%$ to $53\%$ of all athletes report they would do steroids to improve performance.
In $95\%$ of all surveys, we would capture the sample proportion of athletes who would use steroids to improve performance.

title: Situation for Two Proportions
question_text: Which of the following situations would be appropriate for a two-proportion interval?

choices.text: Comparing whether men earn more income than women.
Determining the proportion of people who attend church at least once a week.
Comparing whether dogs are more likely to live longer than cats.
Determining whether males or females are more likely to exercise regularly.
Examining whether a relationship exists between grade point average and hours studied.

title: Unemployment Concerns
question_text:
The threat of unemployment is a major concern for working adults.
In a survey of $1{,}500\text{ working adults}$, $720\text{ men}$ and $780\text{ women}$ were asked the question, “Are you concerned about losing your job within the next $12\text{ months}$?”
Of those who were surveyed, $312\text{ males}$ said “yes,” and $240\text{ females}$ said “yes.”
Why would it be considered incorrect to use a one-proportion $Z$-interval in this situation?

choices.text: This data follows the $T$ distribution.
It is not known if the sampling distribution is approximately normal.
The data compares two independent proportions.
No standard deviation is given.
The survey contains apparent bias.

title: One-Proportion Z-Test
question_text:
The landlord of a $16$-story apartment building is curious if his tenants are happy with the current temperature in the building.
He surveys the first floor and finds that $26$ out of the $40$ tenants are happy with the current temperature. Suppose the landlord wanted to perform a one-proportion z-test.
Which of the conditions are violated for this procedure?

choices.text: The population is not at least $10$ times the sample.
The sampling distribution is not approximately normal.
The expected counts are not more than $5$.
The sample is too small.
The data does not come from an SRS.

title: Rotten Tomatoes
question_text: WellMart orders huge numbers of tomatoes to sell. It decides to randomly sample a bunch of tomatoes and finds that $0.16$ of them are rotten. The manager declared that $4$ times as many should have been sampled, and the same proportion of $0.16$ were rotten. How did the width of the confidence interval change, if at all, when the sample size increased by a factor of $4$?

choices.text: It decreased by one-half.
It decreased by one-fourth.
It stayed the same.
It increased by a factor of $2$.
It increased by a factor of $4$.

title: Two-Proportion Z-Interval: Conditions
question_text:
A high school athletic director was interested whether high school males are more likely to compete in sports than high school females are.
He randomly sampled $200$ high school males across the country and found that $82$ of them participated in at least one high school sport at some point during the year. This compares to $68$ out of $200$ randomly sampled high school females who participated in at least one sport during the year.
Suppose the athletic director wanted to perform a two-proportion $Z$-interval.
In addition to needing two independent random samples, another necessary condition is

choices.text: Sample sizes must be large, say at least $30$ each.
Combined sample sizes must be large, say at least $30$.
$200 \cdot (0.34)$ and $200\cdot (0.41)$ must both be at least $5$, as well as $200\cdot (0.66)$ and $200 \cdot (0.59)$.
$200 \cdot (0.5)$ must be at least $5$.
The parent population must be roughly normal.

title: One Proportion $z$-Interval: Indoor Cats
question_text:
A veterinarian was interested in the proportion of homeowners who had strictly indoor cats. She randomly selected $40$ homeowners and found that $14$ of them had cats that were indoor-only.
Which of the following represents a $99\%$ confidence interval for the true proportion of homeowners that have cats that stay indoors?

title: One Proportion $z$-Interval: Mine Stage
question_text:
A parent was interested in the proportion of toddlers who go through the "mine" stage. This is identified as when a toddler refers to everything as "mine," even when it is not his or hers.
The parent randomly sampled $100$ other parents that went into toy store and asked them if their child has experienced the "mine" stage. Of these $100$ parents, $89$ parents said their child has gone through or is currently going through the "mine" stage.
Which of the following represents a $99.6\%$ confidence interval for the proportion of toddlers that go through the "mine" stage?

title: Constructing a $2$ Proportion $z$-Interval: High School Break Up
question_text:
Independent random samples of $50$ boys and $50$ girls in a school were asked if they are depressed for more than a week after they got broken up with by their significant other. Of the $50$ boys, $26$ said yes, and of the $50$ girls, $35$ said yes.
Which of the following is a $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference in the proportion of boys compared to the proportion of girls who are depressed for more than a week after they have been broken with by their significant other in this school?

title: Conditions for Weight Loss
question_text:
A new weight-loss drug was on the market. Its slogan promised that people could "lose $10\%$ of their weight in the first month". A research company wanted to test this claim and to examine the difference between men and women. $66$ women and $64$ men were randomly selected from those using the drug. Of the women, $28$ said that they lost $10\%$ of their weight and $38$ of the men said that they did. A researcher wanted to know if more men lost weight.
In checking to see if this research met the conditions for a test for the difference of two population proportions, the researcher would verify all of these conditions except:

choices.text: The participants were chosen randomly.
The sample sizes were less than $10\%$ of the population sizes.
A pooled proportion, $\hat{p}_{c}$ was used to check that the sampling distribution was approximately normally distributed..

Each sample size was checked to be of size $30$ or higher.

A $99\%$ confidence interval was constructed on this data with a $5\%$ margin of error. Suppose instead that a $90\%$ confidence interval was constructed on this same sample.
This $90\%$ confidence interval will have a margin of error of about

question_text:

Difference = $\mu(1)-\mu(2) $

tables:
