title: Large Counts Condition
question_text: Why is it important to check the large counts condition when dealing with sampling distributions of the sample proportion, $\hat{p}$?

choices.text: To ensure the sample is large enough
To be ensure that each trial is independent from each other
To be able to use the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of $\hat{p}$
To ensure that the usage of the normal approximation is a appropriate
In order to use the mean of the sampling distribution of $\hat{p}$

solution:
When dealing with sampling distributions, the shape of the distribution can vary from one to another. In order to ensure that we can use the normal approximation when dealing with inference problems for the sample proportion, $\hat{p}$, we must first check the Large Counts Condition,

$np \geq 10$

and

$n(1-p) \geq 10$

If both of these conditions are true, then we can apply the normal approximation to our inference problem.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Marshmallows?
question_text: Clucky Arms Cereal was looking into the proportion of cereal pieces that are marshmallows in each of its cereal boxes. choices.text: We are $95\%$ confident that the mean number of marshmallows in each box of Clucky Arms Cereal is $35\%$.
We are confident that every box of Clucky Arms Cereal will contain between $32\%$ and $38\%$ marshmallows as the true population proportion.
We are $95\%$ confident that repeated samples of any size will still contain between $32\%$ and $38\%$ marshmallows.
We are $95\%$ confident that every box of Clucky Arms Cereal will contain about one-third marshmallows.
We are $95\%$ confident that the interval from $32\%$ to $38\%$ captures the population proportion of marshmallows in boxes of Clucky Arms Cereal.

title: Confidence Intervals: Coffee Shop Opening Times

A survey of $500\text{ customers}$ for a national chain of coffee houses was conducted to measure whether customers wanted an earlier opening time or were satisfied with the current opening time.

choices.text: $(0.58263; 0.69336)$; no, because the confidence interval does not contain $0.5$.

title: Type II Error: Avalanche Airbag Pack
question_text: A boss was not satisfied with the survival rate of his company's avalanche airbag pack. His company redesigned their pack in the hopes of increasing the survival rate. Which of the following conditions would a Type II error be committed?

choices.text: The company concludes that the new airbag pack increases the survival rate when it actually does not increase the survival rate.
The company concludes that the new airbag pack does not increase the survival rate when it actually does increase the survival rate.
The company concludes that the new airbag pack increases the survival rate when it really does increase the survival rate.
The company concludes that the new airbag pack does not increase the survival rate when it really does not increase the survival rate.
A Type II error cannot be committed in this situation.

title: Smelly Customers?
question_text:
A large company sold two different types of deodorant, called Dusty and Nab. It wanted to compare the proportions of customers who were displeased with the performance of these products. A confidence interval was found. If the lower bound of the resulting confidence interval was $-0.072$, and the difference of the proportions was $0.05$, find the confidence level of the confidence interval.
Define $\hat{p}_{1}$ to be the proportion of Dusty customers and $\hat{p}_{2}$ to be the proportion of Nab customers.

choices.text: The confidence level cannot be found.

title: Southpaws and $p$-Values
question_text:
People who are left-handed are sometimes referred to as “southpaws”. According to some reports $10\%$ of people are left-handed, but Billy doesn't believe this is true and decides to do a study. He randomly selects $130$ people and finds that $20$ of them are left-handed.
What is the $p$-value for the appropriate significance test?

choices.text: We cannot conduct a significance test because conditions for doing so are not satisfied in this situation.

title: Definition of Margin of Error: Pop Star
question_text:
A publication reported that a current pop star "gained the student body approval" after his performance at homecoming. A poll was conducted randomly, and its findings were that $90\%$ of the students felt that the pop star's performance was the highlight of homecoming. The poll of $100$ students had a margin of error of $5\%$.
Which of the following statements best describes the margin of error?

choices.text: About $5\%$ of the students do not like the pop star.
About $5\%$ of the $100$ students refused to answer.
The difference between the sample percentage and the population percentage is likely to be less than $5\%$.
About $5\%$ of the students were expected to change their minds after the survey.
Not all of the $100$ seniors know the pop star.

title: Ghost Sightings: Investigating Proportions
question_text:
According to some studies, women are more likely to believe in ghosts than men. Casper wondered whether women were also more likely to report having seen a ghost than men and decided to do a study.
In Casper's random sample of $85$ women, $10$ women reported having seen a ghost at some point in their lives. In his random sample of $63$ men, only $4$ reported having seen a ghost.
Which of the following shows how to calculate the z-statistic for a test of the difference in the proportions of men and women who would report that they have seen a ghost?

choices.text: $\dfrac { \frac { 10 }{ 85 } -\frac { 4 }{ 63 } }{ \sqrt { \left( \frac { 10 }{ 85 } \right) \left( \frac { 4 }{ 63 } \right) \left( \frac { 1 }{ 85 } +\frac { 1 }{ 63 } \right) } } $
$\dfrac { \frac { 10 }{ 85 } -\frac { 4 }{ 63 } }{ \sqrt { \left( \frac { 14 }{ 148 } \right) \left( \frac { 134 }{ 148 } \right) \left( \frac { 10 }{ 85 } +\frac { 4 }{ 63 } \right) } } $
$\dfrac { \frac { 10 }{ 85 } -\frac { 4 }{ 63 } }{ \sqrt { \left( \frac { 14 }{ 148 } \right) \left( \frac { 134 }{ 148 } \right) \left( \frac { 1 }{ 85 } +\frac { 1 }{ 63 } \right) } }$

$\dfrac { \frac { 10 }{ 85 } -\frac { 4 }{ 63 } }{ \sqrt { \frac { \left( \frac { 4 }{ 63 } \right) \left( \frac { 59 }{ 63 } \right) }{ 63 } +\frac { \left( \frac { 10 }{ 85 } \right) \left( \frac { 75 }{ 85 } \right) }{ 85 } } }$

$\dfrac { \frac { 10 }{ 85 } -\frac { 4 }{ 63 } }{ \sqrt { \frac { \left( \frac { 4 }{ 63 } \right) \left( \frac { 10 }{ 85 } \right) }{ 148 } +\frac { \left( \frac { 59 }{ 63 } \right) \left( \frac { 75 }{ 85 } \right) }{ 148 } } } $

title: Red Marbles
question_text:
A students statistics teacher brings a bag of marbles to class. He states that the proportion of red marbles is $0.50$. To test this proportion, he will have students select random samples of $20$ marbles from the bag. When the student selects their sample of marbles, they get $16$ red marbles for a proportion of $0.80$.
They think this proportion is high, and they don't believe the teacher's proportion of $0.50$ is correct. So, they run a simulation that takes $50$ samples from the teacher's bag of marbles with a known proportion of $0.50$ red marbles. The dot plot of the data is below.
Loading question supplement...
What proportion of samples in the student's simulation gave a sample proportion of at least $0.80$?
solution:
Since you simulate the bag of marbles $50$ times, you have $50$ total observations on the dot plot given. Then looking at the dots, there is only $1$ sample that produced a sample proportion of at least $0.80$.

Therefore, we only have $\frac{1}{50}$ samples that produced a sample proportion of $0.80$, therefore the proportion of samples that is at least $0.80$ is equal to $0.02$.

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: Sound Cards and Motherboards
question_text: A Tech company produces sound cards and motherboards. It was concerned about how many parts were coming out defective. choices.text: A two-sample $t$-test for a difference between two population proportions.
A two-sample $z$-test for a difference between two population proportions.

title: Two-Proportion $Z$-Test Risks
question_text:
In a survey done in a small town last year, $8$ out of $12$ randomly selected people said they approve of the job the mayor is doing.

Why would it be inappropriate to perform a two-proportion $Z$-test to determine whether the mayor’s approval rating has changed?

choices.text: It is illogical to perform an inferential procedure like a two-proportion $Z$-test when the population data is already known.
The data does not come from simple random samples.
The populations are most likely NOT at least $10$ times each sample.

title: Hypothesis Test Logic
question_text: Which of the following statements gives a good synopsis of the logic behind hypothesis tests?

choices.text: The fact that a result such as ours is likely, given no change occurred, serves as good evidence the change did not occur.
The fact that a result such as ours is unlikely, given no change occurs, gives a low probability that the null hypothesis is true.
The fact that a result such as ours is unlikely, given no change occurred, serves as good evidence the change did occur.

title: Hypertension and High-Stress Jobs: A Hypothesis Test
question_text:
Hypertension, or high blood pressure, is a serious condition that can lead to many different types of health problems. According to the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute, about $1$-in-$3$ American adults suffer from this condition. Some studies suggest there is a link between stress and hypertension. Other studies suggest that men are more likely to suffer from hypertension than women.
Historically, however, men have often held more high-stress jobs than women. Times have been changing, though, and many women now hold the same types of high-stress jobs as men. Do men and women in these types of high-stress jobs suffer from hypertension at the same rates?
Heidi decides to do a study. She randomly selects the health records of $104\text{ women}$ in high-stress jobs and finds that $25\%$ of them suffer from hypertension. She also randomly selects the health records of $150\text{ men}$ in high-stress jobs and finds that $36\%$ of them suffer from hypertension. It is reasonable to consider her samples to be independent.
Does this provide evidence at the $\alpha = 0.05$ level that the rates of hypertension are not the same in men and women with high-stress jobs?

choices.text: Yes, since the proportion of males with hypertension is much greater than the proportion of females with hypertension, the hypertension rates cannot possibly be equal.
Yes, since $p = 0.03$, we have strong evidence to suggest that the proportion of men who suffer from hypertension is greater than the proportion of females who suffer from hypertension.
No, more men in our sample had hypertension than females, but there were also more men sampled so this is to be expected even if the rates of hypertension truly are equal.
No, since $p = 0.06$, our results do not provide enough evidence to suggest that the hypertension rates are not equal.
We cannot perform a significance test in this situation since not all conditions are satisfied.

title: Baseball Pitcher
question_text:
A baseball player claims he throws $90\%$ strikes when he's pitching. His AP Statistics attends the next game he pitches, and records the number of strikes. The baseball player threw $80\%$ strikes during the game the teacher attended.
The teacher decides to run a simulation with a random number generator where the proportion of strikes is known to be $0.9$. What question is the teacher most likely trying to answer?

choices.text: How many strikes the player will throw in his next game?
What is the shape of the distribution of proportion of strikes?
What is the expected number of strikes the player will throw?
How likely is it that a true $90\%$ strike thrower will only throw $80\%$ strikes?
What are the odds the player throws $80\%$ strikes in the next game?

solution:
Since the teacher was told the proportion of strikes the student should be throwing was $90\%$, the teacher should expect the student to be around $90\%$. When the teacher observed the student, the student only threw $80\%$ strikes. The teacher has to ask, "Is this close enough to $90\%$, or do I have evidence the student is not a $90\%$ strike-thrower?"

Therefore, by doing a simulation where the known proportion of strikes thrown is $90\%$, the teacher is seeing if $80\%$ happens enough by chance to say the player could actually be a $90\%$ strike-thrower and this game just happened by chance.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Parts of the Confidence Interval
question_text: A sociologist named Dana wanted to know how many girls at age $15$ were interested in pursuing a career in the sciences. Dana’s first step in her study was to randomly choose $3{,}000$ girls across the country and ask them if they were interested in a career in the sciences. $996$ girls replied that they did intend to pursue such a career. Dana created a confidence interval based on her collected data. Given that the upper limit of the confidence interval is $0.352$, find both the margin of error and the confidence level.

choices.text:
margin of error: $0.02$
confidence level: $80\%$

margin of error: $0.02$
confidence level: $95\%$

margin of error: $0.02$
confidence level: $98\%$

margin of error: $0.03$
confidence level: $98\%$

margin of error: $0.03$
confidence level: $95\%$

title: Margin of Error: Female Karate Students
question_text:
There are $250$ children signed up for karate at the local studio.
Of those, $70\%$ are boys and $30\%$ are girls. Assume a $95\%$ level of confidence and that these $250$ students represent a random sample of all children signed up for karate.
What is the margin of error for the percentage of girls taking karate?

title: Conditions!
question_text: Susie wants to create a confidence interval for the difference of two proportions. She is working to present the results to the president of her company. Which of the following correctly describes conditions that she must verify?

choices.text: Susie knows to verify that the samples are taken in a random fashion.

Susie must ensure random sampling occurs and must check that those sample sizes are less than or equal to $10\%$ of the size of the populations. In addition, she must check that those sample sizes multiplied by the sample proportions are all greater than or equal to $10$.

Susie must check for independence by ensuring random sampling and by ensuring that those sample sizes are less than or equal to $30\%$ of the size of the populations. In addition, she must check for approximate normality by checking that those sample sizes multiplied by the sample proportions, as well as by one minus those sample proportions, are all greater than or equal to $10$.

Susie must check for independence by ensuring random sampling and by ensuring that those sample sizes are less than or equal to $10\%$ of the size of the populations. In addition, she must check for approximate normality by checking that those sample sizes multiplied by the sample proportions, as well as by one minus those sample proportions, are all greater than or equal to $10$.

Susie must check for approximate normality by ensuring random sampling and by ensuring that those sample sizes are less than or equal to $10\%$ of the size of the populations. In addition, she must check for independence by checking that those sample sizes multiplied by the sample proportions, as well as by one minus those sample proportions, are all greater than or equal to $10$.

title: Calling an Election Based on a Sample
question_text:
On November 3, 1948, the Chicago Daily Tribune made a famous big mistake when they published the headline Dewey Defeats Truman. No newspaper wants to make that type of mistake! Yet, on election night you can turn on the television and hear statements like “with $3\%$ of the precincts reporting, we are now calling the election in favor of Candidate X”.
Suppose your town (population: $7320$) has a hotly contested two-candidate race for mayor and you would like to be able to call the election. To gather data, you station yourself outside the town's only polling place and randomly select $200$ individuals to ask who they voted for.
If $55\%$ of those individuals say they voted for Candidate Y (and we assume that they are being truthful), would you be willing to call the election in Candidate Y's favor?

choices.text: Yes, because far more than half of the voters sampled said that they voted for Candidate Y.
Yes. Since a significance test returns a $p$-value of $p = 0.04$, we have strong evidence to suggest that more than $50\%$ of voters voted for Candidate Y.
No. At the $\alpha = 0.05$ level, we do not have enough evidence to believe that the proportion of voters supporting Candidate Y is greater than $0.50$.
No, because a sample size of $200$ is too small to provide reliable results.
We cannot conduct a significance test because conditions for doing so are not satisfied in this situation.

title: One Proportion $z$-Interval: Left-Handed Students
question_text:
A student at RHAM high school wondered what percent of the students in her school were left-handed. She randomly sampled $150$ students at her school and found $21$ of them to be left-handed.
Which of the following represents a $95\%$ confidence interval for the proportion of left-handed students at RHAM High School?

title: Effect of Significance Level: Types of Error and Power
question_text:
If the significance level is increased it will:
I. Increase the probability of a type I error.
II. Increase the probability of a type II error.
III. Increase the power of a test.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
I and III only.
II and III only.
I, II, and III.

title: Type I Error: Efficiency Rating of a Boiler
question_text:
A new boiler is being advertised to have an efficiency rate of $91\%$. The company's competitor believes the new boiler is producing an efficiency rate of less than $91\%$. The company's competitor designs an experiment by randomly selecting 100 of the new boilers to test their efficiency rate.
Under which of the following conditions would a Type I error be committed?

choices.text: The competitor's company concludes that the new boiler's efficiency rate is less than $91\%$ when it is actually $91\%$.
The competitor's company concludes that the new boiler's efficiency rate is not less than $91\%$ when it is actually less than $91\%$.
The competitor's company concludes that the new boiler's efficiency rate is $91\%$ when it is actually $91\%$.
The competitor's company concludes that the new boiler's efficiency rate is less than $91\%$ when it is really less than $91\%$.
A type I error cannot be committed in this situation.

title: Margin of Error
question_text: The margin of error of a confidence interval increases as the

choices.text: Sample mean increases.
Sample size increases.
Sample mean decreases.
Standard error decreases.
Confidence level increases.

title: Blue Candies
question_text:
Two AP Statistics students are doing a project regarding a certain famous chocolate candies. The company that produces the candies claims that $8\%$ of the candies are blue. The students want to investigate this and head to the large candy machine at their local mall. Each student inserts multiple quarters into the machine and get a sample of $30$ candies on each turn. They record the proportion of blue candies on each sample and create an approximate sampling distribution of the candies obtained.
The first student is confused when the graph of the sampling distribution after many, many trials does not model a normal distribution. What is the most important reason why the distribution is not normal?

choices.text: The sample size is not large enough
The number of expected success and failures are not large enough
The population is most likely not normal
The students did not select enough samples
The students selected too many candies per sample

solution:
When dealing with sampling distributions, the shape is unknown at the beginning, but does approach an approximately normal shape if certain conditions are met. In this case, the student was surprised that the shape was not approximately normal. In order for the sampling distribution to be approximately normal, the expected number of successes and failures need to be greater than or equal to $10$. This is called the Large Counts Condition and must be check in order to use the normal approximation for the sampling distribution of sample proportions.

Choice 'B" is correct.

title: Significant Results
question_text: If a hypothesis test is performed and the results are significant at significance level alpha, then

choices.text: Alpha is a small value.
The $p$-value is greater than alpha.
The $p$-value is equal to $2$ alpha.
The $p$-value is less than alpha.

title: What Happens to Margin of Error when the Sample Size Changes?
question_text:
In an effort to determine what percentage of teenagers text and drive at Griswold High School, a student randomly selected $50$ teenage drivers from Griswold and constructed a $95\%$ confidence interval. Suppose that the student decides to construct the $95\%$ confidence interval again, but this time she randomly selects $100$ students.
What would happen to the margin of error?

choices.text: The margin of error would increase.
The margin of error would decrease.
The margin of error would not change.
Can't tell, because the margin of error varies from sample to sample.
Can't tell, because we don't know the point estimate from the samples.

title: Type of Significance Test: Energy Drinks
question_text:
A study reported that the proportion of college students who experience heart palpitations after drinking energy drinks is $0.18$. The dean of a university believes that the proportion of students at his university who experience heart palpitations after drinking an energy drink is greater than $0.18$.
If a large random sample is used, which of the following is the most appropriate test to investigate the dean’s belief?

choices.text: A z-test for a proportion.
A z-test for a difference between two proportions.
A chi-square test for homogeneity.
A t-test for a mean.
A matched-pairs t-test.

title: Attending College?
question_text:
In a school district, there are $5{,}100$ boys and $5{,}200$ girls attending the public high schools. The superintendent wanted to know if there is a difference in the proportions of boys and girls planning to attend college. Random samples of $100$ boys and $90$ girls were asked this question. $90\%$ of the girls and $82\%$ of the boys said they planned to attend college. The superintendent needed to verify the conditions for this test for the difference of two population proportions.
Which of the following is actually a correct result? Let the $1$ group be the boys and the $2$ group be the girls.

choices.text: $n_{1}\hat{p}_{c}\approx86.2$
$n_{2}\hat{p}_{c}\approx77.6$

title: Interpret Proportion Intervals
question_text:
A biologist hopes to estimate the proportion of alligators in Florida that are adults.
When sampling alligators, the biologist computes the one-proportion $Z$-interval going from $0.67$ to $0.74$ at $99\%$ confidence.
What conclusion can be drawn about the proportion of all adult alligators in Florida, based off of the interval?

choices.text: The true proportion of adult alligators in Florida is probably somewhere between $0.67$ and $0.74$; the process used gives correct results $99\%$ of the time in repeated trials.
$99\%$ of samples such as this one will catch the interval between $0.67$ and $0.74$ (as long as the samples are conducted in Florida).
$99\%$ of samples such as this, conducted in Florida, will have a sample proportion between $0.67$ and $0.74$, as long as many samples are conducted.
$70.5\%$ of alligators in Florida are adults.
There is a $99\%$ probability that between $67\%$ and $74\%$ of alligators in Florida are adults.

title: Psychic Abilities
question_text:
A researcher wants to determine whether a proclaimed psychic really has any special abilities.
Four decks of regular playing cards are shuffled together so that the researcher has $208\text{ cards}$ in a pile. Half the cards are colored red, and the other half are black. As the researcher looks at each card, the blindfolded psychic calls out the card’s color. Cards are replaced and shuffled after each trial.
Assuming conditions are met, at the $5\%$ level of significance, what is the least number of cards the mind reader must call correctly to show that he is not merely guessing?

title: Margin of Error Application
question_text:
You are unsure if a coin is balanced or not, so you flip it many times.
Giving the estimate closest to your solution, about how many flips should you perform to make sure that you are within $1\%$ of the true proportion, based on a $95\%$ confidence interval?

title: Reducing Type II Errors
question_text:
Which of the following statements is/are true given the following situation?
When performing a two-sample $T$-test, possible ways to reduce the probability of a type II error would be to
I. Increase alpha.
II. Increase sample size.
III. Use a matched pairs experimental design.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
II and III only.

title: Which Wattage to Buy
question_text: A researcher was hired to examine a company's production of defective light bulbs. The bulbs were made in two wattages, $60$ and $100$. Fifty $60$-watt bulbs were randomly selected and $72$ $100$-watt bulbs were randomly selected. Eight defective bulbs were found in the $60$-watt type and $9$ defective bulbs were found in the $100$-watt type. The researcher decided to create a confidence interval for the difference of the proportion of defective bulbs. Which of the following is the lower bound of the $98\%$ confidence interval?

title: Type II Error in Context
question_text:
A study on women’s weights was recently completed.
Fifteen randomly selected high school females from an urban setting were compared to $16$ randomly selected high school females from a rural setting. The results are below:
Two-Sample T for Urban Weights vs. Rural Weights
N Mean StDev SE Mean
Urban Weights 15 126.1 10.5 2.7
Rural Weights 16 128.8 13.2 3.3


Difference = $\mu$ (Urban Weights) - $\mu$ (Rural Weights)
Estimate for difference: $-2.68$
$95\%$ CI for difference: $(-11.45, 6.09)$
$T$-test of difference = $0$ (vs. not =): $T$-value = $-0.63$
$P$-value = $0.537$
DF = $28$
A type II error in the context of this study would involve
tables:
NMeanStDevSE Mean
Urban Weights15126.110.52.7
Rural Weights16128.813.23.3

choices.text: Implying there is no difference in urban versus rural weights, when really there is a difference.
Implying there is a difference in urban versus rural weights, when really there is no difference.
Implying the difference between urban and rural weights is $2.68$\text{ pounds}$, when in fact it is more.
Implying the difference between urban and rural weights is $2.68\text{ pounds}$, when in fact it is less.
Implying there is no difference in urban versus rural weights, when in fact there really is no difference.

title: Disney Princesses Put to the Test
question_text:
Ava loves all of the Disney princesses, but her favorite is Elsa, from the movie Frozen. She thinks everyone should love Elsa, and she just can't let it go! Ava wants to survey a large sample of young girls and ask them to vote for their favorite princess from the following list:
Ariel
Belle
Elsa
Jasmine
Mulan
Ava believes that $40\%$ of young girls would choose Elsa. What type of significance test should she conduct in order to test this theory?

choices.text: One-sample $t$-test for proportions.
One-sample $z$-test for proportions.
A $z$-test for a difference in proportions.
${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ test for goodness of fit.
${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ test for independence.

title: Interpreting a Confidence Interval
question_text:
In $2014$, the FIFA (Men's) World Cup was held in Brazil. In $2016$, Brazil also hosted the Summer Olympics.
Researchers decided to investigate which fans knew where their next big event would be held.
In $2014$, researchers asked a random sample of fans attending the FIFA World Cup to identify where the next World Cup would be held. Of those fans surveyed, $61\%$ correctly said that the next World Cup was scheduled to be held in Russia.
In $2016$, researchers also asked a random sample of fans attending the Summer Olympics to identify where the next Summer Olympics would be held. Of those fans surveyed, $56\%$ correctly identified that the next Summer Olympics were scheduled to be held in Japan.
A $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference in population proportions (World Cup fans - Summer Olympics fans) was constructed and found to be $(-0.04, 0.14)$.
Which of the following provides the best interpretation of this confidence interval?

choices.text: The probability that a World Cup fan will know where the next World Cup will be held is $95\%$ higher than the probability that a Summer Olympics fan will know where the next Summer Olympics will be held, but the proportion for both fans is somewhere between $-0.04$ and $0.14$.

There is a $95\%$ chance that the percent of World Cup fans who know that the next World Cup will be held in Russia is between $4\%$ less and $14\%$ more than the percent of Summer Olympics fans who know that the next Summer Olympics will be held in Japan.

The researchers are $95\%$ confident that between $4\%$ less and $14\%$ more of the World Cup fans surveyed knew where their next big event would be held than did Summer Olympics fans who were surveyed.

The researchers are $95\%$ confident that the percent of fans attending the $2014$ World Cup who know where their next big event will be held is somewhere between $14\%$ higher and $4\%$ lower than the percent of fans attending the $2016$ Summer Olympics who know where their next big event will be held.

The researchers are $95\%$ confident that the proportion of World Cup fans who know where their next big event will be held is somewhere between $0.04$ higher and $0.14$ lower than the proportion of Summer Olympics fans who know where their next big event will be held.

title: Job Satisfaction Survey - Confidence Interval
question_text:
Suppose $500\text{ randomly selected employees}$ were asked if they are satisfied with their current job.
Of those surveyed, $261\text{ employees}$ responded that they were satisfied with their current job.
What conclusions can we gather from a $90\%$ confidence interval constructed from this data?

choices.text: This interval gives us strong evidence that more than $50\%$ of people are happy with their job.
We are $90\%$ confident that between about $47.8\%$ and $56.6\%$ of all employed people are satisfied with their current job.
We are $90\%$ confident that between about $47.8\%$ and $56.6\%$ of people sampled in this survey are satisfied with their current job.
We are $90\%$ confident that between about $48.5\%$ and $55.9\%$ of all employed people are satisfied with their current job.
We are $90\%$ confident more individuals are happy with their current job than dissatisfied with their current job.

title: How's the Weather?
question_text:
Blue Fin Real Estate was interested in what prompted people to choose to live on either the East Coast or the West Coast. Random samples of $400$ people on each coast were asked what the most important factor was in their decision. On the East Coast, $68$ people chose weather and on the West Coast, $88$ people chose weather.
Blue Fin wanted to know if there was a difference in the proportions of choice of weather between people living on the East and West Coasts. Given a significance level of $\alpha=0.05$, determine the range of where the $p$-value falls and whether or not we can reject the null hypothesis that the proportions are really the same.

choices.text:
$0.025<p$-value$<0.05$
Fail to reject $Ho$, there is no difference in the proportions.

$0.05<p$-value$<0.10$
Fail to reject $Ho$, there is no difference in the proportions.

$0.05<p$-value$<0.10$
Reject $Ho$, there is a difference in the proportions.

$0.025<p$-value$<0.05$
Reject $Ho$, there is a difference in the proportions.

0.05<p-value<0.10
Reject Ho, there is no difference in the proportions.

title: Point Estimator for One Proportion $z$-Interval: Airline Flight
question_text:
A $99\%$ confidence interval for the proportion of people who don't show up for their airline flights is $(0.022,0.076)$.
Using this data, what is the point estimate for the proportion of people who don't show up for their flights?

choices.text: It cannot be determined from the information given.

title: Are the Ratings Running Better?
question_text:
On the Nile Company website, items are reviewed by customers on a scale from $1$ to $5$ diamonds (with $5$ diamonds being the best rating possible).
The maker of Mike's Running Shoes was concerned about the percentage of customers rating their running shoes at $5$ diamonds. A survey of $50$ random customers last year produced $42$ customers giving this top rating of $5$ diamond to their shoes, but this year a survey of $54$ random customers yielded only $40$ customers giving the same high rating.
Calculate a $95\%$ confidence interval to give an interval estimate for the change in ratings.

title: Shape of Distribution
question_text:
Suppose the graduation rate for high school students in a certain state is $91\%$. A sample survey contacts an SRS of $100$ recent high school seniors and calculates the proportion $\hat{p}$ in this sample who graduated high school.
What is the shape of the sampling distribution of $\hat{p}$?

choices.text: Uniform
Bimodal
Approximately Normal
Skewed Left
The shape is unknown

solution:
Since we are dealing with a sample proportion, $\hat{p}$, we can use the Large Counts Condition to tell us the shape. The only shape we would be able to prove is approximately normal.

The sampling distribution of any $\hat{p}$ is approximately normal if:

$np \geq 10$

and

$n(1 - p) \geq 10$

Since our $n=100$ and $p = 0.91$, the inequality $n(1-p)$ does not equal at least $10$ as $100(0.09)$ only equals $9$. Therefore, the shape of the sampling distribution is unknown.

Choice 'E" is correct.

title: Two-sided Conclusion
question_text:
A group of college students in a psychology class wonders if the order of treatments changes the outcome of a study.
To test this, they ask students in a blind taste test which of two colas they prefer, Pepsi or Coke. In this blind taste test, the first $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Pepsi and then Coke. The next $50\text{ randomly chosen subjects}$ are given Coke and then Pepsi.
Suppose the test statistic is $z = 1.56$ when comparing the proportion of those who preferred Pepsi when tasted first to the proportion who liked Pepsi when tasted second.
On a two-sided test, what is the appropriate conclusion?

choices.text: Since $p > 0.05$, strong evidence exists of no difference between the treatments.
Since $p <0.1$, strong evidence exists of a difference in treatments.
Since $p < 0.05$, strong evidence exists of a difference in treatments.
Since $p > 0.1$, there is insufficient evidence of a difference in preference based on which order the sodas are given.
Since $p > 0.1$, strong evidence exists that order does not affect preference.

title: Why Do We Reject the Null?
question_text: Which of the following best describes why we would choose to reject the null hypothesis when our $p$-value is very small?

choices.text: A small $p$-value gives us little confidence in our results.
A small $p$-value leaves little room for margin of error. Therefore, it is best to reject the null hypothesis.

A small $p$-value indicates that the standard deviation was quite large. Since there is so much variation around the value in our null hypothesis, we have good reason to doubt that it is really true. Therefore, we should reject it.
A very small $p$-value means that our results were very unlikely based upon the assumption that the null hypothesis is true. This may lead us to reject the null hypothesis.
If our $p$-value is very small, we should not reject our null hypothesis! The null hypothesis is probably true!

title: One Proportion $z$-Interval: Finding the Minimum Sample Size
question_text:
You want to design a study for the proportion of adults who agree with this statement: "Do you think this coin will land on tails when I flip it?". You will use a $95\%$ confidence interval, and you want the margin of error to be $.05$ or less.
What is the minimum sample size that is required for those conditions?

title: Type I Error
question_text: A type I error is best described as an error result in

choices.text: Rejecting a true null hypothesis.
Rejecting a false null hypothesis.
Not rejecting a true null hypothesis.
Not rejecting a false null hypothesis.
Making two successive incorrect statistical decisions in two independent experiments.

title: Construction $2$ Proportion $z$-Interval: Fruits and Vegetables
question_text:
A nutritionist was interested in seeing if there was difference in people from the U.S. who prefer fruit over vegetables compared with the people in Canada who prefer fruit over vegetables. The nutritionist randomly selected $200\text{ people}$ from each country, and found that $136\text{ people}$ from the U.S. and $108\text{ people}$ from Canada favored fruit over vegetables.
Which formula calculates the $98\%$ confidence interval for the difference in proportions of Americans who prefer fruit over vegetables to Canadians who do so?

title: P-value and significance level: What to Do?
question_text:
Suppose in a significance test a P-value of $14\%$ is produced.
The correct conclusion at the $10\%$ significance level would be to:

choices.text: Reject the ${ H }_{ 0 }$.
Accept the ${ H }_{ 0 }$.
Fail to reject ${ H }_{ 0 }$
Accept the ${ H }_{ A }$.
It cannot be determined from the information given.

title: Which Distribution for Two Population Proportions?
question_text: When completing a significance test for the difference between two population proportions, which of the following distributions should be used?

choices.text: A binomial distribution where $n$ is the combined number of observations from both populations and $p$ is the overall proportion of successful observations.
A $z$-distribution that assumes a mean difference of $0$.
A $t$-distribution that assumes a mean difference of $0$.
A ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ distribution where $df = n-1$ and $n$ is the combined number of observations from both populations.
None of the above.

title: What Is the Largest Confidence Level? $1$-sided Test
question_text:
A one proportion $z$-test was used to conduct a test of the null hypotheses:
$$H_0: p = 0.08$$

$$H_a: p < 0.08$$
The $p$-value was $0.047$. A confidence interval for $p$ is to be constructed.
Of the following, which is the largest level of confidence for which the confidence interval will NOT contain $0.08$?

title: NFL Viewership
question_text:
In a survey on NFL viewership, $589$ subjects were asked if they watch NFL football on a regular basis during the season. In this survey, $43\%$ responded favorably, with a margin of error of $4\%$.
The confidence interval used in this situation is a

choices.text: $95\%$ confidence one-proportion $Z$-interval.
$99\%$ confidence one-proportion $Z$-interval.
$95\%$ confidence one-sample $T$-interval.
$90\%$ confidence proportion $Z$-interval.
Cannot be determined with the given information.

title: Not as Much Tattoo Ink? Find the $p$-Value
question_text:
Travis recently heard a report claiming that $35\%$ of young adults have at least one tattoo. He thinks that the actual percentage is lower for students at his university. To investigate, he randomly selects $60\text{ students}$ from his university and finds that $17$ of them have at least one tattoo.
Assuming that all conditions have been satisfied, what is the $p$-value for the appropriate significance test?

title: Test Statistic
question_text: A test statistic for the z- or t-distribution represents

choices.text: The probability of getting a result, or more extreme, given the null hypothesis was true.
The probability of a result, or more extreme, given the alternative hypothesis was true.
The number of standard deviations the result was away from the mean.
The distance away from the mean, using the units represented in the problem.
The amount of evidence one has to reject the alternative hypothesis.

title: Senator Approval
question_text:
Suppose $15$ randomly chosen subjects are questioned on whether they approve of their U.S. senator.
Of these, $3$ subjects approved, and $12$ did not approve of their senator. A $90\%$ confidence interval was computed on this data.
Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: We are $90\%$ confident that the true proportion of subjects who approve of their senator is between $3\%$ and $37\%$.
This survey gives strong evidence that the true proportion of subjects who approve of their senator is less than $35\%$.
We are $90\%$ confident that the true proportion of subjects who approve of their senator is between $13.3\%$ and $26.6\%$.
We are $90\%$ confident that the true proportion of subjects who approve of their senator is between $17\%$ and $23\%$.
A confidence interval in this situation should NOT be done as assumptions are not met.

title: Meaning of a Confidence Level for Proportions: Town Budget
question_text:
A random sample of $100$ citizens in a town were asked: "Would you approve the budget proposal?". A $90\%$ confidence interval was constructed for the proportion of citizens who would approve the budget and yielded a result of $(0.567, 0.634)$.
Which of the following statements is correct?

choices.text: About $90\%$ of all random samples of $100$ citizens from this town would result in a $90\%$ confidence interval of $(0.567,0.634)$.
$90\%$ of citizens in the survey reported that they had a $56.7\%$ to $63.4\%$ chance of approving the budget.
$90\%$ of all possible samples of $100$ citizens will contain the interval $(0.567,0.634)$.
About $90\%$ of all random samples of $100$ citizens from the town would result in a confidence interval that captures the population proportion of citizens who approve the budget.
$90\%$ of the time the interval from $(0.567, 0.634)$ will contain the population proportion of citizens who would approve the budget.

title: Sample Size: Effect on $Z$-Statistic and $P$-Value
question_text:
Miguel conducted a one-sample $z$-test for a population proportion. Later, he realized that while he had correctly computed the sample proportion (which was larger than his hypothesized proportion), he had incorrectly recorded the sample size when calculating the standard error. In reality, the actual sample size was smaller than the sample size he had used in his calculation.
If Miguel revises his calculation of standard error to decrease the sample size, which of the following describes the effect upon the $z$-statistic and the corresponding $p$-value?
Note: his alternative hypothesis is that $p > p_0$

choices.text: Both the $z$-statistic and the $p$-value will remain unchanged.
Both the $z$-statistic and the $p$-value will decrease.
Both the $z$-statistic and the $p$-value will increase.
The $z$-statistic will decrease and the $p$-value will increase.
The $z$-statistic will increase and the $p$-value will decrease.

title: Testing Conclusions: Kitana and Other Female Gamers
question_text:
Once upon a time a greater proportion of males played video games than females. Kitana, Jade, Lara and other female gamers wanted to know if this was still true and decided to investigate. Assuming all conditions were satisfied, a $z$-statistic of $z = 1.08$ was obtained from a test using the following hypotheses:
$$H_0: p_{males} = p_{females}$$
$$H_a: p_{males} > p_{females}$$
What should Kitana and her friends conclude based upon the results of her test?

choices.text: Since the sample of females produced a greater proportion of gamers than the sample of males, it appears that the proportion of females who play video games is now higher than the proportion of males who play video games.

Since the sample of males produced a greater proportion of gamers than the sample of females, it appears that the proportion of males who play video games is still higher than the proportion of females who play video games.

Since the $p$-value of the test was greater than $0.05$, we do not have enough evidence to rule out the possibility that the proportion of females who play video games is now equal to the proportion of males who play video games.

Since the $p$-value of the test was less than $0.05$, we have good evidence to suggest that the proportion of females who play video games is still less than the proportion of males who play video games.

Since the $z$-statistic is greater than $1$, the observed difference in proportions is more than $1$ standard deviation above a mean difference of $0$. Because this happens so rarely, our data proves that the proportion of males who play video games is still greater than the proportion of females who play video games.

title: Minimum Sample Size: Adults and Social Media
question_text:
Cara and all of her high school friends have social media accounts, but she wonders about the proportion of adults who use social media. She hypothesizes that this proportion would be about $65\%$ and decides that she wants to conduct a study.
What is the minimum number of adults she must include in her study for the results of the significance test to be valid?

title: Two-Proportion Test: Power
question_text:
Which of the following statements is/are NOT true about power in the context of a two-proportion test?
I. Large sample sizes will often allow the statistician to find a significant difference between the two proportions if one really exists.
II. Low alpha levels will allow the statistician to find a significant difference between the two proportions if one really exists.
III. Power will be $1$, the probability of a Type I error.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
II and III only.

title: Playing Giddy Up - Go: Standard Deviation of Proportion
question_text:
Giddy Up - Go is a hot new game app that can be downloaded on smartphones. Researchers wanted to know what proportion of smartphone users have downloaded the app. They believe that the actual proportion is $0.10$ and have decided to investigate.
After surveying a random sample of $225$ smartphone users, the researchers determined that $27$ had downloaded the app.
In constructing a confidence interval, which of the following shows how to calculate the standard deviation of the sample proportion?

title: Traffic Accidents
question_text:
A traffic engineer is curious if elderly drivers are more or less likely to get into accidents than teenage drivers.
The engineer randomly sampled $100$ teenage drivers and $100$ drivers more than $80$ years old, asking both groups if they have gotten in an accident in the last year.
A hypothesis test of $ { p }_{ 1 }= { p }_{ 2 }$ vs. ${ p }_{ 1 } ≠ { p }_{ 2 }$ gives a test statistic $z = 1.13$.
Assuming conditions for inference have been met, what conclusion can be made?

choices.text: Strong evidence exists to suggest that younger and older drivers are equally likely to get into an accident.
Weak evidence exists to suggest that younger and older drivers are equally likely to get into an accident.
There is insufficient information to come to any conclusion.
There is strong evidence of a difference in accident rates between older and younger drivers.
There is insufficient evidence to conclude older and younger drivers have different accident rates.

title: Finding the P-value of a 1-sided When Given a 2-sided P-value
question_text:
A two-sided hypothesis test obtained a $p$-value of $0.36$.
If the test was conducted as a one-tailed test using the same set of data, which of the following is true about the possible $p$-values that could have been acquired?

choices.text: The only possible $p$- value is $0.18$.
The only possible $p$- value is $0.72$.
The only possible $p$- value is $0.82$.
The possible $p$- values are $0.18$ and $0.72$.
The possible $p$- values are $0.18$ and $0.82$.

title: What Influences the Width of a Confidence Interval?
question_text: Which of the following will decrease the width of a confidence interval?

choices.text: Increase the value of $z^*$.
Increase the sample size.
Increase the confidence level.
Increase the value of the margin of error.
Change the value of $\hat{p}$ so that it gets closer to 0.5.

title: Best Pizza in Town
question_text:
Suppose a newspaper claims that $50\%$ of all residents in a town say that Restaurant $A$ has the best pizza in the town. A local fact-checker decides that he wants to test this claim and takes a SRS of $50$ residents from the town and asked them what Restaurant's pizza they prefer. In his sample, $45\%$ of people say they prefer Restaurant $A$.
The fact-checker then decides to simulate the responses to see if $45\%$ is a possible outcome if the population proportion is known to be $50\%$. Given is the fact-checker's sampling distribution for $\hat{p}$, the sample proportion of local residents that prefer Restaurant $A$.
What does each dot on the dot plot represent?

choices.text: The number of people who selected Restaurant $A$ in a single trial
The proportion of people who selected Restaurant $A$ in a single trial.
The proportion of people whole selected Restaurant $A$ from $50$ trials
The average number of people who selected Restaurant $A$ from $50$ trials
The proportion of people who did not selected Restaurant A from $50$ trials

solution:
The above dot plot represents the simulation of local residents selecting their favorite restaurant's pizza with a known proportion of $0.50$ who prefer Restaurant $A$. The fact-checker decided that he wanted to simulate the newspaper claim that stated that $50\%$ of the local town preferred Restaurant $A$.

Therefore, each dot on the dot plot represents one trial of the simulation, which will provide us with the proportion of local residents that prefer Restaurant $A$'s pizza.

Choice 'B" is correct.

title: Was the New Mattress Successful?
question_text: A company was offering a $30$-day trial on its new mattress product. The CEO of the company believed that the mattress would be successful as long as only $10\%$ of its customers returned their mattresses. The owner of a large store was afraid that the percentage would be greater than this, so $80$ random customers were selected and it was found that $12$ of them returned their mattress. Was the product successful at a significance level of $0.05$?

choices.text: Yes, because the $p$-value was between $0.10$ and $0.15$ which is too high to reject the null hypothesis that only $10\%$ of mattresses would be returned.
Yes, because the p-value was between $0.05$ and $0.10$ which is too high to reject the null hypothesis that only $10\%$ of mattresses would be returned.
No, because the p-value was between $0.05$ and $0.10$ which is low enough to reject the null hypothesis that only $10\%$ of mattresses would be returned.
No, because the p-value was between $0.10$ and $0.15$ which is too high to reject the null hypothesis that only $10\%$ of mattresses would be returned.
No, $15\%$ of the customers returned their mattresses and this is greater than $10\%$.

title: How to Reduce the Margin of Error to $1/5$ of the Original?
question_text:
A one-proportion $z$-interval was constructed. A researcher wants to reduce the margin of error to one-fifth of its original margin of error.
What would she have to do to the sample size?

choices.text: This cannot be answered without the sample size.
Divide the sample size by $5$.
Divide the sample size by $25$.
Multiply the sample size by $5$.
Multiply the sample size by $25$.

title: A Salty Question
question_text: A spice company was curious as to whether people preferred using salt or pepper. This company sold to many stores on both coasts. The company asked whether sales were higher for salt or pepper in $50$ randomly selected stores on the West Coast and another $50$ on the East Coast. On the West Coast, $30$ stores said that more salt was sold and on the East Coast, $18$ stores said that more salt was sold. Which would be the correct conclusion for a $95\%$ confidence interval?

choices.text: We are $95\%$ confident that the interval from $0.05$ to $0.43$ captures the true difference in the proportions of salt preference shown by store sales of the West Coast over the East Coast.
We are $95\%$ confident that the interval from $0.14$ to $0.34$ captures the true difference in the proportions of salt preference shown by store sales of the West Coast over the East Coast.
We are $95\%$ confident that the interval from $0.08$ to $0.40$ captures the true difference in the proportions of salt preference shown by store sales of the West Coast over the East Coast.
We are $95\%$ confident that the probability that West Coast stores sell more salt is between $0.05$ to $0.43$.
We are $95\%$ confident that the probability that West Coast stores sell more salt is between $0.14$ to $0.34$.

title: Home-Field Advantage
question_text:
A sports analyst wishes to make the claim that baseball teams are more likely to win home games than away games.
The analyst selects a local baseball team that has won $54$ of its $81\text{ home games}$ this season.
Assuming an equal number of home and away games, what is the maximum number of away games the home team can win for the analyst’s claim to be true at the $5\%$ level?

choices.text: Enough evidence already exists since the sample proportion of $\frac{54}{81}$ is already significantly greater than a $50\%$ chance of winning.

title: Sample Size and Significance: Who Has the Greatest Power?
question_text: In a hypothesis test, ${ H }_{ 0 }:p=0.8$ versus ${ H }_{ a }:p>0.8$ the power of the test $p=0.8$ would be the greatest for which of the following choices of sample size $n$ and significance level $\alpha $ ?

choices.text: $n=140\qquad \alpha =0.05$
$n=240\qquad \alpha =0.05$
$n=140\qquad \alpha =0.10$
$n=240\qquad \alpha =0.10$
It cannot be determined from the information given.

title: Type II error: West Wake Up Time Versus East
question_text:
A sleep specialist believes that adults on the West Coast sleep less hours per day than adults on the East Coast. Collecting large random samples of adults from the West Coast and East Coast, the sleep specialist studies the amount of hours per day adults on the West Coast sleep compared to adults on the East Coast.
Which of the following describes a Type II error in the context of the situation?

choices.text: The sleep specialist correctly concludes the average amount of hours per day adults sleep on the West Coast is less than adults on the East Coast.

The sleep specialist concludes the average amount of hours per day adults sleep on the West Coast is less than adults on the East Coast when in reality adults on the West Coast average the same amount of sleep as adults on the East Coast.

The sleep specialist concludes the average amount of hours per day adults sleep on the West Coast is not less than adults on the East Coast when in reality adults on the West Coast average less sleep than adults on the East Coast.

The sleep specialist concludes the average amount of hours per day adults sleep on the West Coast is the same as adults on the East Coast when in reality adults on the West Coast average the same amount of sleep as adults on the East Coast.
A type II error cannot be committed in this situation.

title: Cat Ownership and Test Conditions
question_text:
According to the American Veterinary Medical Foundation, $30.4\%$ of U. S. households owned at least one cat in 2012. Josephina wonders if this percentage is currently true for households in her town. To investigate, she contacts randomly selected households in her town and determines the proportion of these households that own at least one cat. To analyze the results of her study she will use a one sample $z$-test for proportions.
Which of the following is a condition that must be satisfied in order for her test to be valid?

choices.text: Josephina must gather data from at least $30\text{ households}$.

Josephina must select a sample size, $n$, such that:
$0.304n\ge10$
$\left( 1-0.304 \right) n\ge10$
The population of households that own at least one cat must be at least twice as large as Josephina's sample size.
Josephina must make sure that there are no outliers in the number of cats owned by a household in her sample.
Josephina must know that the population distribution for households that own at least one cat is approximately normal.

title: Jeans on Sale
question_text: A company produced two lines of women's blue jeans, the Cheapos and the Fancies. The CEO of the company wanted to sample its stores to find the proportions of pants on hand which were purchased on a given day. It was found that in a sample of $80$ Cheapos, a proportion of $0.45$ was sold, and in a sample of $80$ Fancies, a proportion of $0.25$ was sold. Calculate an approximate interval estimate of the difference of on-hand inventory sold based on a $90\%$ confidence interval.

choices.text: About $20\%$

title: Who Wins?
question_text: Five interns work for a large popcorn company. They are in a competition to see who can come up with the best idea to help with popcorn sales. They are required to use some sort of statistical test. Their five ideas are listed below. Four are in the running because they seemed to make sense, but one did not make sense. Which one mentions a test which does not coordinate with the information to be collected?

choices.text: Annie suggested that $50$ random households be surveyed and asked about the amount they spent on popcorn they purchased in the previous month. Then Annie planned to take those numbers and run a one-sample $z$-test for a population proportion.

Bob suggested that $50$ random movie theaters be surveyed and asked about the amount of popcorn sales they had in the previous month. Then Bob would test to see if sales exceeded $\$10,000$ by using a one-sample t-test for a population mean.

Carly suggested $50$ random convenience stores be surveyed. She wanted to find what percentage of sales on average over the past week was for popcorn. Then Carly would test to see if sales surpassed $20\%$ using a one-sample $z$-test for a population proportion.

Dan wanted to compare sales in convenience stores and grocery stores. He would sample $30$ random stores of each to obtain their sales for the previous week. Dan would then construct a confidence interval for the difference of two population means.

Eduardo suggested that $50$ random grocery stores be surveyed and asked about the amount of popcorn sales they had in the previous month. Then Eduardo would make a confidence interval for the sample mean.

title: Computer Output T-Test | 1 of 2
question_text:
A study on women’s weights was recently completed.
Fifteen randomly selected high school females from an urban setting were compared to $16$ randomly selected high school females from a rural setting. Assume that the distribution of both populations are approximately normal. The results are below:
Two-Sample T for Urban Weights vs. Rural Weights
N Mean StDev SE Mean
Urban Weights 15 126.1 10.5 2.7
Rural Weights 16 128.8 13.2 3.3


$\text{ Difference }= \mu \text{ (Urban Weights)} - \mu \text{ (Rural Weights)}$
Estimate for difference: $-2.68$
$95\%$ confidence interval for difference: ($-11.45, 6.09$)
$\text{T-test of difference }= 0$
$\text{T-value }= -0.63$
$\text{ P-value }= 0.537$
$\text{ DF }= 28$
What can one conclude from the results of the two-sample $T$-test?
tables:
NMeanStDevSE Mean
Urban Weights15126.110.52.7
Rural Weights16128.813.23.3

choices.text: Strong evidence exists that females from rural and urban areas weigh about the same.
Weak evidence exists that females from rural and urban areas have different weights.
There was a failure to find sufficient evidence of a difference between weights for rural and urban high school females.
Strong evidence exists that rural high school females weigh more than urban high school females.
The conditions for this test were not met, so any conclusions are invalid.

title: Track Times
question_text:
Suppose Jimmy and Bobby are two long-time competitors on the same track team in the $400$-meter dash.
Jimmy and Bobby have ran $10$ races this year. Jimmy has averaged $56.2$ seconds with a standard deviation of $1.3$ seconds, while Bobby has averaged $55.8$ seconds with a standard deviation of $1.3$ seconds. Bobby asked the coach to perform a two-sample T-test to determine if he is significantly better than Jimmy this year.
What conclusion does the coach make?

choices.text: Any inferential procedure in this context does not make sense.
Bobby is faster at the alpha $5\%$ level, but not at the $1\%$ level.
Jimmy is faster at the alpha $5\%$ level, but not at the $1\%$ level.
Bobby is faster at the alpha $1\%$ level.
There is insufficient evidence at the alpha $10\%$ level to determine who is faster.

title: Heights of American Women
question_text:
Fifth grader Scott is studying the heights of American women for a science fair project.
Scott’s teacher told him that the heights of American females are normally distributed with the population standard deviation of $2.4\text{ inches}$, but he cannot remember the value for the mean.
Scott’s older brother suggests that he estimate the unknown mean by calculating a confidence interval using data that Scott has collected for the heights of four women, as follows:
$63 \text{ inches}$
$69\text{ inches}$
$62\text{ inches}$
$66\text{ inches}$
Based on this, Scott’s $99\%$ confidence interval would be:

title: Conditions for a One-Sample $t$-Test
question_text: A company wishes to find out the number of one of its products its customers buy per year. It decides to sample its customers to estimate the population mean of its number of sales. Which of the following lists a set of conditions needed to verify running a one-sample $t$-test?

choices.text:
It chooses to sample $100$ of its customers.
These customers will be chosen randomly from a list of its $500$ customers who buy this product each year.

It chooses to sample $100$ of its customers.
These customers will be selected from a list of its $2000$ customers who buy this product each year.

It chooses to sample $100$ of its customers.
These customers will be chosen randomly from a list of its $2000$ customers who buy this product each year.

It chooses to sample $20$ of its customers who will be chosen randomly from its list of $400$ customers who buy the product each year.
Two of these $20$ customers are atypical, purchasing abnormally large amounts of the item.

title: Evidence from a Test: Growing Jalapeños for Salsa
question_text:
Felipe wants to grow his own jalapeño peppers so that he can make fresh salsa. When he picked out his seedlings at the plant nursery, he was told that jalapeño peppers of this variety reach an average length of $2.75\text{ inches}$ with a standard deviation of $0.25\text{ inches}$.
Felipe thinks that the average length of his peppers is less than $2.75\text{ inches}$ and decides to do a test. Assume all of the appropriate conditions have been satisfied.
If Felipe finds that $8$ randomly selected peppers have an average length of $2.625\text{ inches}$, is this enough evidence to suggest that his peppers are shorter on average than what was advertised to him?

choices.text: There is definitely enough evidence to suggest that the average length of this variety of jalapeño pepper is less than $2.75\text{ inches}$. The person at the nursery was lying to Felipe.

There is enough evidence to suggest that the average length of peppers on Felipe's plants is less than $2.75\text{ inches}$. Maybe his peppers are just not growing to be as long as the true average for some reason.
There is enough evidence for Felipe to conclude that the actual average length of his jalapeño peppers is $2.625\text{ inches}$.
There is not enough evidence to suggest that the average length of Felipe's jalapeño peppers is less than $2.75\text{ inches}$. His results could simply be the result of sampling variability.
There is not enough evidence to suggest that the average length of Felipe's jalapeño peppers is $2.625\text{ inches}$. His results were probably just the result of bad luck.

title: Constructing a $2$-sample Mean Interval: Dunkin Bucks
question_text:
Dunkin Bucks is interested in the number of cups of coffee their adults customers drink per day compared with their teenage customers. Dunkin Bucks randomly selects $75$ adults and $75$ teenagers and asks them: "How many cups of coffee do you drink?" The resulting data is below:
N Average cups Standard Deviation
Adults $75$ $1.8$ $0.6$
Teenagers $75$ $1.3$ $0.3$


Which of the following represents a $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference in the average number of cups of coffee drunk per day between Dunkin Bucks adult customers and teenage customers?
tables:
NAverage cupsStandard Deviation
Adults$75$$1.8$$0.6$
Teenagers$75$$1.3$$0.3$

title: Carrot Chips and $p$-Values
question_text:
Jessica Rabbit loves carrot chips and buys one ounce bags to pack with her lunch. According to the label, there are an average of $25\text{ chips per ounce}$. Jessica suspects that the true average is lower and decides to investigate. She selects $12\text{ bags of chips}$ (which she is willing to consider a random sample) and finds the average number of chips per bag is $23.4$ with a standard deviation of $4.6$.
Assuming all conditions are satisfied, what is the $p$-value for the appropriate statistical test?

title: Formula: Degrees of Freedom
question_text: Determine the appropriate degrees of freedom on a two-sample $T$-test with samples of size $25$ and $17$.

title: Analyzing $T$-Table Results
question_text:
Suppose a one-sided test gives a test statistic $t = 2.45$ for a sample of size $n=24$.
What conclusion can be made at the $\alpha = 5\%$ level?

choices.text: Reject $H_0$ at the $5\%$ level.
Fail to reject $H_0$ at the $5\%$ level.
Reject $H_a$ at the $5\%$ level.
Fail to reject $H_a$ at the $5\%$ level.
Retain the null at the $5\%$ level.

title: Math SAT Scores
question_text: For an AP Statistics project, a student named Joe was curious as to the average math SAT scores of students at his school. He chose $30$ seniors at random and found an average SAT math score of $542$ with a standard deviation of $81$. He wanted to construct a $99\%$ confidence interval. Find the margin of error for that interval.

choices.text: margin of error $=2.750\lgroup\dfrac{81}{\sqrt{30}}\rgroup$
margin of error $=2.045\lgroup\dfrac{81}{\sqrt{30}}\rgroup$
margin of error $=2.756\lgroup\dfrac{81}{\sqrt{30}}\rgroup$
margin of error $=2.756\lgroup\dfrac{30}{\sqrt{81}}\rgroup$
margin of error $=2.750\lgroup\dfrac{81}{30}\rgroup$

title: Proof?
question_text: Which confidence interval below is the most convincing one to show that two sample means are in fact not different?

title: Interpreting a Confidence Interval
question_text:
A $90\%$ confidence interval for an unknown population mean, $\mu$, has been calculated as $87±12$.
What is the correct interpretation of this confidence interval?

choices.text: We are $90\%$ confident that the unknown population mean is between $75$ and $99$.
There is a $0.9$ probability that the unknown population mean is between $75$ and $99$.
$90\%$ of all confidence intervals will be between $75$ and $99$.
If we took many samples from this population, $90\%$ of the computed confidence intervals would contain the unknown population mean.
$90\%$ of data from the population is between $75$ and $99$.

title: Pole-Vaulting to New Heights: What Are Your Hypotheses?
question_text:
Today, poles used for pole-vaulting are usually made of fiberglass and carbon fiber. A sporting goods company has developed a pole made from a new composite material and they believe that using this pole will allow vaulters to reach greater heights. They plan to conduct a study involving a sample of $30$ experienced pole-vaulters.
Each pole-vaulter will be given $5$ attempts to vault with a traditional pole made of fiberglass and carbon fiber, and their highest vault will be recorded. At a different time, each pole-vaulter will also be given $5$ attempts to vault with a pole made of the new material and their highest vault will be recorded. Which pole is used first will be randomly determined.
For each pole-vaulter, researchers will also record the difference between their highest vault using the new pole and their highest vault using the traditional pole (New – Traditional).
After verifying that the necessary conditions are satisfied, researchers plan to conduct a test.
What are the appropriate hypotheses?

choices.text:
${ H }_{ 0 }: { \mu }_{ traditional } = { \mu }_{ new }$
${ H }_{ a }: { \mu }_{ traditional } < { \mu }_{ new }$

${ H }_{ 0 }: { \mu }_{ traditional } = { \mu }_{ new }$
${ H }_{ a }: { \mu }_{ traditional } \neq { \mu }_{ new }$

${ H }_{ 0 }: { \mu }_{ difference } = 0$
${ H }_{ a }: { \mu }_{ difference } < 0$

${ H }_{ 0 }: { \mu }_{ difference } = 0$
${ H }_{ a }: { \mu }_{ difference } \neq 0$

${ H }_{ 0 }: { \mu }_{ difference } = 0$
${H }_{ a }: { \mu }_{ difference } > 0$

title: Find the Critical Value for Mean with Unknown Standard Deviation
question_text:
You want to compute a $95\%$ confidence interval for the mean population with an unknown standard deviation. The data is collected from an SRS of $25$ observations, and it is approximately normal.
What critical value would we need for the $95\%$ confidence interval?

title: Can We Proceed?
question_text: We want to create a $99\%$ confidence interval for the different of the means of the effectiveness of two drugs to reduce the incidence of headaches. Forty-two headache patients are randomly selected from several large medical practices and half of them are given one drug and half the other drug. Determination of which drug was given to which patient was decided by a coin flip. Means and standard deviations of the subjects are obtained. What conditions need to be verified in order to continue with this study and create a confidence interval?

choices.text: Both samples should be checked for skewness and the size of the population of headache patients should be checked.
The check for independence has been verified but the check for normal approximation of the sampling distribution has not been verified.
The check for normal approximation of the sampling distribution has been verified but the check for independence has not been verified.
Since there are $42$ patients, and this number is greater than $30$, then the only other thing needed to be checked is the randomization process.
Nothing else needs to be done. All conditions are verified and the confidence interval may be calculated.

title: Correct Hypotheses: Heights of Twins
question_text:
A random sample on heights of $50$ pairs of $18$ year old identical twins was used to determine whether the second born twin tends to be taller than the first born.
Let ${ \mu }_{ 2 } $ represent the average height of the second born, let ${ \mu }_{ 1 } $ represent the average height of the first born twin, and let ${ \mu }_{ d }$ represents the average difference in the height (height of second born minus height of first born) for all pairs of twins.
Which of the following would be the null and alternative hypothesis for this study?

title: TV Station Standard Deviation
question_text:
A television programmer at a local news station surveyed the last $30\text{ weekday nights}$ and recorded the number of viewers on the $10$ p.m. news.
Last year, approximately $475{,}000\text{ people}$ viewed the weekday evening news per night based off data from the entire year.
This year, $30$ randomly sampled weekday nights found an average $495{,}000\text{ people per night}$ watching the weekday evening news.
If this increase is significant at the $1\%$ level, what is the standard deviation of the sample?

choices.text: $44{,}494$ or greater.
Less than $44{,}494$.
$8{,}123$ or greater.

title: $t$-distribution vs. Normal Distribution
question_text: In what way is the $t$-distribution different from the standard normal distribution?

choices.text: There are many $t$-distributions based on the number of degrees of freedom, but only one standard normal distribution.
The $t$-distribution cannot be used to determine if an observed statistic is unusual, but the standard normal distribution can be used in this way.
The area under the curve of the $t$-distribution changes as the number of degrees of freedom changes. The area under the standard normal curve is always $1$.
The $t$-distribution is not useful in constructing confidence intervals.
The $t$-distribution is not useful in conducting hypothesis tests.

title: Finding a Critical $t$-value for a Confidence Level
question_text: What is the critical value of $t$ for a $95\%$ confidence interval with $20$ degrees of freedom?

title: LSAT Challenge
question_text:
Two competing universities each believed that they better prepared their students for law school. They hired an independent researcher to create a $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference between the mean LSAT scores of the two schools. Thirty-five pre-law students from each school were randomly selected. At School $1$ the mean LSAT score was $171$ with a standard deviation of $14$. At School $2$ the mean LSAT score was $168$ with a standard deviation of $11$.
Using Table B for your critical value, which is the correct $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference between the mean LSAT scores of the two schools?

title: Plant Yield
question_text:
A gardener wishes to determine which of two different potato plants gives the highest yield (in terms of pounds per plant).
In a large field, $15$ plants of variety A were planted in random locations. In a different large field, $15$ plants of variety B were planted in random locations.
Variety A averaged $56.43\text{ pounds per plant}$, with a standard deviation of $0.1\text{ pounds}$, and variety B averaged $56.53\text{ pounds per plant}$ with a standard deviation of $0.14\text{ pounds}$. When performing a two-sample $T$-test on this data, the $p$-value was $0.033$.
Which of the following statements is/are true concerning the interpretation of these results?
I. These results cannot be trusted, as randomization was not properly used in this context.
II. These results may not be useful, as the difference is so small.
III. These results may not be useful, as it is likely that the sampling distribution will not be approximately normal.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
II and III only.

title: Game Time: Standard Error
question_text:
In recent years, new rules have been put in place to try to speed up the amount of time it takes to complete a professional baseball game. Before these rules were enacted, the mean length of a professional baseball game was about $172\text{ minutes}$.

When conducting his test, what value would Hank use for the standard error of the statistic?

choices.text: We cannot determine the standard error since we don't know the standard deviation for the games that were played prior to the new rules being enacted. We need to know this in order to conduct a $2$-sample $t$-test for a difference in means.

title: Males/Females ACT
question_text:

question_text:
