title: Average Time Spent on Homework
question_text:
A high school principal claims that his students spend an average of $50$ minutes on their homework each night. The Statistics teacher does not believe the Principal's claim is true. To test the claim, the teacher decides to model a sampling distribution of samples of $30$ random students from the large high school.
Given is the graph of the sampling distribution for the average amount of time spent on homework for $30$ students
Should the teacher believe the Principal's claim that students at this school typically work on homework for an average of $50$ minutes per day?

choices.text: Yes, because $50$ minutes or more happened enough times in the sampling distribution that it couldn't have happened by chance.
Yes, because the graph is approximately Normal as the sample size was greater than $30$
No, because the graph was centered around $40$ and not $50$
No, because $50$ only happened $4$ times in the sampling distribution
No, because the teacher did not ask all students at the school

solution:
When looking to see if a value is a plausible value for a true parameter value, we can see if it happens during trials of chance behavior. In this instance, the teacher selected random samples of students to simulate a sampling distribution of sample means. In the sampling distribution, we see that there are four dots at $50$ and two dots at $55$ (which is also evidence for $50$).

Therefore, since we have a fair amount of dots, in fact $\frac{6}{26} \approx 23\%$ of the time, we believe that the Principal is not lying with his claim.

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: Convincing Evidence That Seniors Are Absent More Often?
question_text:
In a certain state, officials at the Department of Education wanted to investigate whether seniors in high school are absent more often than other high school students. At the end of the school year, a random sample of $50$ seniors from the state was selected, and their attendance records were analyzed.
The mean number of days these seniors were absent from school was $6.2$ with a standard deviation of $2.1$. Attendance records were also analyzed for a second, independent random sample of $50$ high school students in the state who were not seniors. The mean number of days these students were absent was $5.7$ days with a standard deviation of $1.6$. No outliers were found in either sample.
Does the data provide convincing evidence at the $\alpha=0.05$ level that seniors in high school have more absences on average than other high school students?

choices.text: No, since the test statistic is less than $2.0$, the difference in sample averages was not significant enough to suggest that seniors are absent more often on average than other high school students.
No, since the $p$-value of the test is greater than $0.05$, we do not have sufficient evidence to suggest that seniors have more absences on average than other high school students.

Yes, since the $p$-value of the test is less than $0.02$, it is also less than $0.05$. Therefore, at the $\alpha=0.05$ level, we have strong evidence to suggest that seniors are absent more often on average than other high schools students.
Yes, since the sample average for seniors was $0.50$ days greater than the sample average for other high school students, we do have convincing evidence at the $\alpha=0.05$ level.
No conclusion can be reached since the conditions for inference have not been satisfied.

title: Average Tax Refund
question_text:
According to the Internal Revenue Service, IRS, the average tax return for an American citizen is $\$3{,}401$. An accountant examines the records of $30$ random clients and finds the average tax return for his clients to be $\$3{,}520$.
Explain why the accountant should not make the claim that the stated amount by the IRS is incorrect.

choices.text: Since the accountant does not know the standard deviation of from the IRS, he is unable to determine the probability that his observation happened purely by chance.
The accountant's sample size is much smaller than all taxpayers, so the accountant cannot compare the two groups
Since we do not know the that population, or the accountant's sample, are Normal data, we cannot make an assumption on the data
The accountant's data could have a large outlier which is affecting the data since the mean is a non-resistant measure
Since the data was random, the data cannot be generalized for the entire population

solution:
Very rarely will a sample mean equal the population mean, due to sampling variability. Therefore, the accountant's sample is simply a statistic because it describes the sample. Since we do not know the standard deviation, we cannot use the normal distribution to find the probability of the sample happening, if the population mean is correct.

Therefore, the accountant is unable to make the claim that the IRS made is incorrect.

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: Are the Batteries Lasting Long Enough?
question_text: The Durabell Battery company was concerned about the life of its EE battery. choices.text: Clearly, the new mean battery life has decreased from $34$ to $33.4$ hours. Thus, we can reject the null hypothesis and show that the EE battery life has decreased.

Because we obtain a $p$-value of $0.94$, which is greater than our significance level of $0.05$, we cannot reject the null hypothesis. Thus, we do not have enough evidence to show that the mean EE battery life has decreased.

Because we obtain a $p$-value of $0.06$, which is greater than our significance level of $0.05$, we must reject the null hypothesis. Thus, we have enough evidence to show that the mean EE battery life has decreased.

Because we obtain a $p$-value of $0.12$, which is greater than our significance level of $0.05$, we cannot reject the null hypothesis. Thus, we do not have enough evidence to show that the mean EE battery life has decreased.

Because we obtain a $p$-value of $0.06$, which is greater than our significance level of $0.05$, we cannot reject the null hypothesis. Thus, we do not have enough evidence to show that the mean EE battery life has decreased.

title: The Effect of Increasing Sample Size
question_text:
Jason conducted a one-sample $t$-test for a population mean. Later, he realized that he had made a mistake when entering the sample size into his calculations. The actual sample size was in fact larger than the sample size he had used in his calculations.
How will this change the results associated with his test?

choices.text: The standard deviation of the related $t$-distribution will be larger than previously calculated.
The actual $p$-value will be smaller than previously calculated.
The power of the test will be smaller than previously calculated.
The probability of making a Type I error will be larger than previously calculated.
The probability of making a Type II error will be larger than previously calculated.

title: Bugs and Blue Porch Ceilings: Finding the $p$-Value
question_text:
In many southern U. S. states, porch ceilings are painted a light blue color. Some people believe that the color tricks spiders, wasps and other insects into thinking that the ceiling is the sky and that this reduces the number of insects found on the porches.
Dixie wonders if this is really true and decides to investigate. She enlists the help of $35$ homeowners in South Carolina whose homes have porches. On each of these homes she paints half of the porch ceiling white and half of the porch ceiling light blue. Which half gets which color is determined by tossing a coin. She also places an insect trap on both sides of each porch.
After a period of two weeks, she counts the number of insects caught in each trap and determines the average number of insects caught near each color of paint. Her results are shown in the table below.
Sample Mean Sample Standard Deviation
Blue Paint 86.4 4.9
White Paint 87.7 5.2
Difference (Blue - White) -1.3 7.1


Assuming all conditions are satisfied, what is the $p$-value for a test to determine whether using light blue paint on porch ceilings will reduce the mean number of bugs on the porch?
tables:
Sample MeanSample Standard Deviation
Blue Paint86.44.9
White Paint87.75.2
Difference (Blue - White)-1.37.1

title: P-value of a 2-Sided Test When Given the t-test Statistic
question_text:
A significance test was performed to test ${ H }_{ 0 }:\mu =16$ versus the alternative ${ H }_{ a }:\mu \neq 16$. A random sample of size $51$ produced a test statistic is $t = 1.348$.
Which of the following intervals contains the P-value for this test?

title: Confidence Level and $1$-sided Significance Testing
question_text:
A one sample $t$-test for was used to conduct a test of the null hypotheses:
$${ H }_{ 0 }:\mu =28$$

$${ H }_{ a }:\mu <28$$
The $p$-value was $0.006$. A confidence interval for *$\mu$ * is to be constructed.
Of the following, which is the largest level of confidence for which the confidence interval will NOT contain $28$?

title: A Zoologist and the Giraffes: Conclusions from a Test
question_text:
A zoologist was looking through his old textbooks and found one that said the average height of an adult male giraffe is $18$ feet with a standard deviation of $1.1$ feet. He sees many giraffes and wonders if this average is true. To check it out, he selects the records of $40$ adult male giraffes that come to see him, records their height and finds the sample average to be $18.35$ feet.
Assuming that he is willing to consider his sample to represent a random sample, what conclusion would he reach after conducting an appropriate statistical test?

choices.text: He should conclude that the textbook is probably wrong. Assuming the average height of adult male giraffes is $18$ feet (as the textbook claimed), getting a sample average as extreme as $18.35$ feet would only happen about $4.4\%$ of the time simply by chance.
He should conclude that the textbook is definitely wrong. The sample average is more than $4$ inches above the value claimed in the textbook. That's a lot!
He can not conclude that the textbook is wrong. The sample average is less that one standard deviation above the mean, so it is fairly likely that he would get this sample average simply by chance.
He can not conclude that the textbook is wrong. Since our $p$-value is greater than $0.05$, we do not have enough evidence to believe that the average height of adult male giraffes is not $18$ feet.
He is not able to conduct a significance test here since not all conditions are satisfied.

title: Headaches
question_text:
We want to create a confidence interval for the difference of the means of the effectiveness of two drugs to reduce the incidence of headaches. Sixty-two headache patients are randomly selected from several large medical practices and half of them are given one drug and half the other drug. Determination of which drug was given to which patient was decided by a coin flip and all conditions were verified.
Three months later the total number of headaches suffered by each group was gathered. Group $1$ had $2.1$ headaches per person with a standard deviation of $1.2$ headaches. Group $2$ had $2.9$ headaches per person with a standard deviation of $1.6$ headaches.
If the upper bound of the confidence interval came out to be $0.02$, find the value of $t^{*}$ that was used in the calculation of this confidence interval.

title: Prom Costs: Upper Bound of Confidence Interval
question_text:
A group of students decided to construct a confidence interval to estimate the average cost of attending prom in their area. To gather data they surveyed a random sample of students who attended prom and surveyed them about how much they had spent.
If the sample mean was $\$914.32$ and the lower bound of their confidence interval was $\$863.57$, what was the largest cost estimated by the confidence interval?

title: Soups On
question_text: A company producing cans of soup was interested in checking the weight of its chicken soup cans. While marked at $16$ ounces, the company was concerned whether it was meeting this amount. A random sample of $36$ cans was taken and the sample mean was found to be $16.2$ ounces with a standard deviation of $0.8$ ounces. Find the value of the $t$ statistic as well as its degrees of freedom.

title: Calculating the Standard Deviation of the Proportion
question_text:
According to the National Center for Education Statistics, $65.9\%$ of students enrolled in college in the fall immediately after completing high school in the year $2013$.
Wendy just did some research for an article she is writing for the school newspaper and knows that at her high school, $84.1\%$ of students who graduated the previous year immediately enrolled to attend college that fall. She started to wonder if the percent of students who enroll in college immediately after completing high school is now greater than $65.9\%$.
To investigate, she contacted $437$ students (some from her school and some from other schools) that she knew would be graduating this year. She found that $80.3\%$ of them were planning to enroll in college immediately after completing high school.
If Wendy is willing to consider that all conditions have been satisfied, which of the following shows how to calculate the standard deviation of the proportion for the appropriate statistical test?
correct_answer: There are a lot of percentages given in this problem. Be careful!

title: Cereal Boxes
question_text:
A spokesman for a large cereal company is interested in whether a new promotion of including a toy in every box of cereal would greatly increase sales.
He figures that age would be a factor, so he selects one pair of subjects at each age range from $10$ to $79$ by increments of $5\text{ years}$.
The spokesman flips a coin to decide which of the pair gets a coupon for a free prize every time they buy a box of the cereal. After one year, each subject is asked how many boxes of that brand of cereal they bought.
The data is in the table below (scroll right to see full table):
Age Range 10- 14 15- 19 20- 24 24- 29 30- 34 35- 39 40- 44 45- 49 50- 54 55- 59 60- 64 65- 69 70- 74 75-79
With Coupon 9 8 8 5 4 12 14 13 8 6 5 4 4 2
Without Coupon 7 4 8 6 5 7 8 7 6 6 4 3 4 1


From this data, is there convincing statistical evidence that people buy more cereal when a prize coupon is included?
tables:
Age Range10- 1415- 1920- 2424- 2930- 3435- 3940- 4445- 4950- 5455- 5960- 6465- 6970- 7475-79
With Coupon98854121413865442
Without Coupon74865787664341

choices.text: Yes, at the $1\%$, $5\%$, and $10\%$ alpha levels.
Yes, at the $5\%$ and $10\%$ alpha level, but not the $1\%$ level.
Yes, at the $10\%$ alpha level, but not the $5\%$ or $1\%$ levels.
No, not at none of the common alpha levels of $1\%$, $5\%$, or $10\%$.
Yes, since the mean of the “with prize” is above the mean of the “without prize.”

title: SuperChips
question_text: There had been some recent complaints about the SuperChips Cookie Company that there were fewer chocolate chips per cookie than there used to be. Ten years ago, there was shown to be an average of $12$ chips per cookie. The current company president decided to randomly sample $100$ cookies off the line and have the chips counted. He wanted to show that there were even more chips per cookie now. Write the hypotheses that would be used for such a test.

title: The Bigger Quart?
question_text:
Two brands of ice cream which claim to sell quart-sized containers were examined by the ice cream industry to compare the weights of their ice cream. Thirty-seven random quarts of Barry & Jen's Ice Cream were taken and found to have a mean weight of $32.3$ ounces with a standard deviation of $0.8$ ounces. Creyer's Ice Cream had $39$ quarts randomly sampled and these were found to have a mean weight of $31.8$ ounces with a standard deviation of $0.7$ ounces.
Calculate a $98\%$ confidence interval for the difference of the mean weights (B & J's minus Creyer's) and do this using $60$ degrees of freedom. Then, state whether one brand of quart ice creams is bigger than the other or whether they are not statistically different based on your confidence interval.

choices.text:
$(0.154, 0.846)$
No. Barry & Jen's quart-sized ice cream does not appear to weigh more than that of Creyer's because the confidence interval does not contain zero.

$(0.154, 0.846)$
Yes. Barry & Jen's quart-sized ice cream does appear to weigh more than that of Creyer's because the confidence interval does not contain zero.

$(0.087, 0.913)$
Yes. Barry & Jen's quart-sized ice cream does appear to weigh more than that of Creyer's because the confidence interval does not contain zero.

$(0.087, 0.913)$
No. Barry & Jen's quart-sized ice cream does not appear to weigh more than that of Creyer's because the confidence interval does not contain zero.

$(0.098, 0.540)$
Yes. Barry & Jen's quart-sized ice cream does appear to weigh more than that of Creyer's because the confidence interval does not contain zero.

title: Drug Test Results
question_text:
A medical study was being done. Two groups of patients were involved, each group receiving a different strength of a new trial drug designed to reduce the number of headaches they had. From each group, $25$ random patients were selected to receive the drug, while the remainder received a placebo. In Group L, the group receiving the lower dosage, the mean number of headaches over the past month was $19.0$ with a standard deviation of $1.6$. In Group H, the group receiving the higher dosage, the mean number of headaches over the past month was $18.1$ with a standard deviation of $1.3$. The doctors were looking to see if there was a difference in the number of headaches between the two groups.
Given a significance level of $\alpha=0.05$, what can you conclude?

choices.text: Because the $p$-value is less than the significance level, Ho should be rejected. Thus we can say that there is a difference in the means of the different dosages of the new drug and that it appears that the higher dosage of the drug results in fewer headaches.

Because the $p$-value is less than the significance level, Ho cannot be rejected. Thus we can say that there is a difference in the means of the different dosages of the new drug and that it appears that the higher dosage of the drug results in fewer headaches.
Because the $p$-value is greater than the significance level, Ho should be rejected. Thus we can say that there is no difference in the means of the different dosages of the new drug.
Because the $p$-value is greater than the significance level, Ho cannot be rejected. Thus we can say that there is no difference in the means of the different dosages of the new drug.
Because the means of the two samples were nearly equal, we cannot conclude that one drug is different from the other.

title: Effects of Degrees of Freedom on the t-distribution
question_text:
Which of the following statements is true?
I. The area under the $t$-distribution curve to the right of a positive $t$ value with $6$ degrees of freedom is larger than the area to the right of the same t value with $18$ degrees of freedom.
II. The higher the degrees of freedom, the closer the $t$-distribution is to the standard normal distribution.
III. The $t$-distribution is appropriate to use when the population standard deviation is known.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
II and III only.

title: Football Linemen Weights
question_text:
A sports reporter randomly surveyed 53 football linemen from large universities (enrollment $ > 10{,}000$) and randomly surveyed $53$ football linemen from smaller colleges (enrollment $ < 10{,}000 $ ).
Suppose the researcher wished to test whether linemen from large universities are heavier than linemen from smaller colleges. He finds that the average weight of linemen at large universities is $287\text{ lbs}$, while the average weight of linemen at small colleges is $268\text{ lbs}$.
Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: A matched pairs $T$ procedure would be appropriate, where linemen from the smaller school could be appropriately paired with lineman from the larger school.
A weight difference of at least $9.8\text{ lbs}$ would be needed to be able to successfully claim players from the large university weigh more at the alpha = $5\%$ level.
Assumptions are not met in this situation for any inferential procedure to be carried out.

If $100$ more random university and college linemen were surveyed, and respective means of µ(college) = $268$ and µ(universities) = $287$ were found, then the P-value and test statistic would most likely remain the same.
A smaller standard deviation in both samples’ weights will give stronger evidence that university linemen weigh more.

title: Type of Test to Use at the Zoo
question_text:
A large city zoo is seeking donations to expand their Tropical Rain Forest habitat and wants to show potential donors that this habitat is a very popular attraction at the zoo. The zoo's board of directors believes that they will be more likely to receive donations if they can provide good evidence that the proportion of visitors to the zoo who choose to visit the Tropical Rain Forest is, at least, $0.75$.
Over a period of several weeks, surveyors randomly select visitors who are exiting the zoo and ask whether they stopped at the Tropical Rain Forest during their visit.
Assuming the conditions for performing a significance test are satisfied, which of the following tests is most appropriate?

choices.text: One proportion $z$-test.
One proportion $t$-test.
Two sample $Z$-test for proportions.
One sample $T$-test for a population mean.
${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ test for goodness of fit.

title: Best Type of Test for Baking Soufflé
question_text:
A perfectly cooked soufflé is fluffy and rises above the dish that it is cooked in. Chef Celeste wonders if adding an extra egg white to her soufflé recipe would puff up her soufflés and make them rise to a greater height.
Celeste knows that even when she sets the oven temperature to $350$ degrees, however, different ovens will heat to slightly different temperatures and will cook the soufflés a bit differently. To account for this fact, she decides to bake two soufflés in each of twelve different ovens that have been preheated to $350$ degrees. In each oven, one soufflé will contain the extra egg white while the other soufflé will not.
Assuming all conditions are satisfied, which of the following tests could be used to determine if there is a difference in the average height of the soufflés?

choices.text: A $1$-sample $t$-test for determining the mean height of the soufflés.
A $2$-sample $t$-test for the difference between the mean heights of the soufflés using two different recipes
A paired $t$-test for a mean difference in the height of the soufflés when using two different recipes.
A ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ test for homogeneity of the average heights of the soufflés baked with the two different recipes.
A $2$-sample $z$-test for the proportion of soufflés with the extra egg white recipe that rise above the height of soufflés made with the original recipe

title: Standard Error: Effect on $T$-Statistic and $P$-Value
question_text:
Julissa conducted a one-sample $t$-test for a population mean using a one-sided greater than hypothesis. Later, she realized that the value she had used for the standard error was incorrect and that the actual value that she should have used was higher.
Assuming everything else remains constant, what effect will the higher standard error have on the $t$-statistic and the $p$-value for the test?

choices.text: Both the $t$-statistic and the $p$-value will remain unchanged.
Both the $t$-statistic and the $p$-value will decrease.
Both the $t$-statistic and the $p$-value will increase.
The $t$-statistic will decrease and the $p$-value will increase.
The $t$-statistic will increase and the $p$-value will decrease.

title: $t$-statistics and $p$-values
question_text:
From a set of $5\text{ observations}$, a matched pairs $t$-test was conducted using a one-sided (less than) alternative hypothesis.
If the $t$-statistic was $-0.83$, what was the $p$-value?

choices.text: The $p$-value cannot be determined from the information provided.

title: Meaning of a Confidence Level: Study Time
question_text:
A random sample of $60$ students from a large university were asked: "How much time do you spend doing homework a night?".
A $99\%$ confidence interval was constructed for the average amount of time students spend doing homework at this university, and the result was $(.8,2.2)$ hours.
Which of the following statements is TRUE?

choices.text: $99\%$ of all the intervals constructed will contain the interval $(.8,2.2)$ hours.
About $99\%$ of all random samples will capture the population mean for the amount of time students at this university spend doing their homework.
About $99\%$ of all random samples will capture the sample mean for the amount of time students at this university spend doing their homework.
$99\%$ of the time the average amount of time students at this university spend doing homework is between $.8$ to $2.2$ hours
$99\%$ of students at this university spend between $.8$ to $2.2$ hours doing homework.

title: Mail Delivery
question_text: The U.S. government was comparing delivery times between the post offices of two large cities. Many post offices in each city were randomly sampled as to how long mail took to be delivered within each city. They found a $95\%$ confidence interval for delivery times for first-class mail in hours at $(0.43, 1.26)$. Interpret this confidence interval.

choices.text: We see a $95\%$ chance that the difference in mail delivery times is at most $1.26$ hours.
We are $95\%$ confident that there is a difference of $1.26-0.43=0.83$ hours between the mail delivery times of the two cities.
We see a $95\%$ chance that the mail will be delivered on time in less than $1.26$ hours between the two cities.
We are $95\%$ confident that the difference in the population mean times of mail delivery from the two sampled cities is between $0.43$ and $1.26$ hours.
We are $95\%$ confident that the mail delivered between the two cities will vary between $0.43$ and $1.26$ hours due to the difference in their population mean times.

title: Degrees of Freedom
question_text: What is an appropriate number of degrees of freedom to use when conducting a two-sample $t$-test for the difference between two means?

choices.text: $n – 1$, where $n$ is the number of different populations.
$n – 1$, where $n$ is the larger of the two sample sizes.
$n – 1$, where $n$ is the smaller of the two sample sizes.
$n – 1$, where $n$ is the total number of observations in both samples combined.
$n – 2$, where $n$ is the total number of observations in both samples combined.

title: Interpret Income | 2 of 2
question_text:
Last year, the mean annual income of residents in a small town was $\$49{,}382$.
This year, a random sample of $100$ residents found an annual income of $\$52{,}301$. A $95\%$ confidence interval was calculated and extended from $\$50,{1}99$ to $\$54{,}403$.
Which of the following statements is a correct interpretation of the confidence level?

choices.text: We are $95\%$ confident the population mean income of residents in this town for this year is between $\$50{,}199$ and $\$54{,}403$.
We are using a process that will catch the true unknown population mean income of residents in this town for this year $95\%$ of the time in the long run.
Approximately $95\%$ of people in this town earn between $\$50,199$ and $\$54,403$ annually.
We are using a process that will catch the true sample mean $95\%$ of the time in the long run.
We are using a process that will capture the population mean value of $\$49,382$, 95% of the time in the long run.

title: Vaccine Ages
question_text: A state agency was looking at the average age of people receiving a certain vaccine. It wanted to see if this age was significantly different between City A and City B. City A had an average age of $54.$3 years and City B had an average age of $52.9$ years. If the agency was to run a $2$-Sample $t$-Test for the difference of these means, how should the hypotheses be written?

title: Statistical Significance at Various $\alpha$ Levels
question_text:
In a hypothesis test for a population mean, results were found to be statistically significant at the $\alpha = 0.02$ level.
Which of the following statements would also be true about the results of this test?

choices.text: The results would be statistically significant at the $\alpha = 0.01$ level.
The p-value obtained for this test was $p = 0.02$.
The results would be statistically significant at the $\alpha = 0.05$ level.
Since the results were statistically significant at the $\alpha = 0.02$ level, we have sufficient evidence to prove that our null hypothesis was false.
A mistake was made in considering the results to be statistically significant. We can only consider our results to be statistically significant if $\alpha > 0.05$.

title: One-Sample T-Test Output
question_text:
An exercise physiologist is interested in the effect of exercise on heart rate.
She has subjects walk slowly for $5\text{ minutes}$ and records their heart rates. Then she has the subjects run vigorously for $5\text{ minutes}$ and records their heart rates again.
The differences are recorded, (heart rate after running - heart rate before running), with results below:
One-Sample T: Differences
Test of $\mu$ = $0$ vs. > $0$
Variable N Mean StDev SE Mean 96% CI T P
Differences 12 59.88 10.36 3.66 (51.22, 68.53) 16.35 0.000


What is a valid interpretation of the hypothesis test given from the computer output?
tables:
VariableNMeanStDevSE Mean96% CITP
Differences1259.8810.363.66(51.22, 68.53)16.350.000

choices.text: Strong evidence exists that heart rate increased by about $60\text{ beats}$ (after - before running).
Strong evidence exists of an increase in heart rate (after - before running).
There was a failure to find strong evidence of an increase in heart rate since the sample is so small.
There was a failure to find strong evidence of an increase in heart rate because this sample clearly contains bias.
There was a failure to find strong evidence of an increase in heart rate because of the low $p$-value.

title: Finding an Area on the $t$-distribution
question_text: What is the area to the right of $t = 2.015$ with $5$ degrees of freedom?

title: Significance Test: U.S. Versus China
question_text:
A randomized experiment was performed to determine whether the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. is different than the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China.
U.S.A. Manufactured Cars China Manufactured Cars
Average $21.435$ $25.578$
Standard Deviation $6.635$ $7.413$
Number of cars $200$ $85$


Which of the following best describes the conclusion that can be drawn?
tables:
U.S.A. Manufactured CarsChina Manufactured Cars
Average$21.435$$25.578$
Standard Deviation$6.635$$7.413$
Number of cars$200$$85$

choices.text: There is evidence of a statistically significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China since $p<0.01$.

There is no evidence of a statistically significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China since $p<0.01$.

There is evidence of a statistically significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China since $0.01 < p < 0.05$.

There is no evidence of a statistically significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China since $0.01 < p < 0.05$.

There is no evidence of a statistically significant difference in the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in the U.S.A. compared to the average miles per gallon of cars manufactured in China since $p>0.05$.

title: Music Store
question_text:
A music store owner was curious about the number of customers his store gets per day.
He samples the next $25\text{ days}$ and finds an average of $65.5$ customers with a standard deviation of $11.3$ customers.
Assuming these $25\text{ days}$ represent a random sample of all days, a $95\%$ confidence interval for this data would be

choices.text: $11.3\pm 1.96 \cdot \left(\dfrac{65.5}{25}\right)$
$65.5\pm1.96 \cdot \left(\dfrac{11.3}{25}\right)$
$65.5\pm1.96 \cdot \left(\dfrac{11.3}{5}\right)$
$65.5\pm2.064 \cdot \left(\dfrac{11.3}{5}\right)$
$65.5\pm2.06 \cdot \left(\dfrac{11.3}{5}\right)$

title: One Mean $z$-interval: Finding the Minimum Sample Size
question_text:
You are sampling from a population with a known standard deviation of $10$ and an unknown population mean. You want to construct a $99\%$ confidence interval, with a margin of error of no more than $4$.
What is the minimum sample that will produce this interval?

title: Brackish Water Salinity
question_text:
In biology class, you learn that the salinity of brackish water (water that is saltier than fresh water, but less salty than ocean water) generally has a mean of $20$ parts per thousand (ppt).
You go to a nature preserve located near the ocean every day at $4$ p.m. for $40$ successive days and measure the salinity of the water at the same spot in the estuary, where fresh water and ocean water mix and mingle.
At the end of the time period, you calculate the mean and standard deviation of the salinity of your $40$ data points and carry out a one-sample t-test about the mean, calculating the test statistic and the p-value.
What assumption concerning hypothesis testing have you violated in carrying out this experiment?

choices.text: Randomness.
Sample size.
Normality.
Unknown population standard deviation.
P-value.

title: Annual Income Interval
question_text:
One hundred randomly chosen adult subjects in Jacksonville, FL, were asked their annual income.
The data reported from the sample was approximately normal and showed a mean of $\$46{,}203$ with a standard deviation of $\$10{,}201$.
A $95\%$ confidence interval would show, approximately, that we are $95 \% $ confident the average annual income for Jacksonville, Florida residents is between:

choices.text: Assumptions are not met in this situation to compute an appropriate $95\%$ confidence interval.

title: Rose Wells and Her Pet Alien's Significance Test
question_text:
Rose Wells has captured an alien and decides to keep it as a pet. Always curious, Rose wonders if the alien's average body temperature is the same as is normal for humans ($98.6^\circ$) and decides to do a significance test. Below are the alien's temperature readings, gathered at $6$ randomly selected times:
$85.1, 99.8, 93.7, 105.6, 98.2, 100.4$
If Rose assumes that the alien's body temperature follows a normal distribution, what would be the $p$-value of an appropriate significance test?

choices.text: A statistical test cannot be performed because we do not know the standard deviation of all of the alien's body temperatures.

title: The Meaning of Statistical Significance
question_text:
A random sample of size $n = 150$ is selected and a one-sample $t$-test for a population mean is performed. The results are found to be statistically significant.
Which of the following statements best describes the meaning of statistically significant in this situation?

choices.text: The results were very impressive. We should accept the null hypothesis without reservation.
The results were significant enough to prove that our null hypothesis is false.
The results were impressive enough to suggest that our null hypothesis is true.
The results of our experiment or observation were pretty much what we expected based upon our null hypothesis. No big deal.
Assuming our null hypothesis is true, the results we obtained were pretty strange and unlikely.

title: Interpreting $T$-Interval
question_text:
A television programmer at a local news station surveyed the last $30$ weekday nights and recorded the number of viewers on the $10$ p.m. news.
The programmer constructed a one-sample T-interval to find that there is somewhere between $470{,}000$ to $520{,}000\text{ viewers}$ with $95\%$ confidence.
Which of the following statements could be valid interpretations of the interval?

choices.text: There is a $2.5\%$ probability that more than $520{,}000\text{ viewers}$ watch the weekday nightly news.
There are most likely somewhere near $500{,}000\text{ viewers}$ watching the weekday nightly news.
There is a $95\%$ chance that between $470{,}000$ and $520{,}000\text{ viewers}$ watch the weekday nightly news on any given night.
About $95\%$ of nights, this network has between $470{,}000$ and $520{,}000\text{ viewers}$ watching the weekday nightly news.
In the long run, $95\%$ of people watch the weekday nightly news in this community.

title: When Should We Jump into the Pooled Procedures?
question_text: When should we used pooled procedures?

choices.text: When we assume the variances of two populations are equal.
When we assume the means of two populations are equal.
Any time we complete a confidence interval or hypothesis test for a difference in two population proportions.
Any time we use a $z$-test for a population proportion.
Never.

title: College Tuition: Testing the Data
question_text:
According to the National Center for Education Statistics, the average total tuition, fees, room and board at 4-year colleges and universities was $$24{,}706$ in 2013-2014. Mr. Nye believes the average is now higher.
To investigate, he randomly selects one 4-year school from each of the 50 states. He finds the sample average to be $$25{,}322$ and the sample standard deviation to be $$2{,}375$. There are no outliers in his data.
Does his data provide evidence at the $\alpha = 0.05$ level that the average total tuition, fees, room and board at 4-year colleges has increased?

choices.text: No, the $p$-value for the appropriate significance test is $0.07$. Since $0.07 > 0.05$, we do not have sufficient evidence at the $\alpha = 0.05$ level.
No, the sample average is only $$616$ more than the 2013-2014 value. Considering that costs are more than $$20,000$, this is really not that much money.
Yes, the $p$-value for the appropriate significance test is $0.04$, so we have strong evidence to suggest that the cost has increased.
Yes, the sample average represents a $2.5\%$ increase over the 2013-2014 costs. Since this is less than $5\%$, our results are statistically significant at the $\alpha = 0.05$ level.
Mr. Nye cannot conduct a significance test here since not all conditions are satisfied.

title: Can the Interval be Calculated?
question_text:
A company was curious as to the ratings of one of its products by age group. It asked two randomly chosen groups of $32$ of its customers, one group under age $40$ and the other group over age $40$, to give its product a ranking between $1$ and $10$. These people were chosen from a customer list which included $210$ customers under age $40$ and $360$ customers over age $40$. In the under $40$ group the average ranking was $5.7$ with a standard deviation of $1.2$. In the older group the average ranking was $6.3$ with a standard deviation of $1.4$.
Are the conditions for calculating a two-sample confidence interval for estimating the difference of two population means met in the example above?

choices.text: Yes. All of the conditions can be verified.
No. The samples of $32$ people are two small. Each group should be larger in order to avoid the possibility of skewness in the distributions.

No. The problem is that the size of the sample in the under age $40$ group is too large for the size of its population. A sample of $32$ people would require a population of $320$ or more people, and here it is only $210$.
No. The samples are not described as being independent.
No. We do not have enough information about the samples to know whether the sample distribution of their differences is approximately normal in shape.

title: Average Price of Homes: T Procedures
question_text:
A realtor is interested in the average price of homes in his state. He randomly selects $16\text{ homes}$ and records the prices.
Under what conditions could $T$ procedures be safely used in this situation?

choices.text: As long as the sample is larger, say over $30$, $T$ procedures could be used in this case.
$T$ procedures can be used only if the problem states that the parent population is approximately normal.
$T$ procedures cannot be used in this situation as it would be more appropriate to use $Z$ procedures.
$T$ procedures can be used in this situation as is.
$T$ procedures can be used in this situation as long as a graph of the data shows no strong skewness or outliers.

title: Drawing Conclusions: Employee Experience
question_text:
Two large supermarket chains are interested in comparing the experience, in years, that their employees have. The summary statistics are below:
Store $1$ : mean = $5.4, { S }_{ x }= 3.2, n = 34 $
Store $2$ : mean = $6.1, { S }_{ x }= 3.6, n = 36$
When performing a two-sample $T$-test on $H_0: { u }_{ 1 }={ u }_{ 2 }$ versus $H_a: { u }_{ 1 } < { u }_{ 2 } $, what conclusion can be made?
Define ${ u }_{ 1 }$ as the average experience at store $1$, and ${ u }_{ 2 }$ as the average experience at store $2$.

choices.text: Evidence exists that the stores’ employees have the same amount of experience, at the $10\%$ level.
Evidence exists that the second has employees with more experience than those at the first store, significant at the $10\%$ level, but not at the $5\%$ or $1\%$ levels.
Evidence exists the second store has employees with more experience than those at the first store $1$, significant at the $5\%$ level.
There is insufficient evidence that employees at the second store have more experience than those at the first store, at the $10\%$ level.
There is no evidence of there not being a difference in employee experience between the two stores, at the $10\%$ level.

title: Average Number of Emails
question_text:
A school teacher wonders, on average, how many emails does he get a day? To investigate, he selects $30$ random days during the last year, and calculates the mean. His results shows that he got a mean of $\bar{x} = 52.5$.
Can the teacher safely assume that his true average number of emails was $52.5$?

choices.text: Yes, since $n = 30$, the Central Limit Theorem says this result is valid.
Yes, since the days were random, we can generalize this result for the entire population.
Yes, since the $10\%$ condition is met, the teacher can use this statistic.
No, since the distribution is not stated as Normal, he can not use this statistic.
No, since the number found is a statistic, the true population mean most likely differs from this amount.

solution:
When dealing with statistics, numbers that describe a sample, and parameters, numbers that describe a population, it is important to remember that rarely do statistics equal the population parameter. In this case, $\bar{x} = 52.5$ is a statistic, a sample mean. If the teacher had chosen $30$ different days, it is very unlikely that he would've gotten the same sample mean. This is due to Sampling Variability.

Therefore, since the sample mean was only based off one sample, the teacher should not believe this is the true population mean, and use an inference method to find plausible values for his true population mean.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Making Decisions from Output | 2 of 2
question_text:
A veterinarian decided to study the weights (kg) of Siberian and Alaskan huskies.
The veterinarian weighted $13$ randomly selected Siberian Huskies and $12$ randomly selected Alaskan Huskies. A two-sample $t$-test was performed with the results below (two-sided).
Two-Sample $t$ for Siberian Husky vs. Alaskan Husky:

What are the appropriate test statistic and $p$-value for this problem?

$P$-value = $0.002$

title: Comparison: Which Distribution
question_text: When testing a sample against a set population mean, one should typically use

choices.text: The standard normal $Z$-distribution.
The $T$ distribution.
The binomial distribution.
The chi-squared distribution.
The $F$ distribution.

title: Making Decisions from Output | 1 of 2
question_text:
A veterinarian decided to study the weights (kg) of Siberian and Alaskan huskies.
The veterinarian weighted $13$ randomly selected Siberian huskies and $12$ randomly selected Alaskan huskies. A two-sample $t$-test was performed with the results below (two-sided).
Two-Sample $t$ for Siberian Husky vs. Alaskan Husky:
N Mean StDev SE Mean
Siberian Husky 13 18.66 3.89 1.1

$\text{Difference }= \mu \text{(Siberian husky)}-\mu \text{(Alaskan husky)}$
Estimate for difference: $-4.61$

$\text{T-test of Difference }= 0$
$\text{T-value }= -3.56$

What practical conclusions can be made based on these results?
tables:

choices.text: There is no evidence of a difference in weights between the different husky breeds at any of the common alpha levels.
There is evidence of a difference in weights at the $10\%$ level, but not at the $1\%$ or $5\%$ alpha levels.
There is evidence of a difference in weights at the $5\%$ and $10\%$ levels, but not at the $1\%$ level.
There is evidence of a difference in weights at the $1\%$, $5\%$, and $10\%$ alpha levels.
There is evidence Alaskan huskies weigh more than Siberian huskies at the $1\%, 5\%$, and $10\%$ alpha levels.

title: Average Home Price - Realtor
question_text:
A realtor is interested in the average price of homes in his state.
He randomly selects $16\text{ homes}$ and records the prices. The $16\text{ homes}$ averaged a price of $\$183{,}482$ with a standard deviation of $\$41{,}023$.
If the realtor wishes to determine if this year’s prices are higher than last year’s state average of $\$175{,}000$, what would be the appropriate null and alternative hypotheses?

title: World Geography Test: Find the $p$-Value
question_text:
Can Canadian adults identify more countries of the world on a map than American adults? Researchers tested a random sample of $50$ Canadian adults and a random sample of $50$ American adults.
On average, the selected Canadian adults could identify $23.92$ countries with a standard deviation of $4.8$, while Americans in the sample could identify $22.61$ countries with a standard deviation of $6.2$.
Assuming all conditions are satisfied, what is the $p$-value of the appropriate test?

title: Different MPG
question_text:
A large car company is wondering if the fuel efficiency in miles per gallon (MPG) would improve if they use a new tire on their mid-size SUV. The company selects a random sample of $70$ mid-size SUVs and assigns half of them to tire $1$, the new tire, and the other half to tire $2$, the old tire. After running trials on the SUVs, the company finds the average fuel efficiency for tire $1$ to be $25.6$ mpg and the average fuel efficiency for tire $2$ to be $24.3$ mpg.
Does the company have evidence to continue investigating if the new tire improves gas mileage?

choices.text: Yes, because there average difference between tire $1$ and tire $2$ is positive.
Yes, because both samples have sample sizes of at least $30$.
No, because the difference between tire $1$ and tire $2$ is negative.
No, because the difference between tire $1$ and tire $2$ is not large enough
No, because we do not know how many mid-size SUVs the company produces.

solution:
To investigate if the new tires actually improve miles per gallon, the company first needs to see if the average miles per gallon is different between the two types of tires. In this scenario, tire $1$ has an average fuel efficiency of $25.6$ mpg, while tire $2$ has an average fuel efficiency of $24.3$ mpg. If we were to find the difference between the new tire and the old tire, we would get $25.6 - 24.3 = 1.3$ mpg.

Therefore, since there is a positive difference between the two brands of tires, the company should continue its investigation to see if there is a difference between the two brands of tires.

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: Compare the Scores
question_text: A state with a large state university wanted to compare the incoming SAT verbal scores of males and females. It randomly sampled $36$ female students and $30$ male students and found their scores. The females had an average of $578$ with a standard deviation of $32$. The males had an average of $568$ with a standard deviation of $30$. Assuming no technology is available, write the formula for the margin of error of this two-sample $t$-interval of two means with a confidence level of $95\%$.

title: Finding the Margin of Error Given an Interval: Vehicle Speed
question_text:
A $95\%$ confidence interval for a car's average speed (mph) on West Street is $(30,40)$.
From this interval, what is the margin of error for the car's average speed (in mph)?

choices.text: $5\text{ mph}$
$10\text{ mph}$
$35\text{ mph}$
$70\text{ mph}$
It cannot be determined from the information given.

title: National Fitness Challenge
question_text:
Two large high schools are competing with each other in a national fitness challenge.
Five students are selected at random from each school. Their running times for a $5\text{ kilometer}$ run, rounded to the nearest minute, is recorded below:
School A: $30, 35, 30, 32, 24$
Mean: $30.2$
Standard Deviation: $4.025$
School B: $27, 22, 36, 30, 31$
Mean: $29.2$
Standard Deviation: $5.167$
Determine the most exact value of a $95\%$ confidence interval for the difference of the two schools’ running times.

title: Type of Interval to Use: New Running Sneaker
question_text:
A shoe company claims that its lighter sneaker can make you run faster than its competitor's top running sneaker. The company randomly selects $200$ people that attend a seminar about the sneaker. Each subject runs a 100-meter dash with the company's new running sneaker and the competitors' top running sneaker. Subjects are randomized with respect to which type of sneaker they would run with first.
What type of interval would the company use to construct an average difference between the running times for the company's new running sneaker and the competitor's top running sneaker?

choices.text: Paired $z$-interval for means.
Paired $t$-interval for means.
Two sample $z$-interval for means.
Two sample $t$-interval for means.
Two proportion $z$-interval.

title: Hypotheses for Means: Men's Heart Rates vs. Women's Heart Rates
question_text:
A wellness center is running an experiment comparing the exercise heart rate of men versus women. Two large independent random samples of men and women are taken. The wellness center believes there is statistically significant evidence that women's exercise heart rate is greater than men's. Let ${ \mu }_{ W }$ represent the average exercise heart rate of women and ${ \mu }_{ M }$ represent the average exercise heart rate of men.
Which of the following would represent the null and alternative hypotheses?

title: Degrees of Freedom and Statistical Significance
question_text:
Lauren conducted a one-sample $t$-test for a population mean and her results were found to be statistically significant at the $\alpha=0.05$ level.
Later, she realized that she had calculated the $p$-value using the wrong value for degrees of freedom, $\text{df}$. If the true $\text{df}$ should have been higher than the $\text{df}$ she had used in her calculation, would her results still be statistically significant?

choices.text: No, using a higher value for $\text{df}$ would result in a higher $p$-value.
Maybe, using a higher value for $\text{df}$ would result in a higher $p$-value, but the $p$-value may still be less than $0.05$.
Maybe, using a higher value for $\text{df}$ would result in a lower $p$-value, but the $p$-value may then end up being too low for the results to be considered statistically significant.
Yes, using a higher value for $\text{df}$ would result in a lower $p$-value.
It depends on whether Lauren was using a one-sided or two-sided alternative hypothesis.

title: $2$-sided $p$-values
question_text:
In a $2$-sided hypothesis test for a population mean, the $z$-value associated with the sample mean is found to be $1.95$.
What will be the $p$-value for this test?

title: Changes in $t$-distribution with Decrease of D.O.F.
question_text: Which of the following correctly describes the changes in the $t$-distribution when the degrees of freedom decreases?

choices.text: The center decreases, the spread increases and the shape becomes less normal.
The center decreases, the spread increases and the shape becomes more normal.
The center increases, the spread decreases and the shape becomes less normal.
The center remains the same, the spread decreases and the shape becomes more normal.
The center remains the same, the spread increases and the shape becomes less normal.

title: Difference in Reading Times
question_text:
A set of parents is wondering if there is a difference in the average amount of time spent reading by their third-grader and their fifth-grader.
Over the next $35$ nights, the parents record the amount of reading done by both of their kids. The parents then found some summary statistics and graphed the differences between the fifth-grader and the third-grader.
Can the parents claim there is a difference in the average reading times between their two kids?

choices.text: Yes, because the average difference is positive
Yes, because the sampling distribution is approximately normal due to the Central Limit Theorem
Yes, because the IQR is positive
No, because $0$ is in the distribution of differences
No, because the graph is roughly symmetric

solution:
The parents are looking at two-sample data for their fifth-grader and their third-grade student's average reading times. When deciding if there is a difference between the two different samples, the parents need to determine if there is significant enough evidence to claim there is a difference.

When looking at our data, even though the mean is positive, indicating a slight difference between the two readers, when you look at the dot plot, $0$ is an outcome indicating there is a possibility of no difference.

Therefore, the parents do not have convincing evidence of a difference when it comes to the average reading times of their two kids.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: The True Meaning of $p$
question_text:
A one-sided significance test for a population mean was conducted and the resulting $p$-value was $p = 0.03$.
What is the best interpretation of this $p$-value?

choices.text: There is a $3\%$ chance that the statistic obtained from our sample is equal to the true population mean.
We are only $3\%$ confident that our results are correct.
Our results are statistically significant at the $\alpha=0.05$ level. We have sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis.
The probability that we will make a type $II$ error based on our results is about $3\%$.
If our null hypothesis is true, the probability is only $3\%$ that we would obtain a sample statistic as far away from the hypothesized mean as the statistic we actually got from our sample.

title: Condition Not Satisfied - Which One?
question_text:
The Pet Rescue Club at a local high school is considering selling candy bars as a way of raising funds to donate to the local animal shelter. Club members wondered how many candy bars each person should be able to sell on average. They knew that members of the school band had sold the same candy bars for fundraising in the past, so they asked for information from the band director.
The band director, who fancies himself a bit of a statistician on the side, provided the stemplot below which shows the sales results of a random sample of $18\text{ band members}$ who had sold candy bars.
Loading question supplement...
The President of the Pet Rescue Club had planned to use the information provided by the band director to construct a one-sample $t$-interval to estimate the mean number of candy bars each person could be expected to sell. Then she realized that one of the necessary conditions for inference had not been satisfied.
Which condition was not satisfied?

choices.text: The data was not obtained by random sampling of all of the students at the school. Rather, it was only obtained from a random sample of band members.
Although $n>15$, the sample size used is not particularly large. Therefore, $t$-procedures should not be used due to the fact that the distribution of data is skewed right.

Since the sample size is not sufficiently large, say $n\ge25$, we cannot use $t$-procedures unless we know that the population distribution is approximately normal. There is no evidence that this is the case.
The distribution of data provided by the band director contains a high outlier. Therefore, $t$-procedures cannot be used under any circumstances.

Since we do not know the probability that an individual will be able to sell candy bars, we are unable to verify the condition that both $np\ge10$ and $n(1-p)\ge10$. Therefore, we cannot use $t$-procedures.

title: One-Sample $T$ Hypothesis of Ice Water
question_text:
Suppose a psychologist decides to use a matched pairs (paired) experiment to determine how long individuals can hold their hands in ice water when intoxicated compared to sober.
Suppose the psychologist hypothesizes that alcohol will numb the pain, so individuals will be able to keep their hands in the ice water longer when intoxicated.
If the longest amount of time was $5.1\text{ minutes}$, what are the appropriate null and alternative hypotheses for this situation?

choices.text:
$H_0: { u }_{ 1 }= { u }_{ 2 }$
$H_a: { u }_{ 1 }< { u }_{ 2 }$
Define ${ u }_{ 1 }$ as the average time an individual can hold their hands in the ice water when intoxicated, and ${ u }_{ 2 }$ as the average time an individual can hold their hands in the ice water when sober.

$H_0: { u }_{ 1 }={ u }_{ 2 }$
$H_a: { u }_{ 1 } > { u }_{ 2 }$
Define ${ u }_{ 1 }$ as the average time an individual can hold their hands in the ice water when intoxicated and ${ u }_{ 1 }$ as the average time an individual can hold their hands in the ice water when sober.

$H_0: \mu = 0$
$H_a: \mu > 0$
Define $\mu$ as the increase in time an individual can hold their hands in ice water when intoxicated.

$H_0: \mu = 5.1$
$H_a: \mu < 5. 1$
Define $\mu$ as the average amount of time an individual can hold their hands in ice water.

$H_0: \mu = 0$
$H_a: \mu < 0$
Define $\mu$ as the increase in time an individual can hold their hands in ice water when intoxicated.

title: Significance Testing: More Carbonation
question_text:
Cepsi claims its soda stays carbonated longer than its main competitor, Poke. Eight sodas of each brand are randomly selected. They are opened, sealed back up, and then stored in a refrigerator. Starting on the third day after the sodas are opened, every two hours the sodas are checked for carbonation. The table below shows the number of days the soda stay carbonated.
Cepsi 2.9 3.5 3.1 4 4.3 5.2 5 4.7
Poke 4.4 2.6 3.2 3.3 3.9 4 4.9 5.3


Which of the following tests should be conducted to determine if Cepsi’s sodas do, in fact, stay carbonated longer than Poke’s soda?
tables:
Cepsi2.93.53.144.35.254.7
Poke4.42.63.23.33.944.95.3

choices.text: A one-sided, paired $t$-test for means.
A two-sided, paired $t$-test for means.
A one-sided, two-sample $t$-test for means.
A one-sided, two-sample $z$-test for means.
A two-sided, two-sample $t$-test for means.

title: Paired Conditions: Which One?
question_text: Which of the following conditions is NEVER satisfied in a paired $t$-interval?

choices.text: Random.
Normal or Approximately Normal
Independent groups.
All of the conditions will work at some point.

title: Improving Hypothesis Testing
question_text: The power of a hypothesis test can be increased by all of the following except

choices.text: Increasing alpha.
Increasing the sample size.
Calculating the test statistic to more decimal places of accuracy.
Decreasing the standard deviation.
Picking a particular alternative that is farther from the (null) hypothesized parameter.

title: Interpret Income | 1 of 2
question_text:
Last year, the mean annual income of residents in a small town was $\$49,382$.
This year, a random sample of $100$ residents in the same town found an annual income of $\$52,301$. A $95\%$ confidence interval was calculated and extended from $\$50,199$ to $\$54,403$.
Which of the following statements is correct concerning this interval?

choices.text: It seems likely that mean income for this town has risen from last year.
We’re $95\%$ confident that the true mean income of the town this year is $\$52,301$.
We’re $95\%$ confident the true population mean salary of this town last year was between $\$50,199$ and $\$54,403$.
We’re $95\%$ confident the sample mean from this year’s survey is between $\$50,199$ and $\$54,403$.
$95\%$ of samples such as this one would give an interval that captures the population mean of $\$49,382$.

title: Lights On!
question_text: Nicky was just hired at the Specific Electric Company. He was asked to compare the average lifespan of the new light bulbs with that of the old bulbs. His manager told him that he wanted to statistically show that the new lights last longer so that they can be advertised that way. Fortunately, the company has a machine that can hasten the life of the bulbs so it would not take Nicky a very long time to measure their lifespans. He was told to test $25$ random light bulbs of each type. Which of the following is the best statistical method to try to show that the new light bulbs last significantly longer than the old light bulbs?

choices.text: Chi-Square Goodness of Fit Test
Subtract the means and then use a One-Sample $t$-Test.
Two-Sample $z$-Interval
Two-Sample Test using $z^*$
Two-Sample $t$-Test using $t^*$

title: Condition Failed: Restaurant Ages
question_text:
A restaurant wants to estimate the average age of its customers who visit during September. The manager of the restaurant decides to find the average age by asking the ages of the customers on three weekday afternoons between the times of 3 to 4 PM.
He surveyed $40$ customers and found that the distribution to be slightly skewed to the right with an average age of $62$ years.
Which condition for constructing a $1$-sample $t$-interval for means has the manager failed to satisfy?

choices.text: The data is a random sample from the population of interest.
Normality.
The data is a random sample from the population and the shape of the sampling distribution is approximately normal.
The sample is less than $10\%$ of the population.
All the conditions for constructing a $1$-sample $t$-interval for means have failed.

title: Tennis Anyone?
question_text: A company was hired to compare the bounce height of two brands of tennis balls using a $90\%$ confidence interval. A bounce method was established and $15$ balls were randomly selected and tested from each brand. Brand $1$ had a mean bounce height of $5.8$ feet and a standard deviation of $1.1$ feet. Brand $2$ had a bounce height of $5.3$ feet and a standard deviation of $0.9$ feet. Assuming that all conditions were met and that a $d.f. = 14$ would be used, find the margin of error of this confidence interval.

title: Experimental $P$-Value
question_text:
An experiment tests the following:
$H_0: \mu = 17$ vs. $H_a: \mu \neq 17$
The standard normal curve is used to find the $p$-value when the test statistic is $z = 1.71$.
What is the $p$-value of the experiment?

title: Meaning of a Confidence Interval: Growth Spurt
question_text:
Boys tend to hit their growth spurt around 13 years old. A random sample of $100$ boys was taken to find out how many inches they grew from thirteen to fourteen years old. A $98\%$ confidence interval was constructed from this data and yielded a result of $(2.8, 4.3)\text{ inches}$.
Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: $98\%$ of the boys studied in this survey grew between $2.8$ to $4.3\text{ inches}$.
We are $98\%$ confident that boys grew between $2.8$ to $4.3\text{ inches}$ from the age of thirteen to fourteen.
We are $98\%$ confident that the average height that boys grew in this study was between $2.8$ to $4.3\text{ inches}$.
The average height a boy grew from the age of thirteen to fourteen was between $2.8$ to $4.3\text{ inches}$ $98\%$ of the time.
We are $98\%$ confident the average height that boys grew from the ages of thirteen to fourteen was between $2.8$ to $4.3\text{ inches}$.

title: Size of the Samples
question_text: A research firm was trying to decide how large or small its samples should be when constructing confidence intervals for clients. Suppose it was taking samples of two independent means and it chose these sample sizes: $n_{1}=42$ and $n_{2}=52$. For this research the firm wanted to increase the width of the interval as much as possible by changing these sample sizes. Choose the answer below which would achieve the greatest increase in the width of the confidence interval.

title: Confidence Level and $2$-sided Significance Testing
question_text:
A one sample $t$-test for was used to conduct a test of the null hypotheses:
$${ H }_{ 0 }:\mu =23.7$$

$${ H }_{ a }:\mu \neq 23.7$$
The $p$-value was $0.034$. A confidence interval for *$\mu$ * is to be constructed.
Of the following, which is the largest level of confidence for which the confidence interval will NOT contain $23.7$?

title: How to Present Study Results
question_text:
In a study for a new pain medication designed to lower pain for migraine sufferers, a study of random patients was to be done and their decrease in pain was to be measured on a scale from $1$ to $10$ ($10$ is the highest pain possible).
The company wanted to publish results that would give the widest possible confidence interval width. Of course, these results would be dependent upon the patients' reporting, but which of the following would not increase the width of the confidence interval?

choices.text: Increase the confidence level.
Increase the margin of error.
Increase the standard error.
Increase the critical value.
Increase the sample size.

title: Point Estimator for a One Mean $t$-Interval: Fastball
question_text:
A $95\%$ confidence interval for the average fastball (mph) a professional athlete throws is $(96,101)$.
From this interval, what is the point estimate for his average fastball (in mph)?

choices.text: $2.5\text{ mph}$
$5\text{ mph}$
$96\text{ mph}$
$98.5\text{ mph}$
$101\text{ mph}$

title: Day at The Museum: A Statistical Test
question_text:
Jedidiah and Octavius have both visited the American Museum of Natural History in New York City as well as the British Museum in London. They have been wondering if the average number of daily visitors at each museum is equal and decide to investigate. From a random sample of $30\text{ days}$, they determine that the mean number of daily visitors to the American Museum of Natural History is $16,380$ with a sample standard deviation of $1248$ while, the mean number of daily visitors to the British Museum is $18,104$ with a sample standard deviation of $4296$.
Assuming the samples are independent, and that the distribution of the number of daily visitors is approximately normal for both locations, does this data provide evidence that there is a difference in the mean number of daily visitors to these two museums?

choices.text: No, since $p > 0.05$, we do not have sufficient evidence to reject the idea that the mean number of daily visitors to the two museums is equal.

Yes, since the observed mean number of visitors at the British Museum was much higher than the observed number of visitors at the American Museum of Natural History, we must conclude that there is a difference.
Yes, since $p = 0.02$, our results do provide evidence that there is a difference in the mean number of daily visitors to these two museums.
Yes, since $p = 0.04$, our results do provide evidence that there is a difference in the mean number of daily visitors to these two museums.
A significance test cannot be performed since not all conditions are satisfied.

title: Hours of Sleep
question_text:
A statistics teacher at a large high school wants to estimate the average number of hours the students at the school get on a nightly basis. She decides to ask a random sample of $40$ students from the high school "How much sleep did you get last night?" She got a sample mean of $\bar{x} = 6.5$ hours.
If the other statistics teacher decides to select their own sample of $40$ random students, should they expect to get a sample mean of $\bar{x} = 6.5$ as well?

choices.text: Yes, because this would be the sample mean for the entire population
Yes, because the Central Limit Theorem is met
No, because random samples will more than likely produce different statistic values
No, because the distribution is not stated as Normal
No, because the students are independent of each other

solution:
The first teacher's sample produced a statistic of $\bar{x} = 6.5$ hours. When the second teacher selects their sample, there is a good chance that many of the students selected will be different from the first sample. (Although, some students can be in both samples). Therefore, due to sampling variability the different samples of students will more than likely produce different statistic values.

The second teacher should not expect their sample to produce the same statistic value.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Significance of Dunkin Bucks
question_text:
Dunkin Bucks is interested if there is a significant difference in the number of cups of coffee their adult customers drink per day compared with their teenage customers. Dunkin Bucks randomly selects $10\text{ adults}$ and $10\text{ teenagers}$ and asks them: "How many cups of coffee do you drink?" The resulting data is below:
N Average cups Standard Deviation
Adults $10$ $1.8$ $0.6$
Teenagers $10$ $1.3$ $0.3$
