choices.text: There is sufficient evidence of a difference between the average number of cups of coffee an adult drinks compared to a teenager at the $1\%$ significance level, but not at the $5\%$ and $10\%$ significance levels.

There is sufficient evidence of a difference between the average number of cups of coffee an adult drinks compared to a teenager at the $1\%$ and $5\%$ significance levels, but not the $10\%$ significance level.
There is sufficient evidence of a difference between the average number of cups of coffee an adult drinks compared to a teenager at the $1\%$, $5\%$, and $10\%$ significance levels.

There is insufficient evidence of a difference between the average number of cups of coffee an adult drinks compared to a teenager at the $1\%$ significance level, but not the $5\%$ and $10\%$ significance levels.

There is insufficient evidence of a difference between the average number of cups of coffee an adult drinks compared to a teenager at the $1\%$ significance level and $5\%$ significance level, but not the $10\%$ significance level.

title: More SuperChips
question_text: There had been some recent complaints about the SuperChips Cookie Company that there were fewer chocolate chips per cookie than there used to be. Ten years ago there was shown to be an average of $12$ chips per cookie. The current company president decided to randomly sample $100$ cookies off the line and have the chips counted as he wanted to show that the number of chips per cookie had not changed. The average number of chips from the sample was $11$. Can the president go ahead and proceed with the test?

choices.text:
Yes.
Having a sample size much greater than $30$ is enough to prove his point.

No.
He did not check to show that the sampling distribution for the mean was approximately normal.

Yes.
Conditions are verified so he can try to show that the $11$ did not significantly change from the $12$.

No.
The fact that the number dropped from $12$ to $11$ disproves what he is trying to show.

No.
He should be running a matched-pairs test.

title: Graduation Gowns
question_text:
College graduates purchase their gowns based on their height. One graduation gown manufacturer measures a sample of graduates to see if it needs to increase its inventory in the taller sizes. The average height in the random sample of customers was $67\text{ inches}$ with a standard deviation of $4\text{ inches}$.
Which distribution should the manufacturer use to calculate a $95\%$ confidence interval for the average height of its customers? Why?

choices.text: The $z$-distribution should be used because the confidence interval is being constructed for a mean.
The $z$-distribution should be used because the confidence interval is being constructed for a proportion.
The $t$-distribution should be used because the confidence interval is being constructed for a mean.
The $t$-distribution should be used because the confidence interval is being constructed for a proportion.
The chi-square distribution should be used because the confidence interval is being constructed for a proportion.

title: Hypothesis Setup
question_text:
A local sandwich shop decided to slash their prices in an attempt to increase weekly sales.
Historically, their gross sales have been $\$6{,}515$ per week. Since slashing their prices, the last $10\text{ weeks}$ have averaged $\$6{,}879$ per week in sales with a standard deviation of $\$400$.
If the manager wishes to test whether the sales promotion was successful, what would the appropriate null and alternative hypotheses be?

title: Two-Sample $T$-Test
question_text: A two-sample $T$-test attempts to determine if

choices.text: A significant difference exists between two proportions.
A significant difference exists between two means when the population standard deviation is known.
A significant difference exists between two means when the population standard deviation is unknown.
A straight line relationship exists between two quantitative variables.
A relationship exists between two categorical variables.

title: Hypotheses for Means: Waiting Time
question_text:
A valet company claims that a customer's average wait time for their car is $8\text{ minutes}$. After waiting $20\text{ minutes}$ to get your car, Bobby believes the valet company's time to get a car is greater than $8\text{ minutes}$.
Which of the following hypotheses would be used to test your belief?

choices.text:
${ H }_{ 0 }:\overline { x } =8\text{ minutes}$
${ H }_{ a }:\overline { x } \neq 8\text{ minutes}$

${ H }_{ 0 }:\overline { x } =8\text{ minutes}$
${ H }_{ a }:\overline { x } < 8\text{ minutes}$

${ H }_{ 0 }:\overline { x } =8\text{ minutes}$
${ H }_{ a }:\overline { x } > 8\text{ minutes}$

${ H }_{ 0 }:\mu =8\text{ minutes}$
${ H }_{ a }:\mu <8\text{ minutes}$

${ H }_{ 0 }:\mu =8\text{ minutes}$
${ H }_{ a }:\mu >8\text{ minutes}$

title: Violating a Two-Sample $T$ Procedure
question_text:
A hotel manager wishes to compare the number of guests she has per night to the number of guests per night at the other hotel in town.
The manager records the number of guests staying per night during the last $4\text{ weeks}$ at her hotel and compares them to numbers for the last $4\text{ weeks}$ at her competitor’s hotel.
If the manager wishes to perform a two-sample $T$ procedure, what is a potential condition that could be in violation of the $T$ procedure?

choices.text: Sample sizes of $4$ are too small to assume normality.
The data does not come from two independent simple random samples.
In this situation, $np$ and $n (1-p)$ would not be at least $10$, where $n$ is $4$ and $p = 0.5$.
The survey was most likely conducted in a biased manner.
There appear to be no conditions violated.

title: Standard Error of Sample Mean Guinea Pig Weight
question_text:
Jackson weighed all of his pet guinea pigs and found the average weight to be $2.4\text{ pounds}$.
If the standard error of the sample mean was $0.2227$ and the sample standard deviation was $0.63\text{ pounds}$, how many guinea pigs does Jason have?

title: One Sample Mean Interval: Average Number of Tweets
question_text:
Camden was asked by one of his friends how many tweets he sends out a day. Not knowing the exact answer, Camden randomly selected $16$ days from the past and looked at the number of tweets he sent out.
Using his knowledge and AP Statistical power, he decided to construct a $95\%$ confidence interval for the average number of tweets he sent out.
The data he collected from the $16$ days followed an approximately normal distribution with a mean of $3.14$ and standard deviation of $0.68$.
Which of the following represents a $95\%$ confidence interval for the average number of tweets Camden sends out a day?

title: How Many Peas in a Pod?
question_text:
Granny Green owned a huge farm and grew thousands of pea plants. She read that there are $5$ or $6$ peas in a pod on average and she was sure her pods contained more peas than that. She randomly sampled $40$ of her pea pods and decided to do a one-sample t-test to show that the mean number of peas in her pods were higher than the claimed average.
The answer choices below contain both the alternative hypothesis for her test as well as a statement about the condition(s) she needs to verify. Four of the answers contain something wrong, only one answer is correct. Which one?

choices.text:
$H_{a}: \mu>6$
She failed to meet the condition(s) for independence.

$H_{a}: p>6$
She did meet the condition(s) for independence.

$H_{a}: \mu>6$
She failed to meet the condition(s) for showing that the sampling distribution was approximately normal.

$H_{a}: \bar{x}>6$
She did meet the condition(s) for showing that the sampling distribution was approximately normal.

$H_{a}: \mu>6$
Her population of peas were more than $10$ times greater than the size of her sample.

title: Which Route to Take?
question_text:
Nina and Tina live next door to each other and both attend the same school which is some distance away. They are now seniors and have their own cars and each like to drive a different route. They have been arguing as to which route takes less time. So, to complete a project for their statistics class, they designed a matched pairs design where the next $32$ school days, on each day, a coin flip would decide which girl would drive which route. And on each day they recorded their times for the route driven. After $32$ days they wrote down the two driving times for each day and subtracted them, Tina’s favored route minus Nina’s favorite route. Then these times were used in a $1$-sample $t$-test test to see if there was a difference in the driving times for each route.
Four of the answers below contain some false information about Nina’s and Tina’s experiment and statistical analysis. One answer is fully correct. Which is it?

choices.text:
$H_{a}: \mu_{d}> 0$
The population of the distribution of differences is shown to be approximately normal.

$H_{0}: \mu_{d}= 0$
The difference of Nina's route minus Tina's route should also be tested.

$H_{a}: \mu_{d}\neq 0$
Randomness and approximate normality are both shown here.

$H_{0}: \mu_{d}< 0$
Routes were assigned at random.

$H_{a}: \mu_{d}\neq 0$
Routes were not assigned at random.

title: Average Number of Text Messages
question_text:
A husband was curious at the end of the year about the average number of texts his wife sent out each day. He randomly selected $27$ days and found that the data followed an approximately normal distribution, with a mean of $40.3$ and a standard deviation of $5.4$.
Which of the following represents a $99\%$ confidence interval for the average number of texts his wife sent out each day?

title: Critical Value for Mean with Unknown Standard Deviation
question_text:
You want to compute a $90\%$ confidence interval for the mean population with an unknown standard deviation. The data is collected from an SRS of $20$ observations, and is approximately normal.
What critical value would we need for the $90\%$ confidence interval?

title: $z$ vs. $t$ Distribution
question_text: Which of the following statements is true concerning significance tests for a population mean?

choices.text: Tests for a population mean always use the $z$-distribution.
Tests for a population mean always use the $t$-distribution.
When testing for a population mean we use the $z$-distribution if we know the population standard deviation.
When testing for a population mean we use the $t$-distribution if we know the population standard deviation.
When testing for a population mean, we should always complete the procedure using both a $z$-distribution and a $t$-distribution and then average the resulting $p$-values.

title: Significance Test: Comparing Uber Times in Different Areas
question_text:
A statistics teacher wants to see if there is a difference in the mean time needed to wait for an Uber ride in two different metropolitan areas.
Twenty-five randomly selected times are accessed during the day for each area. The mean time waiting for an Uber in the first area is $8.3\text{ minutes}$ with a standard deviation of $1.1\text{ minutes}$, followed by the second area having a mean Uber wait time of $8.9\text{ minutes}$ with a standard deviation of $1.3\text{ minutes}$.
Assuming the conditions for inference are met, which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: The p-value is less than $0.01$; there is a significant difference in mean waiting times for Uber rides in the two different metropolitan areas at the $1$% significance level.
The p-value is less than $0.05$; there is a significant difference in mean waiting times for Uber rides in the two different metropolitan areas at the $5$% significance level.
The p-value is greater than $0.05$; the mean waiting times for the Uber rides in the two different metropolitan areas are the same at the $5$% significance level.
The p-value is less than $0.10$; there is a significant difference in mean waiting times for Uber rides in the two different metropolitan areas at the $10$% significance level.
The p-value is greater than $0.10$; the mean waiting times for the Uber rides in the two different metropolitan areas are the same at the $10$% significance level.

title: You're Applying to How Many Colleges? A Test
question_text:
Conventional wisdom says that high school seniors should apply to about $6-8\text{ colleges}$. Some sources recommend applying to as many as $10\text{ colleges}$. Talia thinks that the actual average number of colleges that seniors at her school have applied to this year is greater than $10$, so she decides to do a study and perform a one-sample $t$-test for the population mean.
The results of Talia's test will not be reliable if which of the following is found to be true?

choices.text: The distribution of the number of colleges applied to by seniors at her school this year is found to be approximately normal.
Talia randomly selects seniors at her school to survey for her study.
Those seniors who Talia surveyed all provide truthful responses about the number of colleges they applied to.
Talia does not know the standard deviation for the number of colleges applied to by all seniors at her school.
Talia uses a sample size of $20$ and finds that the sample contains a few very high outliers.

title: P-values: Fantasy Football
question_text:
Fantasy football consists of a competition where participants select players from different football teams and points are awarded based on the performance of those players. A student was curious if the fantasy football totals for quarterbacks from the first $3\text{ weeks}$ of the season was a good indicator of how well players would do the rest of the season.
The student randomly sampled $21$ starting quarterbacks and measured their average fantasy football points for the first 3 weeks, and sampled another random sample of $21$ quarterbacks and measured their average fantasy football points for the remainder of the season. The student then ran a 2 sample $T$-test to determine if the number of fantasy football points in the first $3\text{ weeks}$ of the season differed from the fantasy football points the rest of the year.
The data is shown below: Mean (first 3 weeks) = $23.92$ Standard Deviation (first 3 weeks) = $10.20$
Mean (remainder of the season) = $18.30$ Standard Deviation (remainder of the season) = $9.20$
After running a two-sided test, a $P$-value of $6.83\%$ was calculated.
How might you interpret the $P$-value in the context of the problem?

choices.text: $6.83\%$ of quarterbacks have lower averages the rest of the season compared to the first three weeks.

If there were really no difference between an NFL quarterback’s performance during the first three weeks and their performance the rest of the season, getting differences in sample means as large as 5.62 points or greater, would be somewhat unlikely (in fact, about $6.83\%$).
Approximately $6.83\%$ of quarterbacks in this sample had higher average fantasy points for the remainder of the season compared to the first three weeks.
There is approximately a $6.83\%$ chance of this data occurring.
There is approximately a $6.83\%$ chance of getting a difference of 5.62 fantasy points, or less,in this sample, by chance alone.

title: Constructing Certain Types of Mean Intervals: Respect Your Boss
question_text:
An insurance company is assessing two of its regional managers (Manager $A$ and Manager $B$) on how well-respected they are by their employees. The insurance company randomly selects $40$ employees from both regions.
They ask the employees to rate how much they respect their managers on a $1-10$ scale, with $1$ representing no respect and $10$ representing the utmost respect. Here are the summary results:
Company N Average Standard Deviation
A 40 8.1 1.4
B 40 6.2 1.1


Which of the following represents a $99\%$ confidence interval for the difference in the averages between how much company $A$'s employees respect their manager when compared with company $B$'s?
tables:
CompanyNAverageStandard Deviation
A408.11.4
B406.21.1

title: Computer Output T-Test | 2 of 2
question_text:
A study on women’s weights was recently completed.
Fifteen randomly selected high school females from an urban setting were compared to $16$ randomly selected high school females from a rural setting. Assume that the distribution of both populations are approximately normal. The results are below:

No evidence exists of a significant difference between urban and rural high school female weights since the interval contains $2.68$.

title: ACT Improvement?
question_text: A national test prep firm advertised that ACT scores would go up after taking one of its courses. To test this, an outside research firm decided to run a matched-pairs test. Forty randomly selected students would take an ACT test before the course and then again after the course. The before and after scores would then be examined and tested to see if there was any improvement. Which of the following would be the correct set of hypotheses for this test?

choices.text:
$H_{0}: \mu_{d}=0$
$H_{a}: \mu_{d}>0$
where $\mu_{d}=$ before - after ACT scores

$H_{0}: \mu_{d}=0$
$H_{a}: \mu_{d}>0$
where $\mu_{d}=$ after - before ACT scores

$H_{0}: \mu_{d}=0$
$H_{a}: \mu_{d}\neq0$
where $\mu_{d}=$ after - before ACT scores

$H_{0}: \mu_{a}-\mu_{b}=0$
$H_{a}: \mu_{a}-\mu_{b}>0$
where $\mu_{a}=$ after scores and where $\mu_{b}=$ before scores

$H_{0}: \bar{x}_{d}=0$
$H_{a}: \bar{x}_{d}\neq0$
where $\bar{x}_{d}=$ after - before ACT scores

title: East Coast vs. West Coast: Two Normal Distributions
question_text:
Nellie's Nachos is a fast food restaurant chain that has locations in many cities throughout the United States. In one Nellie's Nachos restaurant located on the west coast, the average number of customers served per day is $330$ with a standard deviation of $45$. In one Nellie's Nachos restaurant located on the east coast, the average number of customers served per day is $315$ with a standard deviation of $60$.
Assume the distribution of the number of customers served per day is approximately normal at both locations. Also assume that the number of customers served at one store is independent of the number of customers served at the other store.
What is the probability that on one randomly selected day, the number of customers served in the east coast location is greater than the number of customers served in the west coast location?

title: Average Standardized Test Score
question_text:
A teacher at a large high school is interested in finding the average standardized test score for all students in the school. The teacher selects a random sample of $150$ students from the school and finds a mean score of $1050$. In actuality, the mean of the whole school is $1125$ with a standard deviation $50$.
What number above represents a statistic?

choices.text: No numbers given represent a statistic

solution:
Remember, a statistic is a number the represents a sample. Therefore, when the teacher found the mean of the sample, this number is a sample mean, $\bar{x} = 1050$.

Since all the other numbers are either sample sizes or parameter values, $\bar{x} = 1050$ is the only statistic given.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Confidence Interval Conclusion
question_text:
You come across this confidence interval:
$$50\pm2.492\lgroup\dfrac{6}{\sqrt{25}}\rgroup=(47.01,52.99)$$
Which of the following is a correct conclusion?

choices.text: We are $98\%$ confident that the this confidence interval contains the population mean of $50$.
We know that $98\%$ of the time this confidence interval contains all $25$ values.
We are confident that $98\%$ of the time this confidence interval is correct.
We are $98\%$ confident that the this confidence interval captures the population mean.
We are $99\%$ confident that the this confidence interval captures the population mean.

title: Interval Assumptions
question_text: Which of the following could not be a reason for concern when checking assumptions in constructing a confidence interval for a mean?

choices.text: The probability of success being less than $1\%$.
Strong skewness is present when graphing the sample data.
Outliers are present when graphing the sample data.
The sample size is less than $10$.
The data comes from a stratified sample.

title: Pint Size?
question_text: A verified $95\%$ confidence interval showed that the difference between the weights of two different pints of ice cream brands was $(-0.13, 0.21)$ ounces. Describe what this confidence interval is saying.

choices.text: We are $95\%$ sure that one brand of ice cream weighs $0.21$ ounces more than the other brand.
Based on the samples of ice cream, we can be $95\%$ confident that the difference in weights of the pint-sized ice cream brands is between $-0.13$ and $0.21$ ounces.
There is a $95\%$ probability that one brand of ice cream weighs more than the other one.
We are $95\%$ confident that all of the samples taken will have a a difference of means between $-0.13$ and $0.21$ ounces.
Based on the samples of ice cream, we can be $90\%$ confident that the difference in weights of the pint-sized ice cream brands is between $-0.13$ and $0.21$ ounces.

title: Type of Interval to Use: Strength and Conditioning
question_text:
A new strength and conditioning program guarantees that you can add significant distance to how far you can hit a baseball. A baseball coach decides to test this claim by randomly selecting $35$ of his players to do the program. Before they start the program, he has all of his players hit $50$ balls from a baseball tee, recording the average distance (feet) for each player. They then do the new strength and conditioning program. After they complete the program, they hit $50$ balls again from the tee and record their average distance.
Which of the following would be the most appropriate confidence interval for measuring the average difference in the distance the ball traveled before and after the new strength and conditioning program?

choices.text: Paired $z$-interval for means.
Two sample $z$-interval for means.
Paired $t$-interval for means.
Two sample $t$-interval for means.
$\chi^2$ goodness-of-fit interval.

title: Attendance Records
question_text:
A secretary at a local high school keeps track of the attendance records of all students at the high school.
The secretary randomly selects $40\text{ students}$ from the records and constructs a $95\%$ confidence interval to estimate the average number of days students miss per year.
Why would it be incorrect for the secretary to construct a confidence interval for this data?

choices.text: This problem does not differentiate between the categorical reasons for being absent.
It does not make sense to construct a confidence interval when the population data is known.
A distribution such as this one is likely to have data that is strongly skewed to the right.
The sample size is too small for the assumptions to be met.
It is impossible to find the critical $T^*$ value for a problem such as this.

title: Hypothesis Test vs. Interval
question_text:
An exercise physiologist is interested in the effect of exercise on heart rate.
She has the subjects walk slowly for $5\text{ minutes}$ and records their heart rates. Then she has the subjects run vigorously for $5\text{ minutes}$ and records their heart rates again.
The differences are recorded (heart rate after running - heart rate before running), with results below:
One-Sample $T$: Differences
Test of $\mu = 0$ vs. $\mu \neq 0$

Variable N Mean StDev SE Mean 95% CI T P
Differences 8 59.88 10.36 3.66 (51.22,68.53) 16.35 0.000


Why could a confidence interval be more useful in this situation than a hypothesis test?
tables:
VariableNMeanStDevSE Mean95% CITP
Differences859.8810.363.66(51.22,68.53)16.350.000

choices.text: A confidence interval meets the conditions necessary while a hypothesis test does not.
A confidence interval will have more power than a hypothesis test.
A confidence interval will have a lower margin of error than a hypothesis test might.
A confidence interval gives more detailed information than a hypothesis test does.
There is a lower chance of a type II error in a confidence interval than in a hypothesis test.

title: P-value of a 1-sided Test Given t-test
question_text:
A significance test was performed to test ${ H }_{ 0 }:\mu =18$ versus the alternative ${ H }_{ a }:\mu > 18$. Data from a random sample of size $30$ makes a normal distribution and produces a test statistic of $t = 1.734$.
Which of the following intervals contains the P-value for this test?

title: Two-Sample T-Interval
question_text: A two-sample T-interval attempts to estimate

choices.text: The mean of the sum of the two samples.
The mean of the difference between two samples.
Both means of each sample.
The mean of the sum of the two populations.
The mean of the difference between two populations.

title: Tests for Two-Way Tables
question_text:
Which inferential procedure(s) could be constructed from a two-way table?
I. Chi-squared test for association.
II. Chi-squared test for homogeneity.
III. Two-proportion $Z$-test.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
I and II only.
II and III only.
I, II, and III.

title: Chi-Squared Distribution Attributes
question_text:
A chi-squared distribution
I. Will be approximately normal.
II. Will have n-$1$ degrees of freedom, where $n$ is the sample size.
III. Can only be used to determine if there is a difference, not the direction of the difference.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
II and III only.

title: Conditions for Two-Way Tables
question_text:
Which of the following statements is/are true concerning conditions for chi-squared procedures involving two-way tables?
I. Data must come from a random sample or random samples.
II. Expected counts must all be greater than $1$, and no more than $20\%$ of expected counts can be less than $5$.
III. $np$ and $n(1-p)$ must both be greater than $5$ where $n$ is the number of trials and $p$ is the proportion of successes.

choices.text: I only.
II only.
III only.
I and II only.
II and III only.

title: Chi-Squared Values and $p$-values
question_text:
A ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ test for homogeneity of populations was conducted using data found in a two-way table consisting of $6\text{ rows}$ and $3\text{ columns}$. The ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ value was found to be $19.63$.
What can we conclude about the results of this test?

choices.text: Since $p = 0.033$, we have strong evidence to suggest that the distribution of proportions is not the same for each of the different populations.
Since $p = 0.354$, we do not have enough evidence to suggest that the distribution of proportions is not the same for each of the different populations.
Since $p = 19.63$, we do not have any evidence to suggest that the distribution of proportions is not the same for each of the different populations.
Since $p < 0.05$, we have strong evidence that the populations are independent of each other.
Since $p > 0.05$, we cannot conclude that the populations are independent of each other.

title: Choosing the Correct Hypotheses for a Chi-Square Test
question_text: A researcher selects a random sample of secondary school teachers and asks them for their level of teaching (middle or high school) and their job satisfaction. Which of the following are appropriate null and alternative hypotheses for this situation?

choices.text:

title: Hector's Test
question_text: Hector has been assigned to do a chi-square test for independence for his university's statistics class. He has decided to see if there is an association between class year and grade point average, with grade point average split into $3$ categories. He plans to sample $100$ students thinking that this number will give him high enough cell counts. The following five answers contain a hypothesis and a condition for his test. Four of the $5$ answers contain an incorrect statement. Find the answer which is fully correct.

choices.text:
$H_{0}$: There is no difference in distributions of grade point average across the four classes at the university.
The sample size should be $10\%$ or less than the size of the university's population of students.

title: Which Test is Suitable?
question_text:
It has been observed that, if you lose your cell phone, the cell phone is more likely to be returned by the finder if the wallpaper encourages the finder to react in a helpful way. An experiment is performed to investigate this. Using $300$ identical cell phones, $100$ will have a photo of a baby as the wallpaper, $100$ will have a photo of a dog as the wallpaper, and $100$ will have an inspirational quote as the wallpaper. The phones are dropped at random locations around a local university. After $24$ hours, for each type of wallpaper, the number of phones that have been returned will be recorded.
The entire data set will be studied using a hypothesis test. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to use?

choices.text: $z$-test for a population proportion
$z$-test for a population mean
chi-square test for goodness of fit
chi-square test for homogeneity
$2$-sample $z$ test for population proportions

title: Hypotheses About Perceived Attractiveness and Annual Income
question_text:
A researcher wants to do a study to see if there is a relationship between how attractive an individual is perceived as being and their annual income level. He has randomly selected a sample of individuals who all agree to participate in his study.
To rate attractiveness, he will show each individual's picture to a separate large sample of people and will combine their responses in order to classify each individual as being of high, average or low attractiveness. He will then match that up with each individual's annual income level using the following categories: Under $50,000, Between $50,000 and $100,000, Over $100,000.
In order to analyze his results he has decided to use a ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ test. What should his hypotheses be?

choices.text:
$H_0:$ the proportion of people in each attractiveness category will be the same.
$H_a:$ the proportion of people in each attractiveness category will not all be the same.

$H_0:$ the proportion of people in each income category will be the same.
$H_a:$ the proportion of people in each income category will not all be the same.

$H_0:$ for each income category, the proportions of people in each category of perceived attractiveness will be the same.
$H_a:$ for each income category, the proportions of people in each category of perceived attractiveness will not be the same.

$H_0:$ an individual's perceived attractiveness is independent of their annual income level.
$H_a:$ an individual's perceived attractiveness is not independent of their annual income level.

$H_0:$ there is no association between perceived attractiveness and annual income level.
$H_a:$ as perceived attractiveness increases, so does annual income level.

title: Appropriate Null and Alternative Hypotheses
question_text:
A fast food company is offering a prize promotion game.
The company claims that in $0.5\%$ of all orders will receive $\$100$ cash, $1\%$ of all orders will receive $\$10$ cash, and $10\%$ of orders will receive a coupon for a free soft drink. The remaining orders will receive no prizes.
A group of long-time customers were excited about the new promotion, and over the course of the promotion, they placed $651\text{ orders}$. Of these orders, $2$ ended up winning $\$100$, $6$ won $\$10$, and $52$ won a free soft drink.
If this group wanted to do a chi-squared goodness of fit test to test the advertised odds, what would be the appropriate null and alternative hypotheses?

choices.text:
$H_0$: The respective probabilities of winning the different prizes is as advertised.
$H_a$: The respective probability of winning the different prizes is NOT as advertised.

$H_0$: The respective probabilities of winning the different prizes is as advertised.
$H_a$: The respective probabilities of winning the different prizes is greater than advertised.

$H_0$: The respective probabilities of winning the different prizes is as advertised.
$H_a$: The respective probabilities of winning the different prizes is less than advertised.

$H_0$: There is no association between prize winnings and frequency.
$H_a$: There is an association between prize winnings and frequency.

$H_0$: Prize-winning and frequency are independent.
$H_a$: Prize-winning and frequency are not independent.

title: How many should they expect?
question_text:
A large company has the current breakdown of employees: $40\%$ sales, $30\%$ Accounting, $20\%$ Management, $5\%$ Human Resources, $5\%$ Public Relations. The HR manager plans to take a random sample of $50$ employees for a company survey.
How many employees from the Accounting department should they expect?
solution:
To calculate the expected counts for a certain category, one must multiply the sample size by the proportion for that category. For instance, the manager is taking a random sample of $50$ employees and $30\%$ of the employees are in the Accounting Department. Therefore,



$$50(0.3) = 15 \text{ employees}$$

Therefore, the manager should expect $15$ employees from the Accounting department.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Expected Counts of Candy
question_text:
Suppose a well-known candy brand comes in three colors: Orange, Brown, and Yellow. The company that produces the candies claims the color distribution is $45\%$ Orange, $30\%$ Brown, and $25\%$ Yellow.
Which table below correctly identifies the expected number of each candy in a sample of $100$ candies?
solution:
The company claims the color distribution to be $45\%$ Orange, $30\%$ Brown, and $25\%$ Yellow. Therefore, if we want to find the expected number of candies for each color, we can take the sample size, $n = 100$, and multiply it by the proportion of colors for each candy. For instance,

Expected Orange: $100(0.45) = 45$

Expected Brown: $100(0.30) = 30$

Expected Yellow: $100(0.25) = 25$

Therefore, the table in Choice $A$ correctly identifies the expected number for each color.

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: Candy Colors
question_text:
Some years ago Ms. Tracey (a statistics teacher) gave her class bags of a certain type of candy. She had $50$ students in $2$ classes. The candy company claimed that we would find $10\%$ red candies and $20\%$ yellow candies. Well, Ms. Tracey's students found the opposite percentages in the candies!
Do you think that this result is likely due to random variation? And what comment below explains the yes or no answer the best?

choices.text:
Yes.
In bags of candy you would always expect some random variation.

Yes.
There was no random assignment so we cannot draw any conclusions.

Yes.
We do not know if the candies were normally distributed so we cannot make any conclusions.

No.
Fifty bags are a big enough sample to show statistically that the company was wrong.

No.
While we might always expect some random variation, the fact that the percentages were reversed is just not likely.

title: Calculator Troubles with Goodness of Fit
question_text:
Jovita was researching demographics online and found the following information about the distribution of races in her town.
White Non-Hispanic: $81.5\%$
Black: $2.1\%$
American Indian and Alaska Native: $0.0\%$
Asian: $10.5\%$
Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander: $0.0\%$
Hispanic or Latino: $4.8\%$
Two or more races: $1.0\%$
Some other race: $0.1\%$
She wondered whether the information was correct and decided to investigate. A random sample of $245$ residents in her town (population $47,238$) provides the following counts for each category:
White Non-Hispanic: $181$
Black: $8$
American Indian and Alaska Native: $5$
Asian: $28$
Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander: $5$
Hispanic or Latino: $14$
Two or more races: $2$
Some other race: $2$
Jovita entered the actual counts into List $1$ in her $TI84$ calculator and entered the expected counts into List $2$ after applying the appropriate percentages. While she noticed that not all expected counts were above $5$, she remembered her AP Statistics teacher telling her that she should proceed cautiously with an appropriate test even if one of the conditions for performing the test was violated. She then asked the calculator to perform a ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ GOF Test but the calculator returned an error message.
What went wrong?

choices.text: Jovita must have incorrectly entered one of the values into her calculator. This is the only possible explanation for the error message.
Jovita should have been using a different type of test. The calculator returned an error message because a Goodness of Fit Test is not appropriate.
The calculated $p$-value would be greater than $1$. Since this is not possible, the calculator returned an error message.
The calculator was returning an error message because the $p$-value was so incredibly close to $0$ that the calculator ran out of room to deal with the scientific notation.
The ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ statistic cannot be calculated because two of the expected counts are $0$.

title: Type of Smartphones in Usage: Finding Evidence
question_text:
Jackie recently read a report claiming that $43.8\%$ of smartphone users have an Apple iPhone, $39.6\%$ have an Android device, $13.6\%$ have a Blackberry, and $3\%$ have some other type of smartphone. She wonders whether this distribution is true for students at her high school.
To gather data, she randomly surveyed $30\text{ students}$ who have smartphones. She found that $15$ of them have Apple iPhones, $11$ have an Android device, $3$ have a Blackberry, and $1$ has some other type of smartphone.
Does this provide evidence that the distribution of smartphones at this high school is not the same as was stated in the report?

choices.text: Yes. $50\%$ of those surveyed had iPhones and this is far greater than the percentage stated in the report.
Yes. None of the observed counts from the survey match what would be expected if the percentages stated in the report are true for students at this school.
No. The $p$-value for the one-proportion $z$-test is too large for us to be able to conclude that the proportions stated in the report are not correct.
No. The $p$-value from the ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ Goodness of Fit test is too large to provide evidence that the distribution is different from what was reported.
An appropriate significance test cannot be conducted in this situation, since not all conditions are satisfied.

title: Media Company
question_text:
A large media company wonders how their customers are consuming their programming. According to the data analyst that work at their company, the following distribution summarizes the different devices used to consume the company's programming:
Device Phone Tablet Laptop Other
Proportion $ 0.34$ $0.21$ $0.35$ $0.10$
What is true about this population?
tables:
DevicePhoneTabletLaptopOther
Proportion$ 0.34$$0.21$$0.35$$0.10$

choices.text: The data collected was quantitative.
The customers prefer to view on their phone more than their laptop.
The customers use their phone or other devices more than half of the time.
If the company took a random sample of $200$ customers, they should expect about $68$ to prefer their phone.
The company should display the information in a histogram.

solution:
When dealing with categorical data, one can find the expected counts of the distribution by taking a sample size and multiplying it by the proportion for that category. In this case, we are told there is a random sample of $200$ customers, and we already know from the table that $34\%$ of customers prefer to use their phone. Therefore, to find the expected number of customers who prefer phone,

$\text{Expected Counts } = 200(0.34) = 68 \text{ Customers}$

Choice 'D' is correct.

correct_answer: Choice 'A' is correct; chi-squared goodness of fit tests are performed when testing multiple proportions of the same variable. The variable of interest here is the proportion of snakes in each of the four areas, so four proportions are present.

question_text:

title: Gym Preferences

title: Type I Error
question_text:
A fast food company is offering a prize promotion game.

The group wants to do a chi-squared goodness of fit test to test the advertised odds.

Deciding the company does not give away enough free soft drinks, when in reality they do.
Deciding the company gives away too few prizes, when in reality they give away enough prizes.
Deciding the company is corrupt, when in reality it is not.

title: Paper Airplanes
question_text: A statistics student asks $32$ other students to build paper airplanes without specific instructions as to size. He asks them to record both the length of the planes and the length of the flights. He wanted to create a confidence interval for the slope of the regression equation for these variables. What would the value of the degrees of freedom be to obtain the value of $t^{*}$?

title: Conditions Check
question_text: Before doing a $t$-test for slope, only one of the following checks is correct. Which answer correctly describes the reason for the check and the check itself?

choices.text: If the sample size is less than $30$ then the residuals should be checked for linearity.
The size of the population should be checked to make sure it is less than $10$ times larger than the sample.
The standard deviation for $y$ does not vary with $x$. Residuals should be checked.
The true relationship between $x$ and $y$ should be linear. The slope value should be estimated and checked.
If the observed distribution is strongly skewed, then the sample size should be less than $30$.

title: Power in Numbers
question_text:
Rob applied preventative herbicide/fertilizer to stop crabgrass in his lawn. He applied $4$ levels of treatment, each to $4$ sections of his lawn at random, and recorded the change in crabgrass plants per square meter.
Regression analysis was performed and a $98\%$ confidence interval for the slope of the true regression line of change in crabgrass on treatment was constructed.
$98\%$ Confidence Interval: $ (-1.134, -0.8364)$
A lawn care company ran an experiment that tested the same $4$ levels, but each on $200$ sections of lawn at random.
The $98\%$ Confidence Interval obtained by the lawn care company is likely to be $\rule{3cm}{0.25mm}$ in comparison to the confidence interval constructed by Rob.

choices.text: wider
the same in width, but a lower center.
narrower
unpredictably different
the same in width, but a higher center.

question_text: A firm was asked to do a study which asked if the more caffeine a person consumed each day led to fewer hours of sleep. If $40$ participants were randomly selected, and a $t$-test for slope was to be done, what would the alternative hypothesis be?

choices.text: $H_{a}: \beta=0$
$H_{a}: \beta>0$
$H_{a}: \beta<0$
$H_{a}: \beta\neq 0$

title: Crab Grass
question_text:
In the warm summer months, crab grass proliferates and sets seed. Because it is unsightly, many homeowners attempt to interrupt the crabgrass cycle with "preventer" herbicide/fertilizers that inhibit germination.
Rob decided to apply $4$ different levels of the same treatment chemical to his lawn in $16$ total random sections. He then counted and recorded the difference in number of crab grass plants in each treatment area before and after treatment. A linear regression analysis was run, and the residuals for the $16$ data points are listed below.
Use the residual data to estimate $\sigma$, the variability of the change in crabgrass about the true regression line.

choices.text: Without the actual data, it is impossible to estimate the standard deviation of the response variable, change in crab grass.

title: Self-Esteem | 2 of 2
question_text:
A high school principal is curious if a linear relationship exists between student height and score on a self-esteem test.
A random sample of $20$ pairs of students was taken. A linear regression $T$-test was performed on $H_0: B = 0$ vs. $H_a: B > 0$, and the test statistic of $t = 3.19$ was calculated.
If the slope is $1.22$ and margin of error was $3.41$ for a $95\%$ confidence interval, what was the standard error of the slope?

title: Caffeine and Sleeping
question_text: A firm was asked to do a study which asked if the more caffeine a person consumed each day led to fewer hours of sleep. If $40$ participants were randomly selected, and a $t$-test for slope was to be done, what would the null hypothesis be?

title: Fishing Under Pressure
question_text:
Michael travels around the world learning about cuisine and local fishing. A particular area of Canadian water is known to have large quantities of lake trout, but Michael has been unable to catch any. The local fishermen advise him that they believe there is a relationship between falling atmospheric pressure and lake trout feeding activity. As it seems, fish catches rise as the pressure falls.
Michael, ever the analyst, collects pressure readings from historical weather data for the past year and plots each drop in pressure against the Department of Fisheries and Oceans (DFO) lake trout catch data for the area of interest. He believes that the locals are correct.
Michael forms the following hypotheses, and wishes to test at the $\alpha=0.01$ level of significance:
$H_0$: There is no linear relationship between negative pressure change and the number of lake trout caught in the specific area of interest in Canadian water.
$H_A$: There is a negative linear relationship between negative pressure change and the number of lake trout caught in the specific area of interest in Canadian water.
What test is appropriate for this inference procedure?

choices.text: A $z$ test with $n-1$ degrees of freedom for the the slope of the true regression line of Lake Trout Caught on Negative Pressure Change.
A $z$ test with $n-2$ degrees of freedom for the the slope of the true regression line of Lake Trout Caught on Negative Pressure Change.
A $t$ test with $n-1$ degrees of freedom for the the slope of the true regression line of Lake Trout Caught on Negative Pressure Change.
A $t$ test with $n-2$ degrees of freedom for the the $y$-intercept of the true regression line of Lake Trout Caught on Negative Pressure Change.
A $t$ test with $n-2$ degrees of freedom for the the slope of the true regression line of Lake Trout Caught on Negative Pressure Change.

title: Find the Error
question_text:
A pharmaceutical company was testing a new drug. It wanted to show that a higher dose of the drug would result in patients having fewer headaches. Thirty-two patients were to be randomly selected from a group of headache sufferers from several medical practices in a large city. Four different dosages of the drug would be administered and the number of headaches would be counted over a period of time. Data was carefully documented and residuals were examined. A $t$-test was to be done using the following hypotheses:
$H_{0}: \beta=0$
$H_{a}: \beta\neq0$
Something is wrong here. What is incorrect?

choices.text: The sample size is not big enough.
The independence condition was not checked.
Linearity was not checked.
The alternative hypothesis should have a greater than sign.
The alternative hypothesis should have a less than sign.

title: The Correct Condition
question_text: When creating a confidence interval for estimating the slope of a regression line, certain conditions must be met. Four of the five listed conditions below are incorrect. Which is the condition that is correct?

choices.text: Each cell count must be at least $10$.
Analysis of residuals may be used to verify linearity.
Analysis of residuals may be used to check for approximately equal standard deviations for all $y$ values.
Check that the sample size is greater than or equal to $10\%$ of the population size.
The values of $x$ are approximate normally distributed.

title: Predicting Wait Time
question_text:
In $2002$, a large fast-food restaurant wanted to create a linear regression model to predict the wait time, in minutes, for a customer based on the number of items they had ordered. The regression model gave the following equation:
$\widehat{\text{wait time}} = 2.35 + 0.40(\text{items})$
The company has since hired a new data consultant who is interested in seeing if the old model is a still viable for making predictions for restaurant today. Based on a sample of $25$ random orders in $2022$, the data consultant found a new prediction model of
$\widehat{\text{new wait time}} = 1.58 + 0.68(\text{items})$
To determine if the old model is still appropriate to use to estimate the wait time in $2022$, the data consultant constructs a simulated sampling distribution using random samples of $30$ from $2002$. The simulated sampling distribution is found below:
What should the data consultant conclude based off the sampling distribution provided?

choices.text:
The old model is appropriate because
0.68
is not contained in the sampling distribution.

The data is not valid because the consultant only took a sample of size
30
from
2002
.
The old model is no longer an appropriate model because the slope of the new model is not contained in the sampling distribution.
The company should ignore the new model and simply stick with the old model to predict wait times.
There is insufficient evidence to say that the new model is different from the old model.

solution:
When using inference to look at slope of regression models, we want to be able to see if the slope of the old model is still appropriate based on the new model. Since we took many samples from the old data, and simulated a sampling distribution for the slope of the regression line, we were provided with many slopes that could have been a possibility from the old model. When we examined the data, we did not see the new slope,
0.68
in the sampling distribution.

Therefore, we can concluded that the old model is no longer a sufficient model to predict wait time for the company, and they should use the new model.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Starting Salary vs College GPA
question_text:
Sixty-five random recent college graduates were selected and asked their college grade point average (GPA) as well as their starting salary on their first job. This resulted in a a regression equation of $\hat{y}=9.7x + 23.6$ where $x$ is GPA and $\hat{y}$ is the predicted salary (in thousands of dollars). The standard error was $0.25$.
Find a $99\%$ confidence interval for the slope and interpret it.

choices.text:
$(9.035, 10.365)$
We are $99\%$ confident that the interval from $9.035$ to $10.365$ contains the slope of the true regression line relating grade point average and starting salary. We have convincing evidence that there is an association between theses two variables.

$(9.035, 10.365)$
We are $99\%$ confident that the interval from $9.035$ to $10.365$ contains the slope of the true regression line relating grade point average and starting salary. We have convincing evidence that there is no association between theses two variables

$(9.2, 10.2)$
We are $99\%$ confident that the interval from $9.2$ to $10.2$ contains the slope of the true regression line relating grade point average and starting salary. We have convincing evidence that there is an association between theses two variables.

$(9.2, 10.2)$
We are $99\%$ confident that the interval from $9.2$ to $10.2$ contains the slope of the true regression line relating grade point average and starting salary. We have convincing evidence that there is no association between theses two variables.

$(9.465, 9.935)$
We are $99\%$ confident that the interval from $9.465$ to $9.935$ contains the slope of the true regression line relating grade point average and starting salary. We have convincing evidence that there is an association between theses two variables.

title: What Does it Mean?
question_text: Which of the following is the correct way to state a claim for results of a $98\%$ confidence interval about the slope of a regression model?

choices.text: We are $98\%$ confident that we know the true slope of the population model.
We are $98\%$ confident that the true slope of the population model will be at the center of our confidence interval.
If random sampling is done over and over, we know that about $98\%$ of the confidence intervals created would contain the true slope of the population model.
If random sampling is done over and over, we know that about $98\%$ of the time we would know that the mean of our confidence interval created would contain the true slope of the population model.
We are $98\%$ confident that we would find the exact slope of the population model.

title: Does Studying Pay Off?
question_text:
A college statistics professor is interested in showing her students the effect of studying for a test. She selected a random sample of $20$ students from the large class and asked "How long did you study for your previous test?".
Then she plotted the time studied versus the score on the test. Given is the computer output for the linear regression model for the data:
Predictor Coef SE Coef T P
Constant $65.03$ $4.54$ $4.54$ $0.00$
Time Studied $0.0650$ $0.0023$ $6.23$ $0.00$
$S = 4.03$ $r-sq = 88.2$

solution:
The college professor inputted her data into a computer program and created a computer output for the data. The computer output gives numerous data points that provide information for linear regression, as well as for inference for linear regression.

Finding the necessary information is the key to finding the correct answer to the problem. The slope of the linear regression model is located at the intersection of "Time Studied" and "Coef" on the table below:

Therefore, the estimated slope for the regression model for $20$ students is $0.0650$

Choice 'B' is correct.

title: Max Battery Life
question_text:
A popular cell phone maker allows its users to measure the "Max Battery Life" to determine the health of the battery. This compares the user's current battery life to the life of the battery when it was new. A data scientist for the company wants to create a linear regression model for a random sample of $22$ phones and determine the Max Battery Life after a certain amount of time (in months).
Below is the scatter plot (with the regression line plotted), a table of the regression data, and a model sampling distribution if the researcher simulated a sampling distribution for his data:
What question cannot be answered by the provided information?

choices.text: Is the slope of the sample regression data positive or negative?

What is the change in predicted Max Battery Life for an increase of
1
month for the sample data?
Would the correlation of the sample regression line be positive or negative?
Is the sample data linear?
Is the population regression line's slope negative?

solution:
Choice 'E' is correct.

When looking at sample data to make an inference regarding the population data, to have convincing evidence, the statistic must be so rare, that it couldn't have possibly happened by chance. When looking at the simulated sampling distribution, the value of our slope
b
=
−
1.5039
or less occurs numerous times by chance.

Additionally, since
0
occurs enough in our sampling distribution many times, this is also an indication that there is no convincing evidence for the negative slope.

Therefore, we are not able to answer the question definitively. The slope could be negative, or the slope could be positive.

Choice 'E' is correct.

title: Identifying Parameters
question_text: When performing a significance test for a least-squares regression line, what parameter can be tested?

choices.text: The proportion of observations that lie on the line.
The average $x$-value in a set of observations that determine a roughly linear relationship.
The mean $y$-value in a set of observations that determine a roughly linear relationship.
The slope of the line relating two quantitative variables.
The variability found in the sample.

title: Bearing Fruit
question_text:
Apple tree saplings can produce fruit in as little as $4$ years. Jeff, a novice farmer, believes that picking fruit in the spring before it has time to develop during years $4$ through $7$ can increase the yield in years $8$ through $11$ significantly. By pruning the apples from saplings, more energy is devoted to trunk and branch development, thus creating a stronger more capable fruit bearer.
Jeff collected data from an experiment in which $10$ groups of $10$ trees, selected at random had $10\%$, $20\%$, $30\%$, ... $100\%$ of the apples pruned from the trees in the spring during years $4$ through $7$. The treatment groups were then plotted against natural yield in years $8$ through $11$.
Assuming the conditions for regression inference are met, what are the null and alternative hypotheses that Jeff should use to assess his belief?

choices.text:
$H_0$: There is no relationship between the percentage of fruit pruned in years $4$ through $7$ and the natural yield of apples in years $8$ through $11$.
$H_A$: There is a positive linear relationship between the percentage of fruit pruned in years $4$ through $7$ and the natural yield of apples in years $8$ through $11$.

$H_0$: There is a positive linear relationship between the percentage of fruit pruned in years $4$ through $7$ and the natural yield of apples in years $8$ through $11$.
$H_A$: There is no linear relationship between the percentage of fruit pruned in years $4$ through $7$ and the natural yield of apples in years $8$ through $11$.

$H_0$: There is no relationship between the percentage of fruit that Jeff pruned in years $4$ through $7$ and the natural yield of Jeff's apples in years $8$ through $11$
$H_A$: There is a positive linear relationship between the percentage of fruit that Jeff pruned in years $4$ through $7$ and the natural yield of Jeff's apples in years $8$ through $11$

$H_0$: There is a positive linear relationship between the percentage of fruit that Jeff pruned in years $4$ through $7$ and the natural yield of Jeff's apples in years $8$ through $11$.
$H_A$: There is no linear relationship between the percentage of fruit that Jeff pruned in years $4$ through $7$ and the natural yield of Jeff's apples in years $8$ through $11$.

$H_0$: The average amount of natural yield of fruit in years $8$ through $11$ is the same as in years $4$ through $7$.
$H_A$: The average amount of natural yield of fruit in years $8$ through $11$ is greater than in years $4$ through $7$.

title: A Residual
question_text: A firm was conducting a study and found a linear regression model of $\hat{y}=42-6x$. Find the residual of the point $(8, 3)$.

title: Avocado Farm
question_text:
An avocado farmer in California divides his farmland into $8$ different plots. Each plot of land has a different watering system assigned that will use a variable amount of water. During a recent month, the farmer selects $5$ random avocados from each plot of land and measures the average weight of the avocado.
The farmer then compares the average weight (in ounces) to the amount of water used on the specific plot (in gallons). The linear regression model of the data is as follows:
$\widehat{\text{weight}} = 2.31 + 0.042(\text{gallons})$
What is the population of interest for the farmer?

choices.text: $5$ avocados
$40$ avocados
All avocados on his farm
Amount of water used for each plots
Predicted weight

solution:
Using the avocados from his farm, the farmer selected a random sample of $5$ avocados from each plot, resulting in a sample of $40$ avocados. Using the $40$ avocados from the farm, the farmer created a linear regression model to predict the weight of an average avocado on his farm.

Since the farmer selected a random sample from the whole farm land, the population of interest would be all the avocados on the farm.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Follow the Bouncing Ball to Determine the $t$-Statistic
question_text:
Jessica was stuck babysitting and was feeling quite bored from watching her little sister Allison bounce a ball up and down. To ease her boredom she decided to keep track of the number of bounces Allison could complete in various amounts of time.
She then developed the equation for the least squares regression line to be:
$$\hat { y } = 2.136+1.021x$$
...where $\hat { y }$ is the predicted number of bounces and $x$ is the number of seconds.
If the standard error of the slope is $0.763$, what $t$-statistic would Jessica arrive at when completing a $t$-test for the linear regression?

title: Confidence Interval Facts
question_text:
Four statements below about some aspects of confidence intervals for the slope of a regression model are true. One statement is false.
Which statement below is false?

choices.text: Critical values increase in value as degrees of freedom decrease in value.
The width of a regression model tends to increase when the sample size is decreased.
Approximately $C\%$ of confidence intervals will contain the true slope of the regression model in repeated random sampling.
When a confidence interval does not contain zero, then no association between the variables can be shown.
The standard error shows about how far the slope of the derived regression line would vary from the slope of the true regression line.

title: Marty McMath Makes Predictions from Computer Output
question_text:
Marty McMath wants to know if a student's final grade in Algebra II can be used to predict his or her final grade in Precalculus. To investigate, he gathers data from a random sample of $8$ students who have completed both courses.
After noticing that the relationship is roughly linear and confirming that the conditions have been satisfied, he decides to use statistical software to conduct a $2$-sided $t$-test for linear regression where the null hypothesis is the slope equals $0$.
Computer output is shown below.
Predictor Coef SE Coef T
Constant 16.46 3.73 4.41
Algebra II 0.82 0.22 3.73


Unfortunately, he can't figure out how to make the computer output display the $p$-value. Luckily, he knows enough statistics to be able to calculate it from the output shown.
What is the $p$-value?
tables:
PredictorCoefSE CoefT

title: Reality Show
question_text:
The producers of a famous reality show (a show where the contestants do not have much food to eat) are wondering if they can approximate the weight lost for a contestant during their time on the show. The producers select a random sample of $20$ former contestants and use this data to create a linear regression model and a confidence interval for the slope of the regression line. The confidence interval is as follows:
($-8.23, -2.45$)
Do the producers have convincing evidence that contestants will lose weight on their time on the show?

choices.text: Yes, because the intervals are less than $0.05$.
Yes, because both bounds of the confidence interval are negative.
No, because the sample size is not large enough.
No, because the producers created a confidence interval and not a test of significance.
No, because the producers selected a random sample and not the whole population.

solution:
The producers are interested in creating a confidence interval that produces a range of possible values for the slope of the regression model for the predicted weight loss of the population of all contestants on the reality show. When the producers found their interval, the bounds ($-8.23, -2.45$) were both negative numbers. This is implying that the possible range of slopes is between $-8.23$ and $-2.45$.

Since both bounds of the interval are negative, and $0$ is not a plausible value for the slope, there is convincing evidence that the contestants will lose weight when on the show.

Choice 'B' is correct.

title: Interpretation of Slope $t$-Interval: Height, Weight
question_text:
A statistician wanted to construct a $95\%$ confidence interval for the population slope between height (in inches) and weight (in pounds) of his co-workers. He made height the explanatory (independent) variable and weight the response (dependent) variable.
He selected a random sample of $30$ people from work and asked them to list their height and weight. After seeing his conditions were satisfied, he constructed the interval and got a result of $(1.97, 2.89)$.
Which of the following is the correct interpretation of the interval in the context of this study?

choices.text: $95\%$ of the time the population slope relating height to weight for the statistician's co-workers will be in the interval from $1.97$ to $2.89$.
The statistician is $95\%$ confident that for each additional increase in pounds, the average height will increase between $1.97$ to $2.89$ inches.
The statistician is $95\%$ confident that for each additional increase in pounds, the height will increase between $1.97$ to $2.89$ inches
The statistician is $95\%$ confident that the interval from $1.97$ to $2.89$ captures the sample slope for relating height to weight of his co-workers.
The statistician is $95\%$ confident that the interval from $1.97$ to $2.89$ captures the population slope for relating height to weight for his co-workers.

title: Find the Standard Error
question_text: The confidence interval for the slope of a given regression model is $0.6\pm1.2$. If the value of $t^{*}$ is $0.8$, find the value of the standard error for the slope of the regression line.

title: Minutes of Biking
question_text:
Typically, when a person rides a bike for exercise, the number of calories burned increases as the duration of time rode increases. A large local bicycle club finds the population regression line for predicted amount of calories burned vs. the duration of time rode. The equation of the population regression line is:
$\widehat{\text{calories}} = 12.78 + 1.23(\text{minutes})$
One member of the group decides she is going to take a random sample of $20$ bikers from the group and create a sample regression model. Is the member's model guaranteed to have the same slope as the population regression line?

choices.text: Yes, because the sample size is large enough.
Yes, because the slope of the sampling distribution is an unbiased estimator of the population slope.
Yes, because the sample comes from the population.
No, since the member took a random sample, the slope can vary due to sampling variability.
No, because the population size is unknown.

solution:
When the bike club found their regression model, they used all the members of the club, thus giving them the population regression line. When the member of the club created her model using a random sample of $20$ members, she found what is called the sample regression line, since it does not use all the members of the group.

Therefore, whenever randomization is used to estimate the slope and y-intercept of a regression line, there will always be some sort of variability involved. And while it is entirely possible that the member could get the same slope, it is unlikely due to sampling variability.

Choice 'D' is correct.

title: Sampling Distribution for Slope
question_text: A senior at a large high school is finishing up his AP Statistics class and has begun his study of linear regression for slope. Similar to other sampling distributions he has already studied, what characteristics of the sampling distribution should the student not worry about during his study of linear regression for slope?

choices.text: Shape
Center
Correlation
Spread
All characteristics listed are necessary

solution:
Whenever an AP Statistics student is looking at a sampling distribution, there are three main characteristics that the learner should focus on:

Shape: Approximately Normal

Center: Mean of the Sampling Distribution

Spread: Standard Deviation of the Sampling Distribution

Knowing these three characteristics will allow the learned to find probability within the sampling distribution, as well as begin the process of inference whether it's confidence intervals or significance testing.

Therefore, the only characteristic that is not necessary for this student would be correlation.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Points Per Game
question_text:
A sports researcher examines data to determine if a team's average points per game can be used as a predictor for the number of games the team won throughout the season. Of the $350$ teams in the division, the sports researcher selects a random sample of $15$ teams. After he runs the linear regression on the data, he finds the least-squares regression line for the variables points per game ($x$) and the predicted number of wins ($\hat{y}$) to be:
$\widehat{\text{wins}} = 15.52 + 0.056(\text{points per game})$
What question is unknown to the researcher after creating the regression model?

choices.text: What is the slope of the least-squares regression line?
What is the y-intercept of the least-squares regression line?
Will the slope of the regression line always be positive?
What happens to the predicted number of wins if the points per games goes up by $1$?
Does scoring more points equate to winning more games?

solution:
When looking at the regression model, it is important to remember that the sports researcher selected a random sample of $20$ teams from the division population of $350$ teams. Since this process was done randomly, the researcher has to understand that his results could have possibly happened purely by chance, and are not statistically significant. Therefore, the researcher cannot be sure that the slope of the least squares regression line for this model will always be positive.

Choice 'C' is correct.

title: Regression Computer Output
question_text:

title: An Association?
question_text:
We are trying to show that there is an association between study time and test performance. A $98\%$ confidence interval for the slope of this regression model is $(-0.24, 1.03)$.
Can you conclude that an association exists? Why or why not?

choices.text: No because zero is included in the interval, we do not have convincing evidence that there is an association between study time and test performance.
No because we do not have a very large slope, we do not have convincing evidence that there is an association between study time and test performance.
Yes because zero is included in the interval, we do have convincing evidence that there is an association between study time and test performance.
Yes because we are $98\%$ confident of what our true slope will be, we do have convincing evidence that there is an association between study time and test performance.
Yes since it is more likely that the slope is positive, we do have convincing evidence that there is an association between study time and test performance.

title: Tokens and Tickets at the Arcade: Degrees of Freedom
question_text:

question_text: A $95\%$ confidence interval of $(2.6, 4.2)$ was created for a study based on a regression model looking at SAT scores and the number of college acceptances for a random sample of students. choices.text: We are $95\%$ confident that the interval from $2.6$ to $4.2$ contains the slope of the true regression line. Because zero is not contained in the interval, we have evidence to show that an association exists between these two variables.

title: Test and Degrees of Freedom: English vs. Math
question_text:
Some people claim that you can't be good at both Math and English. Lewis wondered about this and decided to investigate whether or not there was a relationship between a student's final grade (out of $100\%$) in Math and the student's final grade (out of $100\%$) in English during his/her freshman year of high school.
He gathered a random sample of $25\text{ students}$ who had just completed their freshman year at his high school and recorded both their final grade in Math and their final grade in English (both in percents).
If Lewis is willing to accept that his sample is representative of what would be found in other high schools as well and assumes that all conditions for inference are met, what type of test should he conduct AND how many degrees of freedom should he use?

choices.text: Lewis should conduct a $1$-sample $z$-test for proportions. Since he will use a $z$-test, there is no need to identify degrees of freedom.
Lewis should conduct a $2$-sample $t$-test for means and should use $24$ degrees of freedom.
Lewis should conduct a $t$-test for the slope of his LSRL and should use $23$ degrees of freedom.

Lewis should conduct a ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ test for association/independence. Since there are $2\text{ subjects}$ being compared (Math and English) and there are $101\text{ possible final grades}$ (in percents from $0\%$ to $100\%$), he should use $(2-1)(101-1)=100\text{ degrees of freedom}$.

Lewis should conduct a ${ \chi }^{ 2 }$ test for homogeneity of populations. Since there are $2$ populations being compared (those who do well in Math and those who do well in English) and there are $101\text{ possible final grades}$ (in percents from $0\%$ to $100\%$), he should use $(2-1)(101-1)=100\text{ degrees of freedom}$.

title: Effects of Squats
question_text:
An elite performance trainer is wondering if the amount of weight that a long-jumper can squat can predict the distance jumped. The trainer has had over $1000$ clients, so he selects a random sample of $25$ long-jumpers and compares the max squat amount to the distance jumped and creates a linear regression model.
What is the response variable for the trainer's regression model ?

choices.text: Distance jumped
Max squat rate
$25$ long-jumpers
Slope of the regression line
$Y$-intercept of the regression line

solution:
When looking at a regression model, there are explanatory and response variables. The explanatory variable is the variable that is causing the response, and in this problem would be the max squat weight for the jumpers. The response variable is the variable that is being measured, and in this problem would the predicted long-jump distance.

Therefore, the response variable for the trainer's regression model is distance jumped.

Choice 'A' is correct.

title: Snow Making
question_text:
Snow making depends on temperature, since water freezes at $32^{\circ} F$. Dave, a snow-making enthusiast, believes that there is no relationship between air temperature and $\%$ relative humidity. He collected and analyzed data on the wet-bulb temperature which relates air temperature to $\%$ relative humidity.
The conditions for regression inference were met and the following $98\%$ confidence interval for $\beta$, the slope of the population regression line of $\%$ relative humidity on air temperature, was constructed:
$$(-10.77,-6.355)$$
Does this interval provide convincing evidence of a linear relationship between air temperature and $\%$ relative humidity at the $\alpha=0.02$ significance level?

choices.text: No because the slope, $\beta$, is larger than $\alpha=0.02$.
Yes because $0$ is not contained within the $98\%$ confidence interval.
Yes because the slope, $\beta$, is larger than the significance level $\alpha=0.02$.

The answer cannot be determined because you cannot test for significance with confidence intervals.
